HEADLINE: Big New Trade Gap Deepens Clinton's Political Problems

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit set yet another record in May, despite remarkably strong exports, compounding a political problem for the Clinton Administration, which is trying to portray its string of trade agreements in Asia and North America as its greatest foreign policy success.
The Commerce Department said today that the deficit was $11.4 billion for the month, just slightly above the April deficit but more than $1 billion higher than many economists expected. President Clinton's economic advisers, increasingly attuned to the politics of the monthly statistics, said that a close look at the figures demonstrated the economy's continued strength. 
 Still, the trade deficit with Japan, which declined slightly from the April level, is running 8 percent ahead of last year's pace, when it reached an annualized $66 billion, a record at the time. Similarly, the gaps with China and Mexico continued to widen sharply.
The Administration's fear is that the deficits with the biggest American trading partners will be easy grist for the Republicans next year. The automotive trade agreement with Japan reached late last month has come under sharp criticism from Republican contenders for the Presidential nomination, and in the aftermath of Mexico's economic debacle late last year, there has been carping in both parties about the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Mr. Clinton is still trying to quell periodic rebellions in his own party over his advocacy of free trade, and today, Representative Peter A. DeFazio of Oregon cited the most recent figures in a letter to House members calling for a commission to re-examine trade policy. Specifically he opposed an expansion of the North American trade pact; this fall, the White House will try to gain accession to the agreement for Chile.
The Commerce Department figures showed that exports of goods and services in May totaled $64.8 billion, and imports were $76.2 billion. In almost every key category, both imports and exports rose: Semiconductor exports, for example, were up nearly 11 percent for the year to date, to $25.46 billion, but imports surged 43 percent from a lower base. Similar trends apply to autos and auto parts.
The best light that the Administration can place on the figures is that exports continue to rise strongly despite trading partners' problems. Canada's economy is in the doldrums, Japan has been unable to lift itself out of recession, and Mexico, seeking to restore itself to financial health, has vastly reduced the consumption of foreign-made goods.
The problem is imports, which rose 1.1 percent in May. Economists had expected a drop because of the weakness of the dollar and a presumed cooling of the American economy. Instead, for the fourth time this year, imports set a monthly record.
"I really don't see this as a political problem because when you look at the imports, they are all the kind of capital goods that show that manufacturers are still buying and expanding," said Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade. "That is exactly what you want to see."
But if the trend continues, and most economists think that it will until early next year, the widening deficits will grow increasingly difficult to explain. The Administration would obviously like to see a decline over the next few months, so it could declare that the succession of market-opening agreements are beginning to work.
Some probably are working. There are signs that exports of flat glass to Japan are on the rise, after an agreement reached last fall. In a speech this week to the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan, Ambassador Walter F. Mondale said, "Sectors that were once the hottest points of contention are now showing the highest growth rates." Mr. Mondale cited the sales of American beef in Japanese supermarkets and semiconductor sales to Japanese electronics concerns.
"When we reached an agreement to open the cellular phone market in the Tokyo-Nagoya corridor a year ago last April, we were greeted with sharp, acrimonious resistance," he said, but now Motorola, which pressed the complaint, "has about a 25 percent share of the cell-phone handset market."
Today, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, made the case that there were small signs of progress in the Administration's most prominent other Asian trouble area: China. In May, the American deficit with China rose to $2.22 billion, or half the monthly deficit with Japan. The deficit for the first five months of the year totals $9.23 billion, and exports and imports are growing 25 percent a year. That presages continuing economic tension, at a time that disputes over human rights and China's suspected export of missile technology have greatly worsened relations.
"Clearly our trade deficit with China will go on for some time," Mr. Kantor said. "But the pace of growth in the deficit is narrowing, and that gives us some reason for optimism."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 24, 1995, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the United States trade deficit in May referred incorrectly to the ranking of the $11.4 billion deficit. It was a record, but only for the period since January 1992, when the Government changed the way it calculates the figures. While it is hard to compare the new calculations with earlier ones, other Government statistics indicate that the monthly deficit was consistently larger in 1986 and 1987 than in recent months.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
A Los Angeles Tenant For I.B.M.'s Extra Space

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 18

 BODY:
The Los Angeles Unified School District has become an unexpected beneficiary of efforts by the International Business Machines Corporation to consolidate its worldwide operations.
I.B.M. has tried for two years to find a subtenant for one-quarter of the 45-floor building on Grand Avenue that bears its name. After engineers found the school district's decades-old business office unsafe, the district recently agreed to a $35 million lease in the I.B.M. building. 
 Brokers say the deal, which will initially cost the district a below-market annual rate of $8.50 a square foot for 273,559 square feet, shows how some tenants are driving bargains in markets where recession has curbed demand for space.
I.B.M. has 500 employees in the building and needs just 125,000 square feet. The company, in an effort to cut costs, has been consolidating its operations, leaving the equivalent space of 20 high-rise buildings vacant last year.
Brokers and school officials say I.B.M. is paying around $32 a square foot on a lease that expires in 1999. Some building tenants are paying as much as $39 a square foot, according to executives involved in the negotiations. I.B.M.'s willingness to subsidize the district's rent shows the lengths some lessees will go to reduce their losses.
"A big tenant in today's market is hard to come by," said Peter Johnston, a senior vice president of Maguire Thomas Partners, the building's developer. Maguire, I.B.M. and JMB Realty are equal owners in the building.
When the I.B.M. building was completed in 1983 at a cost of $180 million, the company occupied 600,000 of the one million square feet in the South Tower, as it is known. The tower is part of the two-building Wells Fargo Center. The center's development is credited with helping revitalize the city's central business district. Nearby are luxury high-rise condominiums and the city's contemporary art museum.
Since 1989, eight new high-rise office buildings have opened their marble-lined lobbies, glutting downtown with 7.8 million square feet of new space. Takers have been few as a deep recession forced cutbacks by traditional downtown tenants.
Given market conditions in downtown, I.B.M.'s negotiating strategy is understandable. In the year's first half, the area's vacancy rate stood at 24 percent and average lease rates in prime office buildings were $18 a square foot. Nearly eight million square feet is unoccupied, including more than one million feet that tenants want to sublease to others.
The 24 percent vacancy rate compares with vacancy rates of 12.8 percent in midtown Manhattan, 18 percent in Chicago, and 9.2 in San Francisco. The only major metropolitan area with a higher rate is Dallas at 33.9 percent, according to CB Commercial, a real estate brokerage firm.
The school district's lease was signed in February and 1,000 of its business service employees began to move uptown in May from a 1913 building on San Pedro Street near the garment center. The district has 56,000 employees.
In December, nearly a year after the Northridge quake, engineering reports confirmed that the district's business service office lacked lateral support and would be unsafe if a moderate quake struck nearby. Improvements would cost $17 million and take a year. The district's board members wanted employees out quickly.
"'We had blown off this building because we were concerned it was too expensive and we were concerned about image," said Robert Niccum, the district's director of real estate.
A three-way competition for the district lease helped drive down lease rates, said Lynn Williams of Cushman Realty, which represented the district.
So did the district's willingness to use I.B.M.'s space as is, without high-priced tenant improvements, Ms. Williams said. Paint and carpeting alone can add $10 a square foot to a lease and can soar to $60 in an unimproved building, she said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Economy's Low May Be Past

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave a favorable portrayal of the economy's health to a House panel today, which some traders in the financial markets viewed as making further interest-rate cuts unlikely soon.
His comments, while open to conflicting interpretations, contributed to big early-afternoon selloffs in the bond and stock markets. 
 A little less than a month ago, Mr. Greenspan had warned a New York audience that the economy seemed to be facing the increased risk of a modest recession. Today, by contrast, he said that "more recent evidence suggests that we may have passed the point of maximum risk."
Ever cautious, Mr. Greenspan added, "But we have certainly not yet reached the point at which no risk of undue economic weakness remains."
Economic growth is likely to resume in the coming months and continue into next year, the Fed chief told a House Banking subcommittee in his semiannual report to Congress on the state of the economy. The risks of inflation have faded, he said, banks are in sound financial condition to lend, businesses and consumers are optimistic, and companies' inventories of unsold goods appear to have dwindled. All that, he said, should lay the foundation for renewed expansion after a pause in the second quarter.
"Going forward, of the several credible outlooks, the most probable is for an upturn in the growth rate of final sales and real gross domestic product over the rest of this year, and a moderate pace of expansion next year with the economy operating in the neighborhood of its potential," Mr. Greenspan said.
But he also left the door open to further interest-rate cuts if inflation remained subdued. "As I noted in my February testimony," he said, "easing would be appropriate if underlying forces were clearly pointing toward reduced inflation pressures in the future."
A lot of financial analysts and traders had been more pessimistic about the economy's health, and thought until today that Mr. Greenspan might follow up the interest-rate reduction two weeks ago by again lowering rates in August or September to help maintain economic growth. But his ambiguous statements today left many disappointed.
"The market is selling off in part because of what he didn't say rather than what he did say," said Sung W. Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "We were all looking for some encouragement from Chairman Greenspan that there would be further cuts in interest rates."
Other analysts thought that Mr. Greenspan gave no clear signal at all about the future course of interest rates. They contended that the bond market overreacted by falling sharply, followed by a steep slide in the stock market.
"Chairman Greenspan's testimony was quite in line with expectations," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "He didn't promise any further reductions in interest rates, but in no way could he do that."
In yet a third view, a few analysts said that Mr. Greenspan, despite the performance of the financial markets today, had signaled in his testimony on inflation that more interest-rate cuts could be on the way. The Fed chief's comments "certainly suggested a scenario that would lead to additional rate cuts in the coming months," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
On July 6, the central bank's interest-rate-setting panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, cut one of the short-term rates it controls by one-quarter of a percentage point, the smallest of its rate-reduction options. Some Democrats on the House Banking subcommittee said today that it should have gone further.
"While raising or lowering interest rates a little sends a signal, perhaps at this point we need more than a signal," said Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts.
But the Republican majority greeted Mr. Greenspan's testimony in terms bordering on reverence.
"The summation of anyone listening to what's occurred today just underscores the imperative need for a professional, competent, independent Federal Reserve system," said Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, the Banking Committee chairman, "and without it, I think stability in this country and around the world would be substantially lessened."
Mr. Greenspan refused to discuss specific tax policies or spending cuts under consideration on Capitol Hill, but he did urge Congress to balance the budget and hinted that the Fed might adjust its policies if significant steps were taken.
"Clearly, the Federal Reserve will have to watch this process carefully," he said, "and take the likely effects of fiscal policy into account in considering the appropriate stance in monetary policy. But there is no doubt, in my judgment, that the net result of moving to budget balance will be a more efficient, more productive U.S. economy."
As usual, Mr. Greenspan avoided questions about the future path of specific markets like the bond, foreign exchange or gold market. But he did point out beneficial side effects of the rise this year in stock and bond prices.
"The positive implications of the rally in financial markets for household debt-service burdens and wealth, and for the cost of capital to business, augur well for spending on consumer durables, on housing and on plant and equipment," he said. He did not speculate on how, if at all, a sustained fall in financial markets might affect the pace of spending and overall economic growth.
Reflecting the consensus of the Federal Open Market Committee, Mr. Greenspan predicted that the economy might grow at a rate of 1.5 percent to 2 percent for all of 1995, and 2.5 percent next year. He estimated that consumer-price inflation would run in a range of 3.125 percent to 3.375 percent this year and slow to the range of 2.875 percent to 3.25 percent next year.
And he forecast that unemployment would rise from 5.6 percent last month to somewhere between 5.75 percent and 6.125 percent by the fourth quarter of this year.

HEADLINE: President Shows Fervent Support For Goals of Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Four months after hinting that he might scale back Federal preference programs based on race and sex in the face of Republican demands to end them, President Clinton today issued a ringing reaffirmation of the goals and results of affirmative action, saying it has been good for America.
"Affirmative action has not always been perfect, and affirmative action should not go on forever," Mr. Clinton said in a speech at the National Archives. "It should be changed now to take care of those things that are wrong, and it should be retired when its job is done. 
 "I am resolved that that day will come, but the evidence suggests, indeed screams, that that day has not come. The job of ending discrimination in this country is not over." [Excerpts, Page B10.]
Administration aides said the White House had concluded not only that most such programs had worked well, but also that the political risks of tinkering with them now far outweighed any benefit Mr. Clinton might gain in new support from moderate voters. In particular, they said, it became apparent that the programs benefited not just minorities but also women, whose electoral support the President needs.
The White House portrayed the President's speech today as the latest in a series of recent efforts to find common ground on divisive issues like Federal spending, violence on television and prayer in the schools. Though his talk was low-key, he made no apologies for his views.
"We should have a simple slogan," Mr. Clinton said, in what seemed a rhyming nod to Jesse Jackson, who has been harshly skeptical of any effort to diminish affirmative action. "Mend it, but don't end it."
Though affirmative action had bipartisan support when programs were begun 25 years ago, Republicans were quick to criticize the President today as defending the status quo. "He should have said end it; you can't mend it," said Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Presidential hopeful who is seeking to roll back his state's affirmative-action programs. The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, who agreed Tuesday to delay consideration of a bill to curtail affirmative action, perhaps until next year, renewed his vow to introduce legislation "to get the Federal Government out of the group-preference business."
Several of the prominent civil rights and political leaders in the President's invited audience this morning suggested he would gain by standing his ground on an issue that has long been one of his central concerns as a post-civil rights era Southern politician.
Mr. Clinton ordered all Federal agencies to review their affirmative-action programs and eliminate or reshape any that impose a quota, create a preference for unqualified people, foster reverse discrimination or continue after their anti-discrimination purposes has been achieved. And he sketched plans for a new program that would set aside some Federal contracts for individuals, regardless of race or sex, if their businesses or employees were located in poor areas.
But the President proposed no elimination of any program, drew back from any suggestion that affirmative action needed profound rethinking and stood foursquare against arguments from Republicans and conservative Democrats alike that such programs had outlived their usefulness.
He imbued the 45-minute talk with personal history, recalling that the poll tax and segregated schools and washrooms were a facts of life in his Arkansas youth and that improvements did "not happen as some sort of random, evolutionary drift" but thanks to hard work, legal challenges and personal courage.
"I think his speech will help him tremendously at the grass-roots level," said Myrlie Evers-Williams, chairwoman of the National Association of Colored People and the widow of the Medgar Evers, the civil rights leader who was assassinated in Mississippi in 1963. "He has shown policies that I think the public will appreciate, and determined not to waver. It was a brave speech."
Mr. Jackson, who got a telephone briefing on the speech from Mr. Clinton on Tuesday, said today that the President "set a good moral tone for the country" and "spoke to America's hopes and not its fears." He complained, though, that the Administration's review took so long that while Mr. Clinton "was in the stands reviewing and reflecting, the opposition was on the field scoring points."
The moderate Democratic Leadership Council, which which has long urged phasing out affirmative action in favor of broader economic development efforts, was less effusive. Its president, Al From, said, "I hope the President's speech today is the first step in this direction."
For his part, Mr. Clinton gave "angry white men" their due, acknowledging that "some people are honestly concerned about the times affirmative action doesn't work, when it's done in the wrong way."
Mr. Clinton vowed that when the Administration found such cases, it would fight them in court, by filing reverse discrimination suits if necessary. "Most of these suits, however, affect women and minorities for a simple reason: because the vast majority of discrimination in America is still discrimination against them."
At another point he said: "Let me be clear about what affirmative action must not mean and what I won't allow it to be.
"It does not mean, and I don't favor, the unjustified preference of the unqualified over the qualified of any race or gender. It doesn't mean -- and I don't favor -- numerical quotas. It doesn't mean, and I don't favor, rejection or selection of any employee or student solely on the basis of race or gender without regard to merit."
George Stephanopoulos, the senior Presidential adviser who supervised the review of preference programs for the White House, said the President had determined not to single out any particular program for change or elimination pending the completion of detailed new guidelines by the Justice Department instructing agencies on compliance with a recent Supreme Court decision, Adarand Constructors v. Pena, that imposed strict new limits on race-based preference programs, requiring that they be narrowly tailored to remedy past discrimination.

HEADLINE: 200 California Students Jeer Bid to End Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19

 BODY:
A boisterous group of 200 University of California students hissed, booed and waved placards during an emotional meeting here with a dozen members of the university's board as they debated proposals to eliminate affirmative-action policies at the university's nine campuses.
The proposals are scheduled to come before the full 26 regents on Thursday at a formal meeting presided over by Gov. Pete Wilson, who has said he approves of terminating policies that use race, sex, religion or national origin as a criterion for admission to the university, as well as for hiring and contracting. 
 The proposals would require the university administration and the faculty senate to suggest substitute criteria that would allow admissions officers to consider matters like an applicant's socioeconomic status.
This afternoon's meeting was called by the university in the hope of defusing the issue, but student leaders and followers of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has been here for several days, promised even more vigorous demonstrations, including a "sing-in" led by Mr. Jackson at the regents meeting on Thursday.
Speaking in a format that permitted three-minute speeches and questions to the regents, a number of students deplored what they said was the intrusion of politics into the debate over affirmative action.
Robin Haaland, a third-year law student at the campus in Hastings, said: "I have been shocked and disgusted by the political maneuvering by Gov. Pete Wilson. He's coming here because of his own political agenda. This is about politicians taking advantage of people's fears about an unstable economy and people's racism."
He was vigorously cheered, but several regents, most of whom are appointed to 12-year terms by the Governor, defended Mr. Wilson's position.
A distinct minority supported the resolutions, but speakers taking that position were greeted with boos and the pumping up and down of signs reading "LIES!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, center, being applauded yesterday by church leaders from around California after declaring at a news conference in San Francisco that he was willing to go to jail to protest changes in affirmative-action policies at the University of California. The ministers plan to stage a protest when the Board of Regents meets on Thursday to vote on eliminating affirmative-action policies. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Clinton Talk on Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech yesterday at the National Archives on Federal affirmative-action programs as recorded by Federal News Service, a transcription company:
In recent weeks, I have begun a conversation with the American people about our fate and our duty to prepare our nation not only to meet the new century but to live and lead in a world transformed to a degree seldom seen in all of our history. Much of this change is good, but it is not all good, and all of us are affected by it. Therefore, we must reach beyond our fears and our divisions to a new time of great and common purpose. 
 Our challenge is twofold: first, to restore the American dream of opportunity and the American value of responsibility; and second, to bring our country together amid all our diversity into a stronger community so that we can find common ground and move forward as one.
More than ever, these two endeavors are inseparable. I am absolutely convinced we cannot restore economic opportunity or solve our social problems unless we find a way to bring the American people together. To bring our people together, we must openly and honestly deal with the issues that divide us. . . .
Our search to find ways to move more quickly to equal opportunity led to the development of what we now call affirmative action. The purpose of affirmative action is to give our nation a way to finally address the systemic exclusion of individuals of talent, on the basis of their gender or race, from opportunities to develop, perform, achieve and contribute. Affirmative action is an effort to develop a systematic approach to open the doors of education, employment, and business development opportunities to qualified individuals who happen to be members of groups that have experienced long-standing and persistent discrimination. . . .
When affirmative action is done right, it is flexible, it is fair and it works.
I know some people are honestly concerned about the times affirmative action doesn't work, when it's done in the wrong way. And I know there are times when some employers don't use it in the right way. They may cut corners and treat a flexible goal as a quota. They may give opportunities to people who are unqualified instead of those who deserve it. They may in so doing allow a different kind of discrimination. When this happens it is also wrong, but it isn't affirmative action, and it is not legal.
So when our Administration finds cases of that sort, we will enforce the law aggressively. The Justice Department files hundreds of cases every year attacking discrimination in employment, including suits on behalf of white males.
Most of these suits, however, affect women and minorities for a simple reason: because the vast majority of discrimination in America is still discrimination against them. . . .
I am resolved that that day will come, but the evidence suggests, indeed screams, that that day has not come. The job of ending discrimination in this country is not over. That should not be surprising. We had slavery for centuries before the passage of the Thirteenth, Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments. We waited another 100 years for the civil rights legislation. Women have had the vote less than 100 years. We have always had difficulty with these things, as most societies do. But we are making more progress than many people.
Based on the evidence, the job is not done. So, here is what I think. We should, we should reaffirm the principle of affirmative action and fix the practices. We should have a simple slogan: mend it but don't end it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: China's Plans to Make Family Car Are Receding, Official Says

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 19

 BODY:
China's "family car" project, an idea that got Western auto makers salivating when they were invited to submit prototypes last year, is likely to be delayed until well into the next century, a senior Chinese official said today.
In the first public comments on the family car by a senior member of China's car bureaucracy since last fall, Huang Fuheng, general manager of the China National Automotive Industry Sales Corporation, said that making family cars salable would be a "very long and very complicated" process. 
 "It's going to be 10 or 15 years before a family car becomes feasible in China," Mr. Huang said in an interview. "It's a complicated process, not something that we can do in a day."
When Beijing held an exhibition for 20 leading foreign car makers last September, some officials suggested China would choose a single model, and could start producing them within five years.
Ford Motor Company recommended a model from its Fiesta line in Europe. Mitsubishi of Japan offered a mini-van while General Motors pushed a Corsa model from Adam Opel, its German subsidiary.
But Chinese auto officials fell silent after the exhibition, causing confusion among car makers. Mr. Huang's comments, coming shortly after an internal Government meeting on the family car project, indicated that car officials are divided about how to proceed.
"There are some people in our planning departments who favor a single model," Mr. Huang said. "My idea is that the family car should not be done in one factory, or in one model. There are several different kinds of cars needed in China."
He also conceded that it would be hard to meet the original demands set out by Chinese car bureaucrats: that it will be modern, with air-conditioning and anti-lock brakes, be fuel-efficient and cost less than $10,000.
"If you make a car that's too old a model, no one will want it; if you make it fully modern, it will be too expensive," he said.
The vast majority of the 1.4 million vehicles made in China last year were trucks; passenger cars totaled only 250,000, and most of those were purchased by Government work units, which can afford a $30,000-$50,000 sedan for their senior officials.
Chinese officials said last year that they want to consolidate the domestic market -- now composed of 120 or so small, inefficient plants making trucks -- into a handful of large companies that can push total production to 3 million by 2000, with more than a million of them cars. By 2010, they said, China should be producing 8 million vehicles, making it the world's second-largest auto market, after the United States.
Their comments, and China's booming economy persuaded several foreign auto makers that it was time to enter the Chinese market seriously. Yet the market they are entering is plagued by a poor supply network, an inexperienced labor force, and high tariffs that limit imports of autos and parts.
Foreign auto executives said today that Mr. Huang's comments clarified a situation they had already begun to sense: that priority is likely to be given to building a car component industry, and that plans for several new passenger car projects will be pared down.
"The family car is definitely way down the line," said Stephanie Hallford, a Ford executive in China. "For him to say that is not really out of context from what we've understood."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Restoration Is Announced For 42d Street

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
The resurrection of 42d Street took a critical step forward yesterday as a Toronto-based production company announced plans to transform two historic buildings into one state-of-the-art theater to be used for large-scale musical productions.
By combining the two theaters, the Lyric and the Academy, the company said it plans to create a 1,850-seat venue that will be used for the type of big, lavish musicals that in recent years have driven the growth of ticket sales on Broadway. 
 The company, Livent Inc., is the producer of the Tony Award-winning musicals "Show Boat" and "Kiss of the Spider Woman."
The opportunity to return the rundown theaters to their original use arose after city and state officials failed to reach an agreement with the entertainment company Viacom, which wanted to turn the theaters into music production studios for its MTV operations.
Viacom refused to comment on why it could not reach an agreement, but a company spokesman said Viacom was considering other sites on 42d Street and the surrounding area.
Livent's chairman and chief executive, Garth H. Drabinsky, said he had been interested in the property for several months and that when Viacom's option expired in May, "We seized the moment."
Mr. Drabinsky, an entrepreneur known for his showmanship and expensive taste, asserted that with Livent's as-yet unnamed theater and the Walt Disney Company's plan to restore the New Amsterdam Theater across the street, "The two most significant venues for musical theater will be on 42d Street."
Disney is expected to announce today that it has completed terms with the city and state to undertake a $34 million restoration of the New Amsterdam, a 92-year-old theater with glorious Art Nouveau detail and a fabled history.
Disney is expected to use the theater to present extravagant productions like its "Beauty and the Beast," which is playing at the Palace Theater. Livent's production of "Show Boat," a lavish revival, has been running at the Gershwin Theater since last October.
Under the terms of a tentative agreement signed with the New 42d Street, the nonprofit organization overseeing the rehabilitation of many theaters on the street, Livent has a nine-month option on the two theaters and will spend that time completing terms of its lease and seeking necessary design and landmark preservation approvals from the city.
Livent and New 42d Street officials refused to reveal the amount that the company is expected to invest in the project, but Mr. Drabinsky cited, as a guideline, the company's recent restoration of the 2,200-seat Pantages Theater in Toronto, which cost about $17.5 million in United States dollars. "That will give you a ballpark of where we are," he said. "We intend to do the same kind of faithful restoration."
Cora Cahan, president of the New 42d Street, said the plan did not call for any public subsidies, such as in the case of Disney, which is expected to finance about 75 percent of the New Amsterdam's costs with low-interest loans provided by the city.
But other theater executives expressed some skepticism about the Livent plan. Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn, the owner of five Broadway theaters, said that while there is a real need for theaters with large stage space and enough seating to produce and support costly musicals, making a profit from the two theaters could prove difficult.
"There's desperate need on Broadway for exactly what he's getting," Mr. Landesman said of Mr. Drabinsky. "That will be the most sought-after venue in the city, but at what cost? We've all been looking at 42d Street, and we can't see any configuration that works economically."
Small Broadway playhouses are plentiful, and some are vacant. However, the ones large enough to house big musicals are in short supply, and those that do exist are booked with long-running engagements. "Phantom of the Opera," for example, has been running at the Majestic Theater since 1988.
Driven by such popular musicals, Broadway attendance has continued a four-year climb, hitting its highest level in 12 years during the 1994-95 season, according to the League of American Theaters and Producers, an industry trade group.
The Lyric and the Academy both have landmark status. The new combined theater will incorporate historic elements and detail, according to Livent, which said it would release architectural renderings of the project within the next 60 days. Both theaters have facades on 42d and 43d Streets, and under Livent's plan, the primary entrance will be the lobby of the Lyric, on the north side of 42d, just west of Times Square. The 42d Street Academy entrance would be used for ancillary theater purposes, and the facades of both theaters, on both streets, will be restored consistent with their original character.
The Academy, originally known as the Apollo, was built in 1920 by the Selwyn brothers and played host to such performers as W.C. Fields, Ethel Merman and Jimmy Durante. In 1987, it was renamed the Academy, and since then it has been used mainly for pop music concerts.
The Lyric, however, has been closed to the public for the last few years and was last used for motion pictures. It was built in 1903 by the composer Reginald De Koven. The Shubert Brothers built their empire inside the Lyric, with their offices upstairs and their productions onstage. Unlike in the Apollo, much of the Lyric's original interior has been destroyed.
The New 42d, set up in 1990 by the city and state, has responsibility for overseeing the rehabilitation of six theaters on the street. Its first project, the New Victory Theater, will be a nonprofit operation dedicated to young people; it is scheduled to open in December. "We are literally bringing this fabled street back to the future," Ms. Cahan said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Lyric Theater on 42d Street, left, and the Academy Theater on 43d Street are to be renovated to become one theater for big musicals. (Photographs by Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Broad Selloff Hits Treasury Issues Hard

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices tumbled yesterday in a broad selloff after comments by the Federal Reserve chairman dashed any remaining hope for another cut in interest rates this summer.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 19/32 , to 10921/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, surged to 6.86 percent, from 6.76 percent on Tuesday. The long-bond yield is at its highest since May 23. Prices of shorter-term maturities also fell sharply, with the yield on the two-year note rising to 5.86 percent from 5.80 percent. 
 The selloff came after the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, told a Housing Banking subcommittee that the risks of both inflation and a recession had faded and that he expected a moderate expansion next year. His optimistic assessment of the economy suggested that the Fed would break with its recent practice of using more than a single rate cut to renew the economy's growth, traders said.
"People are perhaps not so sure we're guaranteed that anymore," said Patrick Retzer, who manages the $68 million Heartland U.S. Government Securities Fund in Milwaukee.
Many traders had still been expecting a rate cut in August since July 6, when the Fed lowered its target for overnight bank loan rates a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent. Treasury prices, however, have been lower since a report on Friday showed surprising strength in retail sales, throwing cold water on those expectations. That report and other recent data have indicated that the economy has not slowed as sharply as previously thought.
In his testimony yesterday, Mr. Greenspan said more rate cuts would be appropriate if "underlying forces were clearly pointing toward reduced inflation pressures in the future." Still, the Fed chief gave no hint he expected to be cutting rates again soon.
"It's not that the market doesn't like what he's said, it's more what he didn't say," said Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston.
The prospect of Treasury auctions and a deluge of new corporate bonds is also pushing yields higher, traders said. The Government will sell about $194.2 billion of securities, including 30-year bonds, in the next four weeks, according to MMS International.
"If the corporate supply continues, that is a lot to digest," said Mark Sauvigne, a trader at Chemical Securities. Companies sold more than $82 billion since early April to lock in lower borrowing costs as interest rates plunged to their lowest level in about a year.
The recent rise in bond yields probably will not deter companies from selling more bonds at what are still "relatively low borrowing rates," said Bob Auwaerter, who manages $7.5 billion of fixed-income securities at the Vanguard Group in Malvern, Pa.
RJR Nabisco Inc. led four companies selling $1.35 billion of bonds yesterday. It sold $650 million worth of bonds, 30 percent more than originally planned.
The two-part sale included $400 million of six-year notes priced to yield 8.043 percent, or 187.5 basis points more than the six-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Also sold was $250 million of 12-year notes yielding 8.819 percent, or 241.9 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note.
In other corporate sales, the First Data Corporation of Hackensack, N.J., a credit card processor, sold $200 million of 10-year notes, and the Vesta Insurance Group of Birmingham, Ala, sold $100 million of 30-year bonds.
Among asset-backed sales, Federated Department Stores and the Advanta Corporation sold a total of $1.15 billion of repackaged credit card loans.
In the junk-bond market, Paging Network Inc. sold $400 million of 12-year notes, or 60 percent more than originally planned.
In the municipal market, New Jersey obtained its lowest 20-year borrowing cost in almost 20 years in its auction of revenue refunding bonds for the state's Transportation Trust Fund Authority. Lehman Brothers won the bidding on the bonds and re-offered the 2015 maturity at a yield of 5.8 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
For First Time in Two Years, Quarterly Net Falls at Ford

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., July 19

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company reported its first quarterly decline in profits in more than two years today, attributing the decline to the softening economy and the weak dollar.
Ford warned that at least the next quarter was also likely to be weak compared with last year, as the company writes off expensive new factory equipment and reduces production to introduce new cars and trucks, including the new version of the Ford Taurus. 
 But, applauding the Federal Reserve's decision to lower interest rates, Ford said it expected auto sales and the economy to rebound during the rest of the year, and then to continue growing slowly at least through 1998.
During the three months ending in June, Ford earned $1.57 billion, or $1.45 a share, down 8.2 percent from $1.71 billion a year ago. The results were below analysts' expectations, and some said today that they could not figure out why the company had disappointed them.
Shares of Ford fell 87.5 cents, to $30.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Ford, the No. 2 auto maker behind the General Motors Corporation, had a mixed quarter. Although its sales of cars and trucks slipped in terms of numbers worldwide, its total sales and revenue climbed an impressive 7.8 percent, to $36.4 billion. Ford attributed the increased revenue to buyers' decisions to opt for more expensive, if fewer, versions of cars and trucks.
Buyers choosing more expensive, and more expensively equipped, vehicles would generally mean more profit, since the company makes far more money on an Explorer sport utility, for example, than on an Escort subcompact car.
But in fact Ford's after-tax profit margins on auto sales worldwide shrank during the quarter, to 3.7 percent, from 4.3 percent a year ago, accounting for its decreased earnings.
Ford said that the lower volume of sales over all caused the drop-off, by leaving the company with fewer sales over which to spread out its fixed costs.
Further, Ford buys many parts, including big-ticket items like engines, from Japan and Germany. As a result, it said, the relative weakness of the dollar substantially drove up its costs during the quarter. David N. McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance, said currency fluctuations cost the company $125 million in the quarter.
But auto industry analysts said those factors were not enough to account for what they called surprisingly weak margins. "I was extremely disappointed," said Jack Kirnan, auto industry analyst at Salomon Brothers in New York. "There is something fundamental in the cost structure that I can't put my hands on that is allowing this deterioration to occur."
High product development costs, he said, could be eating into Ford's profits. Further, Ford may be equipping its vehicles with more expensive features than buyers will pay for, he said, preventing the company from raising prices high enough to offset the new costs.
David M. Garrity, auto industry analyst at Smith Barney, said he had expected to see better profits at Ford in part because it sold a higher proportion of light trucks in the quarter. But increased competition in that market segment may be starting to cut into profits. "Perhaps this quarter gives us an early indication of that," he said. "I was certainly looking for better margins, and was to some extent not satisfied with their explanation."
While Ford's sales were slightly low in the quarter, they did not fall as far as the industry's, and so the company gained market share. Ford finished the quarter with 26.2 percent of the car and truck market in the United States, compared to 25 percent a year ago.
Ford had to offer higher rebates and other incentives to customers to sell those vehicles. Incentives rose to an average of $760 a vehicle in the quarter, compared to $550 a year ago.
That change was far less drastic than the one reported on Tuesday by the Chrysler Corporation. Its average incentive jumped to $1,035, compared with $610 a year ago. Chrysler's earnings fell 85.9 percent in the quarter, to $135 million. The General Motors Corporation is expected to report its earnings on Thursday.
Without specifying the amount, Ford said today that its Mexican operations, with sales down 55 percent, were losing money because of the devaluation of the peso. "The market is a disaster," Mr. McCammon said.
Overseas, Ford's European operations turned in a strong quarter. Profits there almost doubled, climbing to $319 million from $167 million.
Mr. McCammon said interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve probably accounted for the sharp slowdown in auto sales during the first half of the year, which confounded the company's expecations. "The interest rate effect was probably greater than we realized," he said. But, he added, "I don't consider this all bad," since by restraining robust demand in the short term the Federal Reserve may have cleared the way for several years of modest growth.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
When it comes to farm subsidies, the G.O.P. walks a narrow line.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE most effective political salesmen often work on the thinnest margins. Consider the Congressional Republican leadership, which must walk a narrow line between new-fashioned, take-no-prisoners conservatism that intrigued voters in 1994 and old-fashioned, scratch-my-back coalition politics.
On the one hand, Republicans are committed to balancing the budget by 2002. On the other, they are as dependent as Democrats on interest groups that favor welfare -- in their case, corporate welfare. Perhaps nowhere is the contradiction as vivid as in the struggle over farm policy, a 60-year-old machine for increasing the incomes of favored farmers at the expense of taxpayers and consumers. 
 Cuts seem almost inevitable: the budget committees in both the House and Senate are asking farmers to spill blood along with other interests. The big question, suggests Edward Hudgins, director of regulatory studies at the libertarian Cato Institute, is whether the retreat will be purely tactical. "Farm lobbies are going to fight to preserve the underlying system," he predicts, accepting defeat on the size of subsidies rather than the fundamental character of the program.
Not so long ago, few questioned the notion that farming was too risky and too important to be left to the vagaries of free markets. Indeed, the need for a firm helping hand from Washington had a certain plausibility during the 1930's, when a quarter of Americans still scratched out a living on little farms and the Depression left farmers awash in commodities that could not be sold for prices that covered costs.
But that plausibility has been stretched ever thinner as farms consolidated and farming grew more efficient. Today the typical "family" farmer commands millions of dollars worth of land and machinery, and uses commodity futures markets to reduce the risks of price fluctuations.
The New Dealers who let the farm regulation genie out of the bottle probably could not follow the intricacies of the 750-page law that currently determines the price of milk, the output of walnuts, and the type of sweetener that ends up in Mountain Dew. But they would certainly sympathize with the underlying logic of using regulation to augment farm income.
For some key crops like wheat and cotton, farmers are paid the difference between a "target price" and the market price. For others Washington raises prices directly by limiting both production and imports. "It is a Federal crime to sell peanuts without a license," Mr. Hudgins says.
Growers of dozens of varieties of fruits and vegetables have been encouraged to create legal cartels, with the power to force individual farmers to destroy "excess" output. And since all this means that farm commodities are pricey, Washington follows the European Union's strategy of heavily subsidizing exports to keep them competitive in world markets.
Surprisingly, the opening shot in the war on what Karl Zinsmeister, an agricultural specialist at the American Enterprise Institute, calls "farm socialism," came from Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana. Mr. Lugar, the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee and a Presidential hopeful, wants to eliminate export subsidies and trim "deficiency payments" linked to target prices. All told, he would cut $15 billion from a business-as-usual budget likely to cost $41 billion.
But the farm lobbies quickly went to work on the House and Senate budget committees, persuading them to recommend cuts of just $9 billion and $5.5 billion over five years, respectively. The idea, it seems, is to delay the mother of all battles over farm regulation until 2000, when the balanced budget deadline looms.
One may well wonder whether "later" is just another word for "never." For example, while Representive Dick Armey, the House majority leader, has railed against the sugar, tobacco and peanut programs, the fact that they cost the Government nothing -- consumers simply pay more because supply is artificially limited -- makes them far less vulnerable than the big-money subsidy programs, notably corn.
What's more, Mr. Hudgins notes, much of the political sentiment against subsidies comes from the correct assumption that the lion's share of benefits goes to large farmers. If the farm lobbies changed tactics, permitting narrower subsidies targets and making alliances with environmentalists who want to take land out of production, they might be able keep the system of regulation intact.
But Mr. Zinsmeister remains optimistic that revolutionary change is at hand. Diversification of the rural economy, he notes, is blurring the focus of farm-state Congressmen. And as a result, he says, the once-omnipotent farm lobby is on the verge of becoming a "nine-pound gorilla."
Equally important, Mr. Zinsmeister says, many farmers who viewed subsidies and the restrictions that came with them as a necessary evil are now ready to embrace free markets. "They resent being singled out," he argues. "But with everybody's goodies going," he predicts that farmers will bow to the inevitable.

HEADLINE: Defending Affirmative Action

 BODY:
In near-evangelical tones, President Clinton made the moral, legal and practical case yesterday for the embattled cause of affirmative action. It was a sermon the nation needed to hear from a President who can only be helped by exhibiting a strong core of principle. Instead of the aimlessness that has marked so many White House efforts, this speech offered the zest and forthrightness promised by the Bill Clinton of the '92 campaign. Gone, too, was the hair-splitting accommodationism of the recent speech on school prayer.
In an address notably free of apologies and political trimming, Mr. Clinton asserted that "when affirmative action is done right, it is flexible, it is fair, and it works." Instead of running for cover on specious claims of favoritism for minorities and women, Mr. Clinton met the critics straight on. "Let me be clear," he said. "Affirmative action has been good for America." 
 Indeed it has, as Mr. Clinton made clear by reviewing the history of employment and educational discrimination that the right wing's phony new egalitarians want to obliterate with a national dose of historical amnesia. Mr. Clinton forcefully asserted that the record of the past 30 years shows -- "indeed screams" -- that "the job of ending discrimination in this country is not over."
He was tactically smart to promise to correct practices that discredit affirmative action by, for example, cracking down on fraud perpetrated by contractors who put up a false front of minority status. By not getting tangled up in buzzwords like "quotas" and "preferences," Mr. Clinton was able to promise reform that would improve, not undercut, the crusade for fairness.
He assigned Vice President Gore the task of devising Federal contract systems that target economic disadvantage as well as race and gender, using the Federal purse to help areas that also contain concentrations of minorities.
No one could doubt, of course, whom the President had in mind when he condemned those who "use the anxieties of the middle class" to divide the nation over race and gender. As if called by name, two Republican candidates for his job spoke up with predictable churlishness. Gov. Pete Wilson of California lamely parodied the President, saying he should have "ended, not mended," affirmative action. And the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, ever fearful of being out-toughed by one of his party's bully boys, took the floor to say he would soon be introducing a bill to repeal affirmative action programs.
Mr. Clinton made effective use of last month's Supreme Court decision subjecting Federal contracting outreach programs to severe judicial scrutiny. Rather than kill the programs, he said, the Court had laid down a rigorous test based on a compelling public interest, a test he said he would apply. He pledged that his Administration would support only programs that avoid rigid quotas and reverse discrimination, advance only qualified workers and end when they have accomplished their purpose.
Plainly Mr. Clinton has calculated, correctly, that a platform of equivocation would do him no political good. There was hardly any point in trying to please those angry white men said to be abroad in the land by pretending not to believe in the principle of integrating the workplace.
Yet the political dopesters were predicting that this President might well inflict a little pain on minorities and women just to show his toughness to conservative critics. Instead he hinted that he perceived more good will and less anger in the racial majority than some politicians thought.
For the President's generous view of public opinion alone, for addressing the hoped-for sense of justice, there is reason for gratitude. Mr. Clinton took the high road, and the nation can hope he has accurately discerned a magnanimity that will let affirmative action live.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Soybeans, Silver and Copper Set The Pace as Commodities Fall

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Commodities with strong links to the stock and bond markets -- including soybeans, silver and copper -- took their cue from Wall Street's plunge and fell sharply yesterday .
Soybeans are sometimes viewed as an investment barometer among raw physical commodities, while silver and copper are heavily used by industry. 
 In addition, declines in lumber, cotton, energy and livestock prices helped drive the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities down 2.78 points, to 231.43.
The declines in the financial markets were precipitated by comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that indicated the Fed would not cut interest rates again this summer.
Weather forecasts calling for cooler, wetter weather in the Midwest also helped push down soybean prices, which leaped early this week after a record-breaking heat wave wilted crops.
"The forecast has cooled down," said Fred Gesser of Weather Express Inc. "This is a pretty big flip from yesterday and the day before."
 July soybeans fell 18.25 cents, to $6.17 a bushel, at the Chicago Board of Trade.
Silver prices tumbled sharply to new two-week lows as the selloff in stocks and bonds prompted traders to unload positions in metals as well.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, the September silver contract settled 13.2 cents lower at $5.213 an ounce after earlier touching a low of $5.07.
Gold, which is sometimes viewed as a refuge from paper assets, also declined. August gold fell $1.70, to $388.40 an ounce, on the Comex.
 September copper fell to a low of $1.34 a pound, before recovering slightly to close 3.85 cents lower at $1.3475 a pound.
Lumber prices weakened after the Commerce Department released a disappointing housing starts figure for June. Housing starts last month fell one-tenth of 1 percent, while traders had expected a slight increase.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, September lumber dropped the daily limit of $10, to $278 for 1,000 board feet.
Prospects for an excellent cotton crop drove down October cotton the maximum 2 cents, to 75.67 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Crude oil prices ended lower in reaction to slightly bearish weekly inventory data. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, August crude oil declined 2 cents, to $17.33 a barrel, and August gasoline fell 0.89 cent, to 52.69 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BANKAMERICA CORP. (BAC,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that earnings rose 23 percent in the second quarter, helped by its acquisition of the Continental Bank Corporation and a surge in lending revenue.
BankAmerica, the nation's second-largest banking company, earned $645 million, or $1.56 a share, up from $525 million, or $1.33 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. The results surpassed Wall Street forecasts of $1.49 a share. 
 But while total revenue jumped 15 percent, to $3.3 billion, much of the growth came from its acquisition of the Continental Bank of Chicago in September.
BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, plans to focus on wringing more revenue from its existing businesses rather than join a wave of retail bank mergers and acquisitions, said Lewis Coleman, chief financial officer. "We are nervous of the longevity of retail branch banking and find the prices expensive," he said.
The second-quarter results showed how BankAmerica had put behind it problems with bad loans from the recession of the early 1990's, analysts said.
"I think they had been in a no-growth, or slow-growth, mode for so long," said Larry Vitale, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company. "Now that the clips have been taken off their wings, they can go out and make some loans."
BankAmerica posted a 19 percent surge in consumer and commercial lending in the quarter.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts a Steep Decline As Stocks and Bonds Tumble

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against many leading currencies yesterday as American stocks and bonds had a second consecutive day of steep losses.
The declines in the securities markets heightened concern that foreign investors would cut their stakes in American assets and sell dollars as a result. 
 Bonds and stocks tumbled after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, made his semi-annual report to Congress and cast doubt on the prospects for another cut in interest rates anytime soon.
"It's been a tough day for stocks and bonds, and that can be chalked up to expectations for no further rate cuts," said Wayne Grigull, director of foreign exchange at Merrill Lynch in New York. "The concern about capital flowing out of the country has taken its toll on the dollar."
Ordinarily, an indication by the Fed chief that interest rates would not be cut would bolster the dollar since the prospect of steady or higher rates often helps the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
Indeed, the dollar initially rose on Mr. Greenspan's comments. Many currency traders had been expecting another rate cut this summer ever since the Fed pushed short-term interest rates lower by a quarter of a percentage point on July 6.
When stocks and bonds tumbled, however, the dollar followed. The speed of the dollar's decline suggested investors were less wary about possible central bank intervention than they had been after the Fed and the Bank of Japan staged a surprise dollar-buying spree 12 days ago, traders said.
"The market's willing to sell off dollars swiftly, indicating they're not as concerned about intervention," said Michael Faust, international portfolio manager at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser in San Mateo, Calif.
In New York trading, the dollar slumped to an eight-day low of 86.85 yen before settling at 87.32 yen, down from 88.40 yen on Tuesday. Traders speculated that the Fed might have bought dollars for yen on behalf of the Bank of Japan, muting the dollar's slide against the yen. The Fed and the Treasury declined to comment on their activities in the foreign exchange market.
The dollar fell as low as 1.3722 German marks, its lowest since May 9. It was last quoted at 1.3754 marks, down from 1.3899 marks on Tuesday. The British pound rose to $1.5985 from $1.5946.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Caterpillar's Income Shows 34.6% Gain

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 34.6 percent in the second quarter, fueled in part by strong demand for its machines and engines in the United States..
The company said, however, that it expected lower demand in Japan, and cut its outlook for sales growth in Canada and Australia for the remainder of the year. Demand in the United States may also decline if the economy slows, it said. 
 Caterpillar earned $323 million, or $1.62 a share, compared with $240 million, or $1.18 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Although the results were higher than Wall Street's expectations of $1.57 a share, according to a survey by Zacks Investment Research, some analysts were disappointed
"Although their $1.62 a share was an excellent performance versus $1.18 a year ago, the consensus was working with a number around that range," said Barry Bannister, an analyst with S. G. Warburg. "This is an environment where coming in around consensus is not good enough."
Shares of Caterpillar fell $2.25 yesterday, to $69.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., manufactures earthmoving, construction and materials-handling machinery as well as diesel and natural gas engines and turbines and electric power-generation systems.
Sales of Caterpillar equipment in the United States rose 13 percent, to $2.05 billion during the quarter. Sales outside the United States increased 20 percent, to $2.01 billion, with gains in Europe, Asia, Canada, Australia, Africa and the Middle East.
Caterpillar said worldwide dealer inventories rose from a year ago and were in line with current selling rates. American dealer inventories are slightly higher than normal, it said.
The company said that a yearlong strike by the United Automobile Workers union had no impact on its business in the quarter.
Donald Fites, Caterpillar's chairman and chief executive, said that the company continued to improve productivity in its manufacturing operations.
Such improvements, including a $1.8 billion plant modernization program begun in 1987, have helped bolster Caterpillar's earnings. These benefits, however, are not expected to offset sluggish demand, though, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Come to Singapore and Debate the Issues

 BODY:
To the Editor
William Safire (column, July 10) claims Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong of Singapore has "seized a three-year-old invitation" from Williams College to "be used as a powerful symbolic tool in Singapore" (quoting a Williams professor). 
 But Mr. Goh does not need any "symbolic tool." After the college twice invited him to receive an honorary degree, he agreed in March 1994 to go in 1995. This was well before the Christopher Lingle and Flor Contemplacion issues arose.
Mr. Safire has got his facts wrong. Chewing gum does not attract a $1,000 fine, nor does "sharing a marijuana cigarette" "invite the death penalty" in Singapore. And it was Philip Bowring, not Christopher Lingle, who alleged "dynastic politics" in Singapore.
Next, how could the International Herald Tribune have been "humiliated" when it could have contested the legal action of Singapore's ministers, and shown that what it published was true or otherwise fair comment and therefore not defamatory?
Mr. Safire blames the I.H.T.'s lawyers for being "too cozy" with the ruling party. But the I.H.T. was free to engage any leading Queen's Counsel from Britain to cross-examine Mr. Goh, Lee Kuan Yew, and Lee Hsien Loong and demolish their character and testimony.
Mr. Safire again attacks the integrity of the Singapore judiciary. But the 1994 world competitiveness report by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum rated Singapore ahead of Hong Kong, Sweden, Britain and the United States in public confidence in the fair administration of justice.
Francis Seow, described by Mr. Safire as "exiled to Harvard," is a fugitive from justice. He resigned as Singapore's solicitor general in 1971 after improperly exercising his authority over a police investigation. In 1973, he was suspended from legal practice for conduct the court held "wholly deplorable and dishonorable to his profession."
To evade trial for income tax fraud, he produced false medical certificates, signed by doctors procured by Asia Watch, to deceive the courts and his counsel, including his own British Queen's Counsel.
In the last 15 months Mr. Safire has repeatedly criticized Singapore. This time he has attacked Mr. Goh personally. Mr. Goh has therefore asked me to invite Mr. Safire and George T. Crane, who according to Mr. Safire is organizing a "serious, educational counter-award ceremony" at Williams College, to debate with Mr. Goh the issues Mr. Safire has raised.
The debate will be at the National University of Singapore and will receive full international media coverage. Singapore Airlines will be privileged to fly Mr. Safire and Mr. Crane as distinguished guests to Singapore.
This is a serious invitation for a serious purpose, to give Singaporeans a chance to hear American liberals present their case in person on what is wrong in Singapore. American students in Williamstown do not need this exposure. They have it all the time.
 
CHAN HENG WING
Press Secy. to the Prime Minister
Singapore, July 17, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Essay;
Singapore's Fear

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In our last episode about Singapore, we learned that students and faculty at Williams College, an academic bastion of liberalism in Massachusetts, were objecting to the school's plan to honor the Prime Minister of that rich, repressive, anti-American regime.
Evidently Goh Chok Tung, the puppet who is keeping the Prime Minister's seat warm for one of Dictator Lee Kuan Yew's sons, became fearful at the revelation in this space that he may be confronted on his great day by the exiled Singaporean dissident Francis Seow, now a fellow at Harvard Law School. 
 Supporters of academic freedom at Williams want to arrange a debate between Goh and Seow. The trustees, who recently voted (8 to 7) to stick with the embarrassing invitation, hope the college's mistake in honoring repression can be rectified by having such a debate.
But dictator Lee wants Goh to avoid it at all costs. How to duck the dissident without appearing craven?
Result: A left-handed invitation has been extended to me and the Williams "no-Goh" organizer to come to Singapore to debate Mr. Goh. (The all-expense-paid invitation, in a letter to The Times that I hope runs today, is only "to" that island state, but presumably it is not intended to be one-way.)
The letter-writer claims that chewing gum is no longer subject to fine, and that minor drug trafficking no longer draws the death penalty, though those contemplating such crimes would be ill advised to rely on the unsupported assertion of a flack.
The press aide touts the Singapore judiciary -- Lee appointees who corruptly hand down libel judgments decided by the dictator -- as rated ahead of the U.S. in the Geneva-based World Economic Forum's "Competitiveness Report." I checked; this survey is limited to wealthy business executives, most of whose idea of fair justice is the horsewhipping of uppity stockholders. In that poll, China's justice was equated with America's.
The tip-off that Singapore's invitation is a ploy to avert debate at Williams is in the flack's vilification of Francis Seow as "a fugitive from justice" and a tax cheat.
Mr. Seow was the leader of the Law Society, whose crime was to resist the dictator's moves to crush press freedom; even worse, he dared to best Lee Kuan Yew before a parliamentary select committee.
In 1988, the espousal of human rights by this former Solicitor General earned him an arrest and 72 days of torture vividly recounted in "To Catch a Tartar: A Dissident in Lee Kuan Yew's Prison" (a 1994 Yale Center book you'd better not be caught with in Singapore). After the dictator's secret police accused him of being in cahoots with American intelligence and rigged a phony tax prosecution, Seow chose freedom over more torture.
No wonder Goh is so eager to duck his nemesis at Williams. For an Asian politician to debate a white American pundit in front of a hometown Asian crowd is a set-up for a local racist triumph. But for an Asian dictator's front man to face a respected Asian attorney in a free country -- an opponent who can cite chapter and verse of political repression, and tell of torture from personal experience -- that's debating on a level playing field. It would be like China's Li Peng facing Harry Wu.
So here's my answer: In poker terms, I will see Singapore's bid and raise it.
I would be pleased to engage in a one-on-one debate on universal values. But it's no fun to go up against anybody's "stooge," as Mr. Goh recently complained he is so frequently called. I'm ready to debate Lee Kuan Yew himself, and the dictator only.
The venue? A nation under the rule of law -- not Singapore, and not in front of an audience selected for me of Lee's relatives, cane-wielding thugs, Serbian generals, B.N.L. bankers, Packwood accusers and the Saddam Hussein Fan Club.
Since Dictator Lee admires the work of the World Economic Forum in Switzerland, where we have both spoken in recent years, a debate at the next Davos meeting would be accessible to an unintimidated press.
How about it, Mr. Lee? My one proviso: that your man Goh also agrees to debate Francis Seow, the Singaporean opponent your uptight regime obviously fears most, at Williams college this fall.

HEADLINE: Drop in Starts of Multifamily Housing Hurt June Home Building

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
New home construction slipped in June, but the decline was entirely in multifamily housing, the Government said today. Construction of single-family homes rose 3.9 percent.
Lower mortgage rates had been expected to increase demand.
Over all, housing starts fell one-tenth of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.26 million units a year last month, after declining four-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department said. The agency revised the May rate up to 1.26 million units from the 1.24 million reported previously, which also raised the June level. The June rate, however, was still below the 1.29 million expected by Wall Street economists. 
 Weakening overall starts was a 13.4 percent drop in starts of multiple-unit housing in June to a rate of 251,000 buildings.
But construction starts for single-family homes, which are about 80 percent of total starts, rose 3.9 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.01 million units, after hitting a two-year low in May, the department said. Starts of single-family homes are a key measure of consumers' willingness to take on long-term financial commitments.
Economists were also encouraged by a pickup in permits granted for future housing starts. They rose 2.3 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.27 million units after being unchanged in May.
 "Today's numbers tell us that the housing recovery has begun, but it's only going to be a modest recovery," said David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae.
 Construction starts fell in most of the country except the Midwest, where they rose 9.6 percent. They fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in the South, 7.8 percent in the Northeast and 3 percent in the West.
 In the first half of the year, housing starts were running 11.1 percent behind their 1994 pace.
Housing starts had been expected to rise as much as 4 percent in June, on the assumption that lower mortgage rates would bolster demand. A 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, which was above 9 percent at the beginning of the year, was 7.41 percent last week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Still, the National Association of Home Builders' index -- compiled from a monthly survey of builders -- rose for the third consecutive month in June and suggested for the first time since September that more builders were optimistic than pessimistic about their prospects.
 Helping to fuel their optimism was a sharp 19.9 percent jump in sales of new homes in May and a decline in their inventory of unsold homes to 5.6 months worth from 6.9 months.

HEADLINE: U.S. Asks European Talks on Grain Tariffs

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The United States is seeking quick consultations with the European Union to try to reverse a change in the way the Europeans assess tariffs on grain imports, President Clinton's trade representative, Mickey Kantor, announced today.
The Clinton Administration says that a new way of calculating tariffs will impose a new barrier to grain imports, resulting in additional duties of $14 to $25 a metric ton. Mr. Kantor said this violated rules of the World Trade Organization. From 1991 to 1993, the European Union countries imported approximately $400 million of grain annually from the United States. 
 The trade office's filing today follows an announcement Tuesday by Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman that the United States would seek to return to the old formula for calculating tariffs.
The World Trade Organization was created as the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Its rules on agriculture took effect July 1.
At European Union headquarters in Brussels, the agricultural spokesman, Gerry Kiely, responded that "what we are doing is totally compatible with W.T.O. rules." He added that the Europeans would contest the case at the trade organization, though he seemed to leave the door open for compromise.
Canada has also requested consultations on the issue, Mr. Kantor said. Australia, which exports wheat and rice to Europe, is considering a complaint. Grain-trade analysts expect Brazil and Argentina to file, too, as their soybean exports would presumably be harmed by higher tariffs.
