HEADLINE: Industrial Flotsam Elevated to Art

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN 

 BODY:
LIKE waves at the shore, decorating styles of the last decade -- English country, cozy cottage, Art Deco, Old World and New Age -- have risen and receded, leaving their gentle traces on our sensibilities and on the pillows in many living rooms. But these trends, with their feeling of fantasy and escape, have not enthralled the photographer Jan Staller.
For nearly 35 years, Mr. Staller, whose professional focus is the ruins of the man-made landscape (its remote streets and decaying piers, the crumbling West Side Highway, New Jersey landfills, abandoned chemical plants and construction sites after hours), has been attuned to one muse only: 20th-century industrial design, whether in the furniture of masters like George Nelson and Charles Eames or in the myriad anonymous objects that were once an intrinsic part of the machine age. 
 "I'm more interested in the era we're moving out of than the era we're moving into," he said.
A few months ago, Mr. Staller moved into what he called his "dream house" in Greenwich Village and began displaying his artifacts in rooms whose minimalist style and meticulous attention to detail are right on the pulse of a modern sensibility. Ten years ago, the style was called high tech. It has evolved into a less austere version of the industrial esthetic -- call it high-tech redux or industrial romanticism. It incorporates not just the early-20th-century relics but still-in-production objects and one-of-a-kind art pieces that are forged, welded, polished and cast out of metal, of course.
Alongside his apocalyptic photographs -- including some of nuclear test sites in Nevada -- Mr. Staller has arranged his inventory of more than 100 domestic objects -- the "quintessential objects," he calls them, because they embody intriguing design and utility. These items are the industrial antiques of our time and, for Mr. Staller, the ones that should be preserved. "The silicone age that came after the industrial age is pretty dull and principally putty colored," he said.
The cameras, cast-metal toy cars and trucks, early flashlights and compelling old machines like a 1920's megawatt meter that came from a power plant in Philadelphia are packed into display cases from Duralab, a Brooklyn maker of scientific and medical cabinetry that comes in a wide variety of sizes and colors. (The Duralab cabinets in Mr. Staller's kitchen cost less than $15,000.) Simplicity, economy and durability aside, what appealed to Mr. Staller was the fact that they came from an institutional source.
He found just the right spots for his Eames chairs, Le Corbusier sofa and Philco television set, as well as the lamps and tables he designed from aluminum, copper or bronze. Luckily, he is not one to move furniture around in the middle of the night. The dining table top is a sheath of polished copper that weighs 375 pounds.
Even the mops and brooms, the sleekest of their kind, are perfectly lined up in an alcove off the kitchen. "I'm very picky," Mr. Staller said.
The 3,000-square-foot, three-story mid-19th-century brick building has an oblique view of ships passing on the Hudson River, a terrace shaded by a tall tree and a garage where Mr. Staller parks his green Land Rover.
That setting might be just enough perfection for most New Yorkers. But not for Mr. Staller. The renovation of the building was as meticulous and detailed as everything else in his life. The spaces, restructured with the help of Richard Lewis, a New York architect, and Deborah Staller, an architect and Mr. Staller's sister-in-law, became the palette for Mr. Staller's lifelong romance with all things industrial.
THAT passion explains the corrosion-resistant bright yellow electrical outlets in the kitchen, yards of Duralab laboratory cabinets in "eyerest" green that hold socks and underwear in the bedroom, the outdoor table made from a vintage Esso sign and the art piece de resistance: a footboard on which broken gears and bearings are cast in bronze. "The idea was based on some sort of industrial fossil," Mr. Staller said.
Three drive-in-movie speakers have been transformed into intercoms with the aura of African masks, and an explosion-proof cast aluminum telephone from the late 1950's sits regally on the counter in the bedroom. "It came from a mine or gasworks, where any sparks were insulated from the atmosphere," Mr. Staller said. "I thought it was a beautiful object, sort of like an orthopedic shoe, don't you think?"
Mr. Staller's rather unusual esthetic sense has its roots in his childhood. For a few years, infatuated with wiring devices, he collected switches and outlets and wanted to be an electrician.
His father, Erwin Staller, a developer of shopping centers on Long Island and an architecture and design enthusiast, also subscribed to photography and "shelter" magazines. And the basement, equipped with a radial saw and a turning lathe, made furniture-making a family affair. While Erwin Staller sculptured tables out of large pieces of rough-edged wood, inspired by the work of George Nakashima, his son was prolific in the area of salad bowls and candlesticks and once made an elaborate walnut floor lamp with a turned base and stem.
"My parents would raise their eyes and say, 'If only you could put that effort into your schoolwork,' " Mr. Staller said. He would send for free samples of floor coverings and plastic laminates. Later these samples of mass-produced materials would join the discarded meters and gauges and a large ampersand, all found at flea markets and in dumpsters.
During his teens, Mr. Staller went to a boarding school in Vermont, where he declared his future career as an industrial designer. It was not to be his exact fate. But the appeal of high tech, the industrial style that flowered in the early 1980's, never diminished. It found a niche in both his work and his home, with its cement walls, bare wood floors and unadorned fireplace (in which a toy train sits alone on the hearth, looking like the subject of a painting by Magritte). The windows are framed by plain, even satisfyingly dull green curtains. "I call them motel drapes," Mr. Staller said.
"Normally the architect has to fight with the client to give him nice details," Mr. Lewis, the architect, said. "In this case, Jan was the force behind the special details."
Take the footboard of the bed. The 200-pound, roughly half-inch-thick panel is a bronze casting of broken gears and bits of machinery collected by Mr. Staller. They appear imbedded in steel, "as if some machinery had gotten smashed and burned, then found in mud or tar and partially revealed," he said.
The footboard, Mr. Staller added, is reminiscent of "the industrial celebrations in the paintings and reliefs" at Rockefeller Center.
"But that imagery was in celebration of some kind of idea of a smoothly running machine," he continued. His imagery is one of disarray that mirrors the forbidding feeling of his photographs.
He has even asked himself if this end-of-the-civilized-world imagery is appropriate for a bedroom, never mind the time and expense it took to come to fruition. The bed, he acknowledged, is really quite impractical. "I guess that makes my work either art or folly," Mr. Staller said. "I only hope I live with more of the former and less of the latter."

HEADLINE: PARENT & CHILD;
Deciding if It's Time for Kindergarten or Time to Wait a Year

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
SUSAN MILLAR PERRY decided to give her child that extra push in life by holding him back.
When her son, Nick, was just a toddler, Ms. Perry began to agonize over whether to delay his entry into kindergarten by a year, until he was nearly 6. She consulted with friends and his preschool teachers at the West Side Montessori School in Manhattan. She received conflicting advice from a neighbor who acted as a sort of Greek chorus, telling her one day to hold him back, then changing her tone to advise that the current wisdom was to push him forward. 
 In recent years, early-childhood educators have increasingly frowned on the practice of delaying kindergarten for a year, usually until the child is 6 rather than 5. But while most experts agree the strategy does not really help in the long run and might even be harmful, it remains ever popular.
"It is typically done with the best of intentions, but it is a misguided approach," said Barbara Willer, a spokeswoman for the National Association for the Education of Young Children, an organization of early-childhood educators and child-care providers, based in Washington. "Parents who do it are concerned that their children aren't ready or will somehow benefit from being held out a year. But the research is pretty clear that there are no long-term positive effects, and there may in fact be negative effects. Our basic recommendation is to fix the school program, not the child."
Experts say the practice is particularly widespread among more affluent parents who can afford the luxury of paying for an extra year of preschool. And boys tend to be held back more than girls. Experts saw a rise in the practice in the early 1980's, when widespread curriculum changes sent more academic work and testing down to first grade and even kindergarten.
"Because boys develop a little more slowly than girls, people believe that they are more at risk," said Lorrie A. Shepard, a professor of research methods and statistics at the University of Colorado at Boulder.
But the presumed advantages are typically wiped out by third grade, many experts say. And Ms. Shepard said she could point to no hard evidence that the youngest child in a class will achieve less in the first place.
"Able kids are just as able, whether they are just barely 5 or fully 6," she said. "It's the kids who are not very academically able and young that show up in these trend lines as the most disadvantaged in kindergarten class. A lot of parents are misinformed that their kids are at a disadvantage, but they do it anyway."
Ms. Shepard and another professor, Mary Lee Smith, researched programs that gave children an extra year to prepare for school and found no educational gains. In their 1987 study, 40 children from extra-year classes were compared with 40 from schools that did not offer such programs. When both groups had finished first grade, the extra-year students showed a one-month advantage in reading scores but no difference in math or in ratings of things like maturity. Parents also reported that the extra-year children had poorer attitudes toward school.
Some who study child development suggest that delayed school entry is inevitable in an educational system that has become too rigid and structured in the early grades and ignores the intellectual growth rates of individual children.
David Elkind, a professor of child study at Tufts University, sees some rationale in the practice of holding back, even if it means that some older children will have a competitive edge over younger classmates.
"As a general rule, I think it is undemocratic, but I think you have to do what is in the best interest of your child," said Mr. Elkind, who is also an author. "Because the system isn't working properly, should you punish your child? It's a dilemma."
In New York City, where competition is fierce to get into private schools and those public schools that require entrance exams, holding children back is an exceedingly common practice and is even quietly preached by some schools, educators and parents say.
"As slots for private schools in middle and high schools are getting more competitive, parents see holding back as an edge," said Carmen Farina, the principal of Public School 6, a consistently top-scoring school on the Upper East Side. "A child going to an interview will be more verbal at 13 than 12. It is seen as an advantage for advanced grade placement. As they get older, it will hold them in great stead."
Ms. Perry, the editor in chief of Longevity magazine, admits that she and her husband, David, an advertising art director, had archly competitive motives in deciding to hold back Nick, who starts first grade at the Cathedral School in Manhattan this fall.
"This is a competitive world, and this is a competitive city," she said. "I was thinking ahead for middle school, for grade school and where he was at that moment in time."
Delayed entry is also known by experts as red-shirting, from the school athletic tradition of holding promising young players -- in red shirts -- on the bench for a year while they grew. Delaying kindergarten took firm hold in the early 1980's as various education commissions exhorted schools to place more emphasis on back-to-basics academics and improved achievement on standardized tests. Kindergartens began to look more like first grades, and many 5-year-olds couldn't do the work. Anxious parents were increasingly advised to have their children wait. So, many schools created extra-year developmental programs.
But in recent years, the nationwide trend of schools' setting their own policies on the subject appears to have diminished somewhat, as influential educational groups have argued against holding children back, said Sharon Lynn Kagan, a senior associate at the Bush Center in Child Development and Social Policy of Yale University.
"We are acknowledging that schools need to be ready for all children of various levels and abilities," Ms. Kagan said. "We are seeing more emphasis on school change and getting schools ready rather than getting kids ready."
Even though the practice may be declining in the nation as a whole, it thrives in certain middle-class communities, said Elizabeth Graue, an education professor at the University of Wisconsin at Madison. She has studied delayed school entry from an anthropological perspective.
While there are no definitive numbers, she says she has found that the more educated parents are, the more likely they are to hold their children back. "It's people who have the economic resources to be hooked into certain groups," Ms. Graue said, adding that she disliked the practice.
These parents get advice from preschool teachers, pediatricians and others. They read parenting magazines. "In working- or lower-class neighborhoods, parents assume you bring your child in when they're 5," she said. Whites are also more apt to do it than parents in other ethnic groups, she said.
Even though parents assume delayed entry will save children from later failure, Ms. Graue said she had interviewed children who were unhappy about not being with classmates their own age. Some think they are "bad," and some refuse to celebrate their birthdays because they don't want anybody to know they are older, she said.
At the same time, parents of older children are demanding that kindergarten teachers use more advanced curriculums that include things like workbooks and specialized reading materials, she said.
"It makes it hard for the children who came to school when they were supposed to, at age 5," she said. "You have these big 6-year-olds wanting fancier things."
In Westport, Conn., where children are unloaded at the Christ and Holy Trinity preschool from Saabs, Volvos and vans, Margaret Taylor, a real estate lawyer, and her husband, Peter Gillespie, also a lawyer, enrolled their son Colin in a transitional kindergarten program called the 5's.
The couple were worried that their son lacked the necessary emotional maturity for school. The special program, which has mostly boys, allowed Colin to delay his entry into regular school for a year without being labeled a repeater. He attended the 5's kindergarten at the preschool, then went again to kindergarten in the public schools, where he was among the oldest in class.
Ms. Taylor said the decision to place Colin in the 5's was based on careful thinking. The boy, now 9, is studious, but also a worrier who gets upset if he does not understand a problem. "I felt he would be disadvantaged by being the youngest child," she said.
She and her husband made their decision based on things they had noticed about their oldest son, Jeffrey, whom they did not hold back. He is a confident and relaxed boy who just finished seventh grade as one of the youngest in his class. Even though Jeffrey is academically successful, his mother is worried about subtle things, like how he lags in social skills and sports. She said he also struggled with increased homework and with organizing himself in the fifth grade, when he entered middle school. "He was constantly losing stuff," his mother said. "I don't think he had matured enough."
Ms. Taylor said the family had decided not to hold back their youngest son, Ian, a self-assured, outgoing boy whose April birthday will place him in the middle of his kindergarten class.
Along with many educators, Ms. Taylor thinks it is a shame parents are allowed to manipulate children's school careers so directly. "It is out of hand," she said. But even so, she added, "you don't want to think of your child struggling year after year."

HEADLINE: In an Assertive and Democratic Taiwan, a Basic Issue Arises: Who Are We?

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
Chen Ming-tong brushed a mop of hair off his forehead and laughed about his last trip to China.
"China?" he said, his eyes widening. "I'm a foreigner in that country. It's not my country. A lot of their language, I don't even understand their meaning." 
 With those few words, the 40-year-old professor of political science summed up a question that dominates every element of life in Taiwan, from domestic politics to foreign policy: What is the national identity of this island?
"That's the biggest issue," Mr. Chen explained. "I don't deny that there are 10 percent of the people here who want to unite with China at any cost. But the great majority of us identify ourselves as Taiwanese. So we have to ask ourselves: Are we Chinese, or are we Taiwanese? Are we in Taiwan a country, or are we part of China?"
Officially, the Government of Taiwan still says this island is a province of China. But the Government is also doing all it can to create a de facto independence for the island by fostering new political, economic and cultural links with the world.
In particular, Taiwan's new-found economic strength and nascent democracy have infused the Taiwanese with a sense of individual identity. It has even become popular here for politicians -- in what was heresy in the days when Chiang Kai-shek dreamed of reconquering the mainland -- to call for an outright declaration of Taiwan's independence.
But Taiwan's seeming march toward sovereignty faces a huge obstacle: It is furiously opposed by China. Beijing regards the island as a renegade province that must rejoin the motherland, and it has responded to Taiwan's tentative steps with talk of military invasion and threats to sever relations with any country too accommodating of Taiwan's aspirations.
The United States and virtually all other countries recognize China's claim over Taiwan, the "one China" policy that is imbedded in treaties and resolutions. For China, the decision by the United States to allow the ostensibly private visit of Taiwan's President last month -- a departure from American policy -- provoked a diplomatic crisis.
But for this island's 21 million people, the strands that bind Taiwan to China have frayed, and for many they have long since snapped.
"The reality is that Taiwan does not belong to the People's Republic of China," said Shih Ming-te, the leader of the Democratic Progressive Party, the country's largest opposition party. "The P.R.C. never governed Taiwan, not even for one day. For the last 50 years, there have been in reality two independent countries on either side of the Taiwan Strait."
Mr. Shih, like most people here, said independence is not simply an aspiration; it is for all practical purposes reality. Starting in the era of Chiang Kai-shek, who claimed to be the true leader of China right up to his death in 1975, Mr. Shih's calls for independence kept him in prison for more than 25 years, until 1990.
Today he is in Taiwan's legislature and his party, with its public stance for independence, poses the most formidable threat so far to the governing Nationalist Party.
Six months ago, for the first time in Taiwan's history, an opposition politician was elected Mayor of Taipei, the capital. Sitting in his cavernous office in the gleaming marble-clad City Hall, the new Mayor, Chen Shui-bian, surveyed his metropolis of 2.7 million people spread beneath his window. He is also the first native Taiwanese since 1949 to be Mayor of the city.
"We people in Taiwan are different from the people on the mainland," he said. "And Taiwan's future will be decided by its 21 million people."
While that population still suffers strains between the Taiwanese majority who was here before Chiang arrived in 1949 and the island's million or so Chinese who are descended from his followers, it has increasingly and deliberately forged an identity distinct from that of China.
Today even the Nationalists have gradually moved away from their identification with China and things Chinese. Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, himself boasts of his Taiwanese roots, and outside Taipei he is more likely to speak the local Taiwanese dialect than the Mandarin dialect favored by Chinese from northern China. In Taiwan's schools, textbooks that devoted most of their pages to China are being replaced by books focusing on Taiwan.
"How can China claim Taiwan is a province of China?" said Hansen Chien, a member of the Nationalist Party's central committee. "It's ridiculous." But he warned, in a reflection of the ambiguous state of nationalist party policy, that encouraging discussions of independence or declaring Taiwan's independence from China would court disaster.
"That puts our people in immediate danger," he said, citing China's promise to attack the island if it tries to establish itself as a sovereign state. "But in reality the Republic of China is independent," he said, using Taiwan's formal name.
There has been no explicit declaration from the Taiwan Government of a move toward independence, an act the Government still regards as precipitous and unnecessarily inflammatory. Instead, the Government tries to demonstrate the island's distinction from China in political, economic and social spheres.
The most visible sign of this ambiguous, sometimes contradictory policy is Taiwan's continuing effort to regain admission to the United Nations, from which it was ousted in 1971 when the mainland took over the China seat. In June, Taiwan even made a public pledge to donate $1 billion in aid to developing countries if it gained admission to the world body. China, which as a Security Council member has the power to keep Taiwan out, is furious about the efforts to join and most United Nations members, including the United States, reject the idea.
There is much about Taiwan that seems Chinese. Gargantuan neon signs of Chinese ideographs march down broad streets announcing restaurants, shopping malls, book stores. But here, the ideographs in their full forms hark back to traditional China, not the land of Communism, where written Chinese ideographs have been simplified, drained of all historical resonance.
Though its cities are bursting with entrepreneurial ambition, China eschews politics, a free press and the clamor of public debate. Here, there is a feeling of having made it, of needing a rambunctious press, and of thirsting after a debate over the future.
"We're the first independent licensed radio station," said Hsu Lu, the general manager of the Voice of Taipei. "We don't broadcast government propaganda. We want to tell people how things are and listen to what they have to say."
Her station, one of a growing number, grew out of the spread of underground radio stations, which were militantly anti-Government and, importantly, broadcast in the Taiwanese dialect. Last year, when the Government tried to shut down the underground broadcasters, taxi drivers went on strike, forcing the Government to back down.
"That could never happen in China," said Ms. Hsu.
Much of Taiwan's sense of identity and purpose comes from its extraordinary economic growth. In two decades Taiwan has managed to transform itself from a backwater into one of the dominant economic presences in Asia, with the world's 19th-largest economy.
And with economic power has come a surging confidence that buttresses Taiwan's claim to a greater stature in Asia and fuels increasingly aggressive moves toward international recognition.
"Taiwan is now the second largest investor in the region after Japan," said Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a private economic research group. "We should play a more important role in the region."
As Taiwan has pumped up its economic muscles -- the per capita gross national product will be about $12,640 this year, four times what it was a decade ago -- it has embraced tumultuous democratic politics unknown in the Chinese-speaking world.
Later this year, voters will elect a new legislature, one in which the hold of the Nationalist Party is likely to be broken for the first time. Next March, for the first time in Taiwan's history, candidates for the country's presidency will be popularly elected.

Appeal Against Confrontation

TAIPEI, Thursday, July 20 (Reuters) -- President Lee Teng-hui called on China today to give up its "ideological confrontation." His plea came two days after Beijing announced missile tests near Taiwan.
"We sincerely hope Beijing's authorities give up ideological confrontation to open a new age of peaceful competition by Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Straits," Mr. Lee said in a speech to a government seminar. He did not directly refer to the planned missile tests, which are to begin on Friday 85 miles north of Taiwan.
"Only mutual respect will gradually achieve Chinese reunification under the goals of democracy, freedom and equal distribution of wealth," he added.

HEADLINE: With an Abortion Vote and a Budget Cut, House Republicans Counter Clinton

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
The House voted today to abolish abortion coverage for Federal workers who are the victims of rape or incest, overturning one of the earliest of President Clinton's policy decisions.
And ending Congress's traditional hands-off policy on the White House budget, the Republican-controlled House cut $41 million from Mr. Clinton's request for the Executive Office for the 1996 fiscal year, including all money for the Council of Economic Advisers, a major Presidential advisory group. 
 Democrats failed in a series of attempts to make the abortion bill less restrictive, and they did not mount a floor fight over the cuts to the Executive Office budget. But they vowed that the battle would continue on the floor of the Senate, which has yet to take up the issues, and during committee meetings to reconcile what are certain to be differences between the chambers.
Republicans also used the debate to deliver a pointed political message to the Administration on the Mexico bailout plan. By a vote of 245 to 183, the House approved an amendment that would bar the Administration from using the Exchange Stabilization Fund "for the purpose of bolstering any foreign currency."
Although it did not mention any nation by name, the measure was clearly directed at Mr. Clinton's bailout plan for Mexico. The President turned to the Exchange Stabilization Fund for a $20 billion loan to Mexico earlier this year after Congress balked at a plan to rescue the peso. Today's votes came during consideration of a $23.2 billion appropriations bill for the Treasury Department, the United States Postal Service, the Executive Office of the President and various agencies, which passed by a vote of 216 to 211.
The abortion measure would prohibit the Government's health plans for Federal employees from covering abortions, except in cases when a woman's life was at risk. The Government pays for about three-quarters of the health plan for each employee, and the worker pays the balance. Under the bill, no insurance money from a federally subsidized program, including the employee's contributions, could be used to pay for an abortion except when a woman's life was at stake.
"Congress has no right to forcibly compel taxpayers, many of whom share my strong belief in the rights of the unborn, to pay for elective abortions," said Representative J. D. Hayworth, Republican of Arizona.
Opponents made similarly broad arguments against the measure.
"Eliminating this right for one group of women just because they happen to work for the Federal Government is discrimination, pure and simple," said Representative John W. Olver, Democrat of Massachusetts.
About two-thirds of private health plans cover abortion services.
The abortion measure restores to law what had been policy for a decade under the Administrations of Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush. Mr. Clinton had expanded the abortion policy to cover cases of rape and incest, which are believed to account for about 1 percent of all abortions.
On the appropriation for the Executive Office of the President, the House allowed $267.3 million, which was $43.3 million less than Mr. Clinton had requested and $41.1 million less than the current budget.
Congress has oversight of all discretionary spending, including the White House budget, but it has traditionally honored Presidents' requests for the Executive Office.
Few major offices within the White House escaped some kind of cut. The allocation for the National Security Council was $6.5 million, $189,000 less than in 1995; the Office of Policy Development, which advises the White House on domestic policy, received $3.9 million, a cut of $1.1 million, and the Office of Management and Budget was given $55.4 million, which was $2.3 million less than its current budget.
The President's salary -- $250,000 a year -- did not change.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Tempest in a Dugout, Starring McDowell

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
Jack McDowell, as we all know by now, has remarkable dexterity with the digits. The Yankee right-hander can toss the most universally understood obscene gesture with the best of them and not let a camera miss it, as he proved in a remarkable show of bad humor Tuesday night.
The Yankees, the team that employs him to be a tasteful human being as well as a winning pitcher, will take his money, $5,000 of it, because of the foul tempest McDowell stirred after the White Sox, his former team, drilled him with 13 hits and nine runs in four and two-thirds very ugly innings Tuesday. 
 As he walked to the dugout, McDowell gestured to the crowd at Yankee Stadium with the middle finger of his right hand. And although the hometown team gathered itself long enough to defeat the Kansas City Royals, 5-2, yesterday, removing some of the sting of the humiliations of the day before, McDowell remained a major story, and not just because of his lack of etiquette. For now the Yankees, adrift near the bottom of the American League East, must wonder if McDowell was right for this club in the first place.
Remember, when the Yankees first started sniffing around for a big-game pitcher, a search dating back several years, McDowell was but one of a number of tantalizing possibilities. Randy Johnson of the Mariners was another. So was Andy Benes of the Padres.
Fortunately for McDowell, he's no Andy Benes, a hard-luck story who went from July 1994 until June 16 without winning. Unfortunately for the Yankees, McDowell is also no Randy Johnson. No one in major league baseball is; the Mariners' 6-foot-10-inch intimidator has a 10-1 record and a major-league leading 168 strikeouts.
The most dangerous digit in a Randy Johnson game is the index finger the Mariners catcher puts down to call for an unhittable fast ball. Johnson routinely punches out 10-plus hitters a game, even against teams like the Yankees who snort and swear at his antics and swing from the heels in vain attempts to do damage.
A couple of years ago, when that potential was still mostly untapped, the Yankees could have reeled Johnson in. The Mariners were fishing for prospects. Names such as Sterling Hitchcock, the winner of yesterday's game who is now 4-6, popped up. So did that of Bob Wickman, the invaluable middle man in the Yankees' bullpen. And Russell Davis and Gerald Williams, young hitters who to this day cannot carve out regular roles here.
Buck Showalter, the Yankee manager, knows he could make himself crazy thinking about the what-ifs and what-might-have beens. "But I don't, because I know for a fact that the deals talked about weren't in the best interests of our organization," he said. "I don't even remember what they were at the time, but I trust the people who make those decisions."
They are, after all, the same people who made the decisions to sign Jimmy Key and Wade Boggs, to acquire Paul O'Neill and Mike Stanley.
"We always seem to harp on the deals not made as opposed to the deals that were made," Showalter said.
True, economic considerations have made the team wary about picking up big contracts. And Johnson is due to make $5.75 million next year, $6 million the next and has a $6 million option for 1998. But the Yankees have money. And didn't they just sign an outfielder named Darryl Strawberry for $850,000 even as the owner admitted that no one knew if he could still hit? And didn't the club sign arbitration-eligible McDowell to a $5.4 million contract this year?
Undoubtedly, McDowell will want or seek similar figures next year. Question is, should the Yankees give it to him? You judge.
McDowell needed six victories in his last eight games to improve his record to 7-6. The drubbing Tuesday was one of his uglier games this year, but not the only ugly one. His earned run average of 4.78 offers proof of his inconsistency and struggles.
This cannot be what the Yankees expected. It certainly is not what they needed in light of the loss of the club's top pitcher, Jimmy Key. That absence would put pressure on even former Cy Young winners like McDowell. And, the pitcher admitted yesterday: "I'm sure it is. I've gotten blown out of the water. Every four or five starts I get blown out of the water."
Showalter said: "I still think he can turn it around, because of his track record, his stick-to-itiveness and his competitive nature. Jack's not a guy who will wallow in self-pity. He's going to keep coming right back at you."
From here on, though, the team obviously must not only gauge the pitcher's ability to win, but also his ability to deal with New York. If one bad outing can have him flinging fingers, then his emotional makeup comes into question.
"What happened the other night surprised me somewhat because this is a guy who has tremendous respect for the game and the people who went before him," Showalter said. "But from the competitive standpoint, it doesn't surprise me. He gets frustrated with the lack of success, just like everybody else. He's not some iron horse."
Right now, the Yankees don't need an iron horse. They just need a horse. If it is not Key or Johnson, it must be McDowell. He might not win big with Miss Manners. But he is getting paid to win big with the Yankees. Even Jack McDowell's five seconds of fury didn't hide the fact that he has not yet done that.

HEADLINE: In Battle Over Public Lands, Ranchers Push Public Aside

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: KETCHUM, Idaho

 BODY:
The high alpine country near the grave of Ernest Hemingway is some of the prettiest public land in America, with its flower meadows, wild horses and views of the tallest mountains in Idaho. Signs inform visitors that it is a land of "many uses," overseen for the public by the Federal Bureau of Land Management.
But Congress is now poised to grant ranchers virtual control over this and almost every other part of the 270 million acres of Federal land where grazing permits have already been issued. People who hunt, fish or hike say the concept of sharing the use of public lands is being shoved aside for a small special interest. 
 In the heart of the Idaho mountains northeast of Sun Valley, for example, the computer billionaires William Hewlett and David Packard, two of the richest men in America, graze their cattle on nearly 100,000 acres of Federal land that adjoins their 15,000-acre private ranch.
It is not the picture that Western senators have in mind when they evoke the lone cowboy trying to make a go of it against meddlesome Federal bureaucrats. But this ranch, because it is in the middle of a prime recreation and wildlife area, is at the center of a struggle over who controls land that is supposed to be owned by every American.
The Federal land, critics say, will essentially become a private domain for cattle owned by Mr. Hewlett and Mr. Packard under a bill that Congress is likely to pass this summer. And the ranch, which has some of most sublime mountain scenery in the West, has been a source of continual problems.
Many of the small creeks on the property are denuded of brush because of overgrazing, say the Federal officials who monitor the cattle operation. A spring that flows into a stream where the Government has spent millions of dollars trying to restore salmon was overrun with more than 600 cattle in early July, a violation of Federal guidelines. Salmon need clean, cold water to survive -- both of which are affected by heavy upstream cattle grazing.
If the Public Rangeland Management Act, which the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee passed on Wednesday, is enacted, the co-founders of the Hewlett-Packard Company would no longer have to contend with critics in Idaho who have waged a 20-year fight to keep their cattle from polluting streams and overgrazing high elevation grasslands, the critics say.
The bill would also set a fee -- about one-fourth of the rate charged by private landowners -- that could force taxpayers to subsidize grazing well into the next century, according to figures compiled by the Department of Agriculture. The fees would be higher initially than the present rates, but would be much lower over the long run than those proposed by the Clinton Administration. These provisions have led some conservative critics to label the bill "cowboy socialism."
Ranchers, both rich and poor, say they are tired of outsiders from the Federal Government and from environmental groups telling them what to do with cattle on public lands. They say that they are the true environmentalists and that the livestock bill would simply let them take care of the business they know best.
The grazing legislation, sponsored by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, would affect nearly one-eighth of all the land in the United States. It is a response to Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's effort to tighten regulations on the open range, a move that drew wide criticism from ranchers.
Last year more than 68 million people visited public lands -- most of them in the West -- that are overseen by the Bureau of Land Management, a branch of the Department of the Interior. There are about 22,000 ranchers with permits to graze cattle on land managed by the bureau.
Although their numbers are small, the ranchers have the upper hand in Congress for the first time in decades, and they are pushing the Domenici bill, which they say would lock in their advantage for decades.
"It's over," said Dave Nelson, who manages the Hewlett and Packard cattle on what is called the San Felipe allotment in Idaho. "The environmentalists have lost, and all they can do now is take pot shots."
In recent years, environmental groups like the Nature Conservancy have been trying to bid on public lands, with the intention of restoring it or allowing only a minimal amount of grazing. Ranchers fear that such groups are slowly chipping away at their livelihood.
Senator Domenici said his bill, which has wide support among Western senators, would free ranchers who use public lands from heavy regulation.
"In essence, we are calling for an end to the battle and the realization of a stability that will allow a historic way of life to continue to flourish in this modern world," he said.
The larger fight is the age-old debate over the role of the cowboy in the West. In 1993, when the Clinton Administration tried to raise grazing fees and insist on tighter regulations, it was attacked for waging a "war on the West" -- a criticism that continues to haunt it. For that reason, Administration officials say, President Clinton may be reluctant to take on the livestock industry again.
But that has not stopped officials in the land management agencies from attacking the livestock bill as a giveaway to a powerful special interest.
"This bill takes the public out of public lands," said Mike Dombeck, acting director of the Bureau of Land Management. "It returns land management to an era of single use at taxpayers' expense."
Here in Idaho, Federal officials have been working for years to force Mr. Hewlett and Mr. Packard to keep their cattle out of streams and fragile meadows. The officials say the Domenici bill would make it impossible to enforce the most basic of regulations.
They say the land here has improved over the years, but only because they have used their enforcement powers to get the ranchers to comply with environmental laws.
If hunters or backpackers abuse the land -- by burning, camping or killing wildlife in an off-limits area -- they can be immediately fined. But under Senator Domenici's bill, a rancher could consistently violate the standards of care for the land, and it would take "up to 23 years" to get them to change, said Maitland Sharpe, an assistant director of the Bureau of Land Management.
Most ranchers who use public lands comply with regulations and genuinely care about the shape of the range, Mr. Sharpe said. But about 5 percent do not cooperate, and the bill would give them "a unique authority" to do what they want, he said, adding, "This bill takes public lands and turns them into something very close to private ranches."
Ranchers say they can do without much public involvement. In the past, criticism from sportsmen and environmentalists has so hampered their operations that it has made it hard to keep public-land ranches going, many ranchers say.
"The range is not as bad as a lot of these B.L.M. guys and environmentalists say it is," said Mr. Nelson, who runs the San Felipe allotment. Mr. Hewlett and Mr. Packard, both in their 80's, seldom get out to the ranch anymore, he said. Neither responded to requests for an interview.
Robert Stephens, Mr. Packard's son-in-law, said in an interview that the family has tried to be good stewards. "You won't find two stronger conservationists than David Packard and William Hewlett," he said. "If they thought their actions on that ranch were hurting salmon, they would want to do something about it."
On a tour of the land, cattle were seen in areas where they were not supposed to be -- trampling in small springs that flow into creeks that are spawning grounds for the salmon. Other creeks were dry, their banks ripped apart by erosion. There were groves of dead aspen and willow, which dried up when the water table sank from overgrazing, Federal officials said.
The damage is so severe in some areas that "it will take geologic time for it to recover," Mr. Sharpe said.
Mr. Nelson said some of the streams' banks had been destroyed by flash floods in which upland grazing was not a factor. And he conceded that cattle should not have been trampling and defecating in the springs that flow into a salmon-spawning stream. Within days of the reporter's visit, the cattle were moved.
"The cows that go in there do some damage, I won't deny that," Mr. Nelson said. "But they're only in those areas a few days out of the year. You'd be surprised at how quickly the damage can be restored."
He added, "We're very proud of that range. If we didn't have cowboys out there taking care of it, this and other public lands would fall into pretty bad shape."
Paradoxically, the Senate bill, and a similar measure proposed in the House, comes as free market economics is driving all but some of the wealthiest public-land ranchers out of business. Beef prices have fallen by 40 percent in the last year alone.
Without support from the Government, which provides roads, water and forage to ranchers for little or, in some cases, no fees, many cattle operations would leave public land, some experts believe.
The Senate bill would "create and sustain a land-use monopoly that is anathema to American values and harmful to the West," Karl Hess, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, wrote in a recent essay.
But Senator Domenici and the livestock industry backing the bill say that ranchers need protection from other groups that oppose grazing on public land.
For that reason, a new provision has been written into the bill that would prevent everyone except ranchers and adjacent property owners from having a significant say in in how the land should be managed. "Without this change, persons who are not directly affected would be allowed to challenge management decisions affecting individual grazing permits and leases," Mr. Domenici wrote in a June 30 memorandum to other senators.
"In other words, me," said Linn Kincannon of the Idaho Conservation League, the state's oldest conservation group. "They're trying to prevent people like me from having any say in what goes in this huge section of public land in my own backyard."
Ranchers say some of the strongest critics do not care about the land, but simply want to drive cattle out of the area. "Our major concern is the very small percentage of the American public that wants to turn these lands into their so-called natural state," said Bob Sears of the Idaho Cattle Association.

HEADLINE: In House, Tirade on China, but a Vote to Keep Trade as It Is

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
The House railed long and fervently today against China's arrest of Harry Wu, China's use of prisoners as factory workers, China's sale of missile blueprints to its allies and China's use of forced birth control.
But given the opportunity, it declined to show its displeasure in unmistakable fashion: by revoking China's preferred trading status with the United States. 
 It was either the triumph of sweet reason over emotion, as graybeards in both parties said, or a cave-in to multinational corporations and their hired influence-peddlers, as both left-wing Democrats and right-wing Republicans asserted.
By common agreement, it was the narrowest escape yet for advocates of unfettered trade with China, including the Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill.
By a deceptively large margin of 321 to 107, the House voted to kill a resolution that would have revoked China's status as a "most favored nation" in trade with the United States. Federal law demands that Congress review China's standing every year, and the Chinese have clung to their designation every year since the two nations opened economic ties in the 1970's.
But the House renewed the most-favored privilege only after it ordered the White House, by an even more lopsided 416-to-10 vote, to establish a Radio Free Asia and to report on its handling of major American grievances against the Chinese. That measure was a compromise between the advocates and opponents of China's preferred trading status.
Leaders on both sides said they had served notice that both parties were not merely unhappy with the Administration's reluctance to punish China for unacceptable acts, but outright distressed by the fact that China runs a vast trade surplus with the United States even as it ignores American protests over its behavior.
"Part of what we're doing is sending a message to China, and part is about the Administration," said Representative Nancy Pelosi, a California Democrat who favors revoking China's trade status, but agreed to the compromise legislation instead.
In truth, "most favored nation" status is not all that preferential; most nations enjoy the privilege. But not having it is a distinct disadvantage to an exporting nation: the tariff on sweaters and shoes shipped to the United States would leap from 6 percent to 60 percent, for example, and the levy on Christmas tree lights from 8 percent to 50 percent.
Officially, the White House took no position on the compromise bill. But its drafters said the Administration lobbied behind the scenes on its behalf, seeking to avert an uncomfortably close vote on revoking China's preferred trading status.
The White House was trying to find a way for Congress to vent its frustrations without forcing a change in Mr. Clinton's decision last year to separate human rights issues from trade relations.
After the vote this afternoon, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative and one of the officials who pressed Mr. Clinton to extend most-favored-nation status last year, said that balance had been achieved. "This signals the impatience of Congress and the Administration for China to begin to act responsibly globally and at home," he said today. But he said, "It also indicates we are ready to engage in political and economic terms."
Mr. Kantor contended that China would receive "a clear message" from the Congressional vote. Clearly, however, China may get another message: No matter how much it provokes Washington on the human rights front, Mr. Clinton has gone so far in keeping commerce and politics separate that Beijing need not fear a return to the old policy.
China would suffer from tariff increases if it lost its most-favored-nation status. Its trade surplus with the United States has ballooned from about $7 billion five years ago to an estimated $40 billion this year, second only to Japan.
Because of just that, politicians of all stripe find most-favored-nation status a tempting target whenever Chinese behavior falls below American -- or international -- standards.
Congress's majority of free-trade advocates and foreign-affairs moderates has always prevailed in the fight over China's trade standing, aided by a lobbying effort by aircraft makers, petrochemical companies and other firms with nascent business in China.
Last fall's Republican ascendancy brought a flock of economic populists into Representative Peter DeFazio's opposing camp. Mr. DeFazio, an Oregon Democrat, has campaigned vigorously against China's favored status. And although Republican leaders insist they would have won an up-or-down vote on the issue, they elected instead to strike a deal with the anti-China forces.
The legislation passed today censures China for a range of military, trade and human-rights offenses and orders the Clinton Administration to report every six months on how it has addressed them. It also would give the Administration three months to begin broadcasting pro-democracy programs into China. Representative Marcy Kaptur of Ohio, a Democrat against most-favored-nation status, said she and many other opponents come from districts where "people are victims of declining wages and economic power in this country."
Noting that millionaires comprise more than a third of the Senate and about a fifth of the House, she added: "The people who are paying the price for this aren't represented here."

HEADLINE: Third World Migrants Risk Hell for a Dream

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: GYOR, Hungary, July 18

 BODY:
With dreams of a safe and prosperous life in a faraway country, Williappan Ratnarajah sold his family home in war-racked Sri Lanka and paid a casual acquaintance $10,000 to smuggle himself and his younger brother to Germany.
The months-long journey from Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital, to Moscow through Kiev and Bucharest ended in horror last week when his brother, Salam, 24, was one of 18 Sri Lankans who suffocated to death in the back of an airless, padlocked container abandoned on the hot plains of Hungary. 
 Mr. Ratnarajah, 28, survived with 18 others in a second container, attached to the same truck. They had managed to punch a tiny hole in the metal roof during what was to have been their journey to the promised land.
The tragedy was the latest illustration of the sudden surge of trafficking of illegal immigrants into Western Europe, and then often on to the United States, from Asia, Africa and the Middle East through the now porous borders of the former Communist bloc.
Experts calculate that people-smuggling, a business increasingly run by international crime syndicates, reaped up to $1 billion last year.
For the Sri Lankans who survived, the last leg of their trip turned out to be nearly 48 hours of hell.
"When we started they gave us a small container of water and some bread," said Mr. Ratnarajah, tears creeping down his cheeks, as he recalled their last starting point in a forest on the edge of Bucharest, Romania. "We thought the truck would stop for water but it didn't and the water ran out after a short time."
The truck driver ignored their desperate but gradually weakening bangings for help on the walls of his container adjacent to the driver's cabin, he said. "We stopped twice," he recalled. "I'm not sure if it was a border but the driver just came out and said: 'Don't shout, don't shout. Police.' "
Perhaps the driver realized that his charges were dying; perhaps he decided he couldn't make it through the border to Austria. But, according to the Hungarian police, he pulled up here at 3 A.M. last Friday about 20 miles shy of the Austrian border.
He unlocked the first container with Mr. Ratnarajah and 18 others, all of them nearly unconscious, and told them they were in Germany. The next day, the police said they found the truck with blood oozing out of the second container.
Inside were 18 bodies, including that of one woman. Hungarian medical examiners said the dead were all healthy people aged between 18 and 30 and they had died of asphyxiation in soaring summer temperatures over a period of 24 hours.
The Sri Lankans, which included a fairly well-to-do shipping clerk from Colombo and an unemployed young man, took what law enforcement officials describe as a typical route. Many of them flew from Colombo to Moscow on 10-day student visas. They were then kept in safe houses and were closely guarded as they were moved by "agents" from country to country in the former Soviet Union and in Eastern Europe.
They also paid fairly typical prices: whatever the agents decided they could afford.
Mr. Ratnarajah, who worked as a driver in Sri Lanka, said he met a countryman he called Rajah at a roadside restaurant near his hometown, Matale, in February. "He had a lot of passports and tickets in his hands," he recalled. "I asked what he was doing and he said he was sending people to Germany and if I wished he could send me too. He demanded $10,000."
Threatened with being drawn into the civil war in Sri Lanka, Mr. Ratnarajah said his mother was anxious for him and his brother to leave. Three days later, he handed over the cash. "He said within 10 days he would send us to Germany."
With 18 other Sri Lankans the two brothers flew to Moscow, where they stayed in a house for about a month, he said. They were then escorted by train to Kiev for another month or so and then on to Moldova, and then to Bucharest. They were accompanied in their travels by a Sri Lankan called Kumar who made sure they never ventured outside for long or by themselves.
"My brother and I wanted to go back to Sri Lanka, but we didn't have a proper visa for where we were so we were afraid to go to the police or to go back," Mr. Ratnarajah said. He was looking forward, he said, to the refugee camp in Germany where "Rajah" had told him he would be given 10,000 German marks and after that a job.
Another survivor, Sasthi Kumar, a 26-year-old shipping clerk, said he sold part of his wife's dowry for $3,000 and paid Rajah. On the pledge that his wife would be able to join him, he flew to Moscow with another Sri Lankan and traveled through the same capitals.
"We met each other on the bus going from Bucharest to the forest where we got on the truck," Mr. Kumar said.
Maheswaran Devendran, 24, worked in a restaurant in Moscow for two years, before he met up with the Sri Lankan agents. He paid $800, the cheapest rate, from his savings in Russia. In Romania, he said, he was stripped of his gold chain and watch by one of the agents. "I was told: 'Not good to wear, give me,' " he said of his jewelry. "I was alone, so I'm frightened. So I give it."'
Two of the Sri Lankans who were taken by bus from the Bucharest safe houses to the forest to board the ill-fated truck refused to get on, Mr. Ratnarajah said.
And according to him, two of the agents, Rajah and Kumar, were on their way to Germany and were among the 18 who suffocated with his brother.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Compaq Earnings Rise 17%; Apple Net Income Down 25%

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The Compaq Computer Corporation yesterday reported second-quarter earnings that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates and helped restore some measure of calm to the market for technology stocks.
But Apple Computer Inc.'s earnings for its fiscal third quarter -- reported after the stock market had closed -- fell far short of estimates, and its shares fell in after-hours trading. 
 Analysts had expected Apple to earn 90 to 95 cents a share; not counting one-time gains, it earned 80 cents. Apple stock had closed up $1.5625, at $47.0625, in Nasdaq trading. But the stock fell sharply after hours, to $43.
Compaq had been expected to earn 85 cents; it earned 90 cents. Its stock rose $3.50, to $48.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Compaq had a very good quarter, with revenues and earnings both above estimate, and inventories down sequentially," said Todd Bakar, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. Apple "is not shipping as many units as many of us thought they would," he said, noting production difficulties on some models and a shortage of Power PC chips. "They say they have the demand; they go into this quarter with a big backlog and hopefully they can take advantage of that," he said.
In contrast to the cautionary words from the Microsoft Corporation, which prompted the two-day selloff of technology shares, Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's president and chief executive, sounded a note of optimism in his outlook for the second half of the year.
"So far this year, we've seen solid, and really better-than-expected, market growth worldwide," Mr. Pfeiffer said in a telephone interview. "All indications are this is likely to continue," he said, citing the continued strength of the United States economy, stability in the European market and phenomenal growth in personal computer sales in Japan.
Compaq, based in Houston, will broaden its range of computers using the Intel Corporation's Pentium microprocessor, including the addition of a portable machine, and will improve the multimedia capabilities of its Presario consumer line, Mr. Pfeiffer said. He said the company would have machines in stores loaded with Microsoft's Windows 95 when the new operating system is shipped on Aug. 24.
For the second quarter, Compaq earned $246 million, or 90 cents a share, up 17 percent from $210 million, or 78 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 40 percent, to $3.5 billion from $2.5 billion.
Apple said that shipments of the company's Power Macintosh products more than doubled from the comparable quarter a year earlier and that the number of shipped Power Macintosh computers and upgrade units totaled more than two million units since its introduction in March 1994. But supply constraints that have hampered Apple in recent quarters continued, dragging down earnings.
For its fiscal third quarter ended June 30, Apple earned $103 million, or 84 cents a share, compared with $138 million, or $1.16 a share a year earlier.
But the 1994 quarter included a $127 million credit as a result of lower-than-expected costs from restructuring. And the most recent quarter included a $6.1 million credit after an additional adjustment of expenses. Without those adjustments, Apple earned $99.2 million, or 80 cents a share, up from $59.5 million, or 50 cents a share.
Revenues rose 20 percent, to $ 2.58 billion from $2.15 billion.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.M. Rise Bucks Quarter's Auto Earnings Trend

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 20

 BODY:
If they ever played Broadway instead of Wall Street, the Big Three auto companies might consider calling their act The Perils of Pollyanna.
With their widely varying second quarter earnings reports this week, they demonstrated the danger in their business of excessive optimism.
The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, which had breathlessly predicted robust sales this spring, built too many cars and trucks and watched their earnings slide in the second quarter as they ladled out rebates and other incentives to entice indifferent buyers. 
 Today, the General Motors Corporation, widely teased in the industry last year for its relatively gloomy outlook, reported an 18 percent gain in earnings -- exceeding analysts' expectations. G.M.'s conservative production schedule paid off. Its average incentive per vehicle actually fell in the three months ending June 30.
Now, perhaps chastened, all three companies are predicting a mild but sustained recovery in sales, and in the economy in general, over the next two quarters and beyond, thanks partly to the Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates earlier this month.
"I think the soft landing scenario is playing out," J. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, said. "Ninety-five reminds us a lot of 1984."
In 1984, he said, demand trailed off after a run-up in interest rates; after rates subsided, buyers returned and provided the industry with several strong years.
In fact, G.M. now has the highest estimate for total sales this year: 15.3 million cars and trucks, just down from last year's 15.4 million.
Although they are all optimistic -- cautiously so, thank you -- about next year, no one is predicting sales in 1996 except Chrysler, which is calling for 15.5 million. Just six months ago, it was predicting 16.8 million sales in 1996.
To some extent, G.M., with its sober prognostication, made a virtue of necessity last year. Its plants were already straining to keep up with demand, so it had good reason to hope for modest growth at best.
But, perhaps because G.M. did not count on strong growth to bail it out, it has continued to focus on cutting costs in its factories and in its purchases of parts and materials, judging from its earnings report today.
Despite a falloff in sales, profit margins in G.M.'s core North American automotive operations continued to widen -- in stark contrast to the deteriorating margins reported by Ford on Wednesday and highlighted in critical reports by auto stock analysts today.
Investors seized on the distinction between the companies, bidding G.M. stock up $1 on the New York Stock Exchange. In active trading, Ford shares slipped $1.125 a share to close at $29.
Mr. Losh attributed G.M.'s improved margins to two factors: reduction in material costs, because of G.M.'s efforts to consolidate its purchasing to exploit economies of scale; and improved manufacturing productivity, which among other savings resulted in lower overtime costs.
"A plant last year might have been struggling to get out their daily product in eight hours, and maybe they worked an extra half hour of overtime," Mr. Losh said. Now, he said, such plants are hitting their targets without overtime.
Strange as it may sound, from an investor's perspective G.M. may look more attractive because it is less efficient than Ford or Chrysler. Already far leaner than G.M., Ford and Chrysler cannot wring savings as easily from their operations.
Because G.M. is making more money on declining sales, many analysts believe it may be best positioned among the Big Three for earnings growth, although it is far from done with its turnaround.
"Volume down, profits up -- it's another piece of information that the company's effort to rebuild its automotive operations is working," said Phil Fricke, auto industry analyst at Prudential Securities in New York. "For the second quarter in a row, G.M. has looked a lot better than Ford."
In a critique today, Nicholas Lobocarro of S. G. Warburg & Company predicted that Ford's margins would continue to suffer. Ford, he said, is replacing its cars and trucks with new models that are more expensive to make because they have higher "content." That is, they have upscale features like clever air-filtering systems and fancy touches like an unusual console in the new Taurus sedan. Ford is hoping such vehicles will fetch higher prices, as high quality Japanese cars do.
But, Mr. Lococarro wrote, "We are skeptical that all of the higher content costs will be paid for by the consumer (especially on the car side of the market), since the current consumer appears to be very price conscious."
G.M., he noted, is pursuing the opposite strategy, offering the "best value" by building low-cost vehicles. "While it is premature to decide which strategy will translate into greater long-term profitability," he wrote, "investors will likely focus initially on the strategy guaranteed to cause greater short-term costs -- Ford's."
But G.M. may be running into difficulties of its own. It finished the quarter with more cars and trucks sitting unsold on dealers' lots than either of its competitors, which could portend higher rebates and other incentive costs in the third quarter.
"We're reasonably comfortable with the inventory level," Mr. Losh said. "But we'll have to see what happens in the market."
Meanwhile, by biting the bullet and offering heavy incentives, Chrysler has cut its dealers' inventories to levels far below those of its competitors. With its new model mini-van now widely available, it may be poised to rebound in coming quarters.
For the quarter, G.M.'s earnings climbed to $2.3 billion or $2.39 per share, compared with $1.9 billion last year, or $2.23. Wall Street had been expecting about $2.25 a share in the latest quarter. G.M.'s revenues rose 9.3 percent, to $44.1 billion.
On Wednesday, Ford reported its profits slipped 8.2 percent, to $1.57 billion. On Tuesday, Chrysler reported its earnings fell 85.9 percent in the quarter, to $135 million. As a group, the auto companies made $3.9 billion in the quarter, down 13.3 percent from last year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Show Little Change

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, after a sharp decline on Wednesday.
The recent consolidation in the bond market has been fueled by concern that the economy has not slowed enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates for a second time this summer. On July 6, the Fed cut its target for overnight bank loan rates by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent. After that move, many traders had expected to Fed to push rates lower when its policy-making committee meets next in August. 
 Now some market participants fear that this year's powerful rally may have run out of steam.
Traders and investors "want to be told the Fed is going to cut in August," said Mark Taborsky, who manages $280 million in bonds at Abacus Financial Group in Chicago. "Unless they're told that, yields might go" as high as 7.1 percent next month, he said.
Bruce Hillyer, a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in Chicago, said: "You've had a watershed shift in psychology. The bull market's over for quite some time, and nobody wants to be the last one out the door."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond edged up 1/32 yesterday, to 10920/32 , leaving its yield unchanged at 6.86 percent. The price of the two-year note was also unchanged for a yield of 5.88 percent.
The Treasury, meanwhile, auctioned $18.29 billion in 52-week Treasury bills yesterday. The average discount rate was 5.38 percent, up from 5.22 percent at the last auction on June 22. It was the highest rate since bills averaged 5.54 percent on May 25.
Bonds recovered from early declines yesterday after investors sought to buy securities at some of the highest yields in months.
"With the long bond pushing towards 7 percent and inflation easing towards 3 percent, bonds are starting to look attractive," said David Capurro at Franklin Resources in San Mateo, Calif. Mr. Capurro, who manages $520 million of bonds, said he bought 10- and 15-year Treasury notes yesterday.
Despite the recent rise in yields, corporate treasurers are still selling debt because borrowing costs remain lower than they were earlier this year.
"For the next couple of weeks, it'll still be an active calendar," said Mike Allen, an investment banker who helps arrange corporate bond sales at CS First Boston.
The Banc One Corporation and United Companies Financial sold $700 million of bonds yesterday.
Banc One, the banking company based in Columbus, Ohio, sold $600 million of bonds, 20 percent more than planned, in two parts: $300 million of 10-year notes priced to yield 7.09 percent, or 69 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note, and another $300 million of 30-year bonds at a yield of 7.838 percent, or 97.8 basis points more than the 30-year Treasury bond. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
United Companies Financial, an insurer and mortgage lender based in Baton Rouge, La., raised $100 million by selling three-year notes. The notes were priced to yield 7 percent, or 103 basis points more than the three-year Treasury note.
In other trading, Michigan sold $180 million of bonds yesterday.
Merrill Lynch & Company won the bidding on the bonds due 1996 through 2015 at yields lower than those on comparable existing securities. The Michigan bonds due in 10 years were priced to yield 5 percent, or 5.13 percent, according to Bloomberg Fair Value analytics.
The sale came just two days after Moody's Investors Service Inc. raised the credit ratings on $6.15 billion of Michigan's publicly traded debt to AA from A1.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Don't Kill the C.E.A.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Council of Economic Advisers helped persuade President Kennedy to cut taxes and thus spur a recovery -- a decisive case of applying the theories of John Maynard Keynes to public policy.
The council warned President Johnson that he would ignite inflation if he persisted in paying for the Vietnam War by borrowing rather than taxing -- advice he ignored with disastrous consequences. 
 The council steered President Nixon away from lavishly expensive subsidies for supersonic air travel and President Bush away from underwriting the development of advanced television technology that would soon have been obsolete.
The council advised President Clinton to downsize his monster health-care plan. He rejected that counsel, and watched as health-care reform went down the drain.
By anyone's standards, the C.E.A. has dispensed more good advice than bad over the years. Yet despite its solid record and modest size, it has now been abolished by the House, which intends to apply the council's puny $3.5 million budget to deficit reduction. That is a poor decision, and the Senate should reverse it.
The council consists of three economists and an eager staff, most of whom are on temporary loan from universities. It provides Presidents with professional analysis of public policies that is not available anywhere else in government. True, there are dozens of economists scattered throughout the Federal Government. But they are for the most part advocates, representing their cabinet secretaries or vested interests. The council has one client, the President, and one constituency, the consumer. It is the only disinterested voice the President hears.
The council has attracted distinguished members. James Tobin, a Nobel laureate, served on the Kennedy council, whose staff included two more Nobelists, Robert Solow and Kenneth Arrow. Joseph Stiglitz, on many short lists for a future Nobel, serves now. Professional integrity has driven members to oppose their boss when necessary. Martin Feldstein publicly attacked oversize deficits, though he served President Reagan.
The council has also been farsighted. In the Kennedy era, apart from the general tax cut, it designed a novel tax credit for business investment. Michael Boskin, chairman of President Bush's council, pushed for market-based environmental policies that provided companies with financial incentives to fight pollution. The Bush council also pushed for auctioning the broadcast spectrum so that taxpayers could pocket some profit. But mostly the council naysays, telling Presidents that their latest fad, or Congress's, will backfire.
I do not come to this debate without bias. As a graduate student in the 1970's, I was stirred by Professor Solow's descriptions of the heady 1960's, when economists traveled from Cambridge, Mass., to preach the gospel of Keynes. A decade later, it was obvious that economists possessed few macroeconomic answers. But I remain committed to the proposition that professional analysis can save the country from multiple disasters.
The G.O.P attack on the council is doubly ironic. First, the C.E.A. has usually sided with Republicans who prefer markets to bureaucratic controls. Second, it is the Republicans who are pushing the economist's favorite tool, cost-benefit analysis. Senate Republicans might keep one fact in mind. If the council steers a President away from one rotten decision -- just one -- it will have made up for its measly annual budget in perpetuity.
 MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
COCA-COLA CO. (KO,N)

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that profit rose 18.5 percent in the second quarter, meeting Wall Street expectations, as its international sales grew strongly.
The world's biggest soft-drink maker, based in Atlanta, said net income rose to $898 million, or 71 cents a share, from $758 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 13.7 percent, to $4.94 billion from $4.34 billion. 
 Worldwide volume, measured in terms of cases of Coke, Sprite and other brands, rose 10 percent, with volume outside the United States up 11 percent. Coke sells concentrate to bottling companies, which then sell the cases. The company generates about 80 percent of its earnings outside the United States.
Coke's biggest volume increases included a 45 percent jump in Brazil and a 37 percent gain in China. In Mexico, volume rose 1 percent, depressed by the poor economy.
The biggest setback came in the crucial market of Japan, where case sales fell 3 percent. Among the factors Coke cited for the decline were the slumping Japanese economy and the weather. The decline in Japanese volume was mitigated by the yen's rise against the dollar.
In the United States, volume rose 6 percent.
In discussing the results, Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman and chief executive, said, "Sprite, a 34-year-old brand, is the fastest-growing major carbonated soft drink in America, and Coca-Cola Classic continues to record significant volume gains." (Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Future Is Cloudy for U.S. Festival

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: DENVER, July 20

 BODY:
The summer gathering of the nation's developing athletes in Olympic-related sports, the Olympic Festival, begins a 10-day run on Friday and faces an uncertain future on a crowded sports calendar.
The festival, which features 3,500 athletes from around the country competing in 37 sports, began in 1978 and was designed to be held in the three years between Summer Olympics. But growing costs, such as the need to construct velodromes, have made the festival an expensive proposition for host cities, which cannot sign corporate sponsors that compete with the official sponsors of the United States Olympic team and the Summer Games. 
 The lack of elite athletes, who have discovered an explosion of international competitions in the summer, also has put a strain on ticket sales.
The festival, which remains popular with the governing bodies of sports who seek to develop their athletes for later participation in the Olympics, has been scaled back to twice every four years. The next two will be held in 1997 and 1999 at sites to be determined. Further alterations are certain to be recommended on Saturday during a meeting of the executive committee of the United States Olympic Committee.
Several options are possible, such as reducing the number of sports, inviting international athletes and reducing the festival to once every four years.
"We're trying to balance the economic realities with the popularity of the event with our national governing bodies," said Mike Moran, a spokesman for the U.S.O.C. "Each year, it's costing cities more. Having to build facilities may limit the number of cities that can host this. So we have to re-examine things without stifling the growth of our athletes."
Dallas, Phoenix, Seattle and Richmond have expressed interest in being hosts for the 1997 and 1999 festivals, but the format will be decided before the host city is named, Moran said.
"We'd like to define it and let the cities know what they're dealing with," Moran said.
Organizers of the 1995 festival have spread the events among sites in Denver, Colorado Springs and Boulder. Ticket sales and corporate funding had been lagging in recent weeks as organizers worried that they could not meet their $11.9 million budget. But, at a news conference on Tuesday, organizers said the cable firm of Tele-Communications Inc., based in the Denver suburb of Englewood, had committed $150,000 to the festival.
With a recent boost, the total in ticket sales has reached $1.5 million out of a forecast $2.4 million, said organizers, who hope to earn a small surplus with walkup ticket sales and additional funds from concessions and parking.
The equestrian events have been canceled because of the outbreak of an equine viral disease.
