SECTION: Section D; Page 5; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Koreans Seen Buying More U.S. Concerns

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 20

 BODY:
Just as the Japanese are licking their wounds from ill-fated investments in American companies, the Korean giants are starting to buy in.
The announcement by LG Electronics on Monday that it would purchase a controlling stake in the Zenith Electronics Corporation for $350 million was only the latest of a recent spurt of investments in well-known American consumer-products and high-technology companies by South Korean conglomerates. 
 In February, Samsung Electronics bought a 40 percent stake in AST Research, a personal computer maker, for $378 million. It has also bought or invested in six smaller mainly start-up high-technology companies in The United States in the last two years.
Late last year, the Hyundai Corporation spent more than $300 million to buy a microelectronics division from AT&T. The year before it spent $150 million to buy 40 percent of Maxtor, a Silicon Valley disk-drive maker.
And experts predict the acquisition binge will continue as the giant Korean conglomerates, known as chaebol, seek to gain new technologies and increase their sales outside South Korea.
"It's just a natural extension of their empire-building impulse," said Stephen Marvin, chief of research for Ssangyong Securities in Seoul. "The chaebol now have the means to buy overseas companies, and they see the need to broaden their geographical operations."
To be sure, all the South Korean purchases amount to just a fraction of what the Sony Corporation or Matsushita Electric Industrial spent on their ill-fated acquisitions of Hollywood studios. The Korean acquisitions have not gained the same level of attention, or generated the same backlash, in the United States as the Japanese purchases of film studios or investments in highly visible property like Rockefeller Center.
Still, the Koreans are investing for the same reasons as the Japanese did -- to gain technology or entry into new markets, or even because they are caught up by the glamour of Hollywood.
Cheil Food and Chemicals, South Korea's largest food company and part of the Samsung Group, agreed in April to spend $300 million to acquire an 11 percent stake in Dreamworks SKG, the new entertainment company started by Steven Spielberg, Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen.
The United States is not the Koreans' only target. Samsung raised eyebrows in Japan by buying two Japanese concerns -- the Lux Corporation, a maker of audio equipment, and the Union Optical Company. It is rare for Japanese companies to be acquired.
The Korean companies realize that they must gain a more international perspective in order to compete. The Samsung Group is sending 500 young executives each year to live in foreign countries without having to work, just to learn the local language and culture. The people sent to the United States are allowed to travel by air only once. The rest of the time they must go by car, bus or train to get a closer look at the country.
The Koreans are building as well as buying overseas. Both Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Electronics recently announced plans to build billion-dollar semiconductor factories in the United States, their first chip plants outside South Korea. The Koreans are also putting up factories in China and other low-cost Asian nations.
The electronics companies can afford their purchases because they are part of huge conglomerates with interests in everything from shipbuilding and construction to automobiles and financial services. The conglomerates benefit from the strong Japanese yen, which makes competing Korean automobiles and television sets relatively cheaper on world markets. The resulting export boom has contributed to South Korea's strong economic growth -- about 8 percent annually.
But the electronics companies themselves have come into the money because of their huge success in the computer memory-chip business. Samsung Electronics has become the world's largest supplier of dynamic random access memory chips, the relatively low-cost semiconductors that perform short-term memory functions in computers. Hyundai Electronics and LG Semiconductor, which is 60 percent owned by LG Electronics, have also become major producers.
The three companies had combined chip revenue of $8 billion last year, up from $3 billion two years earlier, according to Dataquest, a market research firm. Analysts say profit margins are as high as 30 percent because a chip shortage has kept prices high.
Despite their success in memory chips, and in consumer-electronics products, the South Korean companies are not that technically advanced.
Many of the components and production equipment they use to make chips, videocassette recorders and other products come from Japan, so that the nation's trade deficit, mainly with Japan, balloons when the economy booms. And South Korea has not developed much technology in areas like computers or multimedia products.
"As far as existing consumer electronics are concerned, we are competitive enough," said Lee Hun Jo, chairman and chief executive of LG Electronics, formerly known as Goldstar. "But for multimedia products, we need more technology." LG hopes to get technology for high-definition television and multimedia from Zenith.
Acquisitions allow for technology to be obtained more quickly than if Korean companies tried to develop it themselves. "In a more high-tech area like multimedia, we think indigenous technology development is not the best way," said Paik Man Gi, director of the industrial technology planning division at South Korea's trade ministry.
Even in semiconductors, the Korean companies need to expand beyond memory chips. That explains Hyundai's purchase of what was the NCR microelectronics-products division of AT&T.
Korean companies, which have long been focused on their home market, also lack the brand names and marketing skills of the Japanese. Samsung could not succeed in the world personal computer market because of those deficiencies. But buying a stake in AST will help give it the distribution it needs.
The chaebol are also under pressure from the Government, which is trying to limit the influence over the economy of these huge family-owned companies by making them divest themselves of some operations.
So far, though, the campaign to curb the chaebol has not borne much fruit. Still, the chaebol themselves see the need to become more competitive overseas, in part because their protected home market is being slowly opened. They are modernizing, giving more latitude to professional managers instead of founding-family members.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Are Highest in 3 Years

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims jumped last week to the highest level in nearly three years, the Government said today, pointing to residual weakness in the job market.
Initial claims for state unemployment pay in the week that ended last Saturday rose by 18,000, to 417,000, the highest since 418,000 in the week ended Sept. 19, 1992, the Labor Department said. 
 It was the first time claims have pushed through the 400,000 level since January 1994, and the increase exceeded private economists' forecasts for claims of 368,000 in the latest week.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Tevye and Other Comforts in a Crumbling World

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

A BRIDGE OF LONGING
The Lost Art of Yiddish Storytelling
By David G. Roskies
419 pages. Harvard University Press. $37.50.
In the 1880's, Sholom Aleichem, the beloved storyteller of the doomed kingdom of Eastern European Yiddish life, edited and published "The Jewish People's Library," a handsome literary almanac that included stories by the best Yiddish writers of the time. In David G. Roskies's view, the almanac was a landmark in Jewish culture, but not for the reason it might seem most natural to assume. 
 To most of us, probably, the stories of Aleichem, I. L. Peretz, Isaac Meir Dik and, more recently, Isaac Bashevis Singer, sing of the very essence of the Eastern European Jewish tradition. They incarnate, it would seem, authenticity itself, an eccentric, spiritually rich and materially threadbare way of life that has since, of course, disappeared. But Mr. Roskies, who teaches literature at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, lays out a more complex and interesting theory in "A Bridge of Longing," an ambitious, learned, sometimes difficult study of two centuries of Yiddish literature.
In his view, the mere fact that the world described by the Yiddish writers is widely taken to be authentic is proof of how successful those writers were in what he calls "creative betrayal," an effort by a group of "modern Jewish revolutionaries, rebels and immigrants" to "salvage for a nontraditional audience forms of the culture assumed to be traditional."
"The Jewish People's Library," for example, was a landmark not so much of an authentic tradition as of an invented one. The rabbis, those avatars of high culture, stuck to Torah and Talmud and saw stories about the folk as devices for simple people and women. But the rabbinical tradition, challenged by migration and the 19th-century movement known as Haskala, or enlightenment, was in crisis. And so the Yiddish writers mixed old and new in a new cultural creation aimed at a revival of faith and identity.
The paradox is that the invented culture was so convincing that for succeeding generations it passed for the real thing. "Wherever there are people who look to Yiddish as an authentic expression of yidishkayt," or East European Jewish culture, "it is to these artifacts that they first turn," Mr. Roskies writes.
He lays out his theoretical position at the beginning of an extended exploration of the lives and work of major Yiddish writers of Poland, Russia and the United States who fixed in the minds of later generations the image of the shtetl, the rural Jewish ghetto, as an abode of tragicomic quaintness, homespun philosophy and redemptive religious faith. He begins with Rabbi Nahman of Bratslav, the Hasidic preacher who turned to storytelling "when all else failed."
"It was to rouse those remaining followers from their spiritual slumber, to reconsecrate them to the arduous task of redemption in a world alive with evil and tragedy, that Nahman began telling stories," Mr. Roskies writes. "By bridging Hebrew and Yiddish, the scholars and the folk, mythic past and historic present, Reb Nahman invented a new form of Jewish self-expression."
"A Bridge of Longing" ends with portraits of writers from the scattered world of Yiddish literature -- in America, Australia and Israel -- after World War II and the Holocaust. In between are intellectually luxuriant essays on what might be called the canonical Yiddish writers, from Peretz to Singer.
There are winding, thickly forested passages in Mr. Roskies's book in which the ordinary reader might lose track of the theme. Here and there are bits of gluey jargon from the world of academic literary criticism: phrases about the mediation of binary oppositions, symbolic landscapes, multidetermined mythic figures and mimetic realism. One wishes that Mr. Roskies were, in the spirit of his subject, more plainspoken. Still, he has produced an often brilliant scholarly volume that will help rescue the "lost art of Yiddish storytelling" by explaining what it really was.
The tradition was, as Mr. Roskies explains, often saved by those who already appeared furthest from it. Mr. Peretz, for example, was a struggling urban lawyer, arrested in 1899 for supporting a workers' strike, who turned to Yiddish folklore rather than the orthodox rabbinic teachings to forge a new secular Jewish identity. He turned the dying shtetl of the end of the 19th century into "an ideal setting for fantasy and heroism," and in so doing, Mr. Roskies writes, transformed himself into "the master architect of Jewish modernism."
If it was remarkable that a secular lawyer could reinvent the shtetl, then, as Mr. Roskies puts it, it was "nothing short of miraculous" that Aleichem, the best loved of the Yiddish folklorists, was a stockbroker from the mostly non-Jewish city of Kiev. Sholom Aleichem was the pen name of Solomon Rabinovitch, a well-heeled, cosmopolitan disciple of Gogol, whose most celebrated character, Tevye the Milkman (world-famous as the truculent but affectionate father in the Broadway musical "Fiddler on the Roof"), embodied the Yiddish cultural revolution.
"The mature artist found in Tevye, in the Bible-quoting dairyman, a way to explore life's ironies," Mr. Roskies writes. "And the main irony is this: In a closed and crumbling world with scant intellectual resources, offering the most paltry economic and social rewards, a philosophical giant can exist, and persist."
Tevye, in this sense, becomes a kind of Jewish everyman, but also the perfect emblem of Mr. Roskies's theme of the invented tradition that came to seem more authentic than the tradition it subverted. With his rough-hewn eloquence and relentless, common-sense logic, Tevye represents fortitude and faith in the face of a world of "undeserved catastrophe." Mr. Roskies calls him "the figure of a comic Job." As such, he writes, Tevye "embodies the 'folk' without access to power, politics or the press, but with the ability to protest its innocence and to demand redress."

HEADLINE: Tax Fraud: Two Baseball Legends Say It's So

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Duke Snider and Willie McCovey, two baseball Hall of Famers whose images of power and dignity still sparkle for generations of the game's loyalists, pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal tax fraud charges, saying they had knowingly failed to report thousands of dollars earned by signing autographs and participating in sports memorabilia shows.
The two slugging legends, who had spent their physical primes playing under the bright lights of stadiums across the country, yesterday stood under the ordinary glare of the fluorescent ceiling lights in Federal Court in Brooklyn, where they raised their right hands, swore oaths to tell the truth, and pronounced themselves criminals. And so for the first time, the stars from the game's gilded age were enveloped in a crime that up to now has involved players only from its more troubled present. 
 The 69-year-old Mr. Snider, a couple of Brooklyn neighborhoods removed from the site of Ebbets Field and his glory days with the Dodgers as the Duke of Flatbush, when he hit 407 home runs in 16 seasons, admitted that he had conspired with the promoters of a 1989 sports memorabilia show in Atlantic City not to report a $10,000 payment for his appearance.
The former center fielder, wearing a gold DUKE wristband and a Hall of Fame ring on his right hand, also said he had failed to report more than $100,000 in income from memorabilia shows and promotional appearances from 1984 to 1993. Mr. Snider, who signed a cooperation agreement with prosecutors, is to avoid any jail time.
Mr. McCovey, who is 57 years old and walks with the aid of a cane, pleaded guilty to having failed to list nearly $70,000 in income from 1988 to 1990. Mr. McCovey did not sign a cooperation agreement. The former San Francisco Giants first baseman, who hit 521 home runs in his 22 seasons of major league baseball, was paid $33,000 in cash at the same 1989 Atlantic City show attended by Mr. Snider, and that was part of the income for which he failed to pay taxes. He faces one to seven months in jail.
"We have choices to make in our lives," a contrite Mr. Snider said in a brief exchange with reporters outside the courthouse. "I made the wrong choice. I was knowledgeable. I was aware of the crime I was involved in. And I made the wrong choice. I hope the effects of it won't hurt baseball that badly."
The guilty pleas yesterday were two of the stranger shocks to hit baseball lately. Plagued by poor attendance, ill will resulting from last year's strike, and disaffection over the actions of surly millionaire owners and players, the sport now has to confront the fact that even its most benevolently remembered heroes of the past are capable of money-driven criminality.
"We are very saddened by this," said Bud Selig, the acting commissioner of baseball. "It's a bad day for the game."
The admissions of guilt, however, are unlikely to affect the Hall of Fame status of the two. Jeff Idelson, a spokesman for the Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., said: "There's nothing in the bylaws or the rules" about ejecting people from the hall for criminal convictions.
Prosecutors and Internal Revenue Service agents yesterday all but promised there would be more people entangled by the investigation. Charles T. Franssen, chief of the I.R.S.'s criminal investigation division, said, "Investigations of the sports memorabilia industry are nationwide in scope, and can be expected to include promoters and ballplayers and others."
The sports memorabilia industry has mushroomed in the last 15 years, and experts estimate that mass-autographed merchandise now is a $500 million business. Much of that business, which includes athletes selling their names on home-shopping channels and through mail-order catalogues, is still done at trade shows, where athletes often sign cards, bats, balls and photographs for fixed prices. Many athletes, both current and former stars, have long chosen to be paid in cash at many such shows.
"The problem of this underground economy is serious," Mr. Franssen said.
The 1989 card show in Atlantic City apparently was a colossal success for players, promoters and fans, and, it now appears, for prosecutors, too. The show -- produced by Michael Bertolini, a Staten Island man who was a partner with Pete Rose in Hit King Marketing, and William Hungach, a Brooklynite -- brought together the 11 living players to hit at least 500 career home runs, and also included Pete Rose, Tony Perez and Mr. Snider.
"It seemed like the dawn of a new era in the memorabilia business," said Greg Goldstein, an executive with a card company and a former collector who attended the show.
Yesterday, prosecutors declined to say whether more of the players involved in the show would be indicted, but did not rule out the possibility. Robert Fink, an attorney for Mickey Mantle, said yesterday that while Mr. Mantle had been investigated as part of the inquiry into the Atlantic City show, he was convinced no charges would be brought against Mr. Mantle.
Both Mr. Bertolini and Mr. Hungach have previously pleaded guilty to charges involving their roles in the show, and law-enforcement officials said Mr. Hungach and Mr. Snider were cooperating in the continuing investigation.
"If prosecutors pick any of these shows and go after it, they are going to turn up much of the same kind of stuff," said John L. Pollok, Mr. McCovey's lawyer. As for Mr. McCovey, who walked out of court yesterday without speaking, Mr. Pollok said, "He's humiliated."
Both Mr. Snider, one of the more cherished New York players of his era, and Mr. McCovey, who served as a community relations official with the Giants after his playing days, appeared deeply embarrassed inside the Brooklyn courtroom. Both wore eyeglasses and read their plea agreements without questions. The two men, who both were inducted into the Hall of Fame in the 1980's, spoke only once, and they exchanged difficult smiles.
Outside, Mr. Snider, who once said he never made more than $46,000 a year as a ballplayer, chuckled slightly when he was asked if he really believed a Brooklyn jury would have convicted him of anything. He said there were "a lot of reasons" why he had taken the money and not reported it over the years. He said he had heart bypass surgery in 1987 and had been concerned about the financial welfare of his wife.

HEADLINE: Companies Reach Deal for Renewal In Heart of 42d St.

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
After 15 years of false starts and dashed hopes, a marathon effort to revitalize 42d Street turned an important corner yesterday as a group of entertainment companies and developers announced plans to open glittering attractions along the shadowy strip that was once the heart of American theater.
Nearly 100 years after enterprising theatrical producers like Oscar Hammerstein and Florenz Ziegfeld began developing glorious and ornate theaters just west of Times Square, the Walt Disney Company said it was firmly committed to anchor the next millennium of entertainment on the street. 
 In addition to Disney's plan to bring its trademark family-style amusement to Manhattan, Madame Tussaud's, the London wax museum, and American Multi-Cinemas, a nationwide chain of movie theaters, also announced that they had reached agreements to develop attractions on the block. Along with other recent -- though still tentative -- deals for the renovation of two other theaters and construction of a hotel, the new announcement means that most of 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues is committed for redevelopment.
If Disney's commitment provides the linchpin for the urban renewal project's success, then the musical fantasy "Beauty and the Beast" could go down in history as the savior of 42d Street. While generous government subsidies helped lure Disney executives, their interest in the New Amsterdam was sealed by the musical's long-running success at the Palace Theater on Broadway. The company now says it is set to begin work within a month on its $34 million restoration of the New Amsterdam Theater.
"The future of 42d Street has arrived," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Project, a unit of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. That agency and the New York City Economic Development Corporation have been working jointly since 1980 to rehabilitate the block. "This wonderful, complicated and sometimes tortured block has seen so many twists and turns over the last century," she said. "With this array of entertainment uses, the next 100 years are off to a great start."
But many questions still hover over the street that in recent decades came to be known as "the Deuce," a slick nickname that evoked images of the hustles, scams and lurking danger for which 42d Street gained infamy. While there are firm agreements on some projects -- the restoration of the New Victory Theater is nearing completion -- there are still several vacant properties and major issues involving others that must be resolved.
A plan announced earlier this week to restore the Lyric and Academy theaters left many developers wondering how Livent, the Toronto-based theatrical production company that plans to combine the two adjacent buildings into one large musical theater, can make the expensive project profitable. A plan by the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty to build four office towers in the area has been put on hold until the market for office space rebounds. The financing must still be arranged for a $303 million hotel and entertainment complex proposed by Tishman Urban Development Corporation for the northwest end of that section of the street.
"The question is, will the economics of the marketplace allow those projects to proceed?" said Abby Hamlin, an executive vice president of Weiler Arnow, co-owner of property on the southwest side of the street. "A lot of exciting momentum has been created and this is an important moment," she said. "Now there's a lot of hard work to do."
Disney, whose initial interest in the project spawned a groundswell of inquiries from other entertainers, is already planning to open with a new musical inside the New Amsterdam by spring 1997. Unlike the other companies considering projects on the street, Disney was enticed with big government subsidies, largely in the form of city-financed low-interest loans that will cover about 75 percent of the company's cost.
"Disney was the bell cow," said John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development. "They were the first ones that got everyone else into the fence."
Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chairman and chief executive officer, was unable to attend yesterday's rapidly organized announcement, but was reached by telephone aboard his corporate jet. "This is really going to happen," he marveled. "Even I'm surprised."
Even as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki joined a stage full of corporate executives and public officials in front of the 92-year-old New Amsterdam Theater to announce the agreements, a scantily clad peep show model sat in a second-floor window down the block, eating her lunch -- unfazed by the people who spilled into the street and slowed traffic to get a look at the dignitaries on stage.
The event almost didn't happen. At 2:30 A.M. yesterday, negotiations between Disney and public officials had reached an impasse and broke off without an agreement. Later in the morning, talks resumed, and while the two sides continued to parry and thrust over the final details of their pact, hasty planning for the announcement forged ahead. Earl C. Voelker, American Multi-Cinema's senior vice president for business development, flew in from Buenos Aires, where he was exploring new business opportunities, and Andrew Tansley, executive director of the Tussaud's Group, arrived from London.
Media kits suggested the changing cast of characters who have worked on the 42d Street project over the years. On the folder, a strip of black tape was stuck over the name of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. And since just about everyone involved in the project wanted his or her role noted, the kits contained 25 pages of nothing but press releases from all the various companies and public constituencies.
Despite the last-minute hitches, the deal with Disney was all but sealed last week, when word leaked out that city and state officials had secured letters of intent from American Multi-Cinemas and Tussaud's. Before it would agree to go forward with the New Amsterdam restoration, Disney had wanted the city to entice two more entertainment companies to the block.
This spring, after Tussaud's parent company, Pearson, lost a bitter battle to purchase the white marble One Times Square building, city officials seized the opportunity to make the London entertainer a part of its 42d Street development. Clay B. Lifflander, president of the city's economic development corporation, telephoned crestfallen Tussaud's officials and urged them to come back and consider looking at the 42d Street site, which includes the old Empire, Harris, and Liberty Theaters.
Under the deal's terms, American Multi-Cinemas, based in Kansas City, Mo., and Tussaud's, a top London attraction with 2.6 million visitors a year, will occupy space in a 335-square-foot retail and entertainment complex that will be developed by Forest City Ratner, a Brooklyn-based firm. The project is expected to cost $150 million to develop, and Tussaud's will invest $30 million to create its high-tech wax exhibits, while American Multi-Cinemas is expected to spend $25 million to create the city's largest multiplex, with 25 screens and 5,000 seats.
The construction on the Forest City Ratner complex is expected to generate 1,600 jobs and $6.6 million in city tax revenues over two years, city officials said. After it is completed, they said, the complex will provide 2,800 jobs and $15 million in tax revenues for the city.
In addition to the New Amsterdam and tentative plans to stage entertainment inside the proposed hotel complex, Disney said it would also open a Disney store on the southwest corner of the intersection of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Utility Discounts Permitted

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill into law yesterday that will allow the Board of Public Utility to offer discounted rates to certain retail customers. The Governor said the bill was designed to attract new businesses to New Jersey and persuade others not to relocate. Consumer groups had opposed the bill, singling out a provision that will give the utility board more latitude in setting rates on a case-by-case basis. This part of the legislation "opens the floodgates for utilities to increase the cost of electric service in New Jersey," said Curtis Fisher, program director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group Citzen Lobby.

HEADLINE: Admissions Change Will Alter Elite Campuses, Experts Say

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 21

 BODY:
 While the state's Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, hailed as a "historic achievement" the elimination of affirmative action at the nine-campus University of California, academicians expressed concern today that minority enrollment at the system's elite Berkeley and Los Angeles campuses would decline significantly.
By a vote of 14 to 10, the university's governing Board of Regents, many of them appointed by Governor Wilson and his Republican predecessor, George Deukmejian, late Thursday struck down the use of race, sex, religion, color or national origin as criteria for admission to the university. A parallel measure on hiring and contracting passed 15 to 10. 
 Mr. Wilson, who is seeking the Republican nomination for President, has made his opposition to affirmative action a fundamental part of his campaign.
Ward Connerly, the black businessman and regent who proposed the resolutions to terminate the preference programs, has argued that affirmative action has outlived its usefulness and now undermines achievement by blacks.
The measures require the Regents to adopt supplemental criteria for admission or hiring that replace membership in a racial or ethnic group with evidence of disadvantage, like "an abusive or otherwise dysfunctional home, or a neighborhood of unwholesome or anti-social influences."
Mr. Connerly said today that until these measures were in place, it would be impossible to know the impact of the dismantling of affirmative action, which the university has had in various forms since 1965, when it began an educational-opportunity program for disadvantaged students.
"We shouldn't make policy on how many blacks or Hispanics get admitted," he said. "That's what got us into this trouble in the first place."
Andrew Wong, a supporter of the Connerly measures and the president of Berkeley's graduating class last month, said, "If they decide on a geographical criterion looking for inner-city kids, or if they decide to spend more time with each application and look for obstacles overcome and potential growth, that will help the minorities."
But experts who have looked at the issue say the abandonment of affirmative action is certain to reduce the number of black and Hispanic students and increase the number of Asians at the Berkeley and Los Angeles campuses. In 1994, Asians admitted to Berkeley had a mean grade-point average of 3.95 (out of 4.0) in high school; whites had a 3.86; Hispanic students had a 3.65 and blacks had a 3.43.
Charles Ratliff, deputy director of the California Postsecondary Education Commission, an independent state agency that provides information about higher education, said his organization's study of 20,000 California high school graduates in 1990 found that the removal of race and ethnicity as criteria would mean that many fully eligible black and Hispanic students would be denied admission to campuses of their first choice.
The university guarantees a place for any student who meets the minimum standards of the least-competitive college among the system's eight undergraduate schools.
"Since Berkeley and U.C.L.A. are the most popular schools," Mr. Ratliff said, "their student populations are increasingly going to contain more Asian and white students and fewer blacks and Latinos, if prior academic achievement is the primary basis for selecting each freshman class."
Margaret Heisel, the director of outreach, admissions and student affairs in the university president's office, said the university itself reached the same conclusion in a study released in May.
"The study showed," Ms. Heisel said, "that if you take out race in the admissions criteria and rely exclusively on socioeconomic factors, a great amount of ethnic diversity disappears. African-American are reduced by 40 to 50 percent, Chicano-Latino by 5 to 15 percent, Asians make a gain and whites remain constant."
The statistical validity of the university's study has been challenged by State Senator Tom Campbell, a Republican ally of Mr. Wilson.
For himself, Mr. Wilson said that he rejected the position that the number of black and Hispanic students at Berkeley and U.C.L.A. would greatly diminish."The belief that some parts of the population can't make it is demonstrably false," he said on Thursday.
The Regents, whose meeting continued today, also faced a barrage of criticism organizations and individuals including the National Organization for Women and Walter Massey, the retiring University of California provost and a former director of the National Science Foundation.
Charles Schwartz, a Berkeley professor-emeritus of physics who addressed the Regents today, likened their action to the adoption of a loyalty oath by the Regents in the 1950's.
"That action showed that the Regents were a conduit for political intrusion into the university," Mr. Schwartz said. "Some faculty left, others were fired and the academic reputation of the university suffered immensely. Now people are wondering when it's going to happen again."
The alumni representative to the Regents, Ralph C. Carmona, who opposed the measures, said it would be difficult to recruit outstanding scholars because the impression that the Regents surrendered to political pressure from the Governor may have "irreparably harmed" the university.
Mr. Wilson responded indirectly by replying: "I think many academics believe that this is the greatest educational institution in the country."
 
RESOLUTION
 
Changing Affirmative Action
Following are excerpts from the University of California Board of Regents' resolution on dismantling affirmative-action plans within the university system, as adopted on Thursday.
 
 ON ADMISSIONS Effective Jan. 1, 1997, the University of California shall not use race, religion, sex, color, ethnicity or national origin as a criterion for admission to the university or to any program of study.
Effective Jan. 1, 1997, race, religion, sex, color, ethnicity or national origin shall not be the criterion for admissions in exception to U.C.-eligibility requirements.
The president shall confer with the Academic Senate of the University of California to develop supplemental criteria for consideration by the Board of Regents. . . . In developing such criteria, which shall provide reasonable assurances that the applicant will successfully complete his or her course of study, consideration shall be given to individuals who, despite having suffered disadvantage economically or in terms of their social environment (such as an abusive or otherwise dysfunctional home, or a neighborhood of unwholesome or anti-social influences), have nonetheless demonstrated sufficient character and determination in overcoming obstacles to warrant confidence that the applicant can pursue a course of study to successful completion, provided that any student admitted under this section must be academically eligible for admission.
Because individual members of all of California's diverse races have the intelligence and capacity to succeed at the University of California, this policy will achieve a U.C. population that reflects this state's diversity through the preparation and empowerment of all students in this state to succeed rather than through a system of artificial preferences.
 
ON BUSINESS PRACTICES AND EMPLOYMENT Effective Jan. 1, 1996, the University of California shall not use race, religion, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin as a criterion in its employment and contracting practices.
The president of the University of California is directed to oversee a systemwide evaluation of the University's hiring and contracting practices to identify what actions need to be taken to ensure that all persons have equal access to job competitions, contracts and other business and employment opportunities of the university. A report and recommendations to accomplish this objective shall be presented to the Board of Regents before Dec. 31, 1996.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

U.S. Drops Demand For More Microsoft Papers
The Justice Department abandoned its demand for more documents from Microsoft, but said it was continuing its study of Windows 95 and Microsoft Network and implied that it would decide whether to file a suit within the next several weeks.
 In a two-paragraph letter, the Government said it had become apparent that it would have to rely on information already available if it wanted to make a decision before Aug. 24, which is the official introduction date for Windows 95. [Page 35.]
 
Blinder Comments Lift Yields, Dow Closes Unchanged
The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 6.96 percent, from 6.86 percent, as prices tumbled in a late afternoon selloff. Traders took comments by the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan S. Blinder, to mean there would not be another interest rate cut this summer. [45.]
 
The Dow industrials ended a roller-coaster week unchanged, at 4,641.55, as the expiration of stock and index options came to the market's rescue in late trading. For the week, the Dow lost 67.27 points. The Nasdaq index, which had also been whipsawed during the week, rose 1.20 points yesterday to 961.77. Technology stocks were mixed. [37.]
 
The dollar rose against the yen as traders continued to be wary of dollar purchases by the Bank of Japan in an effort to weaken the yen. The dollar rose to 88.52 yen and also climbed to 1.3856 marks. [36.]
 
Senate Passes Budget Cuts
A revised $16.4 billion package of current-year budget cuts won final approval in the Senate. President Clinton said he would sign the bill, which restores some cuts made to education, job training and environmental programs. The $16.4 billion is the largest midyear budget cut in history. Most of the reductions come from such programs as aid to low-income people, youth and education. [8.]
 
Poor Reviews for Bank Deal
The proposed merger between Corestates Financial and the Bank of Boston was greeted coolly by investors and analysts, as the shares of both companies fell. Some investors moved to block the deal, which the boards of both banking companies were expected to approve at meetings tomorrow. [37.]
 
Smokeless Tobacco Suit Filed
A lawsuit accusing five makers of smokeless tobacco of trying to addict young people and damaging their health is expected to be filed in Federal court in Wichita, Kan. The suit has the potential of involving about 30,000 state residents and could cost the companies more than $1 billion if it is successful. [35.]
 
Coram and Lincare Call Off Deal
Coram Healthcare and Lincare Holdings ended their agreement under which Coram was to have acquired Lincare. The deal was valued at $1.4 billion when it was announced in April. But Coram's stock price has fallen about $10 since then, forcing down the value of the takeover to $537 million. [47.]
 
Esmor Center Criticized
An investigation by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service has found that an immigration prison in New Jersey, run by Esmor Correctional Services, was run like a secretive fief where guards preyed on immigrants. The immigration service said it would not renew its contract for Esmor to run the center. [1.]
 
D'Amato Seeks to Block Bailouts
Days after the House of Representatives passed an amendment aimed at cutting off the bailout funds for Mexico, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said he would introduce similar legislation in the Senate intended to prohibit the President from acting on his own in the future to rescue a country on the brink of bankruptcy. [34.]
 
Los Angeles Times in Cutbacks
The Los Angeles Times announced the end of several innovative sections of the newspaper and the elimination of 150 news-gathering positions. The paper's editor, Shelby Coffey 3d, noted, however, that the paper would have the country's largest news staff, more than 1,100, even after the cuts. [6.]

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Times Cuts Sections and Staff

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 21

 BODY:
In what the newspaper's editor, Shelby Coffey 3d, called one of his toughest days in journalism, The Los Angeles Times announced today the folding of several adventurous sections of the paper and the elimination of 150 news-gathering positions.
"But it should be noted," Mr. Coffey said in a memorandum to the staff, "that even with these difficult reductions, we retain the largest editorial staff in America, over 1,100, with a budget of over $110 million a year for news gathering." 
 The cuts were made, as Mr. Coffey told staff members at a morning meeting, to try to avoid "crashing through the red line" into financial deficit because of the fast-rising costs of newsprint and the painfully slow recovery of the Southern California economy.
"Publishing is a business and journalism isn't," he said in an interview afterward, "but we are inextricably tied together, and if we are not succeeding on the publishing side, we can't be a journalistic success."
The staff reductions today were part of a plan to eliminate 1,750 jobs throughout the various publications of the Times Mirror Company, including 750 jobs that were lost with the closing of New York Newsday on Sunday.
Reporters and editors heard the news at simultaneous departmental meetings at 9:30 A.M. and then returned to their seats to wait to hear whether they were losing their jobs.
"There're literally people sitting at their desks, staring into space, waiting to be tapped on the shoulder," said a reporter, speaking on the condition that his name not be printed. "It is so grim because we are all in the same room, and you are in front of your friends and someone is going to come by and say, 'Hey, let's have a chat,' and everyone's going to know what happened."
Mid-level editors were briefed on Thursday on how to break the news to their reporters, one editor said. Pairs of editors were to summon those employees who were losing their jobs and offer to refer them to job-placement counselors. Employees were offered $3,000 to help in their job search, and severance packages ranged up to one-year's pay for employees with 10 years' seniority.
"I'm sure some of the people on the list did not see this thing coming," the editor said. "I was shocked when I saw the list."
Two plainclothes security guards were posted outside Mr. Coffey's office as a precaution, newsroom employees said. Around the building, some people wept, some hugged each other, some buried themselves in work.
The elimination of 150 "full-time positions" in the news department was accomplished by the layoffs of 73 full-time staff members as well as 80 part-time and 23 temporary employees. The newspaper eliminated 230 jobs earlier this year and plans to let go another 300 non-newsroom employees by the end of the year.
"Virtually all sections, from foreign bureaus to polls to copy messengers, will be impacted," Mr. Coffey said in his memorandum about today's cuts.
He said the newspaper would concentrate on its core mission to provide strong news, analysis, investigative and literary journalism in its main paper. Reporters said no full-time employees were cut from the metropolitan staff.
In large part, the cutbacks were accomplished through the elimination of eight special sections that had been part of the paper's expansion in urban and suburban areas and in Washington.
Nuestro Tiempo, the paper's Spanish-language weekly with a circulation of 400,000, will close, along with City Times, the weekly inner-city section that was inaugurated in response to the racial and social issues raised by the 1992 riots.
At one newsroom gathering this morning, some reporters questioned Mr. Coffey about the implications of reducing service to minorities in this fast-changing city. He responded that other sections of the newspaper would have to work harder to cover these issues.
In his own message to the staff, the publisher, Richard T. Schlosberg 3d, said, "Plans are under way to provide much of the news and advertising from these sections in other formats."
In addition, the newspaper will eliminate a section that has served the affluent Westside as well as three inserts serving the San Fernando Valley and Ventura County.
The highly regarded weekly foreign news section, World Report, was also eliminated because, an editor said, it attracted little advertising. The Sunday Magazine survived, though there had been continuing reports that it would close.
The newspaper also discontinued its Monday-through-Friday Washington edition, which was inaugurated in 1992 and was a symbol of the paper's ambitions to be a national voice with impact in Washington and New York. Mr. Coffey said that the newspaper would be available on the East Coast by air mail and that a small number of copies would be delivered to offices by air freight.
As employees waited to learn their fate, and some reminisced about the days when people traveled first-class and expense accounts were never challenged, one writer buried her head behind her files and tried to work on a story.
"By 12, I figured everybody was done and I hadn't been fired," the writer said. "I came out from behind my desk and said, 'It's over?' like, 'I'm clear?' and an editor shook hands with me and said, 'We survived.' "

HEADLINE: Ernest Mandel, 72, Is Dead; Marxist Economist and Writer

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
Ernest Mandel, a Marxist economist at the center of a debate on free speech and academic freedom during the Nixon Administration, died on Thursday at his home in Brussels. He was 72.
Dr. Mandel died of a heart attack, said his wife, Anne. 
 Dr. Mandel won an international reputation in the 1960's and 70's for his writings, most notably a 1972 book, "Late Capitalism," in which he argued that class struggle was affected by long economic waves of 20 to 40 years, rather than by shorter economic cycles.
But he gained a measure of prominence in the United States not so much for his unconventional economic views but because Attorney General John N. Mitchell denied him a visa in 1969, against the advice of Secretary of State William P. Rogers.
The Attorney General acted under a section of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952, popularly known as the McCarran Act, that barred visas to those who "advocate the economic, international and governmental doctrines of world Communism" and "who write or publish any written or printed matter advocating or teaching the economic international and governmental doctrines of world Communism."
Dr. Mandel at the time was editor of the weekly leftist journal La Gauche. He had been granted visas in 1962 and 1968, and had violated the conditions of his second visit, apparently unwittingly, by addressing a group that was asked for contributions for the legal defense of French demonstrators.
When Mitchell denied him a visa in 1969, Dr. Mandel was defended by several American scholars, who noted that he had spoken out against the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, and that he was not a member of the Communist Party. The visa issue was widely debated in American newspapers, to the apparent surprise of Dr. Mandel.
"It shows that public opinion in the United States is very much alive to the dangers that threaten our basic freedom," he said.
In March 1971, a Federal Court in New York voted to void Mitchell's decision, declaring that the United States could not bar a visitor who preached "anarchistic" doctrines. But on June 29, 1972, the Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 3, that Mitchell had acted within his discretion in denying the visa.
Ernest Mandel was born in Frankfurt. His family moved to Antwerp, Belgium, when he was a child. During World War II, he was a member of the Belgian Resistance. He was arrested three times and eventually sent to a work camp.
Since 1940 Dr. Mandel had been a member of the Socialist Fourth International, which was founded by Trotsky in the 1930's to promote world revolution. After World War II, Dr. Mandel led the Fourth International's Belgian section.
His revolutionary ideas brought Dr. Mandel into frequent conflict with the authorities, and he was banned at various times from entering France, Germany, Switzerland and Australia.
Dr. Mandel's last major work, "Power and Money," was published in 1983.
He is survived by his wife.

HEADLINE: Roller-Coaster Takes a Rest; Dow Doesn't Change at All

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Ending a roller-coaster week, blue-chip stocks ended unchanged yesterday as the expiration of stock and index options came to the market's rescue in late trading.
 The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 4,641.55, unchanged from Thursday's close. 
 The average, which had surged on Monday, lost 50 points on Tuesday and followed with a loss of 57 points on Wednesday, although that was up from its low point for the day, when it was down 134 points.
 For the week, the Dow lost 67.27 points. The big losses Tuesday and Wednesday created fear that the market was beginning a long-awaited correction, but it eked out a small gain, 12.68 points, on Thursday.
 "After two days like Tuesday and Wednesday, the market needed to do a bit of calming down and digesting," said Thom Brown, managing director at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood.
 The two-day drop appeared to burst a speculative bubble that has lifted the technology stocks for so long, and investors were taking defensive positions with consumer growth and basic industry stocks, analysts said.
 "When you get a shake-up in the market based on the speculative area being hit, the money that comes out of that goes into the basic industries," Mr. Brown said.
 The Nasdaq index, which had also been whipsawed during the week, rose 1.20 points yesterday to 961.77.
 In the broader market, advancing issues edged out declines, 1,191 to 1,040, on heavy trading of 431.8 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
 The exchange said the weekly trading volume of 2.002 billion shares was the second-busiest ever, surpassed only by the 2.299 billion shares traded in the week that ended on Oct. 23, 1987, which included the Oct. 19 stock market crash.
 Analysts said yesterday that a late burst of buying at the expiration of stock and index options reversed a late decline that had been prompted by a jump in long-term interest rates.
 "When bonds hit the skids it spilled over into stocks," said Gregory Nie at Kemper Securities. "But there was obviously a buy-side bias to the options expiry."
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 112/32 , to 1088/32 . Its yield climbed to 6.96 percent from 6.86 percent at Thursday's close.
 Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers Global Economic Advisers, said the stock market looked fragile as it closed out a turbulent week.
 "But the bond yield is at the high end of the trading range, and the equity market is moving toward the lower end of its fair value range," he said. "It may present a buying opportunity."
 Among the basic-industry group, the Aluminum Company of America rose 1/8, to 55, and Du Pont was up 5/8, to 70 1/8. Gillette rose 1/2, to 42 7/8, and McDonald's rose 3/4, to 38 5/8.
 Westinghouse topped the Big Board actives list, falling 1/8, to 13. The company and CBS met in New York yesterday to discuss a possible deal whereby Westinghouse would buy CBS for less than $83 a share, a source close to the negotiations said. CBS gained 3/8, to 75 1/4.
 Technology stocks were mixed. Apple Computer fell 35/16 , to 43 3/4, after announcing disappointing third-quarter earnings Thursday, and Microsoft fell 4 1/8, to 92. I.B.M. slipped 1/2, to 103 5/8, but Compaq, which announced unexpectedly strong earnings on Thursday, rose 3/8, to 48 7/8.
 Motorola gained 2 3/4, to 76. Motorola "got knocked down on Tuesday and Wednesday and was not overvalued like all the other techs," Mr. Brown said.
 The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.08, to 553.62. The American Stock Exchange index rose 3.69 to 514.55.
 The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.31, to 296.67. The average share was up 4 cents.
 In Japan, stocks ended higher yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 135.67 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 16,589.09, after trading within a range of 16,481.80 to 16,613.06.

HEADLINE: Hopes for Rate Cut Fade, and Bonds Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices tumbled yesterday in a late afternoon selloff prompted by comments by a top Federal Reserve official that quashed any hopes of another cut in interest rates this summer.
 The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan S. Blinder, who is considered one of the Fed officials most likely to favor cutting interest rates to stimulate the economy, said in an interview yesterday that "the probability of a recession is lower in mid-July than it was in the middle of June." 
 Mr. Blinder's remarks aggravated concern among bond investors that the economy's growth was not feeble enough for the Fed to push short-term interest rates lower any time soon. After the Fed cut its target rate for overnight loans by a quarter of a percentage point on July 6, many traders had expected the Fed to push rates lower when its policy-making committee meets next in August.
 "If you take out the prospect for any near-term Fed easing, there's less of a carrot to look forward to," said Steven Saslow, executive managing director at HSBC Securities in New York.
 Denny Niedringhaus, who manages $150 million of bonds at Southwest Bank in St. Louis, said, "If the economy is going to achieve a soft landing, then maybe we've seen the low in yields and this whole move is over."
 "A lot of people will be throwing in the towel on this market," he said, and that could push bond yields as high as 7.25 percent by Labor Day.
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 112/32 , to 1088/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.96 percent from 6.86 percent.
 The price decline, however, came on low trading volume that exaggerated the move.
 Many traders had already ruled out another rate cut, particularly after the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, told a House Banking subcommittee on Wednesday that the risks of both inflation and a recession had faded. Bond prices fell after his testimony.
 Still, Mr. Greenspan noted, "We have certainly not yet reached the point at which no risk of undue economic weakness remains."
 And Mr. Blinder said yesterday that an apparent recovery in economic growth did not mean that the risk of recession had vanished, adding that he was "open minded" about further interest rate reductions.
 In the corporate market, National City Bank sold $225 million of bonds yesterday. It was the only large sale of investment-grade corporate debt yesterday, as some companies reassessed their borrowing plans after this week's rise in interest rates.
 National City, a unit of the National City Corporation, a Cleveland-based commercial bank, sold $225 million of bonds in a five-part sale.
 The notes, due on July 15, 2010, have a 7.25 percent coupon and were priced at 99.67 to yield 7.287 percent, or 76.7 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury notes. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 The notes are rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 Repsol International Finance B.V., a unit of the Spanish oil company Repsol S.A., plans to sell $300 million of 10-year notes in the days ahead, according to MCM Corporate Watch, which tracks sales of fixed-income and other securities.

HEADLINE: New Rules Cut Estate Taxes For the Inheritors of Houses

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 21

 BODY:
A little-noticed provision in the Pataki administration's new budget gives residents of the state a substantial break on estate taxes, allowing heirs not to pay tax on the first $250,000 of the value of an inherited home.
For taxpayers who own houses as their primary assets, the change -- tucked away among approximately $600 million in income and business tax cuts passed in the budget last month -- could more than triple the worth of assets that heirs could inherit without paying state taxes. The heir of a person with a primary residence valued at $250,000 and an estate worth another $250,000 will now pay $7,500 in inheritance taxes, $12,000 less than under the old rules, the State Tax Department said. The change affects heirs other than surviving spouses, who pay no inheritance taxes. 
 Several lawyers who specialize in estates said the new law would benefit heirs of large and small estates, although the greatest proportional gain would go to the estates of middle-income earners.
One motivation for making the change was to discourage wealthy New Yorkers from moving to states with lower estate taxes, Pataki officials and other Republicans said. But several lawyers said the change did not go far enough in making New York, which has among the highest estate taxes in the nation, competitive with other states.
Thirty-one states, including New Jersey and Florida, have estate-tax rates that equal a credit the Federal Government allows for state inheritance taxes. New York, however, charges more than that credit in many cases, and critics said the new tax break was not enough relief.
One such critic is Albert Kalter, a Manhattan lawyer and chairman of the estate and gift-tax committee of the Bar of the City of New York. "These are sort of Band-Aid approaches by the Legislature to raise the exemption to a level that is really not appropriate," Mr. Kalter said. "New York State has not confronted the issue."
The change was hammered out during last-minute, closed-door negotiations between legislators and the Governor, which is one reason it has received little notice before now. It applies only to primary residences. Several lawyers who handle estates said today that the measure was so obscure they had not heard of it. Others said the law was too new to have been invoked much so far, although it went into effect on June 8, after the budget was passed.
This was the second year that the Legislature tinkered with estate taxes. Last year, lawmakers raised what is known as the unified credit, to $115,000 from $108,800, which effectively means that estates worth less than that amount are not taxed. They also eased inheritance taxes on family businesses.
The new provision was not part of Gov. George E. Pataki's original budget presentation in February; it was added in April by the Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno, as part of the Republican Senate's package of smaller tax cuts. Unlike most of those proposals, which were aimed at specific industries, the estate-tax cut had no visible constituency and was largely unnoticed or ignored by journalists, trade groups and lobbyists.
"I have not seen it, to my embarrassment," one lawyer in Rochester said today, echoing the chagrin of several estate lawyers. "This is a little alarming to me."
Mr. Bruno said today that his original proposal was to make New York conform to Federal law, which does not tax the first $600,000 of an estate. Mr. Bruno said the Governor supported that idea.
"The thing is that people in New York move to Florida because the estate taxes are substantially different, and that is not productive to the economy of this state," Mr. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County, said today.
But Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said he had argued during budget talks that the state could not afford the Republican proposal, which he said would have cost the state more than $100 million. The law that passed will cost $60 million, the State Budget Division estimates. Mr. Silver also said he wanted to direct the tax reduction toward more middle-income earners, a goal shared by Mr. Bruno and Pataki officials, even as they wanted to go further.
The new $250,000 limit easily covers most homes in most areas in the state, with notable exceptions in some neighborhoods of Manhattan and in Westchester County, where the median house price in May was $373,000. The median prices in other parts of the state were $170,100 in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties; $108,000 in the Albany area; $88,849 in Syracuse, and $92,755 in Buffalo.
Joshua S. Rubenstein, an estate lawyer with Rosenman and Colin in Manhattan, said the provision would most help the heirs of people who owned their homes and had modest savings, less than about $115,000. For people with estates up to $1 million, he said, the provision would make New York State's estate taxes roughly equal to those in states like Florida.
Someone with a $10 million estate, he said, would pay about $50,000 less in estate taxes than before, but that person would still pay about $325,000 more than would be required by a state like Florida.
"It may actually be a good incentive for middle-class people to hang around" in New York, Mr. Rubenstein said. "It probably isn't going to do anything to induce the extraordinarily wealthy to stop making their money in New York and then retiring to Florida, Texas or Arizona."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
A Family's Ancestor Was a City's Architect

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman 

 BODY:
AS the small bus pulled up to a tollbooth of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, Edward Embury, who had come here from Denver, shouted to the driver, "Hey, just tell the guy my grandfather designed this bridge; maybe he'll give us a discount."
Mr. Embury was telling the truth. His grandfather Aymar Embury 2d had indeed designed the bridge. Moreover, all but one of the 13 other passengers aboard were also related to the architect, who died in 1966 at the age of 86. 
 None of this, however, should sway a toll taker. Quite rightly she unsentimentally demanded and received $6, probably thinking the remark from the bus was just another of the wise-guy comments she is paid to endure. What did she know about Aymar Embury 2d? What, indeed, do any of us know about him?
It turns out that he not only supervised the design of the Whitestone, he also oversaw plans for the Triborough, the Henry Hudson and the Marine Parkway Bridges. He planned the Central Park Zoo, Orchard Beach, huge swimming pools and parks. During years of Federal Works Projects Administration construction, while he served as chief architect for Robert Moses, he did as much as anyone to bind the city together and to help it dig its way out of the Depression.
With a silhouette that changes like flowing lava, this is a tough town for architects to get and keep respect. Are there many among us who can name more than five architects who have helped shape the best-known skyline on the planet? But the people on the bus were aware and admiring, unabashedly proud of what their ancestor had wrought. They had first thought of the tour last May, arranging to come from many parts of the country to meet at the Central Park Zoo.
"WOW, this is neat," Philip Embury Jr., 4, a great-grandson of the architect, said as the group walked past the seal basin. Without fidgeting too much, he listened as Adrian Benepe, an official of the Municipal Art Society who guided the visitors, explained that the zoo was designed in just 16 weeks and built in just eight months.
"Can you imagine that now?" asked Mr. Benepe, who is himself remotely related to Mr. Embury. "At the height of W.P.A., there were 2,000 architects and engineers working night and day on projects in armories. They slept on cots."
The group moved on to Bradhurst Avenue and 146th Street in Harlem to the Jackie Robinson swimming pool. It was called the Colonial Park pool when Aymar Embury designed it.
"This is like a castle," said Edward Embury, Philip's 9-year-old brother. "It's got towers." It also has a crenelated facade and a vaulted entrance like the Alhambra. Anyone could see that the neighborhood youngsters splashing in its waters liked it fine. "I'd heard about what my grandfather accomplished all my life, but it's great to see people still enjoying his works," said Dorothy Embury Staats, a high school math teacher from Princeton who was 13 when the architect died.
Back on the Parks Department bus, the group crossed the Triborough, the city's chunky aorta that Embury designed, stopping at the Robert Moses Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority Building, which he also designed. In the lobby hangs a plaque with a profile of the architect. The family members took photographs of one another as they stood sideways next to the plaque, debating which of them had the Embury nose.
They advanced to Flushing Meadows Park and the building Mr. Embury designed as a permanent structure for the 1939 World's Fair. It was the original home of the United Nations and now houses the Queens museum and an ice skating rink. It also has a scale-model panorama of all of New York City, which won rave reviews from one of the youngest tour members. "The best thing is the little airplanes coming in and taking off," said Alexander Benepe, who is going into the third grade. "They light up in the dark."
The group stopped briefly to watch and lament the demolition of Mr. Embury's Aquacade theater. As they headed toward the Bronx, Edward Embury pointed to the Whitestone Bridge and said that his grandfather's designs always emphasized how things worked. He said that what appeared to be ornamental elements are lines revealing the tensions within the structure. He also remembered how his grandfather scorned some of his modernist contemporaries.
"You know how he referred to Frank Lloyd Wright? He called him 'No Closets.' "
THE last stop was Orchard Beach, where the beach house needs paint but still looks like the Trocadero in Paris, its curvilinear facade enclosing majestic steps to form a proud pavilion for an economically battered people in need of hope. None of the visitors had been there before, though a few were raised in Greenwich, Conn., which is, geographically, close by. They walked up and down the beach, happily looking at the thousands who, without ever having heard of Aymar Embury, were still obviously enjoying what he had conceived more than 50 years earlier.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Proud though they were of their ancestor's achievement, the Embury clan was still subject to the $6 toll for crossing the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, which he designed more than a half-century ago. (Charles Phelps Cushing, 1947); Aymar Embury 2d (1937)

HEADLINE: 5 Fish Dealers Face Eviction From Market

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Using its new powers to regulate the Fulton Fish Market, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani moved yesterday to evict five wholesale fish dealers, including two companies that are owned by relatives of purported Mafia figures.
Randy M. Mastro, the Mayor's chief of staff, described the evictions as "a significant step in the administration's drive to improve the market's business operations" and said the dealers had to clear out by the end of the month. 
 He added that the city was still reviewing the backgrounds of many of the approximately 40 merchants in the lower Manhattan market and that the city might revoke the leases of some of them.
Joseph L. Forstadt, a lawyer for three companies facing eviction, denounced the action by New York City officials as "bizarre" and said the dealers might sue to be reinstated on the ground that their constitutional rights were violated. Mr. Forstadt asserted that the city had refused to renew a lease for one of his clients, Alphonse Malangone Jr., the owner of the Cape Cod Seafood Company, solely because his father was suspected of being a capo in the Genovese crime family.
"It is absolutely outrageous that Mr. Malangone Jr. is made guilty by his relationship with his father," Mr. Forstadt said.
The other company that faces eviction because of suspected Mafia connections is Preferred Quality Seafood. Thomas Gangi, an officer in Preferred Quality is the son of Rosario Ross Gangi, who Federal and city law-enforcement officials have identified as the Genovese family's boss in the market.
The company's office at 109 South Street was closed yesterday, and Thomas Gangi, who has an unlisted home telephone number, could not be reached.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Mastro said the five wholesalers had been ordered to leave because they had declined to submit sufficient background information. But he would not say whether the suspected organized crime links had anything to do with the city's decision.
The evictions are the first concrete outgrowth of a campaign by the city to rid the Fulton market of organized-crime influence and to improve business conditions. For more than 40 years, law-enforcement and city officials have acknowledged that the market was dominated by the Genovese family, but all previous efforts, including a drive by Mr. Giuliani when he was the United States Attorney in Manhattan, have failed to rid it of mobsters and corruption.
The market is an important cog in the city's economy, generating about $1 billion a year in sales, salaries and related businesses. More than 800 people work full time loading, unloading and selling about 125 million pounds of fish and seafood every year. The country's largest wholesale seafood, it is mainly on city property on South Street extending from Fulton Street to Peck Slip.
Mr. Mastro also said that the city signed leases yesterday with the last of three trade associations representing most of the dealers. The leases with the associations call for gradual increases that will give the city total rents of $2 million in June 1998 compared with about $260,000 in annual rents that the merchants had paid since 1982.
Some dealers had threatened to leave the city over the rent increases and the new regulations, but in the end the trade associations agreed to the new leases. The full licensing and registration regulations calling for extensive investigations of the companies that unload and load supplies will take effect in September.
Mr. Forstadt represented the South Street Sidewalk Association, a group of 21 wholesale dealers who are the main tenants on the west side of South Street between Fulton Street and Beekman Street. Earlier, the city had obtained group leases with associations in the two main buildings on the East Side of South Street that are known as the Tin Building and the New Building.
The rents for the Sidewalk Association dealers will rise from about $80,000 this year to $650,000 a year on June 1, 1998, Mr. Mastro said.
Mr. Forstadt complained that the rent increases were excessive but said the Sidewalk Association had little choice but to accept the terms. Its option of moving out of the city were dashed, he said, when the other merchants' groups agreed to the city's terms.
"This will cause significant increases in the cost of fish to consumers," he asserted. "You can't ask these businesses to pay 10 times more in rent and not add that to what they have to charge."
But Mr. Mastro said the increases were "fair and long overdue." He said that the city's efforts to end mob extortions and cartels at the market would result in more competition and lower operating costs.
The other dealers whose leases were not renewed are S & M Fish Company, 102 South Street; ABC Fillets, 102A South Street, and J-Seafood, 103 South Street.
Mr. Forstadt said that Salvatore Macaluso, the owner of S & M, was planning to sue the city over age discrimination. The lawyer said that Mr. Macaluso, 66, had reduced his business activities because of his age and that the city had refused to renew his lease because his sales was too low.
The owners of J-Seafood, the lawyer said, were living outside the city and did not want to renew the lease.
ABC Fillets, which is not a member of the Sidewalk Association, was closed yesterday and telephone calls to its office were unanswered.

HEADLINE: Nation's Oldest Fun Park To Get a Brand New Look

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRISTOL, Conn.

 BODY:
For three summers, Lake Compounce has opened for just a few days in efforts to save its title as the nation's oldest continually operating amusement park.
Now, thanks in part to $18 million in state bond financing, the 300-acre amusement park not only has reopened for the entire summer, but also may remake itself into a year-round theme park. But as it begins investing $35 million in new rides and attractions, the park faces the challenge of winning back patrons put off by the failures of two management companies over the last decade, a time when other amusement parks prospered. 
 The park's largest hurdle may be the damage to its reputation from its past problems, said Susan E. Mosedale, director of association relations for the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions. "It does depend on the public," she said. "A development company can do everything right and still not succeed."
The park's private owners, including two local businessmen, and state economic development officials say that the $35 million investment is what Lake Compounce has needed all along. On one side of the two-mile lake for which the park is named, the owners are planning to build a water park with more than a dozen splashing rides; across the lake, a new $8 million roller coaster with a dizzying view will be built atop a small mountain.
These additions will complement the older, main park, which has a carousel listed on the National Register of Historic Places, a 100-year-old ballroom overlooking the lake and one of the first electric roller coasters in the country.
A new management company, Funtime Inc., is marketing Lake Compounce as family fun, with everything from kiddie rides to attract parents of young children, to rock-climbing to pull in teen-agers, to ballroom dancing for the older crowd. Eventually, Lake Compounce hopes to have more than a million visitors each year.
State officials approved the financing because they believe the park could boost the local economy and eventually repay the state investment. They also wanted to preserve a historic amusement park.
But Frederick A. Gelsi, a state representative from Enfield, said he sees the Lake Compounce project as a risky venture that would not have received state financing 10 years ago, when public officials were less desperate for ways to boost the state's economy.
"This thing hasn't been making money in all these years," said Mr. Gelsi, who voted against the $18 million the state agreed to bond for the project. "I just couldn't see how pouring more money into it was going to make it work."
Lake Compounce is still a long way from its attendance goals. A weekday visit in late June found at most several hundred visitors; Funtime managers said that more than 16,000 people visited the park during the four-day Fourth of July weekend, a figure they seemed satisfied with.
"We're not looking at this summer as a make-or-break summer," said Thomas R. Clay, marketing manager for Funtime. "This is a first step. It's going to take six or seven years before people in the region recognize us as a major park."
Both state and park officials say that Lake Compounce's earlier problems were caused more by its management companies than by a lack of public interest in the park.
After investing some $28 million in the park, the first manager, Hershey Entertainment, backed out in 1987 because of a change in corporate policy.
A second manager, Joseph Entertainment, a concert promotion company, then lost the sympathy of Bristol residents by presenting noisy rock concerts that clogged local roads. The company went bankrupt in early 1992 because of its other holdings, Mr. Clay said.
Anthony P. Brescia, senior regional manager for the State Department of Economic Development, said Funtime's plans seem "cohesive and sensible and reachable." The state bonding is contingent upon the park owners investing $7 million of their own money and securing a $10.3 million bank loan for the project.
Premier Parks of Oklahoma City has announced plans to buy the stock of Funtime, which had sales of $51 million in 1994. Funtime, based in Cleveland, owns three parks, including one associated with the Columbus, Ohio, zoo.
Many residents of the area remember going to Lake Compounce as children and are rooting for the park to succeed this time. Kathryn Petruzzello of Southington, who was at the park with her family recently, said she had such fond memories of the park that when it closed in the 1980's, she made her husband climb the fence to take pictures.
"We almost got arrested," her husband, Michael, said, teasing her.
Mrs. Petruzzello said, "There are a lot of people in the area who remember it and who are invested in having it stay open. It sort of has its own little fan club."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patrons enjoy "The Round Robbin," one of the attractions at the Lake Compounce Amusement Park. State bond financing may help the owners remake the 300-acre park into a year-round attraction with features for people of all ages. The $18 million in bonds was issued because state officials hope the investment will help the local economy grow and eventually be repaid. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)
