HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Wartime Dreams Revisited

BYLINE: By Stephen Holden 

 BODY:
WHAT TERM COULD BE more oxymoronic than "wartime nostalgia"? Does anyone really want a return to the days of Hitler, Hiroshima and Auschwitz? Yet in America, where no bombs fell and no storm troopers landed during World War II, Hollywood and Tin Pan Alley created a seductive wartime dream world of heroics and hearts and flowers that grows more appealing as the decades slip away.
Fifty years after the end of the World War II, the music that wafted through our national dream life in the early 1940's is regarded by many as the country's finest pop moment. Nostalgia for the 40's dates back to the early 1970's when Bette Midler scored a top 10 single with "Boogie Woogie Bugle Boy," a 1941 Andrews Sisters hit. More recently, cabaret singers like Maureen McGovern, Andrea Marcovicci and Mary Cleere Haran have devoted entire programs to the 1940's, and Barry Manilow has recorded an album of big-band standards. Harry Connick Jr. presents himself as a born-in-New-Orleans reincarnation of Frank Sinatra and Dick Haymes. 
 Discussing his passion for 40's pop, Mr. Connick has used words like "clean" to describe its charm. He doesn't just mean its lack of sexual explicitness but its simplicity, integrity and upbeat attitude.
When America declared war on Japan in 1941, the swing era was already in full flower, with the most popular band, the Glenn Miller Orchestra, defining the optimum musical balance between the visceral and the romantic.
As America went to war, Irving Berlin's "White Christmas," crooned by Bing Crosby in a voice rich with reassurance and faith, projected a Currier and Ives vision of a pristine, snow-christened America to soldiers abroad and their loved ones at home. Crosby, who was 40 when Pearl Harbor was bombed, reigned as the vocal embodiment of American benevolence, while Mr. Sinatra, who was 13 1/2 years younger, brought a new current of erotic tenderness and vulnerability into pop singing. Hits like "I Dream of You," "If You Are But a Dream," "Dream" and "Put Your Dreams Away" were sugarcoated valentines counseling patience and delayed gratification to the wives and girlfriends of American soldiers.
Few sounds are more compellingly wistful than the youthful Sinatra's ardent murmurings. Tomorrow, a three-night celebration of the singer's music will begin with Michael Feinstein singing "Night and Day," Mr. Sinatra's first hit after leaving the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra. In that historic recording, Axel Stordahl's exquisite orchestration, which brought the harmonic vocabulary of Puccini and Rachmaninoff into the pop arena, defined Mr. Sinatra's war-years sound.
Just as they are today, pop music's sound, structure and technology during the war years were a populist esthetic mirror of their time and place. With the birth of swing in the late 1930's, American pop achieved a blend of sophistication and utopian optimisim that prevailed for nearly a decade. But if the ascendance of swing expressed a remarkable unanimity of spirit in America, that communal feeling coincided with shared adversity: a Depression followed by a world war.
The music of the early-40's may have been better made and more wholesome than much of today's pop, but the social and economic climate was in many ways harsher. The standard of living was much lower, and individual opportunities for self-fulfillment were relatively limited. Feminism had subsided after women won the vote in 1920, the civil rights and gay liberation movements were still years away, and there was little in the way of teen-age culture.
IN THIS PURITANICAL CLI-
mate, the more pop-oriented swing bands like those of Glenn Miller and the Dorsey brothers made music that presented the ensemble as a model community ruled by a strong (often dictatorial) male leader surrounded by deferential henchmen and largely anonymous instrumentalists. Although technical expertise within one's assigned role was respected, teamwork was valued above everything, and obedience to authority obligatory.
While the voices of leading swing band vocalists like Bob Eberly, Ray Eberle, Tex Beneke, Marion Hutton and Helen O'Connell had their distinctive traits, they were ultimately homogenous with the ensemble. Their rhythmic and timbral inflections and freedom of interpretative expression were limited by rigid, preset musical formats.
The smoothness of the ensemble blend reflected an unquestioned belief in social decorum, in being "nice," at all costs. The band arrangements emphasized neat, orderly patterns and a group harmony that was emotional as well as musical. Among vocal groups like the Pied Pipers, the Modernaires and the Andrews Sisters, individual styles were subordinated to a scrupulously homogenized sound, accented by synchronized movements and invariably cheery smiles. This team spirit mirrored a society in which it was assumed that every able-bodied man would gladly serve his country or risk social ostracism.
V.J. Day, on Aug. 15, 1945, burst the bubble. Within the next year and a half, eight of the country's most popular swing bands, including those of Benny Goodman and Tommy Dorsey had broken up. (Glenn Miller had died in December 1944 when his plane was lost over the English Channel.) Led by Mr. Sinatra, the era of the model community gave way to the era of the model singer. The reign of the genteel pop crooner ended with the arrival of Elvis Presley and the comeback of Mr. Sinatra, who had reinvented himself as the new king of swing.
In the more sophisticated swing revival that Mr. Sinatra oversaw, the singer ruled, with the band arrangements custom-made to suit his moods. Although obedience to the leader was still necessary, an aura of "niceness" was no longer a requirement.
Cooperation, teamwork and an enforced civility had brought America out of the Depression and enabled the country to triumph in a world war that almost everyone agreed had been worth fighting. It was time for an explosion of individual voices.

LENGTH: 601 words

HEADLINE: THEATER: UP AND COMING -- Caroline Seymour;
'A Difficult Peg to Fit' Finds Her Place in New York

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
AS JEAN, THE ACCOMMODATING but deeply anguished woman at the center of Mike Leigh's ensemble drama, "Ecstasy," Caroline Seymour is the embodiment of the wan, economically enslaved British working class, circa 1979. Living in a squalid, one-room flat in north London, working at a gas station, Jean drinks, smokes, has semi-consensual sex with a galoot she hardly knows and lies to herself and to her equally trapped friends that life is bearable. It is well into the second act before she lets slip a fantasy.
"My character says, 'I want to go to America,' " Ms. Seymour said in an interview on the set at the Judith Anderson Theater on West 42d Street, where the play has just reopened after a move. "And every night I think, 'Bloody 'ell, I made it! This girl didn't.' " 
 Ms. Seymour, who is 29, arrived in New York from England during Christmas week of 1992. Married to an American, Josh Cheuse, a photographer of rock-and-roll bands, she remains unrepentantly British, speaking in the accent and vernacular of her working-class roots, even as she wholeheartedly embraces New York.
In an age of diversity on the New York stage, she is an unusual ethnic presence. Pale-skinned, even sallow, very thin, shy in demeanor but earthy in speech, she is from Essex, a working-class area northeast of London. She was raised by her mother, a nurse, and, from the age of 12, a stepfather, a research scientist.
"I think I wanted to be a lawyer, but it was too much work," she said, a little hazy on how she became interested in theater. "I always enjoyed playing the fool. I kind of dabbled around from the age of 16." She went to Cambridge University, where, with a friend, Abigail Morris, now the artistic director of Soho Poly, a small company in London, she founded Trouble and Strife, a women's theater group (the name is cockney slang for wife).
"The two of us were very disgruntled with the fact that boys from private schools seemed to control everything in Cambridge," she said, describing Trouble and Strife as their revenge. One of her plays written there, "Now and at the Hour of Our Death," about a prisoners' protest in Northern Ireland, was performed at the Irish Arts Center in New York in 1989.
"I'm a difficult peg to fit in any hole," she said. "That's why I came to America. You can define yourself so much more easily here. In England, it's difficult being educated and coming from an ordinary background. People in England are so aware of accents, of what people wear. And it doesn't seem to get better. Americans are less hung up on class."
"Ecstasy," was written by Mr. Leigh (who is better known for his films "Life Is Sweet" and "Naked") in 1979 and performed in London. But it did not have its American premiere until it opened earlier this year at the John Houseman Studio Theater, under the direction of Scott Elliott.
Mr. Elliott, the founder and artistic director of the New Group, which produced the play, had never heard of Ms. Seymour before she was sent to audition by a casting director, and had already decided to hire someone else. "But as soon as Caroline opened her mouth, I knew," Mr. Elliott said.
"There isn't a false move or a false note in any of these performances," Margo Jefferson wrote in The Times, about the six member cast that includes Jared Harris and Patrick Fitzgerald.
The highly favorable reviews of "Ecstasy," Ms. Seymour said, have had a salubrious effect on her career and "there are things in the pipeline." But a regular gig does take up her time: "I'm like, man, where's my social life? I can't go out any more. Blimey!"

HEADLINE: EXPATRIATES;
Dollar Differential

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his article "Americans in a Land of Opportunity: Europe" [July 2], Alan Riding neglects to explain why young American writers and painters no longer go to Europe to develop as artists. Besides the growing insularity of Americans in general, surely the main reason for this is economic, i.e., the weak dollar. 
 When I went to Paris in 1948 to write a book, I lived for $75 a month, eating all my meals in restaurants and going to the opera every week. It was the biggest bargain of my generation, and artists and writers particularly took full advantage of the situation.
 
EDWARD FIELD
New York

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By TERENCE NEILAN

 BODY:

Passage to Poland
 Q. I will be visiting the Masurian region of Poland (former East Prussia) by late August and would like to spend a few days in a town called Elk, formerly Lyck. Are there any hotels or other tourist facilities there? And how can I get there from Warsaw? -- George E. Caspary, Tallahassee, Fla. 
 A. The scene of intense military action in both world wars, Elk is set on a small lake that in the 14th century was the site of a castle established by the Teutonic Knights. The castle has been partially reconstructed, although nothing of the original remains.
In World War I the town, known by its German name of Lyck, was the scene of the battle of Masurian Lakes in February 1915. In World War II the town was about 50 percent destroyed. After the war its German population was evacuated and it became part of Bialystok Province in northeast Poland.
The town, which is 60 miles northwest of Bialystok and about 150 miles north of Warsaw, has only a few hotels but, curiously, two state-run tourist offices.
In the center of town is the Hotel Zodiak, 1 Kajki Street, (4822 87) 102491. A single or double room with a private bathroom is $14, calculated at 2.34 new zlotys to the dollar.
In Szeligi, just outside near Elk, the Hotel Gryfia Mazur, (4822 87) 103709, charges $19 for a single or double room.
For a three-star experience visit the lake at Chelchy, about 10 miles from Elk, and the Lega Inn, (4822 87) 104443. A single costs $42 and a double $47, both with breakfast. Chelchy can be reached by train from Elk. The round-trip fare is about $1 and a taxi from the Chelchy station to the Lega Inn is $9.
Trains from Warsaw Central Station, with a change in Bialystok, leave at 7:15 A.M., arriving in Elk at 11:23 A.M.; at 11:12 A.M., arriving at 3:24 P.M.; at 1:12 P.M., arriving at 5:22 P.M., and at 5:12 P.M., arriving at 9:27 P.M.
One-way ticket prices are $10 in first class and $7 in second.
For tourist information visit Orbis, on Mickiewicza Street, (4822 87) 103843, and P.T.T.K., on Armii Krajowej Street, (4822 87) 103819.
 
Motorbikes in Spain
 Q. My wife and I are planning a self-guided tour of Spain, particularly Valencia and the east coast, and we would like to travel by motorcycle.Can you give me a list of agencies that rent bikes for that purpose? -- Jon Gurney, New York, N.Y.
A. One of the following should fit the bill:
Eurosol, Playa Edificio Eurosol, 46700 Gandia, Valencia, Spain; (34 6) 284 02 52, no fax. The company rents everything from little Maxis and Derbis, both 49 cubic centimeters, to a 250-cubic-centimeter GN. Rates range from $19 a day for the Maxi, calculated at 120 pesetas to the dollar, to $49 a day for the GN ($33 a day for two or more days). Deposits range from $25 to $83 a day, depending on the size of the bike. Prices include 16 percent tax.

On the Road to Morocco
 Q. My husband and I are planning to spend a few days in Morocco and wonder if it is safe to travel there, especially in view of increasing fundamentalism in the Mediterranean area. -- Stephanie Kipperman, San Francisco
A. The fundamentalist fervor that has terrorized Algeria and severely dented Egypt's tourist industry has not shown itself in Morocco, according to both the State Department and the Moroccan Embassy in Washington.
And if you avoid such sparsely populated areas as the Western Sahara (not a difficult thing for most tourists to do) and keep an eye open for crime in the big cities, security should not be a major concern.
The Western Sahara, formerly Spanish Sahara, was long the site of armed conflict between the Polisario Front and Morocco on the issue of independence versus Moroccan sovereignty. Although a cease-fire is in place, the State Department says several violations have occurred and the area cannot be considered safe. In any event, travel to the area is restricted, so your chances of becoming embroiled in guerilla warfare are slim at best.
The country's urban areas have a moderately high crime rate, according to the State Department. Criminals have targeted foreigners for assaults, muggings, thefts, pickpocketings and scams of all kinds, the department said in its latest Consular Information Sheet on Morocco, issued on July 28, 1994.
Commonly reported crimes include falsifying credit-card vouchers and shipping inferior rugs as a substitute for the rugs bought by travelers. Harassment by unemployed Moroccans trying to be guides is a common problem. The department suggests travelers should hire only official tour guides through hotels and travel agencies.
 
Basic Black in Italy
 Q. I am taking a hosteling trip to Europe this summer, using a Eurailpass and taking no fancy clothes. Now I have received an invitation from a friend who is getting married in Italy. Will it be acceptable for me to wear a black dress, the only one I will carry? -- Heidi R. Card, New York, N.Y.
A. The consensus of opinion is that Italians have always considered black a very elegant color and that a black dress at a wedding is unlikely to be considered offensive or out of place. If it's a daytime ceremony, of course, you might suffer from the heat.
Take cheer from a spokeswoman at the Italian Embassy in Washington: she herself wore a black dress at a wedding in the far south of Italy and it was considered "perfectly acceptable," she says. Her fashion suggestion: take something to brighten the dress up a bit; maybe a scarf. TERENCE NEILAN

HEADLINE: Output Is Up; So Are Complaints on Quality

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR 

 BODY:
GENERAL MOTORS is selling every sport utility vehicle it can make, but a survey has found that soon after they find a home, they generate far more customer complaints than do new cars.
No wonder. In my test of Chevrolet's Blazer, Tahoe and Suburban, an ashtray fell out of the dash and a seat adjuster proved balky (Blazer), a power window came off its track (Tahoe), a plastic shield on a shoulder belt was not properly fastened and easily came off, screw covers were not secure, another seat was balky and a light under the hood flickered (Suburban). A colleague recently drove a Tahoe with a Chevrolet engineer and both agreed it had a noisy wiper motor. 
 J. D. Power & Associates, the Agoura Hills, Calif., firm that measures car buyers' satisfaction in the first 90 days of ownership, was surprised in May when it found that the quality of sport-utility vehicles and light trucks had slipped after years of improvement. "Most car segments have generally gotten better year over the year," said Dave Sargent, who directed the light-truck study. "This segment has gotten worse."
One reason may be that the Big Three are cranking out as many of these vehicles as they can, and quality may be taking a back seat to quantity. Also, these are large, complex vehicles that are more difficult to assemble, Mr. Sargent said.
He said he also suspected that many buyers of four-wheel-drive vehicles were simply unaccustomed to driving a truck. Indeed, another Power study found that buyers who had replaced a car with a full-sized truck or a big sport utility were less satisfied after a year than those who had previously owned a truck and bought a new one.
To help satisfy a surge in demand, G.M. acknowledges that it has increased production at the plant where Suburbans and Tahoes are made. But it does not believe quality has declined. In fact, the Suburban's level of complaints dropped from a 1994 J. D. Power study. "Yes, we're making a lot of vehicles, but the trend on the Suburban is in the right direction," said William J. O'Neill, a Chevrolet spokesman.
The Suburban's improvement in the complaint department gave it the best showing among full-sized sport utilities, slightly better than the Tahoe and its sibling, the GMC Yukon. But that is not saying much. Among all light trucks, full-sized sport utilities had the highest number of complaints after three months of ownership. And the number was far higher than the average for cars.
Among compact sport utilities, the Japanese led the way in initial impressions about quality. The Toyota 4Runner ranked highest, with the Nissan Pathfinder a distant No. 2. The Blazer was in the middle of the pack, alongside the Jeep Grand Cherokee.
None of this reflects the little irritations that turn a proud purchaser into a bitter owner. A 7-Eleven Big Gulp soda and a large squeeze bottle kept falling out of the cup holders on the Tahoe and Suburban's dash; there was a convenient button to pop open the rear window, but no warning light to tell you that you were driving with the window up, as I did inadvertently. Leaning into the truck and buckling in a child safety seat was a chore because of the Suburban's height and because the seat belt buckle was not on stiff stem and was difficult to find.
The Blazer's and Tahoe's spare tires are under the rear of the vehicle, which would mean crawling beneath the bumper in the event of a flat -- not a pleasant prospect when you are dressed up and running late. (When else do flats occur?)
But there was one thoughtful touch from Chevrolet. There is a mat and a pair of gloves to help keep you clean.

HEADLINE: Graham Greene, Bigot

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his review of "Graham Greene: The Enemy Within" (July 2), Martin Stannard does his best to ridicule my criticisms of Greene's racism and other "moral failings," but Mr. Stannard's snide comments are no substitute for hard evidence. If he had given serious consideration to Greene's virulent anti-Semitism, he might have been less eager to mock my "politically correct" views. 
 By pretending that there is "very little" evidence behind my charges, he can scold me for launching a purely malicious assault on an "honorable" man, but nothing could be more malicious than Mr. Stannard's suppression of vital facts. Determined to smear me, he cannot acknowledge quotations like these from Greene's published work of the late 1930's: "that Semitic expression in the dark eyes above the hooked nose of being open to the commercial chance" ("Journey Without Maps"); "She deserved something better than a man named Furtstein . . . the domed Semitic forehead, the dark eyes above the rather gaudy tie" ("The Confidential Agent"); "How the financial crisis has improved English films! They have lost their tasteless Semitic opulence" (The Spectator).
These examples and many more are quoted in my book, but no discussion of Greene's anti-Semitism will be found in the official biography by Norman Sherry, which may help explain why Mr. Stannard urges readers to "chuck out" my book and buy Mr. Sherry's. Readers who want to ignore Greene's condemnation of "a large fat foreign Jew" will find that Mr. Sherry has helpfully provided a less damaging version involving merely "a large fat foreigner."
 
MICHAEL SHELDEN
Bloomington, Ind.

HEADLINE: If Your Thinking of Living In/Marble Hill;
A Bit of Manhattan in the Bronx

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
YES, you have crossed the Harlem River and, yes, that is the northern tip of Manhattan island that you can see to the south. But as residents of Marble Hill are quick to point out, you are not in the Bronx: because of a 19th-century public works project that reshaped Manhattan island and severed its topmost land, Marble Hill is across the river and into what logically should be the Bronx.
It is a quirky and little-known neighborhood whose residents consider it a well-kept secret. Where else in Manhattan can you find a six-bedroom, three-story house on a quiet, tree-lined street with an attic, a basement, an enclosed front porch and a pretty facade for sale for $174,000? Or a three-family house with six bedrooms on an architecturally magnificent street with an asking price of $295,000? 
 Realtors link the low prices partly to the fact that the homes are aging and may need repairs, and partly to the eagerness of elderly sellers, most of whom are retiring to their homelands in the Caribbean. Or to the fact that part of the small neighborhood is a giant public housing project.
There are 4,000 households in Marble Hill, but only 135 private homes. The neighborhood is divided, both physically and socially: clustered near the commercial spine of Broadway are the Marble Hill Houses, an 11-building housing development, while up on "the hill," the former site of marble quarries, are the attractive turn-of-the-century houses that lend the neighborhood its cachet.
"It's a very small area and there's a strong sense of neighborhood community about it," said Susan Goldy, president of the Bronx Board of Realtors. "It has the advantage of lower prices than some of the surrounding communities, like Riverdale, and it's really a very affordable alternative to most of Manhattan."
Rental apartments are easy to come by, but houses do not come on the market with great regularity (at last count, there were only five listed with real estate brokers). Some homeowners and landlords choose only to advertise their properties in the classified section of the local paper, The Riverdale Press, and many transactions are done even more informally. "People just don't move out, and when they do they often sell their homes to their neighbors," said H. Michael Pichardo, executive director of the Marble Hill Neighborhood Improvement Corporation.
In what many residents view as a vote of confidence for Marble Hill, City Councilman Guillermo Linares bought a house on Van Corlear Place a year and a half ago. "We just went driving around and looking, and we saw this house that had a sale sign," Mr. Linares said. "We talked to the owner, we looked at the area, we fell in love with it, and we have been very happy."
Mr. Linares said he had traded a relatively cramped and high-rent apartment in Washington Heights for a house with a backyard, three kitchens, three bathrooms, a finished basement, three bedrooms and an attic.
BUT even Mr. Linares, who was elected to represent the neighborhood in 1991, had not been aware of its existence or its status as part of Manhattan before he began campaigning for office. "Even though I had lived in Washington Heights all this time, I thought that on the other side of the 225th Street Bridge was the beginning of the Bronx," he said.
The confusion is extremely common. While Marble Hill residents vote in Manhattan, do jury duty there, and are represented by Manhattan officials, their municipal services come from the Bronx. Their fight for recognition as a Manhattan neighborhood has persisted for years. As recently as this decade, neighbors turned out in force to oppose the move to change their telephone area code from 212 to 718 (they lost).
Marble Hill was lopped from Manhattan in 1895, when the northern channel of the Harlem River was redug to make way for a ship canal. Soon after, the Spuyten Duyvil Creek was filled in, cementing Marble Hill to the Bronx. The Greater New York Charter of 1897 designated Marble Hill as part of Manhattan but not of New York County, producing decades of headaches and squabbles. In 1939, the Bronx Borough President, James J. Lyons, tried unsuccessfully to annex the neighborhood to the Bronx.
In 1984, the matter was settled with some finality when Assemblyman J. Brian Murtaugh and State Senator Franz Leichter sponsored successful legislation declaring the neighborhood part of Manhattan. Mr. Murtaugh, an Inwood resident, is a longtime Marble Hill enthusiast. "It's just a very unusual niche," he said. "It is one of the most ethnically and economically mixed neighborhoods in New York City, and yet they operate like a small town."
A community council meets monthly. In a recent example of civic activism, Mr. Murtaugh pointed to a successful effort by the police and local residents to close a bodega at 228th Street and Marble Hill Avenue where drug sales had been noted.
Formerly an Irish and Jewish bastion, Marble Hill's population is now about 35 percent black and 55 percent Hispanic. In the 50's, the construction of the Marble Hill Houses brought about the radical demographic change. "The church that I served went from an all white to an all black congregation," recalled the Rev. William Tieck, who served for 31 years as the pastor of St. Stephen's United Methodist Church, an old wooden church at the southeast corner of Marble Hill Avenue and 228th Street that serves as a focal point for the community.
The neighborhood's population of middle-class Hispanic people has continued to grow in recent years, and the first Asians have begun moving in. While whites make up only about 8 percent of the population now, their influence still permeates the neighborhood: Broadway is still dotted with Irish pubs that draw a loyal local clientele, and just over the Kingsbridge border are a kosher bakery and an Orthodox synagogue.
The Rev. Leonis Quinlan, the current pastor of St. Stephen's, moved to Marble Hill in 1991 and said that its heavily Dominican flavor came as a pleasant surprise. "It is Dominican in its essence," he said. "You can smell the foods in the air, you can hear the music. You see older men playing dominos in front of the bodegas, and women in traditional dress."
During the day, the neighborhood is populated -- some would say inundated -- by students from John F. Kennedy High School, a school of 5,100 that was built in 1972 for a student body of 3,500. Residents complain that the students generate noise and litter and crowd the local markets at lunchtime. But aside from the annoyance factor, the school's multiracial student body has caused no racial tensions.
"You don't have racial problems here -- there are no bias crimes," Mr. Pichardo of the neighborhood group said. "Show me another neighborhood in the city with this racial composition, this mix, where people get along." Relations are somewhat less harmonious between homeowners and residents of the housing projects.
UPHILL from the boxy housing projects is a cluster of attractive homes, many of them fixer-uppers. And some multifamily dwellings, like the one for sale at 121-123 West 227th Street, are already occupied by tenants with leases, compounding the difficulty of finding a property.
John Brown, an agent with the Robert E. Hill agency in Kingsbridge, said his office received few inquiries about Marble Hill. "At times we thought that the Marble Hill area was going to experience a renaissance, because of its interesting housing stock and its proximity to Manhattan, but it never did," he said.
Other than a few new health-food stores, there are still no signs that Marble Hill or its environs are going upscale. Yet fans of the neighborhood cite the convenience of its shopping district on Broadway, where mid-price retail stores and supermarkets abound.
Most of the shops lie over the Bronx border, but within easy walking distance. Residents also point with pride to the recently built Allen Pavilion, a community hospital operated by Columbia-Presbyterian hospital just across the river in Inwood. And they note the abundance of transportation options: both Metro-North and the IRT have stations in Marble Hill, numerous express buses run from Broadway and 230th Street to midtown Manhattan, and highways are close by.
On the down side, the neighborhood has no movie theaters, and dining options are limited to pubs and the Riverdale Diner. The noise from the elevated subway line is an annoyance to some residents, and the area's public schools are crowded (there are a few parochial schools just outside of Marble Hill). And, as with any urban area, the neighborhood does have its share of drug problems and blighted properties.
One neighborhood stalwart is Dr. Jeffrey L. Gurian, a dentist and comedy writer whose practice lies across the street from St. Stephen's. Through his career as a professional comedian, he has lured various celebrities to his office for dental work. "When they see the private homes and the trees, they all say it's much nicer than they ever expected," Dr. Gurian said.
On the flip side, Dr. Gurian said, the neighbors are equally astonished by some of his clients. When the actor Charlie Sheen and his bodyguard drove to the office in a stretch limousine, the police came over to check out the situation. "They don't expect to see a big stretch limo up here," Dr. Gurian said.

SEPARATE BUT EQUAL: It was the routine task of selecting a jury for a trial that provoked a legal settlement of dispute over whether Marble Hill is part of Manhattan or the Bronx. In May, 1984, State Supreme Court Judge Peter J. McQuillan ruled that a Marble Hill woman could not sit on a jury in a New York County murder case, holding that legislative boundaries for the borough and the county were defined differently and that the woman was a Bronx County resident. Judge McQuillan's decision alarmed Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morganthau, who feared it would enable criminal convictions to be challenged if a Marble Hill resident were convicted of a crime in the wrong jurisdiction or if a Marble Hill resident had sat on a jury in the wrong county. To end the confusion, Assemblyman J. Brian Murtaugh and State Senator Franz Leichter sponsored legislation declaring Marble Hill "part of the Island of Manhattan . . . regardless of the construction of the Harlem Ship Canal." The legislation passed, its sole opposition coming from a handful of Bronx legislators.

HEADLINE: On Electronic Highway, Manhattan Is A Destination

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
YOU can't call it the software industry anymore, because its products go well beyond computer programs. Multimedia is too all-encompassing, while information technology seems to exclude entertainment products. Interactive technology probably comes closest, at least until some newly-coined expression -- infoware is a recent one -- takes hold.
But whatever this amorphous industry is called, the people who form its creative backbone -- the ones who dream up the steady stream of products flitting across the internet, powering business computers, starring in interactive television entertainment and fueling the insatiable lust for video games -- are flocking to this city. 
 Ask them why and, just like Willie Sutton robbed banks "because that's where the money is," they answer simply, "that's where the people are."
"The venture capitalists are here, Bell Labs is near here, the financial companies who were the earliest customers are here, the entertainment companies who are the latest customers are here," said Gail Kleinberg Koch, president of C/A/S Comsearch, an executive recruiting firm specializing in the on-line information and telecommunications industries. "And this is a young person's business, and the young people are here, too."
Nor are they content to trade ideas across the internet. "That creative process, where people sit around a room jamming out an idea, is invaluable to get a product's soul," said Michele A. DiLorenzo, president of Viacom New Media.
The influx represents a wonderful irony for the New York real estate industry, and a compound one at that. Interactive technology made it possible for Wall Street firms to ship their backoffice operations to New Jersey, for employees to telecommute from anywhere, for video conferences to replace farflung meetings, for companies to slash the amount of office space they need.
And that same convergence of computers, telephones and telecommunications fed industry's demand for huge floor plates, cable television hookups, huge amounts of electricity and air-conditioning, raised floors and dropped ceilings, the myriad architectural and infrastructure features whose lack has caused businesses to spurn any number of once-prestigious office buildings.
And now, the interactive technology companies are doing exactly what their products had apparently eliminated a need for: Clustering in New York so they can be with their customers, their suppliers and, yes, with each other. And, they are clustering in funky older buildings in SoHo and Midtown South that are vacant in good part because interactive technology rendered them obsolete.
"There's been this huge bubbling of companies south of 23d Street, and the growth is feeding on itself," said Carl Weisbrod, head of the Alliance for Downtown Manhattan, which hopes to lure many of the companies even further south, to the space-rich financial district. "The companies are attracted by the huge amount of creative talent, and the talented people are attracted by the large number of prospective employers."
Indeed, San Francisco's Silicon Alley and Boston's Route 128 still share a bicoastal lock on the production and operations end of the business, but as Red Burns, chair of the Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, put it, "They make machines in Silicon Valley, and machines do not have ideas, any more than a pen can write a novel."
By the same token, Hollywood remains the movie capital of the world, but when movies and other forms of old media are repackaged and sent forth onto the electronic highways, the entrance to those highways increasingly is here. Viacom New Media and Time Warner Interactive are here, the Sega Channel is here, Delphi Internet Services is here, and Prodigy, another huge on-line service, is coming to Manhattan soon.
"There's a tremendous concentration of entertainment software publishers in New York, so it follows that a whole subculture would grow up around them," said Douglas Lowenstein, president of the Washington, D.C.-based Interactive Digital Software Association.
And, face it -- the atmosphere is just, well, different in New York. "New York and San Francisco are the axes around which the creative world revolves, but I'm just too rambunctious for the West Coast," said Daniel Stechow, who started Brainstorm Interactive, a multimedia company, in Manhattan least year. Jonathan Herbert, the head of Computer Illustration, which makes computer generated images for commercials, is even more adamant: "I get narcolepsy whenever I leave this town," he said.
For landlords, the onslaught of the interactive technology companies is a mixed blessing. They generally rent just a few thousand feet -- yet because their staffs work odd hours, they require 7-day, 24-hour services and power. And small companies are known for high failure rates and shaky credit ratings.
"New York's future lies in high-tech brainpower, but the brainpower companies are so high-risk and use so little space that the buildings we represent are not targeting them yet," said David M. Gialanella, a senior managing director at Cushman & Wakefield.
But the interactive-technology companies can be a godsend to those landlords with outmoded or vacant buildings. "Many of the deals are small, but they soon add up," said Ira Schuman, an executive vice president of the Julien J. Studley brokerage.
Moreover, creative tenants simply are not that demanding. "These companies don't need redundancy, they don't need raised floors, they don't need uninterrupted power service," said Adam E. Krupp, senior vice president of CS Partners, a technology real estate consulting group in Jersey City.
Nor do they need luxury, which makes them particularly tasty prospects for owners of downscale buildings. "These are nontraditional people with nontraditional work habits, and if the air-conditioning isn't working, they'll open a window," said David W. Levinson, executive managing director of the Edward S. Gordon real estate company.
NOT surprisingly, many landlords are actively pursuing even the smallest and newest companies. Rudin Management just offered its vacant building at 55 Broad Street, the former home of Drexel Burnham Lambert, as an industry building for high-tech firms. Manhattan Community College donated 5,000 square feet of space at 30 Broadway for an incubator for five small companies. The Sylvan Lawrence Company, the new leasing agents for 665 Broadway, at Bond Street, are marketing the newly renovated building as "located in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, a well-known location for technology companies."
In the first half of this year Newmark Realty leased close to 190,000 square feet to interactive technology firms in its buildings. "A lot of them cannot pay a great deal in rent, but my gut tells me they represent a market that is ready to crystallize," said Barry Gosin, Newmark's president.
Audrey Novoa's instincts tell her the same thing. Ms. Novoa, a Williams Real Estate managing director, handles leasing at 60 Hudson Street, the telecommunications industry building at Thomas Street. She is actively courting smaller telecommunications-oriented tenants. "So if they have lousy credit we'll rent them four walls, with minimum buildout," she said.
Of course, the handful of well-established interactive-technology companies offer landlords the best of all worlds. Not surprisingly, many are trying to snag Prodigy. The on-line service is based in White Plains, but plans to move about 50 creative people to Manhattan, probably to SoHo. Its new chief executive, Edward Bennett, lives here, but Carol A. Wallace, Prodigy's spokeswoman, insists that is not the reason for the move.
"This is a young industry that has to focus on creating the best content," Ms. Wallace said. "Extra dollars for Manhattan rents are insignificant compared to access to the people who can do this."
Delphi is closing its Cambridge, Mass., headquarters for similar reasons. It is moving the operations side of its business to Lowell, Mass., near Route 128. Creative types are going into a big open-office layout at 620 Avenue of the Americas, the Ladies' Mile building between 18th and 19th Streets that houses Bed, Bath & Beyond.
"We offered a variety of metropolitan locations, but they quickly narrowed in on Manhattan," said Mr. Levinson, who found Delphi its 75,000 square foot space.
"Our products," explained a Delphi spokeswoman, "may build communities that are not restricted by geographic boundaries, but our industry is in that early stage where you have to build relationships."
Even companies that are happily based elsewhere are opening outposts here. Sega, the video-game giant, has no plans to move from Redwood City, Calif., but its new Sega Channel, which offers video games via cable television, is here. "The cable operators are in New York, and that's who we sell to," said Thomas J. Kalinske, Sega's chief executive.
Of course, some companies are in the vicinity purely by choice. GT Interactive Software, the publisher of the hugely successful "Doom" video game, operates out of 16 East 40th Street because its owners own the building. "The bottom line is, we are all from New York and we stayed here," said Ron Chaimowitz, the chief executive.
Long Island has held onto major interactive technology players for the same reason. Acclaim, which publishes the equally successful "Mortal Kombat" video game, started in Oyster Bay, L.I., and recently expanded to nearby Glen Cove. Computer Associates, the huge business software producer, has moved several times, but always within an easy commute of Garden City, where Charles Wong started the company.
"Their main concern has always been to be near where the key people lived," said August A. DiRenzo, a Cushman & Wakefield vice chairman who has been the company's broker for more than a decade.
NOT surprisingly, New York City officials and landlords, particularly those in beleaguered lower Manhattan, are not content to be ruled by historic geography. Nor are they satisfied with the steady flow of interactive technology companies to New York.
They cite studies that show that many of the smallest firms still shun New York because of high taxes and rents, difficulty getting loans, and equal difficulty finding a highly skilled work force. The result, they say, is that as fast as the interactive-technology industry is growing in New York, it is still growing faster elsewhere.
City Hall is looking for ways to catch up. In January Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced the NYC Discovery Fund, a venture-capital fund with mixed public and private funding, aimed at developing high-technology industries. Consolidated Edison and Brooklyn Union Gas have each committed $5 million to the fund.
"This is a chance to help an industry that can replace the manufacturers that have left," said Carol M. Conflato, a section manager of economic development for Con Ed.
The city and several private companies are also trying to find cheap places for that industry to grow. One frontrunner: a new New York Information Technology Center at 55 Broad Street. Originally the Center was slated for half of the 400,000 square foot building, but officials say that interest from potential tenants has been high enough to warrant dedicating the entire building.
"The overriding intent is to create an incubator, a facility where these companies can come together to do their creative work," said Carl G. Symon, general manager of the northeastern area for I.B.M.-North America, which is providing design help for the building.
The Center, originally slated for 11 Broadway, switched over to the Rudin building when Mel Schnell, the co-owner of 11 Broadway who had wanted the center, died, and Moses Marx, the partner who had preferred sticking to conventional rentals, pulled out of the deal.
The Rudins say they will pump more than $15 million into the building, to put in assorted technological bells and whistles, including enhanced electric power systems and four types of telecommunications systems -- voice-grade copper wire, which telephones run on; high-speed wire, which provides speedier access to the Internet; single mode fiberoptics, which can transmit huge volumes of data, like that generated by traders, at the speed of light; and multimode fiberoptics, which is capable of transmitting even denser volumes of data, such as full-motion video and music, at light speed.
"We want this to be a 'plug-and-play' place, where any tenant can inexpensively hook into the Internet," said William C. Rudin, Rudin Management's president.
The center will hold lobby trade shows, provide conference facilities, perhaps even offer purchasing and marketing services so that the small tenants can get the volume discounts usually reserved for big companies. And it will provide all of this at annual per-square-foot rents in the mid-teens.
"These companies are taking their first leaps from lofts and backyards and garages into real office space," said Mr. Weisbrod. "If we charged even $20 a foot, it could be a real problem."
Jonathan and Wesley Rudes, the two brothers in charge of leasing the center, say they have been premarketing it for two years, and have a list of 500 tenants who have expressed interest.
But they concede that the new center has some hard-to-overcome negatives. It is in the kind of glass-box building that many creative types despise. And it is in a neighborhood that still rolls up its sidewalks at night and on weekends. Prodigy, for one, is not even considering locating in lower Manhattan. "We want an older building with a lot of character, in a community that feels alive at any time of day or night," Ms. Wallace said.
THE Rudes brothers acknowledge the problems. "These companies want open spaces with hardwood floors and high ceilings and lots of light and color," said Wes Rudes. He hopes to use paint, dropped ceilings, a "high-tech lobby" and other cosmetic changes to "make this glass and steel place look funky and functional."
He also hopes that a few high-profile tenants will help create a critical mass. I.B.M. and Nynex, for example, both may put research and development facilities in the building, and may provide reduced-rate equipment for tenants. And the New York New Media Association, which Brian T. Horey, a local venture capitalist, started in October, also plans to move down.
That could help generate activity, too. The association, which already has close to 1,300 members, runs several monthly seminars and networking events, ranging from guided tours of the Internet to primers on interactive music to dance parties at the Roxy.
"Our association can bring a community together that is now fragmented in a lot of different pockets," Mr. Horey said.
Mr. Horey meant it metaphorically, but several large New York corporations, including Nynex, Con Ed and I.B.M., have forged an alliance to turn 55 Broad into the epicenter of a much wider physical community. Con Ed, for example, has hired an architect to study whether four buildings -- 55, 60, 67 and 70 Broad Street, which together encompass 2.5 million square feet -- could work together as a high-tech center. The idea is to have the different owners share emergency power systems and other costly technologies, as well as coordinate amenities: If one puts in a deli downstairs, the other should put in a dry cleaner, the third a restaurant, and so forth.
If that proves feasible, it might go a long way to overcoming the neighborhood's isolation. And that, in turn, could create the type of technology enclave in lower Manhattan that Mr. Weisbrod, for one, believes can restore the neighborhood to the boom days it once had.
"It is a gamble, but a calculated gamble," Mr. Weisbrod said. "I think it will be a super home run."

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Truckers Carve a New Route, Crowding a Two-Lane Road

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: EAST AMWELL TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
It seemed like some kind of long-distance magic trick. In November 1993, transportation officials cut the ribbon on the last link of Interstate 287 in northern Passaic County. Fifty miles away, on the other side of the state, tractor-trailers began to inundate a two-lane road.
But what happened is not really much of a mystery. The completion of I-287 created a toll-free alternative to the New Jersey Turnpike for north- and southbound interstate truckers, a route that includes a nine-mile stretch of Route 31 in Hunterdon and Mercer Counties. The 287 link, coupled with several more recent road projects authorized by the state, more than tripled truck traffic along the two-lane portion of Route 31 within 18 months, from 900 trucks a weekday to more than 3,000 a day in March. 
 All this without any improvements to the piece of road itself, a hilly, curvy stretch that winds through a patchwork of houses, cornfields, small businesses and woods in East Amwell and Hopewell Townships.
The resulting mess, residents and local officials say, shows what happens when state planners upgrade some parts of a road system but not others: three fatal accidents involving trucks in the last four months; lines of trucks that make a left turn next to impossible; trucks going too slow and boxing in cars; entire fleets giving the road the appearance of a convoy.
dd "What we've got," said John Mack, an East Amwell Township Committeeman, "is a death-causing piece of public policy that really proves the bureaucrats are sound asleep at the wheel."
State officials acknowledge that the truck congestion is a problem but have no proposals on the table to reduce it, though they do plan to reconfigure some intersections. The Department of Transportation gave up a campaign to turn the stretch into a four-lane divided highway years ago in the face of opposition from residents who feared that the widening would simply attract more traffic.
"What we're looking at at this point is potential speed limit reductions, stepped-up truck safety and that is it," said Jeff Lamm, a spokesman for the Transportation Department.
Before the completion of I-287, the usual route through New Jersey for trucks coming up from Delaware and points south was to cross at the Delaware Memorial Bridge, head north on some combination of the turnpike and I-295, and take the George Washington Bridge into New York.
Now trucks can stay on I-95 through Pennsylvania, cross into New Jersey north of Trenton, take Route 31 to 202 near Flemington and ride I-287 from Somerville up to New York State, crossing the Hudson at the Tappan Zee Bridge.
The route can save more than $61 a round trip, and allows New England-bound truckers to bypass the terror-inducing Cross Bronx Expressway without losing any time.
I-287 isn't the only thing tempting 18-wheelers westward. The treacherous Somerville Circle, where 202 meets I-287, was replaced this year with a system of high-speed flyovers, and workers completed several improvements around the capital collectively known as the Trenton Complex. A study by the Transportation Department predicted that the Trenton Complex would reduce truck traffic on Route 31 slightly. Instead, volume has jumped by a thousand trucks a day.
Nor is the congestion confined to Route 31. Route 206, which passes through Princeton as it links I-295 near Trenton to I-287, has also seen a jump in truck traffic. At a jammed regional meeting on the problem in Princeton on June 29, citizens complained that trucks were spilling onto residential streets, too.
Residents are quick to point out they're not the only losers. Though transportation officials note that truck traffic throughout the state has increased during the last two years of economic boom, most of the newcomers to Route 31 are trucks that used to take the turnpike for at least part of their trip. Even assuming that the average Route 31 trucker is skirting a very modest $7 in turnpike tolls (the fare from the Delaware Memorial Bridge to the George Washington is $20.80), the state is losing more than $5 million in toll revenue a year.
State Highway 31 is not a country lane. It is the biggest north-south road on the western side of the state, and it carries plenty of traffic between the suburban sprawl around Flemington and the Route 1 corridor from Princeton to Trenton.
But it is no limited-access throughway either. There are several dozen residential driveways along the stretch, many of them in the middle of curves. School buses still stop along its broad shoulders.
"D.O.T. talks about speed checks and checking brakes," said William E. Schluter, the State Senator whose district straddles Route 31, "but we're not talking about individual safety violations and carelessness as much as the vast numbers and the dominance of the road. It is very, very unsafe."
Mr. Mack, the East Amwell committeeman, and others have proposed banning trucks from the road, but such a move would mean the loss of Federal funds for a highway bypass in Flemington. Assemblywoman Shirley Turner has recommended cutting the tolls on the turnpike in half -- a proposal endorsed, not surprisingly, by the American Truckers Association -- but even then, the I-287 route would still be cheaper because of differences in bridge tolls.
Now, Mr. Mack said, even if the Transportation Department decided to make Route 31 a dual highway, it would take 12 years. Meanwhile, the trucks continue to barrel down the road.
"I would love to be able to wave a wand and keep trucks off there and have another North Jersey route, maybe in somebody else's district," Mr. Schluter said. "But the number of trucks seems like it's only going to increase as they seek that route that is faster, less costly and saner."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The Layoff Business: How Popular Is It?

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON; Iver peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: LAWRENCE

 BODY:
The school board here in suburban Trenton is talking about getting rid of its staff of school janitors and maintenance workers and replacing them with cheaper services from commercial cleaning companies, and thereby hangs a wider tale about what is going on in New Jersey these days as Governor Whitman's cuts in taxes and controls on state spending work their way down from the capital to the local level.
The district, prosperous and middle class in a state full of prosperous, middle class places, has seen its state aid reduced by hundreds of thousands of dollars at a time when enrollments are once again creeping upward. In earlier years, this pincer movement would have won a sympathetic ear from Trenton and from local taxpayers, who for a decade dutifully passed higher and higher school budgets while the Governor and Legislature down by the Delaware River, whether Republican or Democrat, also dutifully passed on higher and higher levels of state aid. 
 In the process, school boards like Lawrence's also generously began running up the wages and benefits of teachers and nonteachers alike until per-pupil school spending in New Jersey became the highest in the country.
The economic bust of 1990 put an end to the rising incomes and property values that fueled this spiral, but it took the rookie politician in the Governor's office, elected in 1993, to challenge the political culture that grew up around it.
For a while, a lot of people, especially Democrats, assumed hopefully that the Whitman phenomenon would unravel when local taxes began to rise as a result of cuts in state income taxes, the source of money earmarked by the constitution to offset local taxes. What they had not grasped was that ideas, like money, also percolate downward.
The Lawrence Board of Education got that message in April of last year when their proposed budget, with a 4 percent increase in spending, was rejected for the first time in years.
"One thing we learned is that the public has grown more sensitive to spending and taxes, absolutely," said Dennis Casale, president of the town Board of Education. "Another is that the state has put out a number of recommendations that make it clear that they intend to look at costs that do not go into the classroom, and that if they deem those costs to be excessive, those districts are going to be penalized."
Well, custodians are not classroom employees, the board reasoned, and like the Governor turning the operation of motor vehicle offices over to private contractors, the board began talking to private janitorial concerns. What they found was bad news for public employees: instead of the $15 an hour the board was paying custodians, private firms paid $8 or $9, amounting to savings of close to $500,000 a year for the district. This is a mouth-watering sum to school managers who are being squeezed by state cutbacks above and tax-averse voters below.
Like a lot of schools, Lawrence has already made cuts in sports programs, laid off some administrators, reduced library staffs, and now it looks as if it will be the custodians' turn to feel the inexorable logic of cost containment, although Mr. Casale said the board would help them get jobs with the private contractor, and transition payments to soften the loss of income for a while.
The Governor would no doubt agree with the Board's move. After all, she said last month, you can't expect government to support jobs for their own sake. "It's unfair to the taxpayers and its bad government," she said.
But if laying off workers is good politics, is it also good public policy? Richard Leone, a former Democratic state treasurer and fierce critic of Mrs. Whitman's program, is vehement.
"Institutions are not built on savings alone," he said in an interview. "Henry Ford recongnized that his workers had to make enough to be able to afford one of his cars. Bismarck recognized that there needed to be some level of social security or there would be unrest. Now we have a theory that if we lay off enough people we'll all be rich? I don't think so."
So far, New Jerseyans seem to be siding with the Governor on that debate, partly because they believe her when she says that cutting public spending will boost the economy. In the process, however, they should remember that a lot of the savings are being taken out of other people's paychecks.

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
For Safety's Sake and Their Own, Towns Learn to Pamper Pedestrians

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
New Jersey municipalities used to be primarily concerned with moving traffic through town as quickly as possible. Now that concern is shifting -- from cars and trucks to people on foot.
By state law, motorists must yield to pedestrians in crosswalks. But unlike California, where drivers actually do yield -- and are universally berated if they don't -- New Jersey seldom enforces the law. 
 Now, as communities seek to revive aging downtowns or preserve thriving ones, more and more of them are looking for ways to pamper their pedestrians. In Mercer County, Princeton has added zebra-striped crosswalks, brick markings and signs to remind motorists that pedestrians, not motorists, have the right of way. Other towns and cities are adding midblock crosswalks and yield signs; making it easier to get to the bus or train; emphasizing pedestrian issues in planning documents; making downtown businesses more attractive and accessible.
"There's a whole movement to give the downtown back to the pedestrian," said Mayor Marvin Reed of Princeton. "The old-fashioned town where you can walk to places is certainly coming back into vogue."
Peter Calthorpe, owner of Calthorpe Associates, an urban design and architecture firm in San Francisco, says the same thing is happening in cities and towns across the country. "We need to develop places that are more community-oriented and that we have to move back to a more human-scale environment," he said. "Pedestrians are fundamental to that."
Because New Jersey is so densely populated, it is far more prone than most states to pedestrian accidents: they make up more than a fifth of all traffic deaths, compared to a nationwide average of 13 percent. And perhaps for that reason, New Jersey towns are among the pioneers in raising awareness of pedestrians.
"We're knocking them off left and right, and it's the No. 1 problem we have," said Col. Peter J. O'Hagan, director of the State Division of Highway Traffic Safety. "Pedestrian safety has to be done at the local level, and this is something that more towns are starting to realize."
Just ask Michael Gentile, a salesman for L & C Flashing Barricades of Canton, Mass., which makes the increasingly familiar yellow, red and white signs that say, "State Law: Stop for Pedestrians in Crosswalk."
"New Jersey is by far my biggest seller," said Mr. Gentile, who estimated that he has done business with 25 towns. "It's definitely been a pleasant surprise, because we never expected to expand to that area and we don't even have a salesman who deals with New Jersey."
Among L & C's recent customers was Leonia, which placed three such signs on Broad Avenue in June. That borough is also considering whether to form a pedestrian review committee to evaluate development projects and zoning changes, said Tom Toronto, a Leonia Councilman.
Similar signs have popped up in Somerville, Ridgewood and Maplewood. In Millburn, the signs have been put up every Friday since June 23 in front of the Farmers Market.
And the signs are only the easy part. South Orange plans to widen downtown sidewalks and pave its crosswalks with brick, and it is considering adding pedestrian islands on South Orange Avenue.
"Before, the popular myth was that highway funds were free, and so the tendency was to widen the road at the expense of the sidewalk," said Lawrence Houstoun, principal of the Atlantic Group, an urban development consulting firm in Cranbury that has been advising South Orange. "But downtown commerce is not a drive-through window; it's a park-once, move-around-on-foot kind of destination."
In West Orange, several ideas are on the table, according to Susan Berg, director of planning and development: denying requests to waive requirements for sidewalks of a certain width; rewriting the municipal master plan to accommodate pedestrians; requiring developers to prepare plans that include pedestrian access.
In Woodbridge, New Jersey Transit recently renovated a train station, complete with brick-paved crosswalks, historic lampposts and other touches to encourage walkers. In Plainfield, there are plans for a pedestrian-oriented commercial zone near the Netherwood rail station.
Some officials say such measures are all very well, but they warn that pedestrian safety is more than signs and crosswalks. They point out that one-third of the pedestrians killed in traffic accidents are walking drunk. "I think that the more these signs show up, the more pedestrians will have a false sense of security," said Anthony Parenti, president of the New Jersey Police Traffic Officers Association.
Even so, Mr. Parenti and others agree that this is as good a time as any to pay attention to pedestrians.
"Towns are spending a lot of time thinking about being livable, and quality is hot on the municipal agenda," said Chester P. Mattson, director of Bergen County's Department of Planning and Economic Development. "The idea that you have a town center through which you can walk is becoming very attractive to communities."

HEADLINE: HOUSING;
Crackdown on Illegal Housing Collides With a Tradition of Helping Others

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Last December, fire raced through a crowded single-family house in Orange that had been illegally divided into at least three apartments. Fire officials are still not sure how many people were living there -- they say at least 17 -- but 9 died in the flames, their efforts to escape thwarted at least in part by the lack of fire exits.
Since that blaze, and another one three weeks later in nearby Irvington that killed 3 of the 18 inhabitants of a one-family house, officials in several communities have cracked down on illegal apartments and rooming houses. 
 Officials in Orange and East Orange say most people living in illegal apartments are immigrants, mostly Caribbean -- the victims of both fatal fires were from Haiti -- and that the effort to end overcrowding has pitted zoning and safety codes against cultural traditions of extended family.
"If you're from Haiti or the Dominican Republic," said Ronald Salahuddin, director of housing code enforcement for East Orange, "and someone you know is coming into the area and has no place to stay, what are you going to do? You invite them in, and before you know it you have all these people living in one apartment."
"A lot of these people are just not aware of the laws and regulations, that you just can't have four or five people living in one or two rooms," he said.
Though they are sympathetic, Mr. Salahuddin and other officials say they can't afford to risk lives. And so teams of inspectors have been dispatched to look for telltale signs of extra apartments carved out of basements, attics and other areas without permission of zoning boards -- drapes hung in cellar windows, extra mailboxes, new entrances, additional utility meters.
In six months of increased inspections, East Orange officials have found 250 illegal dwellings in a city of 73,000 people. Most of the offending owners eliminated the apartments, but 40 property owners ignored their summonses and wound up in court.
In Orange itself, James Slaughter, the director of planning and development, said efforts to get residents to notify officials of overcrowded buildings has netted 20 violators so far.
"We've essentially tried to encourage people to rat each other out," he said. "Citizens turning in other citizens."
Officials in Irvington have started taking out newspapers ads urging residents to file complaints when they know of illegal dwellings. And David Fuller, the township business administrator, says the municipal court is levying heavier fines against property owners who deliberately rent out illegal apartments. State law allows fines of up to $1,000 for illegal rental, with additional fines of up to $1,000 a day.
Haitian community leaders called overcrowding an unfortunate necessity.
"In some places there will always be more people living in a place than they should, and I think that has more to do with economics than anything else," said the Rev. Emmanes Doxy, president of the Great Commission Learning Center in East Orange, which offers services to Essex County's 10,000 Haitians.
Not all the property owners caught in the sweep were just trying to help out family members. East Orange shut down four unlicensed rooming houses, one of whose owners had squeezed nine families into a house meant for two.
"You have a variety of things," Mr. Salahuddin said. "You have those who aren't consciously trying to break the law, and then you have those that purposely break the law to make money."
State law forbids the creation of any new dwelling units without local approval. In addition, many municipalities -- including Orange and East Orange -- have minimum living space ordinances. Both cities require 150 square feet for the initial occupant and 100 more square feet for each additional occupant.
The effort to get rid of firetraps has been educational as well as punitive. The Orange Fire Department has given out 1,100 free smoke detectors this year, along with lessons on how to use them. East Orange and Orange officials have been distributing fire safety pamphlets printed in English, Spanish and Creole and have visited schools to teach children the basics of fire safety.
State officials say the demand for very inexpensive housing has risen in New Jersey cities as immigration, both legal and illegal, has soared. Many immigrants, for various reasons, do not qualify for public assistance or housing.
At the same time, the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs, citing widespread violations, has closed down nearly half of the boarding houses in the state over the past decade.
"Some of them were illegal, some were substandard, and some of them were toilets," said Robert Friant, spokesman for the Department of Community Affairs.
Mr. Friant said rents at boarding houses, which typically provide meals or other services, run $400 to $450 a month, while rooming houses, which simply rent rooms, charge about $100 less. Currently, there are 1,538 licensed rooming houses in the state with 18,167 beds, and 277 boarding houses with 5,867 beds.
And what happens to a tenant who is forced out of illegal housing? If the building was condemned, the tenant could be eligible for up to $4,800 in state relocation grants over three years. If the building is not condemned, some towns provide emergency moving expenses, $500 in the case of East Orange.
Deborah Middleton, housing director at the nonprofit Isaiah House, East Orange's only shelter, said she did not know of any clients who had come to the shelter as a result of being evicted from an illegal apartment. And officials in both Oranges say most displaced tenants eventually legal housing.
"We're not cold with these people," Mr. Salahuddin said. "We give them something so they at least can move, even if it's the Y.M.C.A. for a month. If somene is living in an illegal basement or attic, even if we're making them leave their apartment, we're giving them their life."

This building on South Essex Street in Orange was cited for having an illegal apartment. (Lenore Victoria Davis for The New York Times)
