HEADLINE: The Day the Jobs Got Up and Moved Away

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: EAST WINDSOR

 BODY:
HERE among the open fields and winding roads of suburban Mercer County, a sprawling steel and brown-brick factory has long provided jobs for hundreds of people, from janitors to rocket scientists. Opened by RCA in 1958, it foreshadowed a regional economy that would flourish in the 1970's and 80's, as office buildings and corporate campuses sprang up between Princeton and Trenton.
But in recent months, what was once the unthinkable became the inevitable: the Lockheed Martin Corporation, the current owner of the East Windsor factory, joined three other major employers to announce plans to leave Mercer, taking a total of 5,400 jobs. The losses amounted to 3,200 positions at Lockheed, which designs and manufactures spacecraft; 900 at the Mobil Corporation's research and development office in Hopewell Junction; 800 at Hill Refrigeration in Trenton, and 500 at a condom factory owned by Carter-Wallace, also in Trenton. 
 To make matters worse, Governor Whitman eliminated 1,200 state jobs in May, including hundreds in Mercer County. All told, the losses make up 3.6 percent of the county's 199,000 jobs.
Economists say the pullouts reflect a devastating case of bad timing. But they represent something much more: the latest and most alarming reminder of the stress on New Jersey's economy, which, like most of its Northeastern neighbors, has watched helplessly in the last few years as a nationwide trend toward leaner corporations moved some high-tech jobs (particularly in the oil and defense industries) out of the region and permanently elminated jobs in manufacturing.
"Simply the scale of the closings that have been announced make it seem like a real high-tech hit on the New Jersey economy," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "But this is part of the broad restructuring that is going on everywhere."
Dr. Hughes said the corporate departures would not permanently damage Mercer County's economy, which has always been bolstered by the presence of Princeton University and the state government. But they will certainly play a role in reshaping it, as manufacturing jobs are phased out and service-sector jobs -- whether they be at fast-food restaurants or consulting firms -- multiply.
In some ways, the job cuts in Mercer County reflect a situation New Jersey has been battling for decades: the decline of manufacturing jobs. But now, besides that, Mercer, which has one of the highest concentrations of high-tech industries in the state, has found itself hostage to corporate forces that in part are beyond its control: the need to consolidate jobs to places where operating costs are less onerous. Many of the scientists and engineers working for Mobil and Lockheed will be transferred to other sites, and the rest may find new opportunities in the county's growing high-tech sector. But Carter-Wallace and Hill employees who have spent their lives in manufacturing jobs might not be so lucky.
The state has lost almost 300,000 factory jobs since 1979, and only 500,000 remain, according to the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. Unless they receive intensive training for other work, factory workers have few options beyond low-wage jobs in the retail and service sectors.
"The manufacturing workers are never going to find an equivalent job," Dr. Hughes said. "The real disaster is for them, because their incomes will be permanently reduced."
The search for solutions promises to be difficult, in part because officials here are more accustomed to curbing development than encouraging it. Mercer County's suburbs flourished in the 1980's, even as its one city, Trenton, was struggling. In fact, development was so rapid that it was curtailed with strict zoning laws.
But now, as the last manufacturing jobs trickle out of Trenton, Mercer County is wondering how to help thousands of assembly-line workers make the transition to a high-tech economy. Meanwhile, as New Jersey towns receive less state and Federal money, they are fighting to keep the businesses they have and attract more. While the retail and service sectors are doing well, there is increasing pressure to lure pharmaceuticals, telecommunications companies and other corporate giants -- no small feat given the state's stringent regulations and high taxes and labor costs.
"We are lagging behind other states in being business friendly, and there's no magic bullet to change things dramatically," Dr. Hughes said. "It's going to be a long, slow process."
INDUSTRY
The Bottom Line
 Emotions are running high in Mercer County these days, and everyone has an opinion about the cause and effect of the abrupt, severe job cuts. But as the debate intensifies, the voices of corporate executives are conspicuously silent.
Beyond a few terse press releases, Carter-Wallace, Hill, Lockheed and Mobil have offered scant explanation for their decisions to leave the county. Their announcements, which came between December and June, were similar in theme: "downsizing" was essential, and the directive to cut costs precluded staying in central New Jersey.
"We are in a fiercely competitive business environment, and changes in the way we run our business are essential to our future," the Mobil chairman, Lucio A. Noto, said when he announced the cuts on May 2. "Failure to change means failure to compete in the long term."
For both Mobil and Lockheed, the job cuts reached far beyond Mercer County. Mobil's decision to close its research center in Hopewell Junction was part of a plan to lay off 4,700 workers, or more than 9 percent of its work force. And Lockheed's East Windsor factory was among the 12 corporations designated for closing last month. That consolidation will eliminate 12,000 jobs and eventually save $1.8 billion a year, the company said.
Charles Manor, a Lockheed spokesman, said the decision to leave East Windsor had everything to do with savings at a time when the defense industry is fighting for survival. The company, he said, will save millions of dollars by moving its operations at East Windsor and another plant in Valley Forge, Pa., to a larger, more modern site in Sunnyvale, Calif.
In Mobil's case, the company will lay off 250 of its Hopewell employees and transfer 650 to Paulsboro, in Sussex County, or Dallas. Mobil officials have said it would have cost twice as much to move the Paulsboro employees to Hopewell, because that plant is larger and has an attached refinery.
Mobil, which opened its Hopewell plant in 1959, wanted to build a small refinery there a decade ago, but the town would not allow it.
Dr. Hughes, the Rutgers economist, pointed out that both the Lockheed and Mobil buildings are almost 50 years old, and it made sense for both companies to choose more modern plants.
"These were among the first generation of suburban industrial facilities," he said. "Now they are lagging in basic infrastructure, and it's easier to build new ones from scratch."
Although Carter-Wallace and Hill are also abandoning aging plants, both in Trenton, they had another incentive to leave New Jersey, said Alan J. Steinberg, an assistant commissioner at the state Department of Commerce and Economic Development. Unlike Lockheed and Mobil, their work force was unionized, and the cost of labor will probably be much lower in Chesterfield, Va., where the two companies will have neighboring properties.
"Our labor costs are higher than average, and we're proud of that," Mr. Steinberg said. "We have an intelligent labor force used to a higher standard of living."
 
GOVERNMENT
'A Losing Game'
 If jobs are a political issue, losing 5,400 of them is fodder for endless recriminations. And Robert D. Prunetti, the Mercer County Executive, is at the center of the storm.
Mr. Prunetti is up for re-election this year, and his critics place the blame on his shoulders. Some say he did not communicate with executives at Lockheed and the three other corporations until it was too late. Others say he has not done enough to lure businesses in the way of tax relief and other incentives.
But Mr. Prunetti, a Republican who says he has focused on economic development since he took office in 1991, insists that the sudden departures were beyond his or any other government official's control.
"This is not a Mercer County problem, or even a New Jersey problem," Mr. Prunetti said. "Cost-cutting is the name of the game, and companies are going to go where they can make the most money with the tightest budget."
In the case of Lockheed, Mr. Prunetti prompted the state Economic Development Authority to offer a last-minute enticement in June, days before the corporation announced it was closing its East Windsor plant. The state offered to float bonds to pay for the expansion and upgrading of the plant. As part of the deal, New Jersey would pay for and hold title to the plant, leasing it back to Lockheed at favorable rates.
But Lockheed, Mr. Prunetti said, was determined to get out.
"The bottom line is, They were not interested," he said. "They had a facility in California that was only 25 percent occupied, and it made more sense to go there."
Dr. Hughes agrees that when it comes to retaining business, governments have limited means -- especially in a high-cost state like New Jersey.
"Incentives can become a losing game, and you can destroy your whole tax base," he said. "The cost of doing business in New Jersey weighs heavily against the state, and governments can only affect corporate decisions at the margin."
But that doesn't mean they can't try harder, Mr. Prunetti said, adding that his top priority is easing environmental and planning regulations and simplifying the process of getting permits.
"If a company goes to Virginia, it can be up and operating in six months," he said. "In New Jersey, it can take four years to get one permit."
While the loss of 5,400 jobs will be devastating, Mr. Prunetti said, it does not constitute an economic catastrophe. By summer's end, he said, Mercer County will have 2,400 new jobs: 1,200 in retail, 1,000 at a new post office in West Windsor and 200 at a medical diagnostics firm, also in West Windsor. The county's office space is 82 percent full, the highest rate since before the recession.
As for the workers losing jobs at Carter-Wallace, Hill, Lockheed and Mobil, the county recently started a program with job training and a job bank. An $800,000 grant from the Federal Department of Labor will be used to counsel and train the 800 Hill employees, and Mr. Prunetti hopes to obtain more money as the other layoffs occur.
But the main emphasis, he said, must be attracting new business.
"The best thing we can do," he said, "is be an advocate of people who want to come in here and create jobs."
 
LABOR
'Nothing in the Middle'
 As the July heat enveloped his small red house, Rick Moore drew on a cigarette and recalled his first day of work at Hill Refrigeration. The year was 1970, and he was fresh out of high school, counting on a long career at the company his father and grandfather had retired from. Over time he rose through the ranks, eventually becoming a supervisor and earning $40,000 a year.
Then last month, as Mr. Moore prepared to celebrate his 25th anniversary at the Trenton factory, his career ended abruptly. He is among 800 Hill employees losing their jobs as the company, which makes freezer units for grocery stores, prepares to move to Virginia. And no matter how long and hard the search, he does not expect to find a new job that pays as much as his old one.
"What kept people at Hill was job security, benefits and steady pay, but that kind of job is becoming extinct," said Mr. Moore, 43, who lives in Ewing with his wife and daughter. "There are Ivy League paychecks and minimum-wage paychecks, and nothing in the middle for people like me."
While he collects $400 a week in unemployment benefits, Mr. Moore is pinning his hopes on Mercer County's $800,000 grant to find new jobs for Hill workers. The idea is to prepare them for service-sector jobs, such as electrical contracting or computer repair, that will offer security as manufacturing jobs dwindle. But many of Mr. Moore's co-workers, he said, are not even aware that help is available, and he is skeptical that it will benefit more than a few.
"Most people won't take advantage of that money because they won't know how to access it," he said. "Even if they do train us in something new, all the jobs are moving to other states where it's easier to do business."
If Mr. Moore had his way, New Jersey would simplify its maze of regulations and Trenton would clean up old industrial sites to attract new manufacturing businesses. But his friend Jack Nealon, who has spent 14 years at Hill and will stay on until October, scoffs at his wishful thinking.
"America's changing and we've got to change with it," said Mr. Nealon, 44, who distributes parts for refrigeration units. "The answer is not another manufacturing job in another filthy factory."
There are no clear answers at this point, as Mr. Moore awaits calls from employment agencies and his wife works overtime at a textile company on Route 1. The prospect of staying in Mercer County is questionable, as more jobs require a college education and the cost of living continues to rise. Life was better in the 1960's, he said, when his father earned enough at Hill to live in Pennington, one of the county's most affluent towns.
"Twenty-five years ago it was a decent family business, a place to put your life into," he said. "If you didn't like working there, you could walk down the street and get another manufacturing job."
Mr. Moore said he would apply for government jobs, and if all else fails, he will consider a minimum-wage job at one of the new department stores along Route 1. But the possibility that he will never find another manufacturing job, he said, is jarring.
"I don't know anything else but labor," he said, lighting another cigarette. "Maybe this county isn't trying to squeeze out people like me, but it certainly isn't doing anything to save us."
 
 
A Scary Prospect: Growth
 MERCER COUNTYU is home to some of the quietest, most picturesque towns in New Jersey, and for good reason: in recent years, strict zoning laws have slowed the pace of development. Even densely populated towns like Princeton and Lawrence still have cornfields and lush, wooded areas.
 But as luring business to New Jersey becomes a priority, Mercer County is one of several that face a quandary: How to improve the local economy without compromising the quality of life that draws families and businesses there inthe first place?
 Many towns that hve resisted development are relaxing their zoning laws, suddenly eager to catch up with other parts of the state. West Windsor and Hamilton recently lifted sewer moratoriums that had stifled both residential and commercial growth, and now they are among the fastest-growing towns in the county, with subdivisions, shopping centers and office complexes in the works.
 The Mercer County Executive, Robert D. Prunetti, has advocated easing environmental regulations to encourage development. But planners at MSM Regional Council, which monitors growth inMerce, Somerset and Middlesex Counties, warn that such a policy could do more harm than good.
 "You can't just throw out regulations the way the fervor seems to be going," said Dianne Brake, president of the council. "Streamlining should be associated with certain areas that are prime for development."
 The best policy, Ms. Brake said, is to preserve small towns wiht little capacity for extra traffic and utilities, and focus on areas that already have plenty, like Hamilton and the heavily traveled Route 1 corridor between Princeton and Trenton. Route 1 will be widened over the next two years, and a maze of highways around Trenton, including I-195 and I-295, were recently connected.
 The connected highways will affect towns like Hopewell, whose proximity to the Mercer County Airport has made it a focus for future development. And Bristol Meyers-Squibb, a pharmaceutical company with headquarters in Lawrence, is developing an industrial complex on a 600-acre tract. Mr. Prunetti said the county is negotiating to expand Hopewell's sewage capacity, to accommodate the growth.
 Another focal point is Trenton - last year, Mercer County Waterfront Park with a 6,200-seat baseball stadium, opened along the Delaware River. And a 45-acre site known as the Roebling complex, which used to house factories, will be transformed into shops, offices, housing for the elderly and a 350-seat performing arts center.
 "I don't think we should have rampant development, but we've got to plan carefuly and designate certain areas for it," Mr. Prunetti said. "Towns need to understand they are part of a bigger picture, compromise and work together."
 That mindset appears to be growing more common, as towns that once thwarted development, like Hopewell, finally accept it.
 "All our municipal and county officials are very cooperative because frankly, everyone is scared," said Edward Meara, executive director of the Mercer County Chamber of Commerce. "The lack of development is starting to hit everyone's pocketbook." ABBY GOODNOUGH

Chart: Trenton Made, the World Took

Mercer: Fewer Goods, More Services
 
Like the rest of the state, Mercer County has lost manufacturing jobs while gaining service jobs. Over the last decade, total employment in the county has still registered a healthy gain -- 13 percent, to 198,800 nonfarm jobs. (The county's population grew 00 percent in the decade, to 000,000.) But many new service jobs -- in discount stores, warehouses and fast-food chains -- pay less than the old factory jobs did.

HEADLINE: Mr. Murdoch Goes To Washington

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A WEEK from Tuesday, Rupert Murdoch is scheduled to appear before the House ethics committee, where he will be grilled by Democrats about his company's lucrative book deal with the Republican House Speaker, Newt Gingrich. Over on the House floor that week, perhaps even that same day, Republican lawmakers will be trying to push through a major telecommunications bill that would, among other things, let the media baron buy still more television stations and newspapers in the United States.
In one sense, this is all in a week's notoriety for Mr. Murdoch -- a man fiercely admired by some as a brilliant entrepreneur and just as fiercely reviled by others as a harsh and domineering mogul. But the simple fact of this double-barreled, center-stage presence in Congress also represents a new phase in a remarkable career: After years as an outsider in the capital's whirl of money and politics, Mr. Murdoch has come to Washington. 
 It's not that he has become an avid habitue of the capital's dinner-party circuit, the latest darling of the conservative establishment. Still, in his characteristically aloof way, Mr. Murdoch and his Australia-based company, the News Corporation, have become increasingly visible, and influential, in this new Republican world.
"News Corporation is dramatically more active here than it was a few years ago," said Tim Boggs, Time Warner's top lobbyist in Washington. "A lot of it reflects the growing complexity of the company and its business plan, with interests in so many different areas."
Mr. Murdoch's efforts in Washington come at a crucial time for his company's expansionist ambitions. As ever, though, his interests and intentions are far from one-dimensional -- a mix of the financial, the political and the personal. He has ridden into town, so to speak, on a Republican deregulatory tide, and the welcome, after all those years in the wilderness, has been warm indeed. "It's been like pushing on an open door," said Peggy Binzel, Mr. Murdoch's Congressional lobbyist.
Though he didn't show up in person, Mr. Murdoch contributed $100,000 as one of nine honorary chairmen of a fund-raising dinner last month for House Republicans. Next month, he will sponsor a dinner for Senator Larry Pressler, the South Dakota Republican who heads the Commerce Committee.
He has invested $3 million to underwrite a new conservative weekly magazine in Washington called The Standard. The magazine, which should hit the stands shortly after Labor Day, will be edited by William Kristol, who was one of former Vice President Dan Quayle's top advisers and is considered one of the Republican Party's leading intellectual lights.
And though Mr. Murdoch's patronage of The Standard is unlikely to make him much money, it will place him in a role that he clearly savors: Like The New York Post, which is often stridently conservative, it will give him a piece of the political debate in one of the media capitals of the world.
But it is on the legislative and regulatory fronts where Mr. Murdoch has been most active, and where he has the most to gain.
To be sure, every segment of the tightly regulated communications industry lobbies and spends heavily on political contributions. Dollar for dollar, Mr. Murdoch's efforts pale when compared with those of the local and long-distance telephone companies as they struggle to enter each other's markets.
Yet Mr. Murdoch would be a big winner if Congress, as is expected, passes a telecommunications bill eliminating most of the rules that restrict a company from owning more than 12 television stations. To that end, his lobbyist, Ms. Binzel, organized a coalition with ABC, NBC, CBS and The Tribune Company that successfully persuaded the Senate to eliminate the numerical limits as long as a company's stations do not reach more than 35 percent of the population. The House version would also end prohibitions against owning a television station and a newspaper in the same city.
In an interview from Australia, where he has been holding a month-long management retreat, Mr. Murdoch said he was not seeking any special preferences. "We believe in deregulation whether it hurts us or helps us and we've been absolutely consistent about that. Deregulation is in the public interest."
On the regulatory side, Mr. Murdoch fended off efforts by the Federal Communications Commission to strictly enforce foreign ownership limits on his company. Those limits would have required the News Corporation to reduce its equity in its TV stations from 99 percent to 20 percent. Meantime, largely unnoticed -- except by his industry rivals -- Mr. Murdoch has successfully exploited peculiar features of the ownership rules to acquire 20 to 25 percent ownership stakes in stations and extend his reach to roughly 35 percent of the nation's population.
Preston Padden, the News Corporation's head of Government affairs, says those who look for a "grand plan" in Mr. Murdoch's Washington activities will be disappointed.
"There is no strategic planning group, no floor of M.B.A.'s," he said. "It's Rupert waking up earlier than his competition with eight great ideas before breakfast."
Still, the deregulation of broadcast ownership seems to cut to the heart of Mr. Murdoch's ambitions. For while Mr. Murdoch's global empire includes newspapers, the Twentieth Century Fox studio, book publishers and stakes in broadcasting satellites in Europe and Asia, the biggest profits are coming from American television stations.
"America is very much the basis of News Corporation's activities," Mr. Murdoch said .And that means television stations. "Networks do not make a lot of money, but the stations they own do," he said. "If you look at Capital Cities/ABC, the stations make about four times as much money as the network."
There are those, many of them Democrats, who say that in this new political climate, Mr. Murdoch has become too involved -- most notably in his $4.5 million book deal with Mr. Gingrich, the Georgia Republican. Mr. Murdoch met with Mr. Gingrich several weeks before the book contract was signed, and acknowledged discussing his battle with the F.C.C. over foreign ownership rules. But he has vehemently denied trying to enlist Mr. Gingrich's support and said his company did not lobby in Congress on that issue at all.
Mr. Murdoch has shown scant interest in windy debates about the "information highway," and has testified at almost none of the scores of Congressional hearings on communications policy during the last few years.
In fact, he said his company had played no role at all on the most important segments of the telecommunications bill, which is primarily aimed at letting local telephone, long-distance companies and cable television networks enter one another's markets.
And he actually parted ways with other over-the-air broadcasters in recent months, who have been lobbying Congress for legislation to prevent cable television operators from burying their channels when they offer menus with more than 100 video services.
But the News Corporation was ferocious and successful in fighting the F.C.C. on complaints that the company violated rules that forbid a foreign company from owning more than 20 percent of an American television station.
In April, the F.C.C.'s staff circulated a confidential draft order that would have forced the company to reduce its equity in the stations to 20 percent and would have fined it $500,000.
"We can think of few circumstances that could be more intuitively contrary to the Congressional interest in safeguarding national security," the draft order read. Though it gave Mr. Murdoch a chance to show that an exception to the rules would be in the public interest, the draft order concluded that an exception "is inconsistent with the public interest in this case."
After news organizations reported about the draft order, company executives said that a restructuring would impose hundreds of millions of dollars in tax liabilities. The company had already deluged the agency with legal briefs, along with testimonials from programmers and stations that had signed up as Fox network affiliates. The company had even persuaded several former F.C.C. officials to recant statements that they had not understood Fox's ownership structure at the time the company's licenses were approved.
Within the F.C.C., a majority of the agency's five commissioners drastically revised the original recommendation. Led by Commissioner James Quello, a Democrat who argued that the News Corporation had greatly enhanced the public interest by launching a fourth national television network, the final order backed away from explicit demands for restructuring or fines and three of the commissioners said that Fox had enhanced the public interest.
Meantime, in the last 18 months, Fox television stations have signed deals to acquire stakes of 20 to 25 percent in 17 stations. All told, these stations reach about 35 percent of the population -- a wider reach than ABC, NBC or CBS have with their company-owned stations.
"He has pioneered creative ownership relationships and taken advantage of F.C.C. rules to become the No. 1 stakeholder in American television stations," said Gerald Waldron, a lawyer for affiliates of ABC, NBC and CBS.
Yet, despite loud protests by both NBC and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which objected on grounds that Mr. Murdoch's efforts were preventing minorities from gaining ownership of television stations, those stations will not be counted against the current limit of 12 stations. That is because the F.C.C.'s arcane rules allow a company to own as much as 49 percent of a station, without it being counted against ownership limits, if a single company owns the other 51 percent.
Mr. Murdoch supports eliminating rules that prohibit companies from owning a newspaper and a television station in one market. But he said he was unsure about the wisdom of buying more papers.
"I love newspapers and I would love to have one or two more," he said. "But I don't know if I could justify it economically to my shareholders. At the moment, the newspapers are about to go into a period of extreme suffering because of high paper prices and it's likely to last for a long time."
Mr. Murdoch said that even he is unsure what the company will do next. He recently made a multi-billion-dollar offer to acquire the extensive television holdings of Italy's Fininvest, owned by Silvio Berlusconi. Mr. Murdoch was rebuffed, which leaves him scouring the globe once again.
Broadly, however, he seems intent on expanding the amount of entertainment and information his company produces and then finding new channels of distribution. The Fox television stations constitute the foundation of his American operations. In Europe, Mr. Murdoch is beaming television programming to homes by satellite over British Sky Broadcasting. In Asia, News Corporation owns a 63 percent stake in Star TV, a direct broadcast satellite that covers much of the continent.
Beyond his immediate business interests, he seems determined to carve out a role in the broader political debate. And that, some say, might even strain his relations with politicians.
"If he was simply acting to maximize profit, he would have shied away from a controversial magazine like The Standard because it could actually hurt his relations with some politicians," said Mr. Kristol. "We've made it clear we are going to be critical and that we'll go after Republicans too."
One longtime business acquaintance said that Mr. Murdoch runs the risk of alienating executives within the entertainment industry, who tend to be centrist Democrats.
"It's never been a secret that Murdoch is conservative," said Barry Diller, who started the Fox Television Network for Mr. Murdoch. "But if he continues to unsheathe that harsh conservatism, it will impose some operational difficulties. Extreme political views, whether liberal or conservative, particularly with a broadcasting base, make a lot of people exceedingly nervous -- both those you work with and those in government."
To Mr. Murdoch, though, investing in The Standard is "fun."
"We don't think it'll lose much," he added. "It's a worthwhile exercise. For a company our size, I suppose it's a bit of a hobby. I think it will be an important voice. I hope it will be an important voice."
 
 
 
Ownership Limits a Problem? Just Change the Definition
 FEDERAL regulations prohibit a company from owning more than 12 television stations in the United States, but Rupert Murdoch has masterfully blurred the definition of ownership.
Mr. Murdoch's Fox Television Stations Inc., which now owns 11 stations and has signed an agreement to buy one more, has already bumped against the ceiling. But it has capitalized on a quirk in the rules to acquire stakes of 20 or 25 percent in 17 other stations that together cover more than 10 percent of the national population.
Consider the case of WLUK, Channel 2 in Green Bay, Wis. The station was acquired earlier this year by a company called Savoy-Fox, a business in which Fox owns a 25 percent stake and whose president, Thomas Herwitz, was general manager of Fox's Washington television station from 1989 to 1993.
Under its agreement with Savoy-Fox, moreover, Mr. Murdoch's company has options to increase its 25 percent stake of nonvoting stock to 50 percent and to convert those shares into voting stock. Meanwhile, the station will be an affiliate of the Fox Television Network.
The Federal Communications Commission approved the takeover of WLUK in April, but not without controversy. One of the agency's five commissioners, Susan Ness, said the deal clearly violated the spirit of the ownership restrictions.
"Considering the entire web of relationships, it stretches the imagination to believe that the potential for influence does not exist," Ms. Ness said in a statement at the time of the decision.
Savoy-Fox is awaiting approval to acquire three other stations, but the F.C.C. has been scrutinizing those deals closely and has yet to make a decision. EDMUND L. ANDREWS
 
 
 
Deregulation, Deregulation: Murdoch's Washington Agenda
1. Expanding television holdings.
Fox Television Stations owns eight stations and either holds or is acquiring partial stakes in more than 20 others. Current rules prohibit the company from owning majority control in more than 12 stations. News Corporation, along with ABC, NBC and CBS, is pushing Congress to end most limits. Approval, as part of a broad telecommunications bill, is considered likely.
 
2. Resolving foreign ownership dispute.
The F.C.C. has given News Corporation, based in Australia, an opportunity to get an exemption to rules forbidding foreign companies from owning television stations. The commission must still approve the company's petition that an exception would be in the public interest, and is expected to do so on Friday.
 
3. Ending cross-owndership rules.
News Corporation is seeking repeal of restrictions that forbid companies from owning newspapers and television stations, or newspapers and cable television systems, in the same market. This is part of the telecommunications bill.
 
4. Alternative uses for digital television.
News Corporation, with most other broadcasters, is seeking freedom to use new channels designed for high-definition television for an alternative purpose: to offer several different programs at once, using digital technology. The F.C.C. is expected to support that position.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Week That Was Bad, and Real Bad

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Oh, so that is what a really bad day in the stock market feels like.
Until lunchtime last Wednesday, bad days had become so infrequent that professional traders seemed momentarily addled when technology stocks led a lemming-like plunge in midday prices across all the major stock markets. 
 Firsthand evidence of that unsteadiness was offered by Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm. "I put in a bid to buy a little bit of Hewlett-Packard at $77 a share," Mr. Birinyi recalled on Friday. "I got it for $76.50 a share. So I went to buy another little bit at $75, and got it for $74.50." When professional traders start shoving Hewlett-Packard shares at a willing buyer for $2 a share less than he'd paid just moments before, "you know you've got an over-reaction," Mr. Birinyi said.
But if the week erased a few cocky smiles from the unlined faces of technology-fund managers, it did not seem to shake America's faith in the single most important idea to emerge from the stock market in the last decade: Buy on weakness.
On Wednesday, as the market bucked like an air mattress in the surf, major mutual fund organizations reported no evidence of panicky redemptions. Carl Wittnebert, the managing editor of the Mutual Fund Trim Tabs newsletter in Santa Rosa, Calif., tracks the flow of cash into mutual funds -- a decent proxy for Main Street sentiment. On Friday, his verdict on the week was: "As of now, nothing at all dramatic has happened." Buyers "may have pulled back a tad," he said, but sellers were not at all plentiful, and the overall cash flows were "quite stable."
The result was a Dow that closed Friday at 4,641.55 points, down 1.4 percent for the week. The Nasdaq composite index closed at 961.77, down 3.7 percent from the prior week's close.
But the week that ended with barely a whimper in the stock market closed with a bruising bang in the bond market. In a realm where prices typically move in fractions, the price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell more than 5 percent during the week. In other words, the value of a $1,000 30-year Treasury bond has fallen about $50 since last weekend.
One historical fact embedded even in young minds is that a contributor to the stock market crash in October 1987 was the bruising decline in the bond market that began six months earlier. So a bad week for bonds is bound to cause some uneasiness.
Is the bond market's pain likely to continue? Probably not, in the view of several veteran bond-watchers. The economist David B. Bostian Jr. of the Bostian Group in New York, who has been optimistic about bonds for months, believes the market was just blowing off some steam after "a buying panic" that pushed prices up and yields down in June. "There is still a bullish case for bonds," he said, "but the market is just retracing to a more sustainable level." Samuel Kahan, an economist for Fuji Securities in Chicago, agreed that there were no deep-seated inflation fears behind the market's recent plunge. "There was a lot of supply hitting the market and I think people just decided to step back a little," he said on Friday.
As for the stock market, Mr. Kahan is watching his own personal indicator. "I have a favorite client who has an uncanny ability to pick market tops and bottoms," he said. "When he calls me up and says he's ready to buy stocks, I'll know we've reached the peak. He hasn't called me yet."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
When Business Partners Are Marriage Partners

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
JAMI AND KLAUS HEIDEGGER met in 1982 when she was an aerobics instructor and he was a rising star on Austria's Olympic ski team. Three years later they were married, and now they run Kiehl's, a Manhattan-based cosmetics company.
The enterprise, with yearly revenue of $10 million, surely makes money. But, in the couple's eyes, it makes their marriage, too. 
 "It's not enough to just be in love or in lust, because these things fade away," said Mrs. Heidegger, the willowy and voluble president and principal owner of Kiehl's. "For some people, it's a child that keeps the relationship going, but for us, even more than our child, it's the business." Indeed, she said, for them weekends pale in comparison to Monday morning, "when the faxes start coming through."
Theirs is but one fin-de-siecle twist on the hoary concept of the mom-and-pop storefront, and such arrangements are growing fast. Whether because of corporate cutbacks, the increased presence of women in the work force or other causes, more than one million couples work together, up from 500,000 in 1986, said Sharon Nelton, an editor at Nation's Business in Washington. That doubling counts spouses who have their own businesses, as well as the relative few working for someone else.
Corporate America may frown on the practice: indeed, one recent survey found that 65 percent of managers disapprove of married people working side by side. But couples are mixing the nuptial and the entrepreneurial in fields from medicine to marketing.
THEY seem to toil no less hard than unrelated workmates. Consider the grueling pace of Helen and Stephen Colen, two physicians who run a husband-and-wife plastic surgery practice on Park Avenue in Manhattan. If he's in the office, she's in surgery, and vice versa. She was in surgery as she went into labor with their first child -- they have two -- but went to the delivery room only after she had finished stitching her patient. And the chores of their personal lives are also formally assigned: She books their airline tickets, but he's in charge of cooking dinner.
The Heideggers are similarly hard charging. They have given up what Mrs. Heidegger calls "sybaritic friends" -- those not connected with their work -- and have done away with formal family meals to accommodate their work schedule. They are also inclined not to send their 4-year-old daughter to school quite yet. "I just want to focus on my business," Mrs. Heidegger said. "I don't want to have to schmooze the teachers or jockey for position in the P.T.A."
Hard charging or laid back, "working marriages" have their bright sides. While some people may balk at having spouses who know exactly how much time they take for lunch, co-working couples do sidestep the jealousy and tension that often arises when one spouse's career overwhelms the other's. Other partner-spouses cite such benefits as growing trust, increased camaraderie and enhanced mutual respect.
Dr. William Bygrave, director of the Center for Entrepreneurial Studies at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., credits on-the-job togetherness with saving his marriage. Dr. Bygrave ran his own technology company in the early 1970's, and his wife came aboard as a part-time secretary. "She got to know my customers and my business," he said. "It made her much more empathetic toward the problems. Before that, I had been this grouchy guy who came home and was totally unanimated, because my brain would be totally involved with some issue with the company."
Also, couples who are partners often develop exceptionally close and satisfying work relationships. Helen Colen's patients will often see her husband for a consultation if she is not around, for example; his will meet with her on the aftereffects of a tummy tuck or a proboscis redesign. Now and then they operate together, particularly if a patient has flown in from overseas and has only a few days for multiple procedures.
"When I have a difficult surgery coming up, very often I'll ask my husband's opinion," Helen Colen said. "And it's very nice to talk to someone who really cares that my patients do well. If you ask another colleague, sometimes they'll just answer off the cuff."
Of the dangers in working together, the biggest is that disputes and ill feelings either at home or at work can poison the other realm. Couples who work together can jeopardize their marriages, especially if they endlessly intertwine the emotional and the professional, said Dr. Paul Baard, a psychotherapist and associate professor of communication and management at Fordham University's Graduate School of Business.
"Couples need to be very clear about their boundaries," Dr. Baard said. "Any relationship is going to be strained by pressure, and business pressures, which are greater than ever today, bring out the worst in people."
Combining family and business may also hurt the chance for marketplace success, said Paul Reynolds, a professor at Marquette University in Milwaukee. In a survey of fledgling Wisconsin businesses two years ago, he found that more than half were family-owned, with most of that group run by couples. But in additional research, he found that nonfamily businesses, while outnumbered, were much more likely to flourish and expand.
"Many of the decisions are being made on the basis of family considerations, not on what's best for the business," he said about the family-run companies. "Rather than expand the business, the principals might decide they're going to take a month off and go on vacation. Then their competitors take the market."
Similarly, some venture capitalists will never invest in a company, no matter how promising, that is headed by a husband-and-wife team, Dr. Bygrave of Babson College said. "The last thing they want to happen in the middle of running and growing a company is to get involved in the strife between two partners," Dr. Bygrave said. "It's a significant risk."
The Levys of Manhattan are well aware of the pitfalls, personal and professional, of marrying family and business. Rosann Levy, the marketer for her husband's accounting firm, Arthur D. Levy & Company, said they and their son, who is also in the business, regularly meet with a family therapist to help keep things running smoothly.
"I believe very strongly in having an objective facilitator to help you get through things," Ms. Levy said. "There are change-and-control issues, control between husbands and wives."
To avoid damaging run-ins, many couples develop divisions of labor. Nathaniel and Charlesetta Lee founded the United Academy of Beauty in Phoenix in 1969, fulfilling her childhood dream. Today they've diversified into real estate, operations which Mr. Lee manages, and they are opening a string of hair salons around Arizona, over which Mrs. Lee presides.
"Not everybody can work together," Mrs. Lee said. "But he's a good business partner and I can depend on him, and I try to be the same way."
The Heideggers divide chores, too. She does the hiring and looks for new products, while he runs the factory in Jersey City. "What I do there," he said, "isn't interfering with what she's doing here." Still, tussles are unavoidable. Mrs. Heidegger is in charge of the free-sample giveaways, for instance, and Mr. Heidegger says she sometimes goes overboard.
OTHERS advise working couples to leave the personal side at the office door. But some people don't bother with such compartmentalization. "Everything is open to discussion at all times," said Lois McCutcheon, a real estate agent in Middle Haddam, Conn., who since 1964 has shared her occupation, her office and even her desk with her husband, Ron.
For three years, Dr. Helen Colen insisted on maintaining a separate practice, explaining that she had wanted time to establish herself professionally before joining forces with her husband. "If you have two people running a business, people always defer to the man," she said, "and I didn't want that to happen."
Perhaps the best advice for co-working couples comes from Joe Mancuso, president of the Manhattan-based Center for Entrepreneurial Management, where his wife, Karla, is vice president. "It's nice to know other couples who are also in business but are not competitors," he said. "You can go out to dinner once in a while and ask detailed questions of one another." As in, how do you guys do it?
 
 
 
If Connubial Bliss Fades, Family Business Can Suffer
 FAME and success: Some couples who worked together had both. But good fortune is not insurance against divorce. And a split between co-working spouses reaches not only to their marriage but also to their livelihood.
Consider Fred and Gale Hayman, the co-owners of perfume maker Giorgio Inc. Starting with a women's wear boutique on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, Calif., they hit the jackpot with one overpowering fragrance. After divorcing in 1983, they tried to run the company together but apparently could not stop fighting. Eventually they sold out to Avon Products, and divided $185 million. (Avon later sold Giorgio to the Procter & Gamble Company.)
The founders of Esprit de Corp., the sportswear company, fared much worse. Susie and Doug Tompkins clashed for years -- almost from the company's start in 1968 -- over its strategic direction. Eventually, their marriage went completely awry and they put the company up for sale. No one bought, however, and in 1990, Mr. Tompkins sold his interest to an investment group headed by Mrs. Tompkins. She later left management.
Hollywood has had several feuding business couples. There's Mary Tyler Moore, who back in 1981 divorced Grant Tinker, with whom she founded MTM Enterprises, the company that produced her shows, among others. He, of course, later ran NBC, while she kept producing shows. More recently, Roseanne and Tom Arnold, who owned a production company together, parted ways. And remember Lucille Ball and Desi Arnez?
Perhaps the biggest corporate soap opera of late was played out in Washington. In 1993, soon after Herbert H. Haft, the patriarch of the Dart Group, began to quarrel with his son and heir-apparent, Robert M. Haft, the entire family unraveled. Herbert's wife, Gloria, sided with Robert and was fired from the Dart board. Soon, the couple was in a bitter divorce. Gloria, who had helped Herbert start their first drug store, considered herself an equal partner in building the Haft retailing and real estate empire.
Just this year, Jann and Jane Wenner, founders of Rolling Stone magazine and Wenner Media, split. Though Jane had no official title beyond director, she actively advised the magazines and is said to have mediated disputes between Mr. Wenner and employees. What's more, she owns a stake in the company -- so the divorce will probably affect the company.
Splits can be easier, at least on the business, when couples work together in large corporations. Often, one spouse just goes elsewhere. That's what Joni Evans, then president of the trade book division at Simon & Schuster, did in 1987 when her marriage to the publisher's chief executive, Richard E. Snyder, foundered and their year-long divorce proceeding turned rancorous. Ms. Evans took her editorial skills to a rival, Random House, though she has since become a literary agent at the William Morris Agency.
Such are the trials and tribulations of rich and famous working couples. Remove the headlines and the picture doubtless looks much the same for everybody else. JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

HEADLINE: Crime Lab;
Mystery of New York, the Suddenly Safer City

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY'S murder, robbery and burglary rates have plummeted to their lowest levels in a quarter century -- a development that has become a marvel of American law enforcement. But Police Commissioner William J. Bratton will not be satisfied until every last criminologist surrenders.
 "We'll knock them down like ducks in a row," said Mr. Bratton, speaking of all the standard criminological theories about how crime waves are tied to the size of the youth population, or to changes in the weather, or to unemployment levels, or to drug use patterns, or to the availability of guns. 
 As an enthusiastic brawler and bragger, Mr. Bratton wants the world to believe that it is his aggressive new crime strategies, and just about nothing else, that have forced New York's thugs into a fast retreat.
 Still, almost everyone else who studies crime is mystified by New York's 30 percent drop in murder and shooting incidents so far this year. Attorney General Janet Reno has called on her researchers to study it, and local social scientists are faxing faster than speeding bullets to foundations with grant proposals to test one new theory or another.
 Many cities have increased their police forces and seen crime rates decline, just as New York has, but this city's drop is simply breathtaking. As of Thursday, the 648 murders so far this year were 312 below last year's total on July 20. Over the first six months, reported robberies fell by 21.9 percent, burglaries by 18.1 percent and motor vehicle theft by 25.2 percent over the same period in 1994. Only with rape, a crime that women are believed to be reporting more often, have the numbers remained roughly the same.

 
 
More Than Cops
 "There's a miracle happening before our eyes and we don't know why it's happening," said Jeffrey Fagan, director of the Center for Violence Research and Prevention at Columbia University. "Cops deserve credit, but it would be a first in the history of social science for there to be a single reason for such a dramatic change in social behavior."
 Central to the question of why crime has dropped so dramatically in New York two years in a row is the issue of whether crime is preventable by police work at all. Many researchers say crime is an inexorable symptom of deeper social trends, like the breakdown of family or community, that police cannot possibly control. Deferring to criminologists, police chiefs have accepted the notion that individual crimes are random events, driven by passion or desperation, made more lethal in recent years by the easy availability of guns.
 Mr. Bratton has disputed such thinking, and he has made New York City a laboratory for perhaps the most innovative policing of any big city in the country. In the crackdown on minor offenses, like public beer drinking and urination and unlicensed street vending, Mr. Bratton's department found new ways to frisk people for guns and check their records for outstanding warrants. Suddenly people brought into precinct station houses for nothing more serious than graffiti-scrawling were pressed for information about drug or gun dealing.

 
 
In the War Room
 Mr. Bratton ordered the department's number-crunchers, who once measured productivity by clocking how fast patrol cars responded to calls, to design computer maps to plot crime trends daily for every street in the city. The approach likens criminals to enemy army units that can be squashed or deterred before they make their next move. The commissioner has advanced his predecessors' community policing policies by giving local precinct commanders wide latitude in creating their own anti-crime strategies.
 Before Mr. Bratton took over the department, neighborhood officers were ordered not to make narcotics arrests out of fear they would be tempted into corruption. Few anti-gun and narcotics units worked nights or weekends, leaving criminals an open field to operate. That has changed, and arrests have climbed by more than 25 percent.
 "I want to challenge the old idea that policing can't make a substantial impact on social change," Mr. Bratton said. "American policing has been swatting at mosquitoes for 20 years. In New York we've learned how to drain the swamp."
 Nevertheless, those ducks Mr. Bratton promises to knock down keep quacking. And while they cannot explain why the drop in crime accelerated precisely at the time the new crime strategies took effect in the middle of last year, these theories offered by criminologists do suggest that something more than Mr. Bratton's innovations are contributing to the city's good fortunes.

 
THEORY The drop in New York's crime rate reflects a national trend.
 While some medium-sized cities continue to record more crime, the nation as a whole, and big cities in particular, is seeing less. Baltimore, Cleveland, Houston, Jacksonville, Los Angeles, Memphis, Milwaukee, Nashville, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, San Antonio, San Diego and San Francisco all saw their murder rates drop by better than 10 percent last year. The 32 percent drop in Houston's murder rate for the first six months of this year was slightly better than New York's 31 percent slide, and Phoenix and Chicago were not too far behind.
 "Different cities point to different reasons," said Marie Simonetti Rosen, publisher of Law Enforcement News. "Some say it's the impact of community policing, some say it's the impact of tougher jail sentences, some say it's because of special courts dealing with guns, domestic violence and drugs."
 But New York's drop in virtually every category of crime is more sustained and steeper than any other major city's. While most of the cities that experienced drops in violent crimes last year were coming off a couple of years of rising murder and robbery rates, New York's drop of 12.3 percent in all felonies last year came as an acceleration of three straight years of gentle declines.

 
THEORY The crack-cocaine epidemic that fueled the crime wave has ebbed.
 New York criminologists offer some strong, albeit anecdotal, evidence that crack smoking is going out of style among youths who grew up watching their neighborhoods ravaged by agitated users and pistol-toting sellers fighting for turf.
 "The kids who are around the age of 18 have gravitated away from hard drugs, from both use and distribution," said Richard S. Curtis, an anthropologist at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan. "Crack has just played itself out." Mr. Curtis based his conclusions on interviews and focus groups including hundreds of New York City youths over the last two years.
 "They were really disillusioned with what crack had done," he concluded, adding that the increasingly aggressive police work may have "sped up" the growing conclusion of inner city youths that drugs and crime do not pay.
 In his own interviews with youths recently released from the city jail on Rikers Island, Mr. Fagan, the Columbia University criminologist, has arrived at similar findings. "There has been some cultural adaptation to the slaughter," he said.
 Mr. Fagan has also concluded that crime is decreasing as heroin slowly replaces crack as the drug of choice in New York. "While crack is a stimulant, heroin is a depressant," he said. And because heroin is purer and cheaper today than during its last surge in the 1960's, he has concluded that heroin addicts are not commiting as many robberies and burglaries as they did 30 years ago to support their habits.
 The police department disputes such conclusions, noting that 78 percent of the people arrested in Manhattan in February tested positive for cocaine, while only 22 percent tested positive for heroin and other opiates.

 
THEORY Most of the adolescents who shot up New York over the last decade ended up behind bars or murdered in gang wars, while the total number of people in their prime crime years has fallen.
 Criminologists note that the 55,000 felons imprisoned in New York State is about double the number locked up a decade ago. More than half come from the city, and about half of those have been in prison for less than five years. Figuring that each one of the newly imprisoned New Yorkers would commit five or six felonies in a year, that's a considerable number of murders, rapes and robberies prevented.
 Another estimated 3,000 people involved in narcotics crimes have been killed over the last five years in New York.
 But criminologists cannot explain how these factors could have come into play so suddenly the second half of last year, when New York's crime began falling so fast.
 Perhaps the most popular theory, and the one most disdained by Mr. Bratton, argues that the crime rate is determined by the number of youths in society at any given time. At a news conference two weeks ago, Mr. Bratton disparaged the major proponent of demographic criminology, James Alan Fox of Northeastern University, as well as the journalists who go to him for his opinions.
 "Most of the decline that has occurred would have occurred anyway," Mr. Fox said in an interview last week. "The baby boom generation, which comprises almost a third of the population, is getting older. They are middle-aged, and they are not nearly as aggressive and violent as they were when they were younger."
 Mr. Bratton, backed by city demographers, rejects such thinking, noting that from 1990 to 1995 the city saw a decrease of only 6 to 7 percent in the number of people between the ages of 15 and 29, the age group that commits and is victimized by the vast majority of crimes.
 But those ducks are persistent.
 "To resolve the researchers' questions, we need to know what is happening with crack markets, gun markets, juvenile violence, and comparing New York City police tactics with other cities," said Jeremy Travis, director of the National Institute of Justice, the Justice Department's research arm. "Understanding takes time."

HEADLINE: Medicare, Turning 30, Won't Be What It Was

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER and ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Thirty years after its creation, Medicare celebrates its anniversary this summer as a rare creature in the politics of the 1990's: a big, ambitious, exceedingly popular Government program that worked.
Nevertheless, it stands on the brink of extraordinary change. 
 Few dispute the successes of Medicare. When President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the bill creating it on July 30, 1965, only half of America's elderly had any health insurance. Today, the Government insurance program pays hospital and doctor bills for more than 37 million Americans 65 and older. This age group is the only one in America with virtually universal coverage.
Despite its successes -- and perhaps, in part, because of them -- Democrats, Republicans and policy-makers of all stripes now agree that Medicare in its current form cannot be sustained. They say its costs, which totaled $159.5 billion last year and are rising at an annual rate of 10 percent, must be controlled before the great wave of baby boomers begins to hit the rolls around 2010.
Beyond the need for cost control, the consensus breaks down. Politicians and policy-makers are bitterly divided over how Medicare should be changed, and how quickly. Democrats, using this month's anniversary to recall past glories, say that Republicans fought the creation of Medicare and should not be trusted with its overhaul today.
But Democrats in Congress and the White House, exhausted from their effort to redesign the nation's health care system in 1993 and 1994, have advanced few proposals of their own to improve the financial condition of Medicare. The party that sought bold innovations in health policy in the last two years is now advocating a cautious, go-slow approach to changes in Medicare.
Congressional Republicans say they are simply trying to govern and save a program that is badly out of date. Many favor a proposal that would constitute one of the most profound changes in the history of the program: the Government, which now acts as the insurer, paying doctors and hospitals for covered services, would instead contribute a fixed amount of money to a health insurance plan on behalf of each Medicare beneficiary. In the argot of health policy, a defined benefit would be replaced by a defined contribution, which Medicare recipients could use to purchase coverage in the marketplace.
Republicans say this proposal, described in internal documents that came to light this month, would offer the elderly the chance to pick and choose among health plans with different benefit packages and different premiums. Under this arrangement, sometimes known as a voucher system, elderly consumers would win because they would have more choices, and Government would win because it would have more control over the cost of the program, Republicans say.
"Senior citizens deserve the same choices available to other Americans," Representative Jim McCrery, a Louisiana Republican, said this week. "Medicare beneficiaries are given only one option when they enroll in the program, a bureaucratic, outdated, one-size-fits-all program that has not really changed since Congress passed it 30 years ago."
But Democrats say costs can be contained through less drastic steps. The voucher system, the Democrats argue, would send a vulnerable population into a fiercely competitive, confusing market. They see it as a step toward ending the fundamental promise of Medicare: an entitlement to first-class care for older Americans.
"Vouchers are a cruel birthday present on the 30th anniversary of Medicare," said Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
Differences between the two parties are intensified because Medicare's future has become enmeshed in the great budget battle of 1995. Republicans say their immediate goal is to prevent a central part of Medicare, the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund, from going bankrupt. But Democrats assert that the Republicans are trying to ram through changes in Medicare over the next 10 weeks so they can deliver on their promise of a tax cut and a balanced budget by 2002.
Republicans counter that the Democrats are abdicating their responsibility to help find a solution because they want to exploit Medicare as a political issue in the 1996 elections.
In fact, the stakes for both parties are huge.
"There are folks on both sides of this who are spoiling for an ideological Armageddon," said Bruce C. Vladeck, administrator of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare.
It would not be the first epic battle. Today's debate echoes concerns that were raised from the start about the proper role of Government, the trade-off between costs and benefits, and the degree to which the private market can be trusted to meet the insurance needs of the elderly.
 
The Past
Access for All Was Grand Goal
 Medicare's defenders say it is easy to take the program for granted in the summer of 1995. Before its enactment, they say, a serious illness could wipe out the savings of a lifetime, elderly people were often consigned to charity wards, and in any given year one-third of the aged did not see physicians.
Since the early 1960's, life expectancy at age 65 has increased by nearly three years. Procedures like cataract surgery, hip replacements and coronary bypass operations have vastly improved the quality of life for many elderly.
As Democrats are only too happy to recall, it was their party that championed national health insurance, beginning with President Harry S. Truman, who in 1945 urged Congress to establish such a program. In the debate over Medicare, Democrats said that only a true social insurance program, financed by payroll taxes and covering everyone, would spread the risk sufficiently and insure that all the elderly, rich and poor, were brought into the mainstream of American medicine. Republicans, by and large, argued for a voluntary system.
Bob Dole, who was then a Republican Representative from Kansas, put it this way in the House debate on Medicare on April 8, 1965: "The real opposition to the bill stems from the fact hospitalization benefits are to be financed by a compulsory payroll tax administered by the Social Security Administration." He added, "The point is that nearly everyone supports the concept that adequate medical protection should be made available to the aged, but it should be voluntary and should reflect ability to pay."
The costs of the program were a concern from the start, and not just to Republicans. But the architects of Medicare were more concerned about the program's grander goals. It had taken eight years, four election cycles, the assassination of a President and the Johnson landslide of 1964 to bring them to the point of passing this program.
Joseph A. Califano Jr., then a young White House aide, remembers sitting at a crucial moment with President Johnson and Lawrence F. O'Brien Jr., a White House adviser, in a small room off the Oval Office:
"Larry O'Brien said, 'Mr. President, we can't get Medicare out of Ways and Means unless we give the doctors and hospitals the reimbursement system they want.' Mr. Johnson replied, 'Get it out.' "
Mr. Califano added: "Our eyes were focused on access. We were not focused on costs."
In the 1980's, Congress revised Medicare's methods of paying hospitals and doctors, trying with some success to slow the increase in costs. In 1983, Congress decided that hospitals should receive uniform rates set in advance for each patient with a particular illness. Under a 1989 law that took effect in 1992, doctors are paid according to a fee schedule.
Medicare payments are made from trust funds, which are basically accounting devices in the Federal budget. The Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is financed with payroll taxes. The Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund, for doctors and other outpatient services, is financed with general tax revenues (65 percent), premiums paid by beneficiaries (31 percent) and interest from Government securities (4 percent).
The Medicare payroll tax has been repeatedly increased, most recently in 1986. Medicare remains essentially what it was in the beginning, a promise by the Government to give the elderly free choice of doctors and specialists, and to reimburse those doctors on the basis of each service they perform.
Beneficiaries are responsible for deductibles, copayments and many other costs not covered by Medicare. Most elderly people buy private Medigap insurance to help cover these costs.
Medicare's fee-for-service system was the norm for medicine in 1965, but it is no longer. Millions of workers are now enrolled in health maintenance organizations and other forms of managed care aimed at coordinating services and controlling costs. Often such arrangements restrict patients' choice of doctors, and the doctors often receive flat monthly fees for their services. Medicare recipients can enroll in H.M.O.'s today, but fewer than 10 percent of the 37 million beneficiaries have done so.
 
The Proposal
With Alternatives, Responsibility
 The voucher system favored by many Republicans would push Medicare recipients into the new medical marketplace. Once a year, under this proposal, Medicare beneficiaries would choose which health plan they wanted. They would receive cash rebates if they chose plans charging less than the standard Federal payment, but would have to make up the difference with their own money if they chose plans costing more.
Some might select an H.M.O. covering prescription drugs, routine physical examinations and dental care. Others might prefer a plan with a high deductible that offers less protection at lower cost. Or, Republicans are quick to note, people could choose to stay with the traditional Medicare program.
It is not only conservatives who say Medicare beneficiaries should have more choices, and more financial responsibility for what they choose. In a recent paper on the future of Medicare, Henry J. Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, and Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office under the Democrats, said Medicare recipients now had "little direct financial stake in the selection of health care plans or providers."
Beneficiaries "should bear the financial consequences of their choices," they said. They too propose that the Government contribute a fixed sum toward the purchase of an insurance policy for each Medicare beneficiary, but with this difference: Each plan would have to provide, at minimum, a package of benefits or services defined by the Government.
"It's too risky to allow variation in benefit packages," said Mr. Reischauer.
By contrast, the conservative Heritage Foundation and many Republicans want to encourage plans to offer different benefit packages, including benefits not now covered by Medicare.
Republicans cite the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program as a model for Medicare. The Federal employees' program is, in effect, a supermarket through which 300 private health plans are offered to nine million Federal employees, retirees and dependents, including members of Congress, White House officials and judges. The Federal Office of Personnel Management supervises the operation, disseminates information on the plans in a standard format and informally encourages insurers to offer new benefits.
In the Federal employees' program, the Government contribution is not simply a flat dollar amount. It is based on 60 percent of average premiums for the six biggest health plans. But the economic incentives are still powerful. Federal employees shop avidly. In the last decade, they have steadily migrated into lower-cost plans.
 
The Debate
Free to Choose, Or Is It Coercion?
 Any debate over a voucher system will focus on this question: Are the elderly being given more options, or are they being forced into lower-cost health plans by a web of financial incentives and disincentives imposed by a Government trying to save money?
Prof. Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University, said that under the Republican proposals, "you would have a larger choice among a more varied set of health insurance products, with all the glory and danger that brings." Beneficiaries would have a wider choice of health plans, he said, but "less choice of a doctor" within many of those plans.
In addition, he said, under these proposals, "the beneficiary would bear the risk of health care cost inflation, whereas now the taxpayer bears that risk."
Republicans like the idea of a defined Federal contribution, or voucher, because it would give the Government more control over Medicare costs. But that is a major source of concern for many Democrats.
"This proposal is put forward as choice, but it's really fiscal coercion," said Judith Feder, a deputy assistant secretary of Health and Human Services.
Given the Republicans' commitment to cut projected Medicare spending by $270 billion, or 14 percent, over seven years, she said, it is clear that the Federal payment on behalf of each beneficiary will grow less than the cost of health care or private insurance, so the value of the voucher will quickly erode.
Republicans reject such forecasts. They insist that the details of their proposal have not been decided. Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, said her party could "guarantee to the seniors of America a payment that would buy them the same basket of services they get under Medicare now."
Representative Bill Thomas of California, the chairman of the Ways and Means subcommittee on health, said Republicans would not allow elderly people with vouchers to be "shoved out into the cold."
But an underlying assumption of many Republican proposals is that people who choose the traditional fee-for-service Medicare program would pay more: higher premiums, deductibles and copayments.
One of the thorniest problems with a voucher program is how to calculate the Federal payment -- specifically, how to adjust the standard Federal payment for the medical condition of a particular beneficiary. How much, for example, will it take to guarantee that an 85-year-old paraplegic can find decent coverage in the open market?
In theory, plans should receive less money for enrolling healthy people than for signing up sick people. Otherwise, the use of vouchers will probably not save money for the Government and insurance companies may try to exclude sick or frail elderly. So far, actuaries have had difficulty devising a reliable way to make such "risk adjustments."
The Republicans may require health plans to enroll any Medicare beneficiary who wants to sign up. Mr. Vladeck, the Medicare administrator, said that an extensive regime of Federal regulation would be needed to enforce such a requirement and to make sure private health plans do not discriminate against sick elderly people. President Clinton was harshly criticized when he proposed such regulation as part of his plan to remake the nation's health care system, Mr. Vladeck said. But without such regulation, he said, a voucher system will not work.
 
The Politics
Behind the Fight, A Broader Issue
 The Republican voucher proposal, though still under development, is now at the heart of a debate with vast political implications. How voters view the Medicare struggle can frame the 1996 election, strategists in both parties say. Will the Republicans be able to campaign as the party that delivered a balanced budget and a large tax cut? Only if they can deliver on $270 billion in Medicare savings.
Will they be able to produce those savings without being punished at the polls by the elderly and their allies? Only if they can persuade the American people that the changes in Medicare are for the good of the program.
Republicans are clearly on the defensive on this issue, but they have made strides in recent months in pressing their argument that Medicare's costs must be controlled or the program is destined for bankruptcy.
"If I were a Democrat, I would not want to be in a position where Republicans balance the budget, deliver a tax cut and I'm not able to make any points on Medicare," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster. "If we block them from doing that, we're in a very commanding position with a year left to try to increase our Congressional majority."
Democrats, for their part, are intent on using the coming weeks to remind the American people of Medicare's proud history, and the Democratic Party's role in creating it. "We advocated the program, we got it passed, we've paid constant attention to keeping it solvent and strong and now we're at the barricades defending it and the people who benefit from it from the Republican assault," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader.
The Clinton Administration is also urging caution on Medicare restructuring and regularly denouncing the Republicans' motives, although Mr. Clinton himself has called for about $124 billion in Medicare savings over seven years.
But Mr. Clinton has argued throughout that Medicare cannot be truly overhauled, and thus Federal health care costs cannot truly be contained, without more comprehensive changes to the health care system.
In the end, the struggle over Medicare may turn out to be emblematic of the broader debate now under way between the two parties: Are there jobs, like insuring the elderly, that government simply does better? Or, as Speaker Newt Gingrich put it in his book, "To Renew America," is Medicare "a government monopoly and therefore inefficient, wasteful and slow to adapt to innovations in technology and management"? Would the market forces of the private sector simply do better?
It was an issue decided one way in 1965, but very much open in the summer of 1995.
And it will ultimately be debated, as it was in 1965, with the understanding that Medicare is not just another Government program. As Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, put it before the Medicare vote 30 years ago: "The spirit in which this law is written draws deeply upon the ancient dreams of all mankind. In Leviticus, it is written, 'Thou shall rise up before the hoary head, and honor the face of an old man.' "

Johnson signed the bill that created the Medicare program in a ceremony held at the Truman Library in Independence, Mo., on July 30, 1965. Lady Bird Johnson and Bess Truman stood behind their husbands. (United Press International, 1965) (pg. 24)
 
Chart: "CHRONOLOGY: Important Dates in Medicare History"
 
1965 -- President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Medicare bill. The new law provides basic health insurance for Americans 65 and older who are entitled to Social Security or the Railroad Retirement benefits.
 
1966 -- Medicare program goes into effect.
 
1972 -- Coverage is extended to people under 65 who are blind or seriously disabled and to certain people with end-stage kidney failure.
 
1977 -- Responsibility for administering Medicare is transferred from the Social Security Administration to a new agency, the Health Care Financing Administration.
 
1980 -- Coverage of home health services is expanded.
 
1981 -- Congress authorizes gradual increases in deductibles.
 
1982 -- Congress expanded Medicare to cover hospice care for the terminally ill.
 
1983 -- Congress establishes a new method of hospital reimbursement, paying uniform rates set in advance for each patient with a particular illness.
 
1988 -- Congress approves the Catastrophic Coverage Act to protect Medicare beneficiaries from financial ruin because of the high cost of acute illness. To finance it, monthly premiums would gradually increase, and the wealthiest 40 percent would pay an income tax surtax. Angry beneficiaries protest, and in 1989 Congress repeals the law.
 
1989 -- Congress establishes a new method of paying doctors based on a fee schedule rather than "reasonable charges."
 
1990 -- Congress increases the deductible to $100 from $75. It sets Federal standards for private Medigap policies supplementing Medicare.
 
1993 -- Congress removes the limit on earnings subject to the Medicare payroll tax, so the tax applies to apply to all earnings, not just the first $135,000. MONICA BORKOWSKI
