HEADLINE: Guarding the Turf, Stepping on Toes;
Henry Stern, Passionate and Blunt, Champions the City Parks

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
There is a certain "Car 54, Where Are You?" quality to careering about the boroughs with Henry J. Stern, New York City's odd duck of a Parks Commissioner, who over two recent days fielded calls from his chauffered Crown Victoria about the mini-crises that roll through a job he would happily keep for life.
He bristled at news that a sulking corporate donor wants a larger sign in Central Park advertising its largesse: "They're trying to push us," he said into the car phone. "If they're so noble, what do they care if the letters are an inch and a quarter high?" 
He perked up at reports that Frieda, a rambunctious circus elephant at a park in Queens, could have a history of dangerous behavior: "Frieda has a record?"
And at a stop to dedicate a playground in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, where a ribbon-cutting ended with complaints from Russian-speaking children and grandparents about teen-age gangs in the park, Mr. Stern listened sympathetically and promised more patrols, then left for his next event.
"It's basically Italians hitting on the Russians," he muttered as he slid into his car.
Friends say the comment was classic Henry Stern, the view of a man who grew up in an immigrant upper Manhattan neighborhood in the 1940's and sees the world in stark ethnic, racial and religious terms. Now, in his second stint as Parks Commissioner, Mr. Stern is one of the most eccentric and controversial members of the Giuliani administration. A tree-loving pixie and master politician, he has what his detractors say is a mean streak in private that sometimes seeps out in public.
For years Mr. Stern has suffered from recurring foot-in-mouth disease, as when he introduced his dog to a group of Chinese-American children in April by saying they could "pet him -- but don't eat him."
No one doubts that Mr. Stern has a very hard job or that he passionately loves the parks. "When Henry was Parks Commissioner, he was living in his own Camelot," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, his old boss and longtime friend.
Mr. Stern, a rumpled, scrawny, white-haired 60-year-old, presides over a Parks Department that has been under siege for 25 years. He battles daily to save an empire of 1,500 properties and more than two million trees from further budget cuts at a time when layoffs will soon reduce his roster of full-time workers to a record low of 2,400. He had twice that many when he was Parks Commissioner in the last decade.
Yet Mr. Stern is managing to adjust to a job that has changed with the social, economic and political fabric of New York City in the 1990's. In the 1980's, as a liberal under a Democratic mayor, he was like a general in charge of a personal army, commanding generous public spending for city parks. Today, under a Republican mayor, he must manage the citizens groups and donors who help the parks in lean times. He has also swallowed budget cuts without publicly taking on the Mayor who gave him his job.
"The peculiar nature of our service lends itself to reduction," he said. "Say you cut the grass once a week. The next year, you cut it every three weeks. And so on. If there were a strike and nobody came in and the grass was never cut, what would you have? Long grass. So who would die from long grass?"
The proliferation of crack cocaine has also changed the Commissioner's mission, redefining what a park should be. "It's more than just green space," he said. "Once it was, 'If you build it, they will come.' Now you think, 'Who will use it?' What is the critical mass that will make a park safe?' Because a deserted park is a dangerous park."
Mr. Stern said he had also changed over the years, drifting politically from the left to the center. A longtime Liberal Party member who supported Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the last election, Mr. Stern is well aware of the people who say that his politics are governed by personal expediency and that this little-l liberal has had to look the other way while a Republican Mayor has cut programs for the poor.
Mr. Stern argues with that. "The ideological divide in New York City politics is not between Democrats and Republicans," he said. "It's between the left and the middle. And I'm in the middle, as is Giuliani."
But does he agree with everything Mr. Giuliani does?
"You can't ask me that question," he said. "He's my employer."
Mr. Stern's supporters say he has done a fine job of defending his empire from even greater budget cuts, and they praise him for putting welfare recipients to work in city parks. His critics, however, many of them former employees, complain about what they call his silly -- if attention-grabbing -- daily events. Mr. Stern has dressed up for events as an astronaut, as King Neptune and as a shepherd, with Little Bo Peep at his side. Last year an elaborate funeral he staged for a tree got lots of press, but it also drew angry complaints about wasted money.
Mr. Stern is infamous for his unusual attention to bizarre details, particularly his propensity to play with numbers, which amuses him but can sometimes humiliate his employees. Once Mr. Stern reduced a secretary's raise so the last two digits of her annual salary would match her age; another time, he held an employee's annual raise to $2,010 because that was 10 times the man's home-telephone area code. "It was to tease him," Mr. Stern said. "He might have gotten more if he hadn't lived in New Jersey."
No one has ever said Mr. Stern is easy to work for. When he was executive director of parks in 1966, Mr. Stern discovered one afternoon that an attendant at a Brooklyn pool had signed in but was not there. Suspicious, Mr. Stern went to the man's home and found his prey sound asleep. "Eventually, I got fired for that attitude," Mr. Stern said.
Mr. Stern is still known for boring into his managers when he sees something out of order in their parks: a puddle, graffiti on a tree, litter. "The staff feeling is that he has mellowed a bit -- emphasize 'a bit,' " said Jack Linn, an Assistant Commissioner.
 
In Hot Water
Awkward Humor, Or Blatant Racism?
 The staff also cites Mr. Stern's tendency to say things in public that he should not.
This spring, after Mr. Stern haplessly introduced his golden retriever, Boomer, to the Chinese-American children, his remark ignited a minor furor. The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, shot off a letter to Mr. Stern expressing her "extreme displeasure" with his "offensive comments." In a recent interview in his office, in the Central Park Arsenal, Mr. Stern played down his remark as "an offhand comment made affectionately to a group of about 12 kids." Then he took a political swipe at Ms. Messinger. "If she felt this way, why didn't she call me?" he said. "Why didn't she say, 'Henry, you buh-buh-buh-buh-buh, why did you say that?' But she shot first. And that's politics. She's running for Mayor."
Mr. Stern's associates agree that he has exhibited a pattern over the years of what have been construed as racist remarks to reporters, parks officials and friends. Mr. Stern shrugs that off, too. "I kid around," he said. "I mean, I will say things. I mean, I will tell, in private, Jewish jokes." Mr. Stern admitted that he was "certainly politically incorrect" and that he saw "institutions weakened by crazy racial gerrymandering." He smiled. "I also think that I don't feel guilty," he said, "because I am Jewish, white, male or heterosexual."
One critical official said the Parks Department under Mr. Stern had a "plantation" aspect: The high command is largely white, while the field force is largely black and Hispanic, which has been a problem under most other commissioners as well. Mr. Stern acknowledged that he did not have any blacks in senior management positions. But he also noted that he had appointed the first two black Parks Department officials when he worked for the Parks Department in 1966, and he said he was searching for more black managers.
"You do the best you can, without being ridiculous," he said. "You don't want to appoint someone who can't deliver. There are many qualified people who can do these jobs. I'm just not sure they want to work for the City Parks Department in 1995."
 
Chaos to Go
Tuning In, And Tuning Out
 11:15 A.M., somewhere on the Gowanus Expressway: "Portable One calling Longshot. Shadow, is Rebound there?"
Mr. Stern was in the back seat -- he is Portable One -- radioing his office about what appeared to be a matter of some urgency.
Well, maybe not. "How are you doing on the mail?" asked Mr. Stern when he reached the person he needed.
Mr. Stern uses a walkie-talkie to keep in constant touch with his office, and he gives code names to his staff members, most of them young and male. There is Roadrunner, Starfish, Nairobi. One staff member has rejected Shrimp as a moniker. Frank Raffaele, Yale '95, is "Turtle."
"Commissioner," said Mr. Raffaele one recent afternoon in Mr. Stern's car, "Portable 2 would like to 10-1 you." (Translation: First Deputy Commissioner Alan M. Moss wanted to telephone Mr. Stern.)
"Turtle," Mr. Stern said, "why did I call Commissioner Moss?"
"I think Commissioner Moss would like to talk to you about graffiti," Mr. Raffaele said.
Mr. Stern looked toward a group of birds near 43d Street. "Look at all those pigeons on the light fixtures," he said, absorbed.
Mr. Stern is known for his fascination with animals, living and in sculpture, and he has formed the American Association for the Advancement and Appreciation of Animals in Art and Architecture, or the 7A. That led him to 86th Street and Park Avenue on a recent morning to admire a building that he calls his "mecca"; it has 22 tortoises and 51 hares carved whimsically into the stone. "There they are," he said, marveling.
The people of upper Park Avenue, however, could not help noticing that Mr. Stern was attired in wet Parks Department swimming trunks, a polo shirt and black dress shoes and socks. A woman gave him a strange look, unaware that her Parks Commissioner had been dressing in his car after a sluggish lap of backstroke for a swimming event on the Upper East Side. Mr. Stern resumed dressing when he returned to the car, nonchalantly pulling dress trousers over his wet trunks.
Later in the day, Mr. Stern was back in his office wing chair, with a half-eaten can of peas, a favorite snack, to his right, his collection of ducks spread almost everywhere else and his family photos nearby. Mr. Stern met his wife, Dr. Margaret Ewing, a pediatrician, at a grape-strike fund raiser on the Upper West Side. "This was before lettuce," he said. Today, they have two teen-age sons and live on the East Side.
There are a few other key things that define Mr. Stern. He grew up in Inwood, a mixture of Jewish, Irish and Greek immigrants several generations ago but now a largely Dominican neighborhood. His father made tents. He was a child prodigy, graduating from the Bronx High School of Science at 15. He has been a public servant for nearly four decades, and he makes $110,000 a year. His closest friend was the late Robert F. Wagner Jr., who hired him at Citizens Union, a civic group that monitors city government, when Mr. Stern was between his two appointments to run the parks. (After the Liberal Party and Mr. Wagner backed Mr. Giuliani, the groundwork for Mr. Stern's reappointment as Parks Commissioner was laid.)
Mr. Stern turned 60 recently. "I was always used to being the youngest at everything," he said. "But I still feel the same way. I still feel as immature as ever."

Family: Married to Margaret Ewing, M.D.; two sons, Jared Stern, 17, and Kenan Stern, 15.
 
Interests: City history and geography; words and numbers; animal art; human behavior.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lists 10 Soviet-Built Nuclear Reactors as High Risks

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Underscoring previous warnings from Western experts about the dangers of Soviet-built nuclear power plants, a Federal intelligence report says 10 reactors in Slovakia, Lithuania, Russia, Bulgaria and Ukraine face an abnormally high risk of failure.
The danger is attributed to design flaws, tattered economies, political disorder and weak regulatory oversight. 
 The 10 reactors, at five power plants, are the most dangerous among a group that poses "significant safety risks," the report says. It was prepared by the Energy Department, distributed to Federal intelligence agencies and made available to a reporter by a private group trying to win financial aid for the troubled plants.
"As a class," the report says, "these reactors continue to experience serious incidents, raising the specter of another accident akin to Chernobyl."
In 1986 the Soviet nuclear power station at Chernobyl near Kiev exploded in the world's worst nuclear accident, killing at least 31 people and spreading significant amounts of radiation across Europe.
All told, about 60 Soviet-designed reactors are operating in former Soviet republics and Eastern Europe.
Russian scientists and managers defend their reactors, saying Western criticism is rooted in ignorance and neglects a series of improvements. United States Energy Department officials have also pointed to "significant progress" made at the power plants.
While Western experts have often voiced alarm over the safety of the Soviet-designed plants, the Federal report is unusual in that it singles out the 10 reactors as particularly worrisome. Because of diplomatic sensitivities, international agencies have tended to shy away from rating the degree of danger of such reactors country by country.
The 10 reactors are Bohunice units 1 and 2 in Slovakia, Ignalina units 1 and 2 in Lithuania, Kola units 1 and 2 in Russia, Kozloduy units 1 and 2 in Bulgaria, and Chernobyl units 1 and 3 in Ukraine.
Unit 2 at Chernobyl was shut down in 1991 after a dangerous fire, and unit 4 was buried in concrete after it blew up in 1986. The report ranks the two remaining Chernobyl reactors as having the highest risk, while the eight other reactors are lumped together in terms of danger.
In interviews, Energy Department officials tried to distance themselves from the report, saying it had been put together over the last two years, was to be periodically updated and in some cases had failed to note improvements and efforts to reduce the dangers.
"We are concerned about the safety status of these plants," said Terry R. Lash, the Energy Department's director of nuclear science. "But I think the host countries have made significant progress in the last two years in making upgrades. Things are on the upswing."
Mr. Lash runs a $121 million program of technical assistance for nuclear plants in the former Soviet bloc, including the ones listed by the report as most dangerous. House Republicans are threatening to cut such aid, although whether they will succeed is uncertain.
Anatoly Shurygin, science attache at the Russian Embassy in Washington, said in an interview that the designs of Russian reactors were comparable or superior to American ones in terms of safety.
"The real problem is economic problems and difficulties," Dr. Shurygin added. "We would be happier to spend much more money for increasing safety."
Gosatomnadzor, a Russian nuclear regulatory agency, told a Russian news agency that the safety of the reactors under its jurisdiction was deteriorating, based on an analysis of plant operations and incidents in 1994 and the first half of 1995.
The agency said engineering support was declining, replacement gear was unavailable and maintenance was being postponed for lack of parts and money.
The Energy Department report was obtained from the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group in Washington that monitors global nuclear work. It declined to say how it had obtained the report.
The group called for the creation of a $10 billion fund by the West that would allow the 10 problematic reactors to be shut down and replaced. Western countries and international lending agencies have committed $1.2 billion to improve safety, but the council says that is inadequate.
David A. Schwarzbach, a council analyst who studies the troubled plants, said the $10 billion replacement fund would be "a small price to pay compared to the cost of another Chernobyl-class accident."
The Energy Department runs the Government's nuclear work and has an intelligence arm that monitors foreign developments. In 1993 the intelligence office set up a program to single out reactors most likely to have problems and to alert policy makers of "imminent accident dangers."
Dated May 1995, the intelligence office's report was prepared by the Pacific Northwest Laboratory, an arm of the Energy Department in Richland, Wash. The report is titled "Most Dangerous Reactors: A Worldwide Compendium of Reactor Risk Assessments."
The likelihood of a particular plant having an accident was judged on the basis of its design, operations, conditions, regulatory oversight, external events, support systems and political environment.
The report graded the plants on each of these criteria and then ranked them on a scale from A to F, with F the highest risk. All of the 10 worrisome plants were given a D, even though Chernobyl was judged the most dangerous.
These were among the findings:
*Bohunice in Slovakia: "The emergency core-cooling system is dangerously undersized."
*Ignalina in Lithuania: Reactors "remain unstable and difficult to control and rely heavily on operator intervention to keep things from going out of kilter."
*Kola in Russia: "Recently, workers staged a sit-in, protesting delays in pay, and the station received an anonymous phone threat, presumably from a worker, to set Kola afire if wages were not paid."
*Kozloduy in Bulgaria: "Rolling blackouts, mostly during winter months, have plagued Bulgaria since 1984. Often, for every three hours with electricity there is one hour without. This power shortage has resulted in severe demand-side pressure to operate Kozloduy whatever the risk."
*Chernobyl in Ukraine: "Today, conditions at the Chernobyl plant are in many ways worse than those that existed prior to the disastrous 1986 accident."
Many of the balky plants are old and scheduled for retirement. But economic pressures tend to keep them open. The Ukrainian Government has agreed in principle to shut down the remaining reactors at Chernobyl by 2000, but only if the West provides $4 billion for replacements, repairs and waste mitigation.
Armenia is preparing to restart its Metsamor unit 1 out of economic necessity, despite international objections that it is unsafe. The Energy report gives Metsamor a grade of D, though it is not on the list because it is shut down.
"Armenia," the report said, "does not plan to replace the reactor's obsolete control system until after the restart" because of its urgency and a lack of money.

HEADLINE: Clinton Regains His Voice With 3 Speeches

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Inside the White House they call them "the trilogy" -- the series of highly personal speeches President Clinton has delivered this summer in an effort to re-establish his voice and the power of the President to lead as much through oratory as through legislative agility.
In doing so, Mr. Clinton has harkened back to 1991, when as governor of Arkansas he went three times to his alma mater of Georgetown University to deliver a series of speeches setting out his vision of a "new covenant" between the government and the American people. 
 Now, four years later, having watched in frustration as he was branded an indecisive leader, as his health care proposals died and the Democrats were swept from control of Congress, Mr. Clinton is once again seeking to provide Americans with a road map to his personal beliefs and to show where he hopes to lead them through a second term in office.
His speeches, culminating in Mr. Clinton's strong support for affirmative action programs last week, have touched on economics but largely ranged across the field of social and cultural issues that the Republican Presidential candidates have sought to make their own, from school prayer to violence in the media to affirmative action.
To a large degree Mr. Clinton's approach to the potent issues has been to try to defuse them by telling Americans they can find "common ground" -- classic Clinton to the political strategists who remember him counseling them in 1992 to seek not the "wedge issues" that divide the country, but the "web issues" of coalition.
For while he has taken strong stands, in favor of affirmative action and in support of personal religious expression in schools, Mr. Clinton has also told Americans that the Republicans have presented the country with false choices.
The same First Amendment that bars establishment of a state religion, he said, also prohibits government from barring free exercise of religion. "Affirmative action," he counseled, "did not cause the great economic problems of the American middle class."
Whether the center will hold on such volatile issues is far from certain, as the Republican Presidential candidates vie for support of the religious right and present an almost solid block of opposition to affirmative action as discriminatory. And nowhere is that issue as dangerous to Mr. Clinton as in California, where Gov. Pete Wilson is trying to use it as a stepping stone in his quest for the Presidential nomination.
But simply by speaking out in these areas of controversy, Mr. Clinton may have helped himself, political analysts say.
"If you look at what people saw as the central character deficiency in Clinton, it was not that he was too far to the left or too far to the right," said Carter Eskew, a Democratic political consultant, "it was that he didn't stand for anything and wouldn't take a position on controversial issues."
An array of Presidential advisers from across the various camps in the factionalized White House has had a role in the preparation of the speeches, among them political consultants Dick Morris and Frank Greer; senior speechwriter Donald Baer; senior adviser George R. Stephanopoulos; William Curry, counselor to the president, and Melanne Verveer, the First Lady's deputy chief of staff.
But it has been Mr. Clinton, his aides say, who has been the driving force behind the carefully staged addresses, staying up until the early hours of morning to polish them, persisting with them even when advisers were dubious or fearful of the political consequences.
"These are all issues he has thought about and wrestled with much of his professional and personal life," said Mr. Stephanopoulos. "I think he's really been aching to speak on them."
Administration officials describe the speeches as the culmination of a long period of rumination by Mr. Clinton that began in the November and December days after the Republicans won control of Congress. The defeat, they say, made him more determined to explain who he is perhaps before it was too late and to return to the New Democratic themes of centrism on which he was originally elected.
Some of the ideas started to be forged in the preparations for January's State of the Union address, when Mr. Clinton invited more than a dozen academics and writers to a retreat at Camp David, people like Robert D. Putnam, who had written about civic disengagement in America, and Stephen L. Carter, a professor of law at Yale University who has written about the growing tendency in American law and politics to ban religion from the public realm.
The idea that the July speeches compose a trilogy has become almost talismanic inside the Administration because of the symmetry with the three speeches of 1991. But in reality the sequence of speeches and the number was developed partly through accidents of schedule.
The affirmative action address had long been promised as a culmination of a four-month-long study of preference programs for women and minorities. Mr. Clinton's decision to take on the issue of religion in the schools, by contrast, was controversial inside the White House.
While Education Secretary Richard Riley had strongly supported the President's stand, a number of the President's other advisers had felt queasy about this address and the President's assertion that the First Amendment "does not convert our schools into religion-free zones." The aides feared it could alienate Jewish voters or turn into the controversy of last fall when Mr. Clinton briefly suggested that he would not rule out his support for a constitutional amendment to allow organized prayer that was not coerced. But Mr. Clinton, a practicing Baptist, followed his own counsel.
In fact, the President has really delivered four news-making speeches recently, though one was a less-formal appearance at Vice President Al Gore's conference on the family in Nashville. There, Mr. Clinton endorsed Congressional proposals to require television makers to instill a computer chip that could screen out programs broadcasters coded as violent.
And starting on Monday, Mr. Clinton will extend his theme of common ground to the first of a new set of speeches, these putting forth his views on economic issues and the confrontation over the budget that looms with the Republican Congress.
For political speeches, the addresses so far have been strikingly personal. Mr. Clinton used his brother Roger's problems with drugs to speak about how a person cannot be helped unless he assumes personal responsibility for himself. When speaking about affirmative action, Mr. Clinton recalled graduating from a segregated high school in a state where the poll tax was still in place in 1960. The President even considered delivering his defense of affirmative action from the steps of Little Rock Central High School, integrated under the order of President Eisenhower.
In each case, after receiving speech drafts, Mr. Clinton edited and rewrote them well into the hours before dawn. Last Wednesday the Cabinet members and guests assembled in the National Archives for the affirmative action speech were kept waiting for 40 minutes, in part because Mr. Clinton was still tinkering with his words.
Whatever their effect on their audiences or their political impact, those who know him say the act of giving the speeches has been galvanizing for Mr. Clinton. "They are important not just for the public sense of him but his own sense of self," said Mr. Eskew.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1115 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

STOCKS
 
Sugar Blues for the Market
Let's see. The stock market soars, led by technology stocks. Microsoft, the highest of tech, reports surprisingly strong earnings. So naturally the market nose-dives, led by technology stocks. At one point in Wednesday's free-fall, in fact, with the Dow down 130, Microsoft shares were $18 below where they'd been two days earlier. What happened? Perhaps it was that dreaded "correction" -- an odd term implying that the notoriously illogical market has some "correct" level from which foolish investors deviate. Or perhaps it was the Wall Street equivalent of gorging on sweets and then crashing after the sugar high. In any case, traders pulled out of it and the market held steady for the rest of the week. Bill Gates won't have to go to work at McDonald's.
 
GREENSPAN WATCH
 
Flirting With Clarity
Alan Greenspan may have had something to do with that market bump, too. If he ever made himself totally clear, of course, the Dow would probably rise or fall 1,000 points in a day. There's no remote danger of him doing that, but last week he did skate perilously close to clarity, saying the economy "may have passed the point of maximum risk." In his usual hedging fashion, he added, "We have certainly not yet reached the point" where no risk remains. But the markets seemed to fix on his optimism, which might mean he has no plans for further interest-rate cuts. Or it might not.
 
ELECTRONICS
 
U.S. TV Maker? No Such Thing
Considering that the average American lives and breathes by the almighty Tube, you'd think making TV sets would be the ideal home-town business. Far from it. Yes, many of the names sound all-American: G.E., RCA, Motorola, Zenith, Magnavox. But G.E. and RCA sets are sold by Thomson of France, Magnavox sets by the Dutch company Philips, and Motorola sets have been renamed Quasars by their Japanese manufacturer, Matsushita. Zenith held on alone -- until last week. A South Korean company called LG Electronics, which makes the Goldstar brand, bought control of Zenith. Now Americans can only sit and watch, at which they're proven experts.
 
TRANSPORTATION
 
Metro-North Strike: Never Mind
For all the fuss, you'd think there had been a strike. Westchester and Connecticut commuters fretted or stayed home or plotted the least painful trek to the subway's far reaches. They watched and waited and talked, talked, talked -- the Strike That Wasn't provided endless conversational fodder. But then Metro-North pulled a trick out of its hat -- a Railway Labor Act cooling-off period -- and, Presto!, no strike threat for four months. Negotiators can get some sleep now, and commuters, after three days at the edge of their train seats, are left wondering whether the whole mess will be back in November. And why does no one mention, by the way, that Metro-North hasn't even raised New York fares for over five years?
 
TOBACCO
 
Is the Marlboro Man Happy?
A survey out last week showed a sharp rise in teen-age smoking -- a big surprise, since that rate had held steady while adult smoking fell. But now, a tough question: Is this good news or bad for the tobacco industry? Last month Philip Morris announced a plan to cut smoking by minors, so presumably it would find this news disturbing. Yet rarely does anyone but a teen-ager start smoking, and if they don't start, there'll be no customers. But let's take Philip Morris at its word, making the next question this: How do you keep kids from starting? It's already illegal to sell minors cigarettes, of course, but that means little. Another survey shows that, nationwide, minors can buy cigarettes 75 percent of the places they try.
 
THINGS MADE IN HEAVEN
 
Scott, Meet Kimberly
It almost sounded like a consumer-hip young couple finding joy in pooling unusual strengths: "Scott is strong in bath tissue and towels; Kimberly is strong in facial tissue." Scott "has nothing in diapers and feminine pads" but "can open a lot of doors in Europe." (As well he should!) But no, this was an analyst talking about Kimberly-Clark's planned purchase of Scott Paper last week, a $7 billion stock transaction the analyst called "a very complementary deal." And it's a deal that would create a powerful rival to the true giant of consumer products, Procter & Gamble. And why is Albert Dunlap smiling? Well, he's chairman of Scott Paper, and he could wind up with $100 million. Nothing to, uh, sneeze at.
 
FRAUD
 
Twice Bitten at Towers?
Two years ago, the gloom was deep for creditors of Towers Financial. Towers descended into bankruptcy; its founder, Steven Hoffenberg, pleaded guilty to fraud, and creditors were out hundreds of millions in an unimaginably vast Ponzi scheme. Then came that fuzzy, golden moment when the pure of heart ride in and do their virtuous best to patch things up. A Los Angeles businessman named John Hall entered the scene, with the hope that he'd do all he could for creditors with Towers' tattered remains. But the fairy tale ends there. A lawsuit now contends that Mr. Hall, too, was merely intent on lining his own pockets -- that he siphoned millions from the patched-up venture by having it pay grossly inflated prices for worthless assets.
 
REGULATION
 
Safety Rules: Hard to Kill
Business is dying to get rid of a lot of environmental, health and safety regulations, and it seemed the reigning Republicans would oblige them. Regulation-slaying legislation, way up there on Congress's checklist, was moving along nicely. But last week, outnumbered Democrats managed to kill it, borrowing the tactic that had sunk Henry Foster's chance to be Surgeon General: talk it to death. And as with Dr. Foster, backers of the bill couldn't quite come up with the votes to cut off debate. "I regret that we have failed the American people again," said Bob Dole, who would have loved to add the bill to his resume as he applies for that job up Pennsylvania Avenue. But environmentalists surely saw no failure.
 
PUBLISHING
 
Let 'em Read Balance Sheets
"I like our core businesses," said Mark Willes. Well, if you say so. It was a bit hard to tell last week. Mr. Willes, after all, is the new head of Times Mirror, whose "core business" is newspapers, and he had just closed New York Newsday, cutting 750 jobs. Just days later, as part of a broad sweep of the broom, he said he would cut 1,000 more newspaper jobs, including 700 at The Los Angeles Times. Yes, costs must be cut, shareholders must be kept cozy and warm, and Mr. Willes, once a General Mills financial executive, is certainly trying to do that. "Core businesses" -- that's the way business people talk, not journalists.

HEADLINE: Foreign Afffairs;
Enter Le Bulldozer

BYLINE: By Thomas L. Friedman 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Now this could get interesting.
 Jacques Chirac has only been President of France for two months, but in that brief span he has demonstrated that he is going to pose a very different challenge for Washington than his predecessors. Mr. Chirac has signaled that he won't be content playing the traditional French role of annoying the U.S., by ostentatiously asserting French independence but ultimately falling in line behind American leadership. No, no, Mr. Chirac is hunting bigger game. He aspires to supplant Washington as leader of the Western alliance, period, full stop, hand over the keys. 
 With the end of the cold war diminishing the importance of the U.S. security umbrella, and with the missing-in-action Clinton Administration leaving a yawning leadership vacuum on the world stage, who's to say Mr. Chirac won't succeed? As the French President pointedly pointed out two weeks ago: "I believe the Atlantic Alliance does not have a leader."
 Hmmmm. Got any candidates, Jacques? Yes, this could get interesting.
 So who is this man who would be king? Mr. Chirac is not your typical French statesman. Unlike his aloof, cautious and calculating predecessor, Francois Mitterrand, Mr. Chirac is impulsive and impetuous -- a gambler in his own way, whose instinct for snap decisions can border on the reckless. As one diplomat in Paris remarked to me: "Chirac is a bulldozer without a steering wheel, and when one of those is on the road everyone else should put on their seat belts."
 Consider his first two months: He dominated the G-7 summit in Halifax, arm-twisting the other leaders to issue a muscular declaration on Bosnia. He ordered a resumption of French nuclear testing in the Pacific, without consulting any of his European Union partners, and when they protested he sniffed that his decision was "irrevocable." Mr. Chirac startled his country by becoming the first President to acknowledge French responsibility for the deportation of thousands of Jews to Nazi death camps during Germany's occupation of France. And it was Mr. Chirac's sudden ultimatum to the allies -- either reinforce the safe havens against further Serbian attacks or France pulls its troops out of Bosnia -- that triggered a U.S. decision to threaten massive air strikes to deter the Serbs.
 How far can Mr. Chirac lead? That depends on two factors. First, Mr. Chirac needs to be able to lead the European Union before he can lead the West. He needs the E.U. power base as a multiplier of French power and right now many E.U. members -- particularly Britain and Germany -- are wary of Mr. Chirac's impulsiveness, and uncertain whether there is any real strategic vision behind it. Second, France has 12.5 percent unemployment, and it is that number, not Bosnia, that the French public is obsessed with. It is worth recalling that Charles de Gaulle, France's last President to really challenge Washington's leadership, was brought down not by foreign policy but by the 1968 student-worker strike in the streets of Paris.
 There is an opportunity here for the U.S., and a risk. At a time when Washington is tired of leading it has in France a President who wants to lead as much as de Gaulle, but is not, like de Gaulle, congenitally anti-American. Mr. Chirac speaks English and has warm feelings toward the U.S. from his summer working the soda fountain at Howard Johnson's. He is a rare breed: a Gaullist baseball fan. Who knows, maybe he could be to Bill Clinton what Margaret Thatcher was to Presidents Reagan and Bush -- an assertive European leader who encourages U.S. leadership, while acting as Washington's full partner. The danger is that Mr. Chirac's impulsiveness will wear thin on Washington and his European allies and there will be total incoherence in the alliance -- with Washington refusing to lead or be led.
 Thirty-some years ago, John Kennedy and Charles de Gaulle also vied for primacy in the Western community, but that was a clash of two titans, each with a very strong vision of his country's role in the world. For now, Bill Clinton and Jacques Chirac look like pale imitations. One hopes that they will find a way to live with each other's weaknesses, and still work together. If not, they could give living proof to Karl Marx's dictum that all great events and personalities in world history appear twice -- "the first time as tragedy, the second time as farce."

HEADLINE: Liberties;
The Vicuna Lacuna

BYLINE: By Maureen Dowd 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Al D'Amato's impersonation of a statesman made my head hurt. And hanging on the words of Howell Heflin was not my idea of how to spend a steamy Friday afternoon.
 But accountability of government is a pillar of our democracy. So I went to hearings all week, and watched Congressional panels on Whitewater, Waco and the Good Ol' Boys Roundup, the racist A.T.F. picnic. 
 The props were unforgettable. Grown men fought for the attention of cameras with a dead man's briefcase. Senators pored over the Roundup invitation, featuring a Redneck Chili Cook-Off judged by "former Rednecks of the Year."
 Congressional hearings are useful, I suppose, although the country still seems pretty confused about what Ronald Reagan knew about Iran-contra, and what happened between Anita Hill and Clarence Thomas. Plus, this is not the Roman Senate. The oratory runs more to Senator Joe Biden vaporizing that the Good Ol' Boys Roundup hurt "the soul of this country" and "the soul of law enforcement" and "the heart and soul" of law enforcement.
 But anyway, let's review what we've learned so far:
 * David Koresh was a pervert.
 * Janet Reno was so green on the job that she was rolled by the F.B.I. in Waco and by the White House in Whitewater.
 * Bernard Nussbaum was such a gifted obstructionist that he could make even an innocent person look guilty.
 * The Republicans have a weakness for conspiracy theories.
 * The Clinton Administration would rather climb a tree to tell a lie than stand on the ground and tell the truth.
 * The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms should be abolished before the Council of Economic Advisers.
 * Good ol' boys are sometimes racists and heavy drinkers.
 * The bottom of a briefcase is in the eye of the beholder.
 You may feel you knew all that already. But this is a Congress more intent on sound bites than civics.
 Senator Arlen Specter said he will convene a panel on the 1992 F.B.I. raid on the white separatist Randy Weaver in Ruby Ridge, Idaho. Senator Barbara Boxer, a Democrat, wants open hearings on Bob Packwood. That way, we could finally prove, beyond any shadow of a doubt, once and for all, absolutely, that Senator Packwood is not the master of his desires.
 Neither was Senator Edward Kennedy, says Senator Mitch McConnell. The Republican Ethics Committee chairman has threatened to hold hearings on Chappaquiddick, the accident that occurred many years ago, before disco. Senator McConnell also would retaliate with a hearing on another Democrat, Senator Tom Daschle, on whether he improperly intervened to help an air-charter company owned by a friend.
 Senator McConnell's threats of revenge hearings are preposterous and tasteless, and perfectly in keeping with the spirit of the 104th Congress.
 Think about it. Why shouldn't the capital complete its descent into partisan madness and get around to all those scandals that got away? The nation's past is riddled with mysteries. Let the hearings commence.
 We could start with that cherry tree. The anti-environmentalism of the Father of His Country is a disgrace. And we could find the smoking teapot of the Harding Administration. We like Ike, but isn't there a piece of unfinished business about Sherman Adams and that coat? What is vicuna, anyway? And where did it go?
 Then Congress could try to get to the bottom of current troubling questions:
 * Does Strom Thurmond know that his hair is the color of Tang?
 * Why does Robert Byrd insist on holding up Senate business with all those references to Brutus and Tacitus? (Call him Tedius.)
 * Did Jesse Jackson teach Bill Clinton to say "Mend it, but don't end it"?
 Oh, and there's that new Senate resolution Senator Byrd got passed saying reporters should have to join legislators in disclosing the sources and amounts of their outside income. Can hearings be far behind? (Who will cover them?)
 First, they'll ask Diane Sawyer questions about her sex life. Then they'll want to know why Larry King never asks follow-up questions. Next they'll try to figure out how bored David Brinkley really is. And then they'll come after me.
 Enough. I'm losing perspective.

HEADLINE: If Your Thinking of Living In/Marble Hill;
A Bit of Manhattan in the Bronx

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM

 BODY:
YES, you have crossed the Harlem River and, yes, that is the northern tip of Manhattan island that you can see to the south. But as residents of Marble Hill are quick to point out, you are not in the Bronx: because of a 19th-century public works project that reshaped Manhattan island and severed its topmost land, Marble Hill is across the river and into what logically should be the Bronx.
It is a quirky and little-known neighborhood whose residents consider it a well-kept secret. Where else in Manhattan can you find a six-bedroom, three-story house on a quiet, tree-lined street with an attic, a basement, an enclosed front porch and a pretty facade for sale for $174,000? Or a three-family house with six bedrooms on an architecturally magnificent street with an asking price of $295,000? 
 Realtors link the low prices partly to the fact that the homes are aging and may need repairs, and partly to the eagerness of elderly sellers, most of whom are retiring to their homelands in the Caribbean. Or to the fact that part of the small neighborhood is a giant public housing project.
There are 4,000 households in Marble Hill, but only 135 private homes. The neighborhood is divided, both physically and socially: clustered near the commercial spine of Broadway are the Marble Hill Houses, an 11-building housing development, while up on "the hill," the former site of marble quarries, are the attractive turn-of-the-century houses that lend the neighborhood its cachet.
"It's a very small area and there's a strong sense of neighborhood community about it," said Susan Goldy, president of the Bronx Board of Realtors. "It has the advantage of lower prices than some of the surrounding communities, like Riverdale, and it's really a very affordable alternative to most of Manhattan."
Rental apartments are easy to come by, but houses do not come on the market with great regularity (at last count, there were only five listed with real estate brokers). Some homeowners and landlords choose only to advertise their properties in the classified section of the local paper, The Riverdale Press, and many transactions are done even more informally. "People just don't move out, and when they do they often sell their homes to their neighbors," said H. Michael Pichardo, executive director of the Marble Hill Neighborhood Improvement Corporation.
In what many residents view as a vote of confidence for Marble Hill, City Councilman Guillermo Linares bought a house on Van Corlear Place a year and a half ago. "We just went driving around and looking, and we saw this house that had a sale sign," Mr. Linares said. "We talked to the owner, we looked at the area, we fell in love with it, and we have been very happy."
Mr. Linares said he had traded a relatively cramped and high-rent apartment in Washington Heights for a house with a backyard, three kitchens, three bathrooms, a finished basement, three bedrooms and an attic.
BUT even Mr. Linares, who was elected to represent the neighborhood in 1991, had not been aware of its existence or its status as part of Manhattan before he began campaigning for office. "Even though I had lived in Washington Heights all this time, I thought that on the other side of the 225th Street Bridge was the beginning of the Bronx," he said.
The confusion is extremely common. While Marble Hill residents vote in Manhattan, do jury duty there, and are represented by Manhattan officials, their municipal services come from the Bronx. Their fight for recognition as a Manhattan neighborhood has persisted for years. As recently as this decade, neighbors turned out in force to oppose the move to change their telephone area code from 212 to 718 (they lost).
Marble Hill was lopped from Manhattan in 1895, when the northern channel of the Harlem River was redug to make way for a ship canal. Soon after, the Spuyten Duyvil Creek was filled in, cementing Marble Hill to the Bronx. The Greater New York Charter of 1897 designated Marble Hill as part of Manhattan but not of New York County, producing decades of headaches and squabbles. In 1939, the Bronx Borough President, James J. Lyons, tried unsuccessfully to annex the neighborhood to the Bronx.
In 1984, the matter was settled with some finality when Assemblyman J. Brian Murtaugh and State Senator Franz Leichter sponsored successful legislation declaring the neighborhood part of Manhattan. Mr. Murtaugh, an Inwood resident, is a longtime Marble Hill enthusiast. "It's just a very unusual niche," he said. "It is one of the most ethnically and economically mixed neighborhoods in New York City, and yet they operate like a small town."
A community council meets monthly. In a recent example of civic activism, Mr. Murtaugh pointed to a successful effort by the police and local residents to close a bodega at 228th Street and Marble Hill Avenue where drug sales had been noted.
Formerly an Irish and Jewish bastion, Marble Hill's population is now about 35 percent black and 55 percent Hispanic. In the 50's, the construction of the Marble Hill Houses brought about the radical demographic change. "The church that I served went from an all white to an all black congregation," recalled the Rev. William Tieck, who served for 31 years as the pastor of St. Stephen's United Methodist Church, an old wooden church at the southeast corner of Marble Hill Avenue and 228th Street that serves as a focal point for the community.
The neighborhood's population of middle-class Hispanic people has continued to grow in recent years, and the first Asians have begun moving in. While whites make up only about 8 percent of the population now, their influence still permeates the neighborhood: Broadway is still dotted with Irish pubs that draw a loyal local clientele, and just over the Kingsbridge border are a kosher bakery and an Orthodox synagogue.
The Rev. Leonis Quinlan, the current pastor of St. Stephen's, moved to Marble Hill in 1991 and said that its heavily Dominican flavor came as a pleasant surprise. "It is Dominican in its essence," he said. "You can smell the foods in the air, you can hear the music. You see older men playing dominos in front of the bodegas, and women in traditional dress."
During the day, the neighborhood is populated -- some would say inundated -- by students from John F. Kennedy High School, a school of 5,100 that was built in 1972 for a student body of 3,500. Residents complain that the students generate noise and litter and crowd the local markets at lunchtime. But aside from the annoyance factor, the school's multiracial student body has caused no racial tensions.
"You don't have racial problems here -- there are no bias crimes," Mr. Pichardo of the neighborhood group said. "Show me another neighborhood in the city with this racial composition, this mix, where people get along." Relations are somewhat less harmonious between homeowners and residents of the housing projects.
UPHILL from the boxy housing projects is a cluster of attractive homes, many of them fixer-uppers. And some multifamily dwellings, like the one for sale at 121-123 West 227th Street, are already occupied by tenants with leases, compounding the difficulty of finding a property.
John Brown, an agent with the Robert E. Hill agency in Kingsbridge, said his office received few inquiries about Marble Hill. "At times we thought that the Marble Hill area was going to experience a renaissance, because of its interesting housing stock and its proximity to Manhattan, but it never did," he said.
Other than a few new health-food stores, there are still no signs that Marble Hill or its environs are going upscale. Yet fans of the neighborhood cite the convenience of its shopping district on Broadway, where mid-price retail stores and supermarkets abound.
Most of the shops lie over the Bronx border, but within easy walking distance. Residents also point with pride to the recently built Allen Pavilion, a community hospital operated by Columbia-Presbyterian hospital just across the river in Inwood. And they note the abundance of transportation options: both Metro-North and the IRT have stations in Marble Hill, numerous express buses run from Broadway and 230th Street to midtown Manhattan, and highways are close by.
On the down side, the neighborhood has no movie theaters, and dining options are limited to pubs and the Riverdale Diner. The noise from the elevated subway line is an annoyance to some residents, and the area's public schools are crowded (there are a few parochial schools just outside of Marble Hill). And, as with any urban area, the neighborhood does have its share of drug problems and blighted properties.
One neighborhood stalwart is Dr. Jeffrey L. Gurian, a dentist and comedy writer whose practice lies across the street from St. Stephen's. Through his career as a professional comedian, he has lured various celebrities to his office for dental work. "When they see the private homes and the trees, they all say it's much nicer than they ever expected," Dr. Gurian said.
On the flip side, Dr. Gurian said, the neighbors are equally astonished by some of his clients. When the actor Charlie Sheen and his bodyguard drove to the office in a stretch limousine, the police came over to check out the situation. "They don't expect to see a big stretch limo up here," Dr. Gurian said.
 Another caption, in the Gazetteer chart with the article, misidentified the house at the left. It was a four-family house at 119-121 West 227th Street, not a one-family house at 46 Adrian Avenue.

SEPARATE BUT EQUAL: It was the routine task of selecting a jury for a trial that provoked a legal settlement of dispute over whether Marble Hill is part of Manhattan or the Bronx. In May, 1984, State Supreme Court Judge Peter J. McQuillan ruled that a Marble Hill woman could not sit on a jury in a New York County murder case, holding that legislative boundaries for the borough and the county were defined differently and that the woman was a Bronx County resident. Judge McQuillan's decision alarmed Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morganthau, who feared it would enable criminal convictions to be challenged if a Marble Hill resident were convicted of a crime in the wrong jurisdiction or if a Marble Hill resident had sat on a jury in the wrong county. To end the confusion, Assemblyman J. Brian Murtaugh and State Senator Franz Leichter sponsored legislation declaring Marble Hill "part of the Island of Manhattan . . . regardless of the construction of the Harlem Ship Canal." The legislation passed, its sole opposition coming from a handful of Bronx legislators.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
What's Bill Got That Worked for John, Dick and Yes, Harry

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
Over the years, people have tried to predict market performance based on such factors as hemline lengths, baseball or football championships and the position of the stars in the sky. Another favorite tactic is to correlate returns with presidential elections, which may not be so unreasonable after all.
 Phoenix Investments, a fund and money management company in Hartford, noted in a recent study that stocks perform best in the third year of a presidential cycle, and the company encourages investors to get in the game before it's too late. 
 Despite last week's volatility, the stock market's performance suggests this pattern may hold for the Clinton Administration. Beginning in the days of President Harry S. Truman and covering the next nine administrations, the Standard & Poor's 500 has averaged a 20.6 percent gain in the third year of each term, compared with average gains of slightly more than 9 percent in the first and second years and 13.6 percent in the final year. During President Clinton's term, the S. & P. returned 10.08 percent the first year, 1.32 percent the second year and 20.21 percent through June 30 of this, the third year.
 William J. Newman, chief investment strategist for Phoenix, said the market cycle was not happenstance. "A new administration prefers to take bad medicine early on, so the post-election year is usually not terribly good for the stock market," he said. Then, as presidential elections loom, it tries to put its best foot forward.
 The recent move by the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates is just another example of attempts to keep the economy going, Mr. Newman said. The Phoenix conclusion: "It only happens every four years! Don't miss out. Invest today!" Investors are left to wonder, though, if the oversized gains already this year can possibly be sustained. CAROLE GOULD

HEADLINE: Why Some Are Switching to Nursing

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHY do people with one college degree leave good jobs to plunk down $25,000 for tuition so they can study tirelessly for 16 months in order to get a degree in nursing?
Ask the 20 students enrolled in the College of New Rochelle's accelerated bachelor of science and nursing program, and the answers are as diverse as the students themselves. 
 Take Marcy Maldonado, 31, one of the students enrolled in the College of New Rochelle's School of Nursing second degree program. Ms. Maldonado, of Queens, said she is seeking retraining because she would eventually like to be a nurse practitioner for the Hispanic community.
"My first degree, in economics, was in such an abstract field that I never felt what I was doing was making a difference," Ms. Maldonado said. "I realized what I missed was working with people. The nursing profession not only involves working with people, but it offers a variety of career possibilities. I know there is a huge need for nurses, especially in Spanish neighborhoods."
Fred Balfour, 42, who is enrolled in the same program, has two degrees, one in business administration and a master's in marketing and finance.
"Financially, I was doing very well," Mr. Balfour said. "I was working in the financial area for the New York City Social Services Department. My motive for getting a third degree? Quite honestly, it is because I have a strong desire to do good, to be of assistance to people in need. Just being in business wasn't enough for me. My wife is a nurse, and I saw how really important her work is."
For the 16 months it will take Mr. Balfour to complete the course, he said his wife has volunteered to be the family's sole breadwinner.
"In addition to the personal satisfaction I hope to find as a nurse, I believe the field of health service is constantly expanding and the opportunities are tremendous," he said. "And salaries are also appealing."
Dr. Connie Vance, dean of the College of New Rochelle School of Nursing, said that starting salaries of former nursing graduates of the second-degree program are ranging between $38,000 and $40,000.
The program, which is intended to provide a fast track to a career change, was begun three years ago. Dr. Vance said: "We developed it in response to the interest in nursing we saw from people with degrees in fields as diverse as banking and dance who were all looking for a way to make the transition to nursing. They queried us because of our reputation as a nursing school. Diversity both in the program and students is a hallmark of New Rochelle's School of Nursing."
Despite their vastly different backgrounds, Dr. Vance said the students share a common trait.
"We find they generally are in the course because they want to serve people," she said. "Nursing is an intimate profession, and that is what students like. Students such as the woman who has a doctorate and had been working as a research chemist, said she missed being involved directly with people."
Second-degree program students, who are mature people in their 30's and 40's, have to be taught differently from younger students, Dr. Vance added. "Ninety-nine percent of our professors have doctorate degrees, and they treat adult learners as a peer group," she said. "A lot is required of the students. The program is arduous. We immerse them in clinical learning experiences right away at small community hospitals and at large urban medical centers in the public health programs and in the home through visiting nurse services."
Currently, there are 20 students -- 4 men and 16 women -- enrolled in the program, which began this month and will be completed in December 1996. The program is kept deliberately small in order to give students personal attention, said Dr. Vance, who added that men have consistently made up 25 percent of the second-degree program's student body.
The School of Nursing, Dr. Vance said, has four degree programs. "The reverse side of the second-degree program is the accelerated program we have for R.N.'s, which leads to a bachelor of science and nursing degree, something a lot of R.N.'s don't have. And we graduated 138 students in May with a bachelor of science degree from our traditional four-year program. We also have a graduate program for masters of science and nursing."
With the advent of health care reform, the graying of the population and the spector of AIDS, Dr. Vance said the demand and opportunities for nurses will "expand and grow to meet the many demands for health care that haven't yet been addressed." She continued: "The emphasis now is on keeping people well. For example, 20 percent of the population in all developed countries is now over 65. And AIDS patients are increasing. What does that signify? That large numbers of nurses will be needed more than ever for health maintenance and home care, making career possibilities for nurses wide open."
Graduates of the second-degree program come from all over the world and have jobs in all areas of health care. For example, Tatyana Falkovich, 42, is a Russian journalist who came to the United States five years ago and now lives in Mamaroneck. Mrs. Falkovich, who previously worked in a physician's office when she first came to the United States, learned about the second-degree nursing program in a newspaper, said her husband Igor Falkovich, a mathematician.
"It was something she liked," he said. "She did well in the course. She graduated in December with a 3.4 average. She is now working as a staff nurse in the general medical unit at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City."
Susan Cavalieri is a biochemist who lives in Larchmont. Mrs. Cavalieri graduated in December 1993. She said she put her first career on hold in order to be at home with her children. "When the time came to go back to work, I felt I really didn't want to be working in a lab all day," she said. "When you're bringing up children, you're constantly involved with people, and I like that, and besides nursing has always interested me. I found the program very intense and demanding and extremely comprehensive."
Mrs. Cavalieri, who now works for a home-care agency, said it took her time to find the right job. "At first I thought of doing research, combining it with nursing, but my children are still teen-agers so I decided it would be better for all of us if I worked closer to home."
But jobs were hard to get, she said. "A lot of hospital nurses were out of work as hospitals were cutting back, and I found myself competing with them," she said. "However, I think that this is only a temporary state of affairs. With the rush to managed health care, I feel that not only will professional nurses be in demand but they will have a lot of increased responsibility."

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 13; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1883 words

HEADLINE: Lessons Learned in School-Work Link

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
WITH a practiced hand and steady eye, David Ferrer examined a group of test tubes containing blood samples to be checked for Lyme disease at the county's Department of Laboratories and Research here.
Such procedures are standard for technicians in laboratories, but David is no ordinary technician. A recent graduate of White Plains High School, he was earning science credit through his school district's School-to-Work program, part of a recently begun national initiative to aid students' transition from school to the workplace. 
 A conference celebrating the first anniversary of School-to-Work was held at Westchester Community College on May 17.
Unlike other programs directed toward the vocational or noncollege-bound student, the Federal School-to-Work Opportunity Act, signed into law by President Clinton in May 1994, is intended for all students. As part of that initiative, New York State received $620,000 to develop programs, with $10 million allocated last year to put the programs into effect. It is possible that $20 million more will be made available this year, according to the national School to Work office in Washington.
Kevin Hart, director of Occupational Education for the Putnam/ Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, said: "It's not about vocationalizing schools. The object of this act is to have students see the relationship between school and work. We're asking districts to think of ways to infuse career education from the earliest grades. Business is interested in the bottom line. They're interested in employees and are very interested in the schools."
As a project that links schools, businesses and the community, School-to-Work is not merely a so-called shadow-job experience. "This has to be more than just employment opportunities," said Jondel Hoye, director of the School-to-Work Opportunities Office in Washington, a joint venture of the United States Departments of Labor and Education. "It's talking about building a system that lets everybody improve their ability to compete. The goal for us is to offer opportunities for all students and to have all employers participate. It's a continuum of the educational process. This is not a substitute for vocational education."
Dr. Augusta S. Kappner, assistant secretary of education for Vocational and Adult Education, said: "What's so exciting -- and so difficult -- is that this requires partnerships on all levels. The future will require all young people to work in careers and to change careers. This gives us a way to apply learning to the world of work. The idea is to invest in states and communities and to use local strategies in a way that integrates the academic and the vocational." In the county, several districts have started pilot projects. White Plains High School and the county are offering from seven to nine students on-site experiences carrying academic credit. Besides David, other classmates have been assigned to locations like the district attorney's office, public information office, and police academy.
Similarly, the Walter Pandas High School in the Lakeland school district has linked its English and math departments around the subject of medicine. Even fourth-graders at the Columbus Magnet Elementary School in New Rochelle had the opportunity to learn about the hotel industry, through classroom and on-site experiences at the Hyatt Hotel in Greenwich.
At the May 17th conference, Joseph Schwatzberg, director of the Occupational Educational Division of the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, announced the formation of the Westchester/Putnam Partnership, which has received $350,000 to begin pilot school-to-work programs in 12 local school districts.
"These funds are to help plant the seeds for systematic change in the public schools," said Dr. Schwartzberg. "We're not preparing our students for the middle-tier paraprofessional and technical jobs that will be available in the year 2000. The bar has been raised, and we have to meet those standards. At some point, all of us go to work. There's dignity in having preparation for work be part of public education, to be part of the fiber and fabric of the system."
The global economy, with its premium placed on technical and information-based skills, is one of the forces behind the school-to-work movement. "With the changes in society, all kids really need to acquire the skills that are required in the marketplace," said Shirley L. Mow, executive director of the Westchester Education Coalition, a nonprofit organization in White Plains. "While we may be complacent in the county, with our high achievement in many schools, compared to other countries, we're middling.
"Businesses are dissatisfied with what the schools produce, and can't hire graduates. There's a terrible waste of young minds and productivity. When the public educational system got set up, there was a factory model for high schools that was designed for mass immigrants. Now that industry has changed, we still have the same educational system. What we need is problem-solving skills, technology, communications and critical thinking. Young people need to have flexibility so they can adapt their skills to different environments and different requirements."
In school-to-work models, Mrs. Mow said, "the academic learning, the core curriculum of history, math, social sciences, English, is integrated into work-based learning." "The idea is to make it more relevant," she continued, "so that instead of just learning geometry, a student could see how it applies to career clusters such as architecture."
To those who would suggest that school-to-work might resemble internship models already in place in high schools or colleges -- like the 23-year-old senior internship program at Woodlands High School in Greenburgh, known as Woodlands Individualized Senior Experiences -- proponents of the current projects offer evidence of school-to-work's more rigorous approach.
"The difference between this program and the typical co-op is the explicit connection between the classroom and the requirements of the workplace," said Dr. Carol A. Rhoder, associate professor of education at the Pace University School of Education in Pleasantville. Dr. Rhoder's graduate students supervise the White Plains high school students, who are required to keep a journal about their experience, do appropriate readings in relevant professional publications as assigned by their on-site job supervisors, and do a self-assessment of their performance as well as an an oral presentation to faculty and supervisors.
"The focus is on developing kids' thinking skills," Dr. Rhoder said. "I'm traditional, and was really skeptical at first, but to even complete the requirements is very hard. The students put in as much time at the work site as in the classroom. It's a lot of work."
Such has been David Ferrer's experience. "I'm working a lot harder here," said David, who will be attending the State University of New York at Albany in the fall. "I wanted to try something new, to not just be one of the average students. It was frustrating at first trying to make exact measurements before I knew how to do it. What I liked best is that I got hands-on experience, and got to see what my education would be used for. Nothing could really prepare you for this kind of stuff."
His supervisor, Dr. Syed H. Abid, said: "In this department, we have a program for participating for training for the medical college students. In the beginning, I was apprehensive about having high school students. I wondered if their lab technique would be up to it, or if they would be overwhelmed by the sophisticated instruments we have.
"But I've been happy. David has been studious and eager to learn, and is a hard worker. He did all the assignments that I asked him to do. His level of work is equivalent to a freshman or sophomore college student. He was a help in our laboratory and I would be happy to do it again."
 
Teaching Facts of Life To Next Entrepreneurs
 NEW ROCHELLE
ON a sunny summer day, when most of their students would be at the beach, 25 or so high school teachers from the metropolitan area were gathered in a darkened conference room watching a video on how to adapt to change.
The teachers were taking part in a new program called Symposium for Entrepreneurship Teaching, under the auspices of the College of New Rochelle's Taylor Institute here. The three-day institute, offered free to the educators, was designed to provide a hands-on curriculum to teach entrepreneurship in the classroom. The two sessions, which ran July 10 to 12 and July 24 to 26, were sponsored by the Price Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies and the Coleman Foundation.
"Entrepreneurship is the engine that is driving our economy," said Russel R. Taylor, who founded the H. W. Taylor Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies at the college in 1988. "More and more people are starting new businesses. A recent survey by Gallup said that 70 percent of high school students want to have their own business. People do not start their own business to get rich, but to have control of their own destiny. Large corporations are laying off people. Even corporate managers must learn to think like entrepreneurs. So teachers are becoming more and more aware of the need to teach entrepreneurship."
Activities included exercises in using case studies for classroom discussion, a stock market contest to help students understand how the stock market functions, exploration of marketing strategies and suggestions for preparing a business plan.
The Taylor Institute will provide matching grants of $500 to the first 10 schools that put the program into effect.
Dr. Taylor's idea for the symposium grew out of his "Bizkids" program, which has been offered to high school students since 1992. It is currently available at New Rochelle High School and Blessed Sacrament/ St. Gabriel's High Schools. Students receive a $50 loan to purchase products for a business, and those who take part are expected to learn the basics of running a small business.
For the teachers enrolled in the symposium, enthusiasm ran high. "The program sounds terrific," said Noel Bloomfeld, who teaches business courses and computer operation at Our Lady of Victory, a Catholic school for girls in Dobbs Ferry. "I'm really big on what students need to survive in the real world and integrating classroom and real life experience."
Phyllis Rothschild, a business teacher at Eastchester High School, said: "Most of the kids are questioning the necessity of school. They don't have much experience relating what they learn to their lives. This makes it very real to them."
For several of the teachers, adding an entrepreneurial component to the business curriculum made sense in today's economic environment. "Everybody knows people who've lost their jobs after 20 years with a big corporation," said Rosanne Moore, a business education teacher at Yorktown High School.
"We're in the post-industrial revolution, and kids have to be able to deal with change. I think it's the wave of the future of our economy. And kids would like this program because it's hands-on and not theoretical." MERRI ROSENBERG

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk
