HEADLINE: Drums Along the Potomac

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is a senior editor of The New Republic and the author of "The Next American Nation: The New Nationalism and the Fourth American Revolution."

 BODY:

TO RENEW AMERICA
By Newt Gingrich.
260 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $24.
 
THE FREEDOM REVOLUTION
The New Republican House Majority Leader Tells
Why Big Government Failed, Why Freedom Works,
and How We Will Rebuild America.
By Dick Armey.
318 pp. Washington: Regnery Publishing. $24.95. 
IN 1961, Edward C. Banfield, lamenting the trend toward ideological politics in the United States, invoked France as a warning: "In France, every argument becomes a matter of principle; the practical results are relegated to second place." Two new books by Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, and Dick Armey, the House majority leader, prove that the transplantation to the Potomac of Gallic dogmatism has not been accompanied by a grafting of either Gallic rigor or Gallic subtlety.
The Gingrich book (platform? infomercial?) is impossible to summarize concisely. Stories of Capitol Hill politicking -- some of them quite interesting -- are interpolated among complicated programs for national policy, inspirational sermons and visions of the future glory of the Republic. Topics range from the Contract With America and the third-wave information age to welfare, defense, environmentalism and Rush Lim baugh. Many of the chapters are divided into multistep plans: "Seventh, we should develop a guest-worker program." But certain themes emerge.
Mr. Gingrich has replaced Jack Kemp as the spokesman in today's grim and prim Republican Party for a certain kind of optimistic futurism. Actually he is fascinated less by the real future than by a past future, the antiseptic high-tech future familiar to those of us who grew up between the 1939 World's Fair and the Apollo missions. Science fiction and adventure stories, he tells us, were better in the 50's: "When I was young, Frank Buck's Bring-'em-Back-Alive adventures, Lindbergh's solo flight across the Atlantic, Arthur C. Clarke's visions of space exploration and the American Museum's diving bell exploring the deep oceans made me believe there was a whole universe waiting to be learned and explored."
As this suggests, Mr. Gingrich, a true child of the media age, is constantly comparing the way the past represented itself with the way the present represents itself. "From the Jamestown colony and the Pilgrims, through de Tocqueville's 'Democracy in America,' up to the Norman Rockwell paintings of the 1940's and 1950's, there was a clear sense of what it meant to be an American," he says. For evidence of the health of American society in the 50's, he writes, "go and look at Reader's Digest and The Saturday Evening Post from around 1955." From the biography of George Washington written by another Republican professor-politician, Henry Cabot Lodge, a pioneer of rigorous German-style scholarship in the United States, Mr. Gingrich says he learned that "America must be described in romantic terms. . . . To me, America is a romance in which we all partake."
"To Renew America" should be subtitled "Songs of Innocence and Experience." The Speaker of the House introduces us to his inner child: "At heart, I am still a happy 4-year-old who gets up every morning hoping to find a cookie that friends or relatives may have left for me somewhere." There is no reason to think this kind of naivete is faux; sentimentality about childhood has been part of American culture since the 19th century. Indeed, we owe Mr. Gingrich's political career, we are told, to his visit to a city hall in 1953, when a kindly bureaucrat in the parks department listened to the little boy lobby for a public zoo, inspired by -- what else? -- the movies: "At 4 in the afternoon, after two exciting African safari films, I wandered into the sunlight dreaming of animals and adventure." The dream has not died: "Why not aspire to build a real Jurassic Park? (It may not be at all impossible, you know.)" Mr. Gingrich also now dreams of orbital honeymoons for the space-shuttle set: "Imagine looking out at the Earth from your honeymoon suite. . . . For those who have everything, a long trip in space will be the equivalent of today's sailboat or yacht or private airplane."
Dick Armey's book develops a more consistent argument. It is a duller read, even though an attempt has been made to liven it up with "Armey's Axioms," most of which sound as though Chairman Mao had been converted to Market-Leninism: "To diagnose our problems, we must understand the full anatomy of the political economy -- especially the invisible foot of the government." Like Mr. Gingrich, Mr. Armey would rather talk about economics than social issues. Though he bitterly denounces "radical feminists" and abortion on demand, he claims to find the answer in moral conversion to the antiabortion cause: "And the answer is right here, in the hearts of America's women."
Much of "The Freedom Revolution" is devoted to his retelling of American history as the story of an expulsion from a laissez-faire Eden, with Franklin Delano Roosevelt assigned the role of Satan, whispering seductively in the ear of the electorate. Satan's little helpers are the "talkers" -- that is, what Irving Kristol called the "new class," Dan Quayle the "cultural elite" and George Wallace the "pointyheads." The talkers serve conservatives as a focus for the diversion of discontent that might otherwise be directed at the people who bankroll the Republican Party: the hereditary rich, corporate executives, the professional elite and Wall Street speculators. Like other right-wing purveyors of new-class demonology, Mr. Armey divides the country into virtuous "doers" and sinister "talkers," who are divided into six subspecies: "politicians, educators, journalists, lawyers (!), theologians and entertainers." (Mr. Armey, an educator before he became a politician, must be the exception to the rule that people like him should be doubly distrusted.) The doers know what the talkers deny: "The market is rational and the government is dumb."
Having suffered under the oppressive rule of New Deal talkers since 1932, we Americans were liberated by the victory of strong but silent can-do Republicans in 1994. "My philosophical reason for writing this book," Mr. Armey tells us, "begins with the simple conviction that what happened last November really was, in every sense, a Freedom Revolution -- a revolution in the bold sense of scrapping an entrenched, arrogant political order, of tossing out the moneychangers." For all his revolutionary rhetoric, though, Mr. Armey is relatively modest in his prescriptions -- he only calls for reducing the size of the Federal Government by one-half.
The standards of intellectual honesty governing political tracts are notoriously low; even so, Mr. Armey violates them repeatedly. From figures showing a degree of upward and downward mobility in the 1980's, Mr. Armey infers: "All told, a person in the poorest income group in 1979 was more likely to end the decade in the richest quintile than to remain at the bottom." Really? Was someone making $10,000 in 1979 more likely to be making $120,000 than $12,000 in 1989? Mr. Armey, a former professor of economics, has bungled his math, and is trying to pass off his howler as evidence that "Ronald Reagan proved, as John Kennedy said, that a rising tide lifts all boats."
Mr. Armey tortures history as well as census data in the service of his cause. This is how he describes the heroism of Lech Walesa: "One day some shipyard workers led by an electrician decided, to hell with the millennium, to hell with 'power principles' and 'dialectics' of history and all that." Nowhere in his encomium to Mr. Walesa does Mr. Armey mention that this "small group of people with a great deal of courage" belonged to a labor union.
OF the two Republican leaders, Mr. Armey undoubtedly is more representative of the right, in his combination of anti-statism, anti-intellectualism, anti-feminism, anti-New Dealism and just plain anti-ism. Mr. Gingrich, like Mr. Kemp (who has been marginalized by the right for his pains), wants to include F. D. R. and Martin Luther King Jr. in an ecumenical pantheon. (To be sure, he makes the condescending argument that King triumphed because he proved that blacks are "capable of the personal responsibilities that went with" the rights of citizens.) What is more, Mr. Gingrich, who claims that everything worthwhile that liberals want to do can be done by more market-oriented or decentralized means, sounds at times like a neoliberal. A fundamentalist free-marketeer like Mr. Armey could not have delivered himself of the following: "We have all seen society change for the better in recent years in its views on smoking, drunk driving and racism." (Typically, and perhaps tactically, Mr. Gingrich neglects to mention that coercive acts of the state have been inseparable from all three reforms.)
Mr. Armey is an ideologue, Mr. Gingrich a politician. Mr. Gingrich's elastic first principles give him a degree of strategic maneuverability denied to someone tied to a program, like Mr. Armey. If Mr. Gingrich did become President, his book suggests that the right would soon be denouncing him for betraying conservative ideology by moving to the center. Indeed, the figure in American politics whom Mr. Gingrich most resembles is another graying baby boomer from the South who is also voluble, at home with pop culture and adept at manipulating the media, and who also combines a technocrat's fascination for detail with a philosophy so vague that it can justify any reversal of direction. Mr. Armey's hopes for ideological purity in the Freedom Revolution may yet be dashed by his colleague and leader, the Republican Party's answer to Bill Clinton.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 23, 1995

SECTION: Section 6; Page 24; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1833 words

HEADLINE: NOT SO FAST

BYLINE: By Bill McKibben; Bill McKibben is the author of "The End of Nature." His latest book, "Hope, Human and Wild," will be published in September.

 BODY:
HERE'S A SHORT CHEMISTRY LESSON. Grasp it and you will grasp the reason the environmental era has barely begun; perhaps you will grasp the history of the next 50 years.
Put a gallon of gasoline in the tank of your car and go out for a drive. Assuming your engine's well tuned, burning that gallon of petroleum should put about half a pound of carbon in the form of carbon monoxide -- CO -- into the air. A generation ago that number was closer to one pound; by decade's end, as new technologies clean the exhaust, it should drop to barely a tenth of a pound. The steady decrease in CO emissions, as well as in those of nitrous oxide and particulates, is the reason the air is clearer and safer now in Los Angeles than it was a generation ago. 
 On the same drive, however, that gallon of gas will transmute itself into almost five and a half pounds of carbon in the form of carbon dioxide. Long considered proof that gas was burning cleanly, invisible and odorless CO2 is the inevitable byproduct of fossil fuel consumption. It doesn't matter if your car's old or new; there's no filter you can stick on the exhaust to reduce CO2 production. And if the wide international consensus of scientists is correct, this carbon dioxide is now warming the planet more quickly and to higher temperatures than ever in human history.
CO versus CO2 . One damn oxygen atom, and all the difference in the world.
If you focus on carbon monoxide, then you can count yourself among the currently fashionable environmental optimists. Pollution, from their perspective, is an unfortunate byproduct of an essentially sound system. Since smog and its many analogues (river pollution, acid rain, crowded landfills) are precisely the sorts of things that can be tamed with filters and scrubbers, or with small changes in human behavior like recycling, the optimists are in some ways right. Though Congress is even now gutting the laws that have begun to clean America, and though there are plenty of poor and minority communities that never began to get cleaned in the first place, the technology exists to diminish smog, to purify drinking water. It's merely a matter of finding the will to pay for it -- there's no reason for rivers to catch fire. (And every poll suggests that the will is there, that after a quarter-century of hard-fought environmental campaigns the American people are far more convinced than their congressmen that the environment is worth cleaning up.) So if CO turns out to be the real issue, then it's just a systems problem. Environmentalism is a success story, and the world we die in will resemble the one we were born into, albeit with more computers.
That's the conventional wisdom of the moment, best expressed by Gregg Easterbrook in his recent book, "A Moment on the Earth." And yet there are those of us who are not soothed -- who grow more worried with each passing month, and not simply by the fact of a Republican Congress. Those in this second camp tend to be focused on problems like widespread extinction, growing populations, dying fisheries and dwindling wilderness -- signals, like the ever-expanding cloud of CO2 , indicating that our societies and their appetites have simply grown too large. Signals still all but ignored.
Since the environmental movement began, all these crises have been lumped together. The same people who worried about clean air worried about recycling and species extinction, about dirty rivers and the press of population. All these causes are important -- now more than ever as the right attempts to undermine environmental protection -- but acting as if they were all essentially the same crisis carries risks as well as benefits. While it's certainly easier to focus on things like smog, which people see around them every day, the logic of focusing on the most visible pollution cuts both ways. Such a narrowly pragmatic vision is potentially paralyzing precisely because you can clean urban air, you can return fish to the Great Lakes, you can recycle enough to keep landfills from overflowing.
Unfortunately, you can do all these quite vital things without having any real effect on the more systematic troubles. The progress we've made in solving environmental problems is deceptive: we're making no progress at all on the deeper problems, because they do not spring from the same sources. One set stems from a defect in the car; the other set comes from the very existence of the car. And in an odd way, solving the first kind of problem makes the deeper ones ever more intractable -- if visible air pollution starts to decline, then the push for better mass transit dwindles, and with it the chances of cutting the invisible CO2 .
The environmental movement, in other words, has reached a diagnostic crisis. To use a medical analogy: The world has presented itself, complaining of chest pains. After three decades of examination, there are still those who insist it's indigestion and want to prescribe some Bromo. Others say arteriosclerosis, which means our most basic behaviors must change. Most people -- not just C.E.O.'s -- badly want to find out that our problems are not related to our life styles. Change frightens us: we've come to believe, for instance, that our well-being is lashed to constant economic growth. "It's the economy, stupid."
And yet the basic laws of chemistry may soon demand that we give up such fixations. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of scientists assembled by the United Nations, has calculated that an immediate 60 percent reduction in fossil fuel use is necessary to stabilize global climate. This could not happen in a world that closely resembles ours. Addicted to growth, busily spreading our vision of the good life around the globe, we are sprinting in the opposite direction. The growth in our economies and populations wipes out our incremental gains in energy efficiency: from 1983 to 1993, despite a tremendous push toward efficiency by power companies, Americans increased their per capita power usage by more than 22 percent. Electric utilities offered rebates for installing compact fluorescent bulbs, and, indeed, between 1986 and 1991 the typical household added one such light. But as Andrew Rudin pointed out recently in Public Power magazine, the typical household also added more than seven incandescent lamps.
Since the greenhouse effect and other consequences of our civilization's basic momentum have yet to hit us full-on, no mass movement has developed to challenge that momentum. "We are in an unusual predicament as a global civilization," Al Gore said when I interviewed him early in his Vice Presidency. "The maximum that is politically feasible, even the maximum that is politically imaginable right now, still falls short of the minimum that is scientifically and ecologically necessary." And that was before Newt Gingrich.
But this state of affairs may not last. According to the most accurate computer models of global climate, for instance, increased global temperatures may be obvious to the man in the street by decade's end. For all the right-wing bluster about taming the environmental movement, for all the happy-talk books about our ecological triumphs, it will take only a hot summer or two, a string of crop failures or some similar catastrophe to bring these issues center stage once more. A spate of recent studies has begun to make clear that an average temperature increase of only a few degrees hides tremendous heat waves, droughts and storms; the insurance industry has actually begun to worry publicly about the greenhouse effect and the losses it will cause.
If and when such stresses really show themselves, though, we will need an environmental movement that understands what is happening -- that understands that more recycling is not the main answer, that is willing to advocate the unpopular and the disturbing. Partly this means a stepped-up political campaign -- continual pressure on governments around the world to sign and fulfill treaties, share renewable technologies and pass steep new taxes on the use of fossil fuels and other polluters. Already a small segment of the environmental movement has begun to focus on such issues.
But remember the numbers. A 60 percent reduction in fossil fuel use? Even under the most hopeful technological scenarios, it won't happen if we're simultaneously doubling or tripling our economies. More money makes reducing smog easier, because you can afford to build better cars; more money makes dealing with the greenhouse effect harder, because you can afford to buy more cars. So the sweet dream that we'll all grow rich enough to turn green is simply that -- a dream, and one that will turn into a nightmare if we try to follow it.
We face tough choices. The most pragmatic realism, rooted in the molecular structure of CO2 , demands electric cars. It also demands nothing less than heresy: an all-out drive for deep thrift, for self-restraint, for smaller families. Brute objectivity requires new ideas about what constitutes sufficiency: smaller homes, more food grown locally, repair instead of replacement. Environmental visionaries have always talked about simplicity and community, but now atmospheric chemists are starting to say the same things. Not for esthetic and moral reasons, but for eminently practical ones. The world can't support a population of five and a half billion people living like middle-class Americans, much less the eight or nine billion that will soon share the planet with us. That's the crux of the issue -- that and the fact that as long as we go on living the way we do everyone else will want to as well. We need China to stop burning so much fossil fuel -- the developing world now produces as much CO2 as the developed -- but China will pay no attention until we start cutting back too.
Clearly, it's as immoral as it is impractical for us to demand that underdeveloped countries remain underdeveloped -- those countries passionately want to develop. But it's terrifying to imagine Asians owning cars in the same numbers as we do. The only way out of this dilemma is to rethink what we mean by "development" -- and to do it here first. We've exported our passion for democracy, our devotion to human rights. But that's not all we've exported. More than a billion humans, one in five of us, watch "Baywatch" every week. If the good life whose pictures we flash around the world doesn't change, then all the treaties on earth won't do the job. We need bicycles and we need buses, and we need to make them seem as marvelous as Miatas.
Rush Limbaugh has it right when he denounces environmentalists as a threat to current ways of life. The systemic environmentalism he fears has one question to ask: "How much is enough?" How much convenience, how many people, how much money? It's a question that won't go away. It's a question with a time limit, too: either we make these changes soon, or it won't be worth the bother.

HEADLINE: The Life and Times Of a Young Rock Band

BYLINE: By ERIN ST. JOHN KELLY 

 BODY:
IT was one of the first warm nights of this cold dark spring. Sri Kesava, a.k.a. Kim Shopov, the pigtailed lead singer of Baby Gopal, was pacing a Brooklyn club, as nervous as a teen-ager giving her first really hip and life-defining party. Ignoring her, a bartender in a "Stupid Is as Stupid Does" T-shirt and an old Polish man ate fried chicken out of Styrofoam containers at the bar. Their chomping on wings and drumsticks appeared undisturbed by the sounds from the black hole of the back room. From behind the gold brocade curtains drifted the band State of Execution's acknowledgement of thanks to "everyone who came down to see us." As recompense the band promised to open up with its song "Whore" for the 30 or so present. The refrain was a predictable "she's a" over and over. A handful of black T-shirted, shaved heads slammed into each other, moshing and snacking from canisters of Pringles potato chips to keep their energy fueled.
For Sri, things were messing up. She and her band had arrived at the show about an hour late. They had apparently been driving around the hinterlands of Greenpoint for some time, perhaps even catching cruel, taunting glimpses of the isle of Manhattan, where they would really rather be playing instead of being ironically relegated to the 996 Club on Manhattan Avenue. Nonetheless, jumpy and swigging from a bottle of imported water, Sri made her way to the sound and light man, who seemed to have had some power over the doings, and she gamely jockeyed for a spot sooner rather than later among Sour, Pittfall, Struggle Within, Nemenon and State of Execution. 
 "If a girl approaches and makes a case to them, people don't get rough and tough," she said later.
By Any Means Necessary is the prevailing credo in the self-perpetuation of a struggling band in New York, particularly at a time when the success of bands like Nirvana has, by most accounts, helped to swell the number of aspirants on the alternative rock scene. "Instead of rock music being on the fringe, bands like Smashing Pumpkins, Nirvana and Pearl Jam have made kids pick up guitars, and they want to be in bands," said Richard Sweret, a vice president of A&R at Arista Records.
Clubs like 996 are an all-important preparation and honing experience for the big time. And though the Brooklyn scene may be burgeoning for artists -- a kind of refuge for a New York Bohemia elbowed out of Manhattan by a heartless rental market -- most musicians still have their eyes focused intently across the river. All along Houston Street, on the Lower East Side and in the East Village are bars and clubs that have long been proving grounds for musical waves. And there are other places that open up and close much like clams disappearing into the wet sand. Some that endure have become hallowed grounds of rock -- places like the venerable and filthy CBGB's on the Bowery, which opened in 1973 and where the likes of The Police toured with their first album and Sonic Youth played in the 1970's. And there are places like Brownies on Avenue A and the Mercury Lounge and The Spiral on East Houston and The Knitting Factory, now in TriBeCa. The coveted prize in the struggles among the bands is a slot at one of these clubs, or in venues like the New York Music Festival, which ended yesterday.
Small bands face the common traps and obstacles: personal feuds, individual life goals, disorganization and no money. Baby Gopal has a nucleus from Washington and Sydney, Australia (Sri's hometown), and a fluidly staffed rhythm section currently from Boston and Brooklyn (by way of New Jersey). It does not have a booker or a record deal. Nor does it have a manager.
For now, the ad hoc answer is Sri, petite, blonde, aerobicized, a Krishna follower and at 25 the oldest band member. She has relentless energy for the finances, the scheduling, the phone calls, the merchandising, the selling of the band. She spends her days in the tiny hot office Baby Gopal shares in the Hari Krishna temple on Schermerhorn Street in Downtown Brooklyn with the like-minded band Shelter, trying to get the band dates, planning rehearsals and even stringing the beaded necklaces they sell at their shows along with T-shirts, 7-inch singles and stickers.
"Blood, sweat and tears I tell you," she says. "Takes 10 phone calls to to make one show."
One of the more tangible goals of this band is the eventual ownership of a van, but meanwhile the mode of transport is the guitar player's father's car. On this night in Greenpoint they played with a borrowed bass player, Justin Hogan, too. He was imported from Boston by Al Garcia-Rivera, the drummer, to fill in for a missing Ray, who was in Oregon getting her braces off. Neither Justin nor Ray would be seen nor heard from again. This kind of impermanence plagues nascent bands.
At about 12:30 A.M. (Sri's entreaty had shortened the wait by at least one band) Baby Gopal played a set, sold a single and then loaded up and set out for home, a few members, at least, dreaming that their submissions of promo packs and tapes would pay off somewhere, and that they would someday be be playing before rapt crowds and appreciative bookers.
"It is so bizarre how everything is concentrated on that little hot-dog," Sri says of Manhattan. "If it fell into the ocean the world would be in a void."
 
NEW YORK IS THE MEDIA BASE, 'THE BEST PLACE TO PLAY
 Sri came to America, to New York, to succeed in a way not possible in Sydney. "I decided to spread my wings instead of sit in my own bath water," she says.
"This is where all the labels are," she says. "Where all the magazines are. It is the media base and the best place to play. Boston, New York and D.C. are all accessible from here, and they are the core of alternative music."
Jim Testa, the publisher and editor of the rock fanzine Jersey Beat, says bands are starting younger and hanging in for longer, describing Nirvana's 1992 album, "Nevermind" as a seminal moment.
"It used to be the only reason you played out was because you loved it," he says. "Now being in a quirky original band you can have a reasonable expectation of making a living." He says this is why mediocre bands are "choking the city."
Baby Gopal defines itself against the rock scene in one way. Three of the members are Hari Krishna followers, "devotees" as they call themselves. Band members say they practice sexual abstinence, don't wear leather, indulge in any mood enhancers or eat meat, though there is a vegetarian schism as to whether dairy or onion and garlic are permissible digestibles.
All is not completely forsaken of the traditions and rites of rock. The band is at least multiply pierced and tattooed. And three of the members toil away in minimum-wage employment -- Gayatri, 22, doing part time office help at Road Runner Records; Al, 21, working at the Gap; Alex Burke, the 22-year-old bass player, the child of a Linden, N.J., detective, working at an organic bakery. (She also demonstrates coffee machines at Macy's in Brooklyn on Sundays.)
Sri is otherwise unemployed. Her last job, months ago, was as a companion to an old woman on the Upper East Side who kept giving Sri, who favors athletic-inspired wear, "nice" clothes to wear and had no inkling of Sri's lifestyle. Sri suspects the woman "was a Republican."
Also following in rock tradition the members want to get on MTV, but there are compromises they will not make. Sexiness of the female members is muted to cuteness. At worst their beliefs are a means of exposure; at best, they seek to be a clean-living influence on those who would listen.
The members want to make it so they can give something back, they say. "Fame is wasted on the dizzy," says Sri. They express modest dreams of success.
"I hope to live off my music and stop working at the Gap" said Al the drummer, who "experimented with cigarettes and beer" in seventh grade, but "gave it up."
Sri likens forming a band to finding a marriage partner. Only harder, because you need to find more than one and all at the same time. "It is difficult finding similar music taste, levels of ambition and commitment to the project" she says. Like securing the ideal mate, luck and the misfortunes of others often plays a part.
In March 1994, after arriving from Sydney and acquiring a green card, Sri had what she considered a "really cute" name for a band -- Baby Gopal, the childhood name of Krishna -- lots of ambition and a readymade genre: "Krishna Edge," a somewhat ethereal, pop-like brand of punk descended from "Straight Edge," a hardcore style based on the rejection of drugs, drink and fascist politics.
But Sri had no actual band.
Enter Gayatri, ne Graham Land, a guitarist on a visit home from England. They were introduced by mutual musician friends while Sri was in Washington. For the next three days they worked on songs together and Sri said she spent time "coercing, begging and torturing him to stay and do my band." They wrote three songs but he resisted her siren song. But he resurfaced a few months later and succumbed.
"In my heart I just knew, here is someone I love writing with," she said. "He was frustrated in England." And Sri had quite the lure: she had secured her band a tour.
The band formed with Sri, Gayatri, Al on the drums and a bass player named Leila. They convened to Connecticut and practiced for a week before hitting the road. Leila designed the band's logo and they had T-shirts and stickers made.
"June was a really happening month," Sri says.
The month-and-a-half long tour kicked off at "The Grand," a club in the East Village. "Oh, don't even mention that show to me," Sri sighs. "Everyone's got to go through it, like their first driving experience. I felt like a big dork. I didn't have any of my raps between songs down."
Surviving dorkiness, the group launched its tour, becoming familiar with promoters and gathering fans in places like the Cootie Hut in Florence, S.C. They formed the beginnings of an all-important mailing list of fans, fanzine writers and promoters.
But the tour ended and the band didn't have anywhere to come home to. It lost Leila, who formed her own band with a member of Shelter to whom she was coincidentally engaged. The band members scattered. Al went back to Boston and his girlfriend. Sri and her boyfriend, Ray, the leader of Shelter, moved to New York. Gayatri didn't want to leave D.C. but then came to New York to do what "was best for the band."
So they shopped for a rehearsal space and a place to live, and realized that they couldn't afford much. Neither Sri nor Gayatri had revenue-generating jobs. They ended up with a deal at the Hari Krishna temple in Downtown Brooklyn. The converted synagogue on Schermerhorn Street had room that was cheap and easily renovated.
Their rehearsal space wasn't completely perfect -- it shared a wall with the bingo hall next door. G-5, I-7 being called is clearly audible to the band and the riffs and melodies of Krishna Edge were clearly audible the other way, too. On both sides of the wall people pursued their dreams but Baby Gopal's rehearsal times, so vital to its pursuit, were curtailed as a courtesy.
This winter the band played in Washington and Boston. Soon the band convulsed. The band's second drummer's girlfriend fell into a coma and he had to resign mid-winter. But Al broke up with his girlfriend in Boston and thus unfettered could rejoin the band on drums. The band got a woman named Ray on bass after Leila left. But then Ray disappeared into Oregon to be relieved of her braces. By May they had Alex Burke, and Gayatri was teaching her the Baby Gopal standards like "Tofu" and "Shiva."
There was also a mishap: the band lost a show at ABC No Rio on Rivington Street for failing to get its lyrics on time to the management, which reserves the right to clear the bands for ideology.
Late June brought very good news: J.P., the booker at the coveted Knitting Factory in TriBeCa, called and offered a place on the bill for July 8. This was a needle in a haystack. Gayatri had dropped off a tape at the club in December. Someone at The Knitting Factory finally listened to it.
"Once or twice a month we try to give somebody a break," says Michael Dorf, owner of the Knitting Factory. "We sift through hundreds of tapes and pick stuff that's interesting and not being done. Stuff that is different."
Displaying her customary super-tenacity Sri says: "Getting shows in Manhattan is different than elsewhere where friends and word of mouth work. In New York you drop your record off and then harass them. Like Chinese water torture, you keep dropping water on the same spot."
It broke prisoners, it broke the Knitting Factory. Asked about her hopes for the show, she was guarded and cryptic. "I see the beginning of a relationship with that venue. J.P. is obviously serious about encouraging younger bands."
 
THE NIGHT OF THE SHOW
 At 6 P.M. July 8, Sri, Alex and Al the drummer were running late after a day of sunbathing on the roof of the Krishna Temple. They were late, said Sri, because they were "mental about clothes." Sri had scavenged a piece of Mary Quant-ish polyester, and had sewed an elastic waistband into it to make a long skirt. Alex sported extra-large black hiphop jeans belted below her pierced navel with an Army/Navy store web belt, and Al had buttoned a plaid cotton shirt to the neck with a pair of knee-length cutoffs. Gayatri selected a Bobby Brady T with clean blue jeans, which were instantly greasy after loading the cars with the band's instruments.
Baby Gopal was to open for the Knitting Factory's Main Room bill, which included Baby Tooth, John S. Hall and Fly Ashtray. The $6 show started at 9 P.M. with a 7 P.M. sound check. When the band arrived and found it could put 10 people on the guest list, it made quick calls to friends who could not afford the cover. Baby Gopal met Baby Tooth and after a friendly negotiation, Al agreed to share the drum kit and Alex finagled the bass amp.
The players were chatting nervously. Only four people sat at the bar. Sri wondered out loud whether there was some "alternative scene" in New York that she was not plugged into. The band got fruit and nuts from a local deli, and stood outside the club munching. Alex's fiance arrived, and three other guest-list people came, which seemed to calm the band a bit. As the sun went down, a small line formed to pay the cover charge.
At one point, Sri shook her head loose from a tight ponytail and asked Gayatri "Up or Down?" "Down." That settled, Sri's shorn locks (a la Debbie Harry 1978) had a halo mark where the elastic had been.
At 9:15 P.M. the band took the stage. The audience, now numbering close to 20, stood feet apart in the roomy space. The audience members were clean cut and largely male. They wore oversize T-shirts and below-the knee cutoffs with suede sneakers, mimicking the band. The few young women looked even younger than their ages, with braided pigtails and pleated skirts. One audience member fondled his prayer beads and chanted, barely audible.
"Thanks for coming," announced Sri. "We're Baby Gopal, the first of the Babies tonight." The band launched into its first song. The audience beat time to the music.
In between songs, Sri asked, "Are there any vegetarians in the room?" One of the beer-drinkers shouted, "I like my food dead," and another "Meat is cheap."
"Really?" said Sri, and Gayatri broke the tension with the lead-in to the next song.
At 9:45 the band ended with "Shiva," and the small audience, which had dwindled only slightly, politely applauded.
The band was not satisfied. "I could only hear me," said Alex. "I started to move around a little but I looked out at the audience and saw mostly my friends, so I stopped. It was like playing a rehearsal."
Life looked cheerier the next day. Gayatri returned on Sunday to collect the proceeds.
"We made $107 for the night," said Sri. "We were really pleased with that. Eighty people came through the door throughout the night, and about a quarter of them were there for our show."
Because of the turnout, Sri said, the Knitting Factory booker was fairly enthusiastic.
"It looks like Baby Gopal will be doing more shows there," said Sri. "We've made another New York contact."
And then she added: "Sometimes I really think we'll make it. It seems like you really have to want it."
 
Rock 101
A Hardcore Curriculum
 
1 Computer as Tool -- "Use the Internet" says Michael Dorf, the owner of The Knitting Factory. It is a "whole new medium" to get word out about your band out.
 
2 Bartender Primacy -- "If you are forming a band, you might want to ask a bartender to join first," says Glenn Boothe, A&R and product manager at Caroline Records. Bands with the most friends win. "Clubs don't have that much patience. Even if the promoter likes your show, you have got to pull in a crowd."
 
3 Whole Lot of Love -- "A person or group must have a sense of what they love -- and get good at it," says Hilly Crystal, owner of CBGB's. "It is the emotion that makes them different. After all, the notes are all the same."
 
4 Corn -- "Do all the things that seem really corny," says Jim Testa, editor and publisher of Jersey Beat, a quarterly fanzine. "Be persistent. Work really hard. Keep a list. Mail out postcards. Be picky about where you play."
 
Other advice:
Mix in the club scene of the Lower East Side and East Village and give your band time to gel.
Be lucky.

HEADLINE: Japan's Leaders to Stay On Despite Poor Election Showing

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, July 24

 BODY:
Voters humiliated Japan's governing coalition in nationwide elections on Sunday, weakening its authority but apparently allowing it to remain in power for the time being.
The immediate result may be to paralyze decision-making even further. But in the medium term, it could bring forward new general elections and stimulate a far-reaching political realignment in Japan. 
 "A political vacuum cannot be allowed for even one day," Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama declared at a news conference this morning. "So we have decided to continue in office."
 The coalition Government may be able to remain in power because Mr. Murayama's Socialist Party apparently squeaked by with enough seats that he will not have to resign to take the blame. But it was the Socialists' worst performance on record.
If the result is that the Government remains in office, but weaker than ever, that is the most disappointing outcome of all for American officials. A weak coalition is unlikely to take measures to deregulate and stimulate the Japanese economy, as Washington would like.
The elections were for seats in Parliament's upper house, which is less important than the lower house. The lower house chooses the Prime Minister, and so Mr. Murayama was not on the ballots.
Yet this was the first national election since the collapse in 1993 of a political system under which the Liberal Democratic Party had governed continuously for 38 years. Inevitably, it was regarded as a referendum on Mr. Murayama and the Socialists, as well as on the other members of his coalition.
The Socialists were the biggest losers. They elected only 16 members to the upper house, out of 126 seats up for election.
In contrast, they had held 41 of the seats up for election. The party had set a goal of 22 seats, the same number it won in the upper house three years ago. Members of the upper house serve six-year terms, with half elected every three years.
The main reason that Mr. Murayama may be able to hold on to his office is simply that the coalition is so fragmented that no one knows what would happen if he did resign. None of those with a hand in power seem eager to risk finding out.
Nevertheless, most major newspapers called in today's editions for early elections, saying that the Government had been so weakened that it would be unable to lead Japan effectively.
The Liberal Democrats, who dominate the coalition even though they allow Mr. Murayama to be Prime Minister, won 46 seats. This was more than any other party, but still much less than expected.
The poor performance may affect who is chosen in September to lead the party, and thus to become a leading candidate for prime minister after the next general elections. The present Liberal Democratic leader is Yohei Kono, who is also Foreign Minister, but the poor results could encourage a challenge by Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Trade Minister.
Mr. Hashimoto emerged strengthened from his confrontation with the United States over trade in autos and auto parts, leading to a last-minute settlement in June in which both sides declared victory.
The outlines of what may eventually become a two-party system were faintly visible in the election results. A substantial majority of the seats were won either by the Liberal Democrats or by the New Frontier Party, a new grouping that favors more rapid deregulation and economic and political restructuring.
The New Frontier Party won fewer seats than the Liberal Democrats but psychologically was the biggest victor. It won 40 seats, up from the 19 it had held among those up for election.
Ichiro Ozawa, the secretary general of the New Frontier Party, urged Mr. Murayama to resign or call new general elections. Elections are expected later this year or early next year, but the Prime Minister -- whose decision it would be to call early elections -- appears unenthusiastic about hastening a vote that presumably would result in his party's losing influence in the lower house as well as the upper one.
Voter turnout was 44.5 percent, easily the lowest in any postwar national election. The previous worst turnout was just over 50 percent.
The poor turnout seemed to reflect general distaste for the political parties and the process. A Gallup poll found that 32 percent of Japanese respondents were dissatisfied with the way democracy works here.
Partly because the parties are awkward coalitions of rival factions, they hesitate to take strong positions on specific issues.
Indeed, one of the few parties to take a clear position on a policy matter was the tiny U.F.O. Party, which ran candidates on a platform of making Japan a leader in hospitality toward extra-terrestials.

HEADLINE: Amid Old Brooklyn Factories, A Shrinking Canvas

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
In the last 15 years, artists by the hundreds have advanced on a desolate warren of empty factory buildings and cobblestone streets in Brooklyn known as Dumbo, for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass.
As traffic rumbled overhead, the artists propped up their canvases and put up curtains in sooty Civil War-era buildings abandoned by manufacturers. They began a Friday pizza night as babies were born. They did their laundry by hiring a car service to take them to gentrified Brooklyn Heights next-door. They became patrons of a local espresso bar that serves freshly baked biscotti and cappuccino with extra foam. They felt blessed to be in a quiet old factory district much like SoHo before it became SoHo. 
 But tensions are simmering now in Dumbo, and artists used to living on the edge are living more precariously than ever before.
Interest has grown in developing the waterfront property along the East River. The Jehovah's Witnesses are quietly buying old buildings and noisily jackhammering them to the ground to construct buildings for missionaries that include a health club. And landlords who once welcomed the artists have chilled to their presence.
"I want them out of here so bad I can taste it," said Martin Prince, an owner of a factory building who inherited more than a dozen homesteading artists when he bought the property 14 years ago. "I feel like they are animals and they ought to be put in cages. We're trying to get rid of them. They are in our way."
One painter, Sara Pasti, who pays about $200 a month for a 2,000-square-foot loft apartment, said: "We feel under siege. They are not passive in their desire to have us disappear."
If there is a place off the beaten track, artists in search of sun-drenched space and dirt-cheap rents will find it, just as they did in SoHo three decades ago and as they are doing now in Williamsburg, Red Hook and Greenpoint, in Brooklyn, and Jersey City and beyond. To a large degree, artists tend to define -- both geographically and intellectually -- the resurgent neighborhoods of a city.
Dumbo is a forbidding outpost lined with dark industrial buildings, some with broken windows and graffiti. Mainly an industrial and commercial district, its choppy, potholed streets are deserted at night. Its artist population grew from a couple dozen artists in the late 1970's to more than 400 in the late 1980's but has slipped back to about 200 artists as eviction battles have escalated and worn nerves.
The area has no legal boundaries but is loosely defined by artists as perhaps four blocks wide and seven blocks long, south of the Brooklyn Navy Yard where the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges nearly converge. One section on its southern border is better known as Fulton Ferry Landing. The name Dumbo is thought to have been coined by an artist who lived there some years ago.
"All of a sudden, everybody has discovered the neighborhood that nobody wanted," Councilman Kenneth Fisher, who represents the community, said. "It's unfortunate that it's taken on this threatening air."
Ms. Pasti, who paints portraits of imagined families, has watched Dumbo transform since she settled in 1980 on the top floor of a factory building at 195-201 Front Street. She has carved out a studio for her large canvases and a cozy loft apartment with $20,000 in renovations. Her bedroom, in a freight elevator shaft, is decorated with a ceiling fan, a throw rug and an antique dresser.
On the factory floors below her, there was once the gentle hum of sewing machines. She saw one doll factory go out of business. Then, a company that produced polyester jackets came and went in the mid-1980's, followed by a factory that made lampshades. A garter and suspender factory expanded its business on the second floor after another company moved away. On the ground floor, Mr. Prince, the president of DLX Industries and the building's landlord, has kept busy manufacturing vinyl products like briefcases and folders, between his court battles to root out about a dozen artists. "They're sleazy but they're not stupid," Mr. Prince said.
The artists' existence in Dumbo hangs by a thread on the Loft Law, passed by the State Legislature in 1982. The law requires landlords to bring industrial lofts up to residential occupancy codes and protects tenants from eviction. More than 12 years after the law was enacted, owners and tenants in Dumbo are at each other's throats over the artists' right to remain. Only 250 out of 820 city-registered loft buildings have been legalized.
Before the Loft Law was passed, landlords were only too happy to have anyone paying rent, and the city looked the other way while artists moved in illegally.
In Ms. Pasti's building and in a 100-year-old factory building next-door at 223 Water Street, the landlords say that they cannot afford to convert industrial lofts to legal residences under Loft Law provisions, and that hazardous, flammable materials make them unsafe for tenants. They have filed hardship claims before the city's Loft Board.
"What I'm trying to do is to bring this building back to a cash-positive flow basis as well as improve the building." said Marsha Egeth, a vice president of Horizon Steel Corporation, a manufacturer of storage cabinets. She helps manage the Water Street property that her father bought in 1975. "We're almost bankrupt because of all the legal bills."
On a recent afternoon, Ms. Egeth gave a tour of the dark nooks of the building, stacked with boxes, sheet metal and cabinets. She pointed to about 10 lofts occupied by artists, including one housing an expectant mother. "I'm hysterical," Ms. Egeth said, throwing up her hands. "I'm afraid of a developing fetus with all this chemical influence. It's toxic. They can't be in this building with what we do."
The disputes have gone beyond words, artists say. Their car tires have been slashed. One third of the tenants in the 24 apartments on Water Street were ordered to leave two years ago when an anonymous call was placed to the Fire Department and the loft apartments were found to be in violation of fire codes. Ms. Egeth said the events were not the doing of her management company.
But Deborah Masters, who creates concrete sculptures in a 5,500-square-foot loft for which she pays $700 a month, said tenants in her building on Water Street are each paying $200 a month in legal fees to stake their claim.
"The pressure is real estate," she said. "Because we're here, rich people want to be here also. That's what happened to SoHo. A few artists were there. Then, wealthier people who were art-world hangers-on moved in, and now fashion models are there. Artists can't afford to eat in SoHo anymore."
What Dumbo lacks in galleries, boutiques and easy access to public transportation, it makes up for in a stunning view of the Manhattan skyline and a stark, cinematic quality. A week does not go by that film crews are not shooting scenes for commercials, music videos and movies, Councilman Fisher said.
Over the years, a number of developments have been proposed for the prime waterfront property. David Walentas, the primary developer in Fulton Ferry Landing, envisions a waterfront filled with shops, entertainment, a marina and a park. "It will happen one of these days," he said. There is a separate community initiative, called Brooklyn Bridge Park, that would transform Piers 1 through 5 and the Empire State Park into a regional recreation area.
Some artists are convinced that the encroaching presence of the Jehovah's Witnesses from their world headquarters in Brooklyn Heights also has put dollar signs in the eyes of landlords and exacerbated efforts to evict them. That claim is vigorously denied by landlords who say they have not been approached by the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society of the Jehovah's Witnesses.
The Witnesses began a massive acquisition campaign in Brooklyn Heights about 15 years ago, buying up old hotels and brownstones. The city shot down their plan to build an apartment tower that would have blocked the view from the Promenade. The Witnesses set their sights on Dumbo, where fewer people live, according to Mr. Fisher.
In the last few years, the Witnesses have rattled the artists in Dumbo who know how to tangle with landlords but not how to deal with a religious group that keeps to itself. On Front Street, the Witnesses have bought at least five old buildings, including a public school and a former lead company, and demolished them, one by one. A deep pit, consuming a city block and surrounded by a corrugated metal fence lined with razor wire, now sits in readiness for a Watchtower printing operation. Further down the same street, volunteer Witnesses are erecting a boxy beige building that will house a recreation center with tennis and racquetball courts and a parking garage.
On a scorching day, the construction workers were expressionless as Mariella Bisson, who paints landscapes, and Ms. Pasti strolled by.
"They are pushing their empire in any direction it will go," whispered Ms. Bisson. "Every business they do business with, they own. It's amazing. They're like army ants. What do you say? They are just going to look at you with robot faces and tell you that your concerns are so well articulated and have you read the Watchtower today. I'm a deeply believing pagan goddess; don't mess with me."
The artists fear that the Witnesses will swallow up their buildings and leave them homeless, but a spokesman for the religious organization said their worries are groundless.
George M. Couch, a vice president of the Watchtower Society of New York, said that the only two sites planned for the area are the recreation center and the printing plant. Last year, the Witnesses opened a 30-story hotel near the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, on Sand Street, for 900 missionaries.
"We've got about all we need, unless it would be something very usable right next to it," Mr. Couch said.
Statements like those do little to allay artists' concern.
"If we are kicked out, in five years, the whole neighborhood will be empty of artists," said Bill Nogosek, a painter dressed in black jeans and a black T-shirt with a silver cross around his neck. "Obviously, there is a big plan in the works."

HEADLINE: Whither CBS?

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., July 23

 BODY:
If the Westinghouse Electric Corporation completes a bid for CBS Inc., the reaction inside CBS may be muted relief that the eight-year reign of Laurence A. Tisch as chairman will end.
But the only truly happy people may be at CBS's competitors, cheered that the new owner would be Westinghouse and not an entrepreneurial company with better prospects of reviving the network's sagging fortunes. Executives from the competing networks and analysts said a CBS-Westinghouse combination would pose little threat of a quick comeback for the network. 
 CBS, which as recently as two years ago was the leader in prime-time programming, is now a distant third. And in its recent second-quarter financial report, earnings were down 52 percent, primarily because of lower advertising revenue and higher fees to station affiliates to remain part of the CBS network.
Both inside and outside CBS, Mr. Tisch's policies have been blamed for CBS's lowly position in the industry. His decisions have included selling off CBS's nonbroadcast properties like its music division, declining to expand the business by buying into cable or international interests as his network competitors have done on a large scale and spending only cautiously in areas like buying more television and radio stations.
Because CBS has minimal debt, and might easily have invested more aggressively in its existing operations or expanded into new ventures, critics have been particulary harsh about Mr. Tisch's stewardship.
"CBS is being systematically dismantled," said John Tinker, a media analyst with Furman Selz. And he and other analysts have serious doubts that Westinghouse -- which already has a heavy debt load that it would have to increase to buy CBS -- is the right company to rejuvenate the network.
"Whoever gets CBS has to ramp it up," Mr. Tinker said. "In the media now you have to compete with whole companies, the Time Warners and Seagrams of the world. These are big guys. CBS and Westinghouse, they're not big enough. You've got to have scale. This is not scale."
Beyond speculation about whether Westinghouse is really what a hungry and depressed CBS needs is the question of Mr. Tisch's intentions. The CBS chairman, who last year made a deal that was later abandoned to merge the company with Barry Diller's QVC Network, has not commented on the current negotiations with Westinghouse. Nor has any other CBS executive indicated, even off the record, what involvement Mr. Tisch has had in helping to shape an offer from Westinghouse.
But Mr. Tisch and several advisers did meet with Michael H. Jordan, the Westinghouse chairman on Friday in Manhattan at the headquarters of the Loews Corporation, which Mr. Tisch also controls. Those talks are expected to resume on Monday, according to executives familiar with the discussion.
Wall Street analysts also suggest that Mr. Tisch's interests are being served by leaks of information to the news media about the Westinghouse bid, because Westinghouse's overtures may flush out other potential bidders who might feel the need to come in -- and push up the price beyond the $80 a share, or $5 billion total, that Westinghouse is expected to offer. Since last Monday, when word of Westinghouse's intentions began to spread, CBS shares have climbed from slightly more than $65 to close on Friday at $75.25, up 37.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Tinker of Furman Selz said almost any of the other media companies that had reportedly looked into buying CBS in the past -- including Turner Broadcasting, Walt Disney, Viacom and Time Warner -- would be better suited than Westinghouse to bringing the network quickly up to speed, both in programming and the alliances the network needs in cable and other forms of media. But, he said, none of those companies have been willing to pay Mr. Tisch's price.
At least one other potential bidder has again expressed an interest, however. Ted Turner of Turner Broadcasting said at an award ceremony honoring him here Friday night that he would have 30 days after a Westinghouse bid is accepted by Mr. Tisch in which to prepare a bid, and that he intended to do so.
But he also said he would first have to complete a deal to buy out Time Warner's 17 percent interest in Turner Broadcasting. Time Warner has long resisted Mr. Turner's broadcast-network ambitions, just as it has resisted his efforts so far to buy back its stake in his company. On Friday, even Mr. Turner characterized his hopes of bidding for CBS as a long shot.
And yet, for some CBS employees the prospect of Mr. Turner's taking over the network makes much more sense than a deal with Westinghouse. After hearing Mr. Turner's comments, one CBS executive said that much of the programming staff was very concerned about Westinghouse's limited media portfolio.
"I really hope Ted isn't joking about making a bid," said the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Among the potential benefits he cited was that CBS News could combine its efforts with Mr. Turner's CNN. Mr. Tisch's rounds of cost-cutting have hit CBS's once-vaunted news operation particularly hard.
The main question about Westinghouse is whether it can infuse the capital that CBS would need for a comeback. The network's own executives concede that they need to spend money on National Football League coverage and other important sports events. The N.F.L. rights they relinquished to Fox last year will come up for renegotiation in two years.
Analysts also contend that CBS needs to find a way to get into cable programming, a field in which ABC, NBC and Fox are all quite active. "Is Westinghouse going to have enough left after paying $5 billion to pay for anything CBS needs?" asked Dennis McAlpine, who analyzes media and entertainment companies for the investment firm Josephthal, Lyon & Ross.
Westinghouse does have a long history in broadcasting. And its radio and television stations, while not the industry's strongest, are generally considered to be well run. CBS's own stations have turned in only average performances in terms of ratings and profits in recent years, compared with the stations owned by ABC and NBC.
Still, a combination of the Westinghouse and CBS stations would give the company the largest base of stations, if not the strongest, in the country. The combined 13 television stations would reach some 30 percent of the national television audience -- if pending Congressional legislation raises the current 25 percent, 12-station limit, as expected.
Who would run CBS for Westinghouse? William C. Korn, chairman of Westinghouse's broadcasting unit, Group W, is not seen as a likely candidate for the job.
But there may be no need for Westinghouse's chairman, Mr. Jordan, to bring in anyone from the outside to lead CBS. The programming has recently been put in the hands of Leslie Moonves, a highly regarded entertainment executive. Both Mr. Moonves and Peter Lund, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, have strong reputations.
"They can do what you need if they're allowed to do more," Mr. McAlpine said.
Mr. Tisch has always backed his programming department with a strong budget, and he reportedly paid more than $10 million to lure Mr. Moonves from his job as head of Warner Brothers Television. And earlier this year, CBS signed an exclusive deal with Steven Bochco, creator of NBC's "NYPD Blue" and other hits, to develop programs for CBS beginning next year.
But CBS has not made any of the expensive, ground-breaking program deals that ABC has made with new production companies like Dreamworks and Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, nor has it spread CBS's program base to cable and international networks.
Westinghouse's strategy, according to those following the proposed deal, will be to cut back on its other businesses in favor of a streamlined communications company. For many at CBS, that may sound distressingly similar to CBS's "pure broadcasting" strategy, which has left them without interests in cable or international broadcasting.
"The good news is that you find two hits and all the economics change," Mr. Tinker said. "The nightmare is that '60 Minutes' falls apart. Then you've got real problems."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1551 words

HEADLINE: Universities Taking On Risks To Overcome Fiscal Squeeze

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Facing bigger student financial-aid needs and shrinking government support, a growing number of top universities are pulling endowment money out of stodgy investments like blue-chip stocks and bonds and putting it into much riskier, high-flying corners of the financial markets: venture capital, leveraged buyouts, hedge funds and emerging markets like Poland and Mexico.
Yale University, which pioneered the approach and has embraced it most aggressively, now puts roughly 60 percent of its portfolio into less-conventional -- and generally riskier -- investments. Duke assigns half its endowment to such investments, and Brown and Notre Dame a third each. 
 "The reasons for this are simple," said Scott C. Malpass, chief investment officer at Notre Dame. "The traditional sources of revenue, like tuition and government support, are not going to be as predictable as they have been."
Many universities believe they have already raised tuitions as much as the market will bear. And because tuition is so high, they are using more and more of their own money for student financial aid. At the same time, government support of the universities is unlikely to grow.
So, while Orange County, Calif., Procter & Gamble and others have lost money in risky investments like derivatives, which sometimes looked more like wagers than investments, many financial experts, instead of being alarmed, are cheering the universities' strategies.
Even the recent loss of $128 million by a rogue broker handling accounts for the Common Fund, a nonprofit company that manages $20 billion in investments for some 1,400 universities, appears not to have daunted them.
"We have some level of comfort with the universities that are doing this because of the diversification," said Naomi Richman, a vice president and assistant director of the public finance department at Moody's Investors Service, the financial rating agency, which has given many of these universities its highest borrowing ratings.
Some investment experts, however, express concern. One pointed to the mid-1970's, when colleges ventured to put more money in the stock market and into growth stocks where the profits come from appreciation in price rather than dividends only to be pummeled by a bear market of 1974.
"I'm supremely suspicious," said John Train, a New York investment manager. "This brings back disagreeable memories of '72-73, when university money managers were seized by a rapture that led them into excess risk, and they were punished horribly in '74."
Although recent years have proved relatively kind to many of these investors, there have been missteps and losses, most of them kept relatively quiet. Harvard, for example, marked down its high-risk investment portfolio by $200 million in 1992, when some of its nontraditional investments lost value. Harvard's total endowment was more than $4.7 billion then. It tightened its controls, but stayed with its overall approach.
One widely followed investment expert, Barton M. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, holds up Yale as an example for other institutional investors like pension funds.
"In order to get double-digit returns on any substantial portfolios for the next 5 or 10 years, you are going to have to be in less-conventional assets," he said.
He points out, "Inevitably there will be dark moments."
Universities like Harvard have been drawn to the alternative investment strategy because it is getting harder and harder to beat the markets, said D. Ronald Daniel, Harvard's treasurer. "In some cases, these investments have gotten riskier and more esoteric," he said. "That is not necessarily bad per se. But if you don't have good controls, you can be taken in."
Although the Ivy League universities and other large, top-ranked institutions have generally moved the farthest, smaller colleges are following.
Swarthmore has gradually been increasing its nonconventional investments and now has about 18 percent of its $500 million investment portfolio abroad -- about a third in emerging markets -- and 10 percent in venture capital, high-yield bonds, corporate reorganizations and other alternative investments.
In recent years, these strategies have paid off and generally outperformed the stock market. In the fiscal year ended in June 1994, for example, when the S.& P. 500 index of stocks was up only 1.4 percent (and the Lehman Brothers aggregate bond index was down 1.3 percent), Yale earned 12 percent on its portfolio, Duke 7.7 percent and Brown 6.3 percent.
The more aggressive approach has allowed universities to use millions of dollars that they earn in the markets to help pay for salaries, student aid and other costs, and still pour millions of dollars back into their endowment funds to offset inflation.
For universities with large endowments, investment income can cover a substantial portion of their costs. Swarthmore, for example, draws more than 30 percent of its operating revenue from earnings on its endowment, Harvard more than 20 percent, and Williams, Bowdoin, Amherst and Smith more than 15 percent of their operating revenues from investment income.
In the current investment climate, many universities have determined that they can afford to spend an amount equal to about 5 percent of the assets in their endowments each year. This means they must earn more than 5 percent just to match inflation.
If the inflation rate for educational spending is running at about 4 percent a year (it tends to be higher than consumer inflation), the university then needs to earn a return of 9 percent on its investments to cover the spending and to maintain the real value of endowment.
An extra 1 percentage point return on $100 million brings a university an extra $1 million -- equal to 40 students paying full tuition of $25,000. As of last year, 163 colleges and universities had endowments of more than $100 million, while 17 had endowments of more than $1 billion. The endowment pool for all American universities is $120 billion.
For many universities, the more aggressive strategies are a complete turnabout from where they were just 25 years ago.
Under trust and estate law, it was widely accepted that holders of endowed funds were allowed to spend only what they earned in dividends and interest, and not the increases in the value of the principal. So most invested in conservative stocks and bonds with high payouts and little price appreciation, rather than taking advantage of growth stocks whose prices were soaring but that paid small dividends. As inflation climbed through the 1960's, the real value of their endowments shrank.
McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, berated colleges and universities for their excessive caution. He set up a panel that helped to reinterpret the trust law -- and alter the investment culture -- by changing their focus to an investment's total return, not just the money it actually paid out annually.
Soon, colleges began to invest in a broader range of stocks, and the stock market portion of their portfolios began to climb. Unfortunately, just as they began to move into stocks in the early 1970's, stocks plummeted, and then languished for most of the rest of the decade. It was not until 1982 that the stock market really took off.
Yale was among the first universities willing to enter into less-traditional investments, acting on the belief that as traditional securities markets became increasingly efficient, it had to turn to areas where the market is less efficient to get higher returns. Newly developed investment theories offered further incentive, by showing that riskier investments did not necessarily add up to a riskier portfolio, but that done right, could even cut risk.
The strong performance of universities like Yale, which had an average annual return of 15.5 percent from 1984 to 1994, is helping to convince others that they, too, should move more strongly into alternative investments. For the 10-period ended June 1994, the median investment pool for about 400 colleges and universities achieved an annualized return of 12.7 percent, according to the National Association of College and University Business Officers.
But smaller universities, often with smaller, less-sophisticated staffs and less money to invest, have turned to the Common Fund, the nonprofit investment management company that the Ford Foundation established in 1971 to help colleges and universities improve their sparse returns. In 1988, the Common Fund set up a separate investment arm specifically to handle private investments in energy, real estate, venture capital and other private equity. And notwithstanding the investment problem last month, the Common Fund has done quite well.
Others are also beginning to offer similar help. One new consultant is William Massey, a former chief financial officer for Stanford University and a professor there. He is working with the P. R. Taylor Group, a financial counseling firm in Palo Alto, Calif., to develop investing strategies, to offer advice on the mix of investments and to help in managing investment advisers.
"We think we can bring this technology to smaller colleges," he said. "If you develop a broadly diversified strategy, it can be very profitable."

HEADLINE: At Yale, an 'Original Thinker' Gets Results, and Attention

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
From a roll-top desk in a Victorian mansion on the edge of Yale's campus, David F. Swenson directs the investment of the university's endowment portfolio and other assets.
At 41, he has already run the portfolio for 10 years -- a decade during which Yale's investments have earned an average annual compound return of 15.5 percent, putting it in the top 1 percent of all institutional funds and helping to push the university's endowment to $3.6 billion from $1.1 billion. (Between 1984 and 1994, investment income added $3 billion, while gifts added another $350 million. During that same time, the endowment contributed $880 million to Yale's budget.) He has drawn the attention not only of other university treasurers but also of Wall Street professionals. 
 Barton Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, calls Mr. Swenson, "a very bright, original thinker who is also very brave, because victory has a thousand alumni fathers but defeat is an orphan."
As at many universities, Mr. Swenson, as chief investment officer, works closely with the business and financial heavyweights who make up the university's investment committee. In any week, he will often be in touch with one or more members with expertise in an area he is thinking about putting money into.
The committee of 14, which meets quarterly, includes Sid Bass, the Texas billionaire; Diana Brooks, the head of Sotheby's; Richard Franke, chairman of John Nuveen & Co., the municipal bond specialists; Charles Ellis of Greenwich Associates, a financial consulting firm, and William Poorvu, a Harvard Business School professor and private investor.
Yale made early forays into alternative investments beginning more than a decade before Mr. Swenson's arrival: leveraged buyouts in 1973, venture capital in 1976 and international stocks in 1980. But it was not until he showed up in 1985 that it systematically began to direct larger sums into these areas.
The slot of chief investment officer had been open more than a year, before William Brainard, Yale's provost, wooed Mr. Swenson, a senior vice president at Lehman Brothers. Mr. Swenson had earned a Ph.D. in economics at Yale and had studied with Mr. Brainard. Although some universities, such as Harvard and Princeton, pay some of their investment professionals salaries on a par with Wall Street, Yale does not, and Mr. Swenson took a huge pay cut, lured by campus life in New Haven, Conn., and the chance to teach, as well as to help Yale.
So far, the university has done well. Over the past two decades its private equity investments -- where it takes a direct stake in a company rather than buying public shares -- have earned percentage returns in the mid-20's. That has helped raise the average return rate on its portfolio. The 15.5 percent per year average return over the last decade is not far from the performance of the stock markets themselves, but well above the performance of many other universities and institutions.
