HEADLINE: Corestates Drops Proposed Merger With Bank of Boston

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Corestates Financial of Philadelphia and the Bank of Bostonannounced yesterday that they had called off a $4.2 billion merger. It was the third time that a potential merger has fallen through for the Boston bank.
The banks said yesterday that they "were unable to agree on a plan that provides sufficient benefits to our shareholders, customers, employees and communities." They had intended to announce the merger this morning. 
 Investors and analysts cheered the collapse of a deal that offered little in the way of cost saving or revenue gain. "Thank God," said Nancy A. Bush, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman.
Hundreds of executives of both banks were poring over each other's books on Saturday before Terrence A. Larson, Corestates' chairman, called off the deal that night.
People close to Mr. Larson said he was troubled by the cultural fit between executives of the two banks. Investment bankers also pointed to the negative reaction of investors; the stock of both companies fell sharply after word leaked of a preliminary deal Thursday night. And the Corestates board may have had concerns about leaving Philadelphia without any major bank company headquarters; the first bank in the country was founded there.
Some investors have been hoping that the Bank of Boston would choose to be acquired outright for $50 a share or more, compared to the roughly $38 in Corestates stock they would have received in the scuttled deal, which had been termed a merger of equals.
Last week, the Mellon Bank Corporation was willing to merge with the Bank of Boston, offering slightly more stock than Corestates; the merged bank would have been based in Boston, a prerequisite of the Bank of Boston board. Nationsbank, and perhaps others, are thought to be willing to pay still more for complete control of the company.
The Bank of Boston board met last night. Afterward, the company sent a statement to its employees indicating that the talks with Corestates had been rocky. While "initially encouraged" by a common focus on customer relations, it said, "it became clear that a common approach would not extend to other aspects of this potential combination." And it did not rule out future talks with other likely partners.
"This is a total embarrassment for the Bank of Boston," said an investment banker.
Ms. Bush of Brown Brothers Harriman said: "Of all the deals that I have ever encountered, that would have been by far the worst. The only thing those banks have in common is the lack of credibility of their managements."
At the beginning of this year, the Bank of Boston was close to merging with Fleet Financial Group of Providence, but when negotiations dragged, Fleet instead bought the Shawmut National Corporation of Hartford. Later, the Bank of Boston was negotiating to merge with First Fidelity Bancorp, but that bank instead sold itself to First Union Corporation.
In these and other negotiations, the Bank of Boston and its chairman, Ira Stepanian, have had a reputation for being difficult and adding conditions after the other side thought terms were complete.
Those familiar with the Bank of Boston said the string of thwarted deals has strained the relationship between Mr. Stepanian and the bank's board.
The Bank of Boston has fewer attractive options left. It could still try to find a similarly sized merger partner willing to move to Boston. But such a deal would hardly please shareholders looking for a premium, and the bank's bargaining position has weakened.
The board could give up its effort to keep the bank based in Boston, and simply auction the company to the highest bidder. Analysts said the bank could probably bring $45 to $47 a share, less than some investors have wanted. The Bank of Boston's mix of business is not the sort for which a big bank would pay top dollar, analysts said.
The majority of its earnings comes from lending to large corporations, one of the most competitive and least profitable areas of banking. About 20 percent of its earnings come from Latin America that while lucrative are of interest only to the handful of the largest banks. Consumer banking, which benefits most from the economies of scale in mergers, represents only 20 percent of the Bank of Boston's profits.
The most likely course now is that the Bank of Boston will halt deal-making and try to remain independent, at least for a while.
"We think we have a very viable company," Charles K. Gifford, the Bank of Boston's president, said in a brief telephone interview yesterday.
But some analysts questioned whether the board would continue to support Mr. Stepanian and Mr. Gifford.
The negative market reaction "does not reflect well on Bank of Boston's management," Ms. Bush said. "There is not a sense that there is a firm hand at the tiller. I would like to see stronger oversight by the board."
Ms. Bush says she is not calling for Mr. Stepanian's ouster, however, because management switches at banks often cause other problems.
Corestates, as a medium-size bank, is also seen as a takeover target, but as such, its stock has risen so much that it would be difficult for a larger bank to buy it at a premium over the current market price.
"Corestates stock is already selling for two times book value, so it's harder for someone to buy it than to buy the Bank of Boston," Ms. Bush said.
Corestates is also in the middle of an extensive restructuring program meant to cut its annual costs by $180 million and analysts do not expect it to rush out and look for another deal.
The uproar among shareholders may quiet the rapid wave of bank mergers. Five deals valued at more than $1 billion have been announced so far this year, three in the last month.
"The outcome here has ramifications beyond the Bank of Boston," said Orin S. Kramer, general partner of Boston Provident Partners, a Fort Lee, N.J., investment fund specializing in banks. "It stands for the proposition that shareholder interests will not be ignored. It became clear to them that had they gone forward, the deal would have been voted down."
Several bank investors said that large holders of Bank of Boston put pressure on Corestates to scuttle the deal, in effect threatening to become hostile shareholders of the combined bank.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Reports Nearby Firing Of 4 Test Missiles by China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 23

 BODY:
The Taiwan military authorities said today that China had fired four test missiles off its southern coast on Friday and Saturday, about 85 miles north of Taiwan.
The missile tests, announced last week by the Chinese Army, appear to be one of several steps taken by China to highlight its displeasure with recent efforts by Taiwan to gain international recognition. 
 Tonight, the New China News Agency issued an official commentary accusing Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, of plotting with "some people" in the United States to declare the island officially independent, and of revealing his plans during a visit to Cornell University last month.
The commentary also accused Taiwan of trying to "squeeze" its way into the United Nations, where China replaced Taiwan in 1971. Mr. Lee recently offered to ease the United Nations' financial woes with a $1 billion contribution.
China has recently threatened to invade Taiwan if it declared independence, even though it has been politically and economically separate from the mainland since Nationalist forces retreated to the island at the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Although Western military analysts do not foresee any invasion soon, last week's missile test announcement sent Taiwan's stock market diving more than 6 percent and forced 144 commercial flights to be re-routed to avoid the area of the tests, which Beijing said would last a week starting on Friday.
"We have spotted four missiles fired by China, two on Friday and two on Saturday," Reuters quoted a senior official from Taiwan's Defense Ministry as saying. "We will continue to keep on high alert for any further activities."
The surface-to-surface, short-range missiles were fired from the Leping military base in the southeastern province of Jiangxi and apparently carried no explosives, according to reports in Taiwan. One missile missed its target and landed harmlessly in the sea, the military official said.
Taiwan newspapers also reported that China had deployed a number of warplanes along its eastern coast, 170 miles across the Taiwan Strait.
A spokesman for China's Foreign Ministry, Shen Guofang, played down the significance of the tests, saying they were normal military exercises.
"If you have an army, you have to conduct exercises," Mr. Shen said.
Yet the timing of the tests left little doubt among Western military and political analysts that they were intended to carry a larger message.
Tonight's commentary reinforced it, accusing Taiwan's President of colluding with "some people" in the United States "who always always follow a policy of opposing and splitting China."
"This is the first time for him to have displayed such nakedness and openness in preaching the separation of the motherland by taking advantage of the forum provided by foreigners," the statement said. "The atmosphere surrounding his attempt to build himself up with the help of foreign forces is also hitherto unknown."

HEADLINE: In America;
Sweatshop Beneficiaries

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The hundreds of thousands of young (and mostly female) factory workers in Central America who earn next to nothing and often live in squalor have been an absolute boon to American clothing company executives like Donald G. Fisher, the chief executive of the Gap and Banana Republic empire, who lives in splendor and paid himself more than $2 million last year.
Judith Viera is an 18-year-old who worked at a maquiladora plant in El Salvador that made clothing for the Gap and other companies. She was paid a pathetic 56 cents an hour. If she wanted to use the bathroom, she had to go through the humiliation of asking a supervisor for a ticket. Anyone who stayed in the bathroom too long was punished by being sent outside to sweep the grounds in the hot sun. 
 Donald Fisher should meet Judith Viera, spend some time with her, listen to her as she describes in a still-childish voice her most modest of dreams. She would like to earn enough money to buy a little more food for her mother and two sisters. She would like to go to high school.
But Donald Fisher is a busy man. It takes a great deal of time to oversee an empire balanced on the backs of youngsters like Ms. Viera (and her counterparts in Asia). After all, the Gap had sales of $3.6 billion last year. And Forbes magazine reported that Mr. Fisher himself is worth $1.5 billion.
No, Donald Fisher wouldn't have time for the likes of Judith Viera. Besides, if they had an honest conversation, Mr. Fisher might come to the conclusion that the maquiladora workers were being exploited. That is a conclusion to be shunned with the same intensity that tobacco executives muster for their denials that cigarettes cause cancer.
The free-trade zones in which the sweatshops flourish in Central America and the Caribbean were promoted by the U.S. Government and largely financed by U.S. taxpayers. They are a scandal. In August 1990, the ludicrously named Salvadoran Foundation for Social and Economic Development (Fusades), a group almost entirely financed by the United States Agency for International Development, placed an ad in Bobbin, a major trade magazine for the apparel industry in the U.S.
The glossy full-color ad showed a young woman seated at a sewing machine in a shirt factory. The text spoke directly to executives in the United States. It said: "Rosa Martinez produces apparel for U.S. markets on her sewing machine in El Salvador. You can hire her for 57 cents an hour."
The ad went out of its way to explain that "Rosa is more than just colorful." It assured the executives who would be shelling out the two quarters and seven pennies an hour that "she and her co-workers are known for their industriousness, reliability and quick learning."
In March 1991, the same ad ran in the same magazine, except for one minor change. "You can hire her for 57 cents an hour" was changed to "You can hire her for 33 cents an hour."
At some point between August and March it was decided that at 57 cents an hour the industrious, reliable and quick-learning Rosa Martinez was overpaid!
Warren Hashagen, a senior vice president at Gap Inc., said on Friday that he did not believe the maquiladora system was "inherently" exploitative. "We believe that it is important to pay at a minimum the legal minimum wage, or the prevailing wage for the industry, whichever is higher," he said. Whether that is a sufficient income for the wage earners, he said, is not his call.
"I'm not an economist," said Mr. Hashagen, "and I'm not an expert on Central America to know whether it's an appropriate wage for the cost of living there and for whatever is provided by the factory otherwise."
In fact, while companies like the Gap, J.C. Penney, Levi Strauss and many others reap the benefits, the maquiladora workers are suffering. In El Salvador, for example, they earn less than one-fifth of the amount needed to meet the minimum cost-of-living requirements. In the luxurious suites of the big U.S. apparel companies, the attitude is: that's their problem.

HEADLINE: Japanese Schools Are Different, Not Better;
Cultural Conditioning

 BODY:
To the Editor:
My 20 years as a student of the Japanese educational system lead me to different conclusions from your July 18 front-page article. 
 Japanese education is responsible for Japan's economic growth, you write. Many aspects of Japanese education you praise are cultural factors -- parental involvement, school as a community, shared responsibility for school facilities.
In Japan, "Government spending on education accounts for a smaller proportion of its gross national product than in the United States," you write. True, but Japan concentrates spending on precollegiate education. United States Government spending is weighted more heavily toward higher education. In addition, Japanese families spend far more on their children's education than American parents.
 
GARY DECOKER
Chairman, Education Department
Ohio Wesleyan University
Delaware, Ohio, July 19, 1995

SECTION: Section A; Page 7; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1146 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Prods Nicaragua on Seized Land

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua

 BODY:
From the day she took office five years ago, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has struggled with the thorniest problem she inherited from the Sandinista National Liberation Front: how to reimburse the owners of the thousands of houses, farms and factories that her predecessors seized as part of their program of social revolution.
Some 2,200 cases have been resolved and more than $260 million in bonds issued to former property owners. 
 But now the United States Congress, dissatisfied with the pace at which the Chamorro Government is compensating Americans who have claims to confiscated properties, is threatening to cut off aid to Nicaragua. That could be a severe problem in a country whose economy has just started to recover from a decade of civil war between the Sandinistas and American-backed rebels.
The get-tough attitude, championed by Senator Jesse Helms, the Republican from North Carolina who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Representative Robert Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, has been encouraged by the property owners themselves, hundreds of whom fled to the United States and became American citizens when the Sandinistas were in power.
"We are now U.S. citizens, paying taxes, and we don't see why our money should go to this country," said Luis Raul Cerna, a leader of the Association of Bondholders, one of several groups that represents owners of confiscated properties. "I want the U.S. Congress to tell the Nicaraguan Government that in order to get more aid, they must obey the law."
Nicaraguan officials say they are dealing with the claims as quickly as they can under difficult and confusing circumstances, and they have been pleading with the United States to be patient.
They point out that many of the properties were seized without legal formalities, creating a welter of conflicting claims and land titles that have overwhelmed the courts here.
"It is not that there is no political will to solve this problem," Foreign Minister Ernesto Leal Sanchez said in an interview here shortly before heading to Washington to argue Nicaragua's case. "It is that the problem is complex and immense."
To avoid a cutoff of aid, the Clinton Administration must certify by July 31, as it has in the past, that Nicaragua has shown progress in resolving the property issue and in correcting human rights abuses, or else grant a special waiver.
But Congress is considering legislation that would remove that authority from the President and place Nicaragua's fate in the hands of a hostile, Republican-dominated Congress. "They've got to show continued progress, and progress has slowed," Mr. Torricelli said in a telephone interview. "This is a new Congress, and we could just cut off aid."
American aid to Nicaragua, in the form of grants, loans, credit and debt forgiveness, has totaled more than $1 billion since Mrs. Chamorro took office, but has been declining and this year is less than $30 million.
Officials here say that what most alarms them is a provision in the Helms-sponsored bill that in the absence of certification would force the United States to vote against loans to Nicaragua in the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.
Nicaraguan Government figures show about 3,000 claims that have yet to be resolved, and the United States Embassy here calculates that about 1,100 of those involve American citizens. The confiscated properties include family homes and farms and ranches amounting to a quarter of the arable land in this country of 4.5 million people, and also factories, stores, machinery, mines and quarries and even shopping malls.
To satisfy all of the property claims, the Nicaraguan Government estimates that it must raise a total of $650 million. That amount, more than double the size of Nicaragua's foreign reserves and equal to two years' worth of the country's exports, is expected to be raised through the privatization of state-owned enterprises like the national telephone and electricity utilities.
Legislation to privatize Telcor, the state telephone company, and use the proceeds to pay off property claimants is pending in the Nicaraguan Parliament. But Mr. Torricelli challenged the seriousness of that effort, saying: "We've been through this discussion before. There are more imaginative ways to resolve some of these cases."
Emilio Pereira, Nicaragua's Minister of the Economy, said one-third of the claims for compensation had been filed by associates, partners and supporters of the Somoza family dictatorship, which was overthrown by the Sandinistas 16 years ago. The same group, he said, accounts for half of the claims that have been settled.
"They were the first to get American citizenship and the first to pressure Congress," Mr. Pereira said.
Much of the land the Sandinistas confiscated, initially from the Somoza family and then later from others considered unfriendly, was turned into agricultural cooperatives or given to squatters.
More than 170,000 families, most of them poor peasants or refugees from the violence of the 1980's who settled on the edge of Managua and other cities, now live on such parcels, though most are still waiting for formal property titles.
The issue is further complicated by the desire of many property claimants to return to their homes rather than accept compensation. Bayardo Arce, a Sandinista commander, and the Cuban Embassy moved into houses owned by the family of Roberto Arguello, president of the Nicaraguan-American Bankers Association, a situation the family still finds difficult to accept.
"Even though in terms of your overall net worth a house may mean nothing, 99 percent of those who had houses taken away want them back because they have such sentimental value," said Mr. Arguello, who now lives in Miami. "That's where you were born and played and saw your father kissing your mother. It represents family, values, tradition."
In addition, many of those already compensated with bonds are unhappy because the bonds are now worth only about 15 percent of face value. "The bonds are a joke right now," Mr. Cerna said.
But several officials here, like Luis Humberto Guzman, the Speaker of Parliament, say there is little legal justification for United States involvement in the controversy. Though many claimants are now American citizens, international law regards them as Nicaraguans, officials contend, because that was their nationality when the properties were confiscated.
The State Department said the American Embassy here "offers assistance regardless of when or how a claimant acquired United States citizenship." But it acknowledged that "principles of international law limit the ability of the United States to 'espouse,' or formally assume as its own, the claims of persons who are not United States citizens at the time their property was confiscated."

Juan Pablo Calero listened to the radio for the outcome of negotiations during a sit-in over the issue in the country's Parliament. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Goals Conflict In Plan to Sell Nuclear Unit

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
A plan by the Federal Government to sell the operations that produce fuel for the nation's nuclear power plants -- the largest privatization ever attempted by Washington -- has long been counted on to demonstrate commitment to leaner government. But with the White House ready to announce details of the sale this week, a debate is raging over whether such a sale would do more harm than good.
The central question is one familiar whenever a government sells off a chunk of itself: would a private owner's financial interests be at odds with the national interest? 
 In this case, critics of the plan are worried about what will happen to America's agreement to buy the uranium from 20,000 Russian bombs, which was to be diluted to make fuel for American nuclear power plants.
Eager to increase profits, the newly privatized business will have strong incentives to drive hard bargains with the Russians, even to the point of risking collapse of the deal, which is intended to keep the uranium from falling into the wrong hands, critics say. The privatization effort is a case study, they suggest, of the difficulties of mixing high diplomacy with a bottom-line mentality.
"We could end up with the worst of possible worlds," said Thomas L. Neff, a nuclear weapons specialist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who first proposed the swords-to-plowshares idea but is a critic of how it would be carried out.
Natural uranium metal cannot be used to power reactors or to make bombs until it is enriched, increasing the proportion of the lighter uranium isotope, U-235, to the far more common U-238. To that end, the Government has operated two giant plants in Kentucky and Ohio since the 1950's that manufacture virtually all the fuel for America's commercial nuclear reactors.
But the Department of Energy, which runs the plants, has been widely criticized for sloppy management and the enrichment operation was singled out for privatization by the Bush Administration. In 1992, Congress created an independent Government entity, the United States Enrichment Corporation, which was ordered to cut costs, improve marketing and prepare a plan for selling shares to the public by July 1995.
"We've transformed a Government bureaucracy into a corporate culture," said William H. Timbers Jr., a former investment banker who has been running the company since 1993. Many analysts agree.
The company, based in Bethesda. Md., has renegotiated its contract with the Lockheed-Martin Corporation for technical operation of the two plants, linking payments to productivity and safety. And, on schedule, Mr. Timbers's team produced a privatization plan to sell stock through a public offering or to merge the agency with an existing corporation. By the letter of the 1992 law, all that is needed to go forward is approval from the White House.
But privatization is far from a done deal. One hurdle requiring legislation involves the accounting of the $2 billion sales price for the purposes of deficit reduction. Under a 1985 law to prohibit gimmickry in budget-making, one-time sales of Government assets cannot offset spending. But both Republicans and Democrats are eager to make an exception for the enrichment corporation in order to support budget outlays.
Other barriers to privatization will not be so easily breached. The company wants to take with it not just the two plants but all the uranium controlled by the Department of Energy. And commercial rivals -- uranium mining companies, traders and processors -- are crying foul. James Graham, the president of Converdyn, a company that converts uranium to gaseous form for enrichment, puts it bluntly. "We can't compete with someone who gets the materials for free," he said.
Congressional sources suggest that a compromise is possible. Besides, those opposed to privatization on the enrichment company's terms have a far bigger fish to fry: the company's unique role in the sale of 500 tons of Russia's weapons-grade uranium.
In 1992, the Bush Administration agreed to buy roughly 40 percent of Russia's stockpile over the next 20 years to keep it from terrorists or rogue states. The deal will generate badly needed cash for Russia -- roughly $12 billion at current market prices. And it will provide employment for nuclear engineers who might otherwise be tempted to pursue their careers in Iran. But apparently neither the Bush nor the Clinton Administrations fully understood the legal and economic consequences.
Russia was already exporting substantial quantities of unenriched uranium, depressing prices in a glutted global market. Indeed, in 1991, the Department of Energy supported a suit against the states of the former Soviet Union that ended in agreements sharply restricting uranium exports to America.
The enriched portion of the Russian weapons-grade uranium has since been exempted from laws involving the dumping at unfair prices. But the exemption does not apply to the natural uranium component, which represents roughly a third of the value.
An American buyer of Russian enriched uranium could comply with the law by stockpiling an equivalent amount of domestic unenriched uranium. But this stockpiled uranium could not be resold until 2003 under the trade agreement, and the Russians are demanding payment on delivery.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, a longtime supporter of nuclear research, would compromise by permitting the Russians to sell the natural uranium component now for delivery in 2003.But with the delay in delivery, the price would not be as high. The Clinton Administration wants to go a step further, giving the President authority to exempt the natural uranium from trade restrictions if there is no other way to get full value for the Russians.
Another issue is the designation of the enrichment corporation as the "executive agent" -- as America's exclusive negotiator and buyer of Russian enriched uranium. This assignment seemed undisputable in 1992, since the company was part of the Government and was experienced in the handling and marketing of uranium fuel. A first small shipment from Russia arrived at the company's Portsmouth, Ohio, plant on June 23.
But Richard A. Falkenrath, a researcher at Harvard University, believes the exclusive designation is a disaster waiting to happen since the relationship between a privatized enrichment company and Minatom, its Russian counterpart, is "inherently adversarial."
Under the agreement, the American enrichment company and Minatom must renegotiate a price each year for the following year's delivery. But the American company has little reason to be generous, he says: the less it pays, the more profit it will make when it resells the fuel to nuclear utilities and the less capital Minatom will have to sustain itself as a competitor in the global market for enrichment services.
Indeed, Mr. Falkenrath argues that the American company has every reason to play tough, even at the risk of stalemate: the less Russian enriched uranium that reaches the market, the higher the market price of the enriched material that the American company produces. Moreover, he says, the company has no financial motivation to buy Russian enrichment services for more than its own cost -- which is roughly one-third less than the current world price.
Mr. Timbers, the enrichment company executive, makes no secret of his exasperation with these unflattering predictions of how his company will behave. He says a breakdown in the negotiations will lead the Government to name another executive agent. "We can be yanked on 30 days' notice," he said.
What is more, he said, collapse of the agreement would give competitors of his company a chance to buy the Russian enriched uranium. "The sale to U.S.E.C. will happen," Mr. Timbers insisted. "I have a strong incentive to be in the middle of the deal -- not on the outside looking in."
But this argument does not persuade Mr. Falkenrath, or a number of Administration officials who have pressed to modify the mechanics of buying the Russian weapons-grade uranium. They worry that it would be hard to identify the culprit if negotiations break down, and that the White House would be under substantial political pressure to defend the enrichment company.
If specialists in arrangements to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons are concerned that a privatized enrichment company will undermine the deal with the Russians, for-profit players in the nuclear industry are equally worried about the prospect that the enrichment company will pull it off.
Nicholas M. Nikazmerad, the president of Nukem, a division of the German conglomerate RWE, says "the intention of U.S.E.C. is to dominate the commercial nuclear market." He is especially critical of leaving it to the Russians to "blend down" the weapons-grade uranium into reactor fuel because Nukem runs a blending plant in Virginia in partnership with the Babcock & Wilcox Company.
Mr. Falkenrath would like to start afresh. In the best of plausible worlds, he says, a privatized enrichment company would become just another bidder for Russian enriched uranium. That is not likely to happen. It would require renegotiation of the agreement with Minatom, which in the past has been eager to deal with a single Government-backed American buyer. What's more, the loss of the right to act as executive agent would make shares of the enrichment company less valuable, depriving Washington of revenue and offending the members of Congress who represent thousands of union workers at the company's enrichment plants.
To be workable in political terms, any alternative arrangement must satisfy both President Clinton and Senator Domenici. The White House argues that the Government already has sufficient leverage to force the enrichment corporation to buy the Russian uranium at a fair price.
However, Senator Domenici will not easily go along with suspension of import restrictions that protect the feeble domestic uranium industry. Nor would he permit the enrichment company the luxury of weighing its own interests against national security in bargaining with the Russians. He wants to require the White House to open sales to other bidders if the company balks at buying the uranium on schedule.
If revenue from the sale of the enrichment corporation is to be counted in the next budget, a compromise must be reached by late September. Secretary of Energy Hazel R. O'Leary, who has championed the privatization effort as well as the Russian uranium deal, thinks it can -- indeed, that it must. "We're serious about both commitments," she said. "I'm prepared to see it to the wire."

HEADLINE: Clinton Attacks the G.O.P. On Priorities in Budget Plan

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
Vowing strong opposition to a Congressional budget plan, President Clinton today accused Republicans of abandoning necessary Government programs for the "luxuries" of carrying out large tax cuts and balancing the budget in seven years.
In a speech that aides said was the beginning of a period of concerted lobbying on the budget, Mr. Clinton came close to issuing a blanket veto threat if Republicans failed to heed his own spending priorities in areas like education, Medicare and environmental protection. He said such programs were the "common ground" -- a phrase echoing more frequently in the President's oratory -- and had long had bipartisan support. 
 "I invite senators and members of Congress from both parties to join with me in balancing the budget while protecting our common ground," Mr. Clinton said in an address to Boys Nation, the high school civics program of the American Legion. "If they refuse," he said, "I must continue to act alone if necessary to protect the common ground that brought every single one of you into this White House today."
Thirty-two years ago, Mr. Clinton himself visited the White House as a Boys Nation representative, and a photographer captured the now-famous scene of the Arkansas teen-ager meeting President John F. Kennedy.
White House officials said Mr. Clinton's speech would be followed with three or four budget-related events a week over the next two to three weeks.
On Tuesday, in a ceremony marking the 30th anniversary of Medicare, Mr. Clinton plans to speak out against the Republican program to save $270 billion in projected Medicare spending over seven years. On Wednesday, aides said, he will defend Government programs like empowerment zones to foster urban investment. And on Friday he will stump for education programs before the American Federation of Teachers.
After months of watching from the sidelines, Mr. Clinton stepped into the fiscal debate in June, outlining his plan to balance the budget over a decade instead of across seven years as is favored by the Republicans. He proposed slowing the growth of Medicare far less than the Republicans would and offering smaller tax cuts, targeted to the middle class.
But he has been virtually ignored by the leaders of the Republican-controlled Congress who have persisted in their drive to erase the Federal deficit by 2002. And House and Senate committees are drafting spending bills that make vast cuts in Government programs long cherished by Democrats, like those for day care, housing, job training, the arts and environmental regulation.
Mr. Clinton underlined the points made in his speech with a statement tonight threatening to veto an appropriations bill passed earlier by a House committee that would pare dozens of health and education programs.
On 26-to-15 vote that followed party lines, the House Appropriations Committee approved the measure providing sharply reduced financing next year for the Departments of Labor, Education and Health and Human Services.
The White House now fears a massive "train wreck" of a budget fight in September and October that could shut down the Government. The new Federal fiscal year begins on Oct. 1.
With that confrontation looming, the President today began his campaign to convince Americans that his budget priorities are more reasonable than those of Congress. In his speech, Mr. Clinton extended to the budget debate his recent theme of finding common ground that was laid out in a series of speeches on civic responsibility, religion in schools and in support of affirmative action programs. He said the Republicans were cutting too deeply into areas valued by most Americans, including Medicare, student loans, and enforcement of environmental laws.
"These priorities are not Democratic or Republican priorities," Mr. Clinton said. "They are common-sense national decisions that have served us very well over the last generation."
The President said the country could not afford to make the kinds of program cuts needed to carry out the Republican plan to erase the deficit by 2002 and also provide $245 billion in tax cuts. "The haste of their schedule and the scope of their tax cut are luxuries and this is not a time for luxuries," Mr. Clinton said.
Republicans seemed decidedly unmoved. Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, alluding to the plans of Mr. Clinton and Congressional Democrats to celebrate Medicare's anniversary, said, "They plan a week of cheap shots and nostalgia." And the House Republican Conference released rebuttals to Mr. Clinton, attacking his 10-year plan to balance the budget as insufficient and based on false economic assumptions.

HEADLINE: A Shelter and a Storm;
As Tax Breaks Change, the Working Poor Lose Out

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
For a dozen years Art and Geneva Terry loved living in Allegheny Commons, an apartment project built under a Great Society program that married the needs of the working poor for housing and the desires of the wealthy for tax shelters. Nights at the project fell silent and safe, because the residents of the 134 apartments went to sleep early so they could get up to go to work.
That silence has vanished. This summer, jobless young men congregate in the parking lot, drinking beer from 40-ounce bottles while waiting for another car to pull off the street for a furtive exchange of dollars and drugs. On one steamy night last month a toddler wearing only a diaper wandered on the sidewalk long past dark, while a boom box kept the sandman at bay. 
 The Terrys are among nearly a million of America's retired and working poor who live in more than 400,000 apartments built in the 1960's and 1970's, financed by wealthy investors' tax shelters. Now, many of these people are being squeezed out in favor of the jobless and the homeless, people whom the Terrys blame for the nightly disturbances in their neighborhood.
The problem for people like the Terrys is a 1990 law intended to encourage tax-shelter investors to keep buildings in low-income housing programs rather than switch them to higher market-based rents or even demolish them and convert the properties to other uses. The law accomplishes this by sharply raising the rents going to the investors and using taxpayer dollars to pay those rents. But by law these premium rents can be paid only on behalf of the very poor, like the homeless, who might otherwise be housed in hotels or short-term housing at even greater cost to the taxpayers.
The working poor do not qualify for such generous subsidies, however. Many of them, receiving only a small subsidy, can no longer afford to live in the buildings, or do not want to because of their new neighbors.
The situation at Allegheny Commons shows how an approach to housing the needy that started in the 1960's with modest subsidies and that expected tenants to pay much of the rent is now housing people who pay little or no rent and is using taxpayers' money to give tax-shelter investors much more than they once received. It also illustrates the effect on the working poor of the Government's attempt to pay less over all for housing subsidies than it did two decades ago.
These changes have produced a perverse economic situation in which tax dollars are being used to prop up the tax shelters at a cost that can be more than 14 times the amount an apartment as previously.
"What we have here is the tip of a very, very large iceberg," said Helen Dunlap, a deputy assistant secretary at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. She said the Government had unintentionally created a situation in which tax-shelter investors were deciding what to do with their buildings based on Government handouts and not the market.
Mr. Terry, who is 67, had an even stronger viewpoint. "The way I see it," he said, "the Government's making me live with people who got no jobs, no responsibilities, just so some rich folks don't have to pay taxes. That's crazy, just plain crazy."
The Clinton Administration, House Republicans, advocates of nonprofit housing and the tax-shelter managers all agree that changes must be made, and quickly. The House is scheduled to vote soon on a $200 million down payment on a seven-year effort to replace what an Appropriations Committee report called "the excessive costs under the existing program."
But a key problem is that in any one year the cost of paying higher rents to the tax-shelter investors is much smaller than the cost of a permanent solution, even though in the long run the current policy will cost much, much more. The permanent solution, all the parties agree, would be for the Government to pay off some of the mortgages of the tax-shelter investors and at the same time reduce the subsidy going to rents.
The housing-industry proposal up for a vote would make one-time grants to reduce the mortgages of the tax-shelter investors. If it works, it might save $5.4 billion over 25 years, according to the National Housing Trust, a group that fights for housing for the poor.
But the plan -- and a similar one advanced by the Clinton Administration but not up for a vote -- would cost about $2.3 billion extra over the next seven years. The higher short-run costs make the outlook dubious in a Congress dominated by Republicans who have vowed to eliminate the budget deficit by 2002.
There is a lot of housing at stake. Just in New York City, there are 170 projects with 49,132 apartments covered by the 1990 law, the National Housing Trust said. Ms. Dunlap of HUD said that few if any of these were likely candidates for conversion to market rents or demolition because of the city's rent control laws. The trust also counts 272 other projects with 67,945 apartments elsewhere in New York State and 23 projects with 2,037 apartments in New Jersey. Data on Connecticut were not available.
The problems began in President Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society, which, in a drive to build housing for the poor and create construction jobs, focused on short-term benefits.
To attract tax-shelter investors, the Government offered them 40-year mortgages on the buildings, with interest rates of as little as 1 percent. It also guaranteed that if the projects did not bring in enough in rent, it would step in to help the investors pay off the mortgages. It also gave the investors the right to pay off the mortgages after 20 years and then be free of rent regulations.
In the mid-1980's, as the first projects turned 20, the investors that owned the most valuable projects moved to pay off their mortgages. Many such projects were in places like the San Francisco area, where exploding real estate values made the prospect of entering the open market attractive. In one early case, in Alameda, Calif., tenants were told their rents would double.
In 1987, in the face of organized protests and concern that some housing would be demolished to make way for shopping malls or parking lots, Congress imposed a moratorium on such conversions.
Three years later Congress passed the Low-Income Housing Preservation and Home Ownership Act, which took away the mortgage prepayment right and the right to charge open-market rents.
But a commitment had been made to tax-shelter operators, so the law gave them two options for compensation. One was to sell to a nonprofit or local government agency at prices set by the Government. The other was to borrow more money, through bank loans guaranteed by the Government, to both finance repairs and allow the tax-shelter investors to withdraw 70 percent of their equity, much as homeowners do when they take out an equity loan.
Peter Richardson -- a vice president at Boston Financial Property Management, which operates the tax shelter that owns Allegheny Commons -- said his firm prepared an analysis in 1993 for its investors. It compared the costs and benefits of selling the project, which would require the investors to pay income taxes on the proceeds, or taking out $2.5 million in additional loans at market rates, which would provide cash without taxes and maintain the tax shelter.
The bottom line, Mr. Richardson said, was that a sale would net the group of investors $111,000 after taxes, while new loans would net them $540,000. (The loans would be repaid not by the investors but by the Government through rents, while the investors would keep about a third of the loan proceeds, less expenses.)
The tax-shelter investors, not surprisingly, chose the new loans, setting the stage for the project's transformation from working-class housing to welfare housing.
Even though its original $2.2 million mortgage was at just 1 percent, Allegheny Commons had just $23,000 in cash flow in 1993 -- not enough to make payments on that debt plus the new $2.5 million loan.
To cover the payments on the second mortgage, the 1990 law that allowed higher rent payments was invoked. Some existing residents of projects like Allegheny Commons qualified for the bigger subsidies, but the Terrys and many other working-class tenants did not, because their incomes were too high.
The Terrys, both retired, pay $400 a month, plus electricity, for their three-bedroom apartment, and Washington pays the tax shelter an additional $57, for a total of $457.
But if the Terrys leave and a homeless person moves in, the rent goes to $838 under an older law known as Section 8. The Government pays the entire rent for many Section 8 tenants. Some existing tenants, who had smaller incomes than the Terrys, qualified for Section 8, while others were told they not only did not qualify, but their rents would be raised as much as 40 percent.
With Section 8 tenants the tax-shelter investors collect nearly twice as much rent, but because those tenants pay little if any of that, the cost to taxpayers for each apartment increases as much as fifteenfold.
The Section 8 money comes not from some new program, but from dollars already budgeted by the Government to house the very poor, so there is no increase in overall spending. But the switch also means that the same number of dollars rents far fewer apartments, thus helping fewer people and squeezing out the working poor.
Federal law requires the Government to seek a mix of income levels in projects it subsidizes. But Ms. Dunlap of HUD said the 1990 law had "exacerbated the drive toward concentrating the poor."
She said the Government cannot just walk away from the program, and leave the working poor and the tax-shelter investors to the open market, because many of the mortgages, which the Government has guaranteed, would default.
Michael Bodaken, president of the National Housing Trust, said, "This is valuable housing stock, worth perhaps $25 billion, and it must be preserved."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 23, 1995

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on July 25 about a change in the tax law that is affecting low-income housing referred incorrectly to estimates by the National Housing Trust on its proposal that one-time grants replace monthly subsidies for tax-sheltered apartment projects. The group estimated that the proposal would save much more than the $5.4 billion cited in the article. The $2.3 billion in increased costs estimated for the first seven years of the plan was a Government estimate, not the group's.

HEADLINE: For Most U.S. Households, Inheritances Hardly Count

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
Benjamin Franklin and your mother may have been right after all, at least according to a new study: affluent Americans typically got that way by staying healthy, getting married and working hard for a good wage, rather than by inheriting their money.
A number of studies in recent years have pointed to a greater concentration of wealth and income among fewer and fewer people, prompting some calls for higher taxes on inheritances to prevent a widening of class divisions. But two surveys covering a total of 20,000 Americans over 50 show that health, marital status and income are the main determinants of wealth, according to a study released today by Rand, a research group based in Santa Monica, Calif. 
 "More than 90 percent of current wealth inequalities have nothing to do with financial inheritances," the study concluded.
The Rand study found that at the 95th percentile of households with a 51- to 60-year-old, assets totaled $843,598 when inheritances were included. Without inheritances, these assets totaled $780,641. By contrast, at the 10th percentile, similar households had $923 in assets and typically no inheritances.
James P. Smith, a Rand economist who wrote the study, said two-thirds of all white households and 90 percent of all minority households had not inherited any financial assets -- like stocks, bonds or cash -- by the time the surveys' respondents had reached their mid-50's.
Robert D. Reischauer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said the results might not be applicable to younger generations, and that big inheritances were limited to such a small percentage of the population that measurements were difficult.
"They're a big deal for a very tiny portion of the population -- maybe 1, 2 percent of the population, if even that," he said.
Mr. Smith acknowledged this, but said the shortage of data on the wealthiest Americans did not undermine the surveys' reliability. "They're an extremely difficult part of the population to survey," he said. "This shouldn't be taken as a statement that the Rockefellers didn't give to their kids and the Kennedys didn't give to their kids."
Inheritances are less of an issue for Americans over 50 because their parents were less prosperous, Mr. Reischauer added, in part because of the Depression.
But Mr. Smith was skeptical that inheritances would play a bigger role in determining wealth inequality among younger Americans. Most Americans in their 50's and older have barely saved enough to last them through retirement, he said, and are not in a position to leave large sums to their heirs.
The median assets in households where respondents were married were four times the median assets in households of divorced respondents, the Rand study found. The average wealth of someone in excellent health was four times the average wealth of someone in poor health. And high income was the best indicator of wealth, with high-earners typically saving a larger percentage of their incomes.
For reasons that are not entirely clear, being married seemed to encourage people to save more, Mr. Smith said. Good health, by contrast, has a clear link to wealth because healthy people can work longer hours and have lower medical bills.
To be sure, the cause and effect in some instances could be interchangeable: People who save may be more likely to get married and they may be healthier because they can afford good medical care.
The study's definition of household wealth included financial assets like stocks, bonds and checking accounts as well as equity in homes, cars, other real estate and stakes in small businesses.
The University of Michigan conducted the surveys for the Rand study, which was largely paid for with grants from the Federal Government's National Institute on Aging.

HEADLINE: Americans Hit the Road With Relish, and Money to Burn

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., July 20

 BODY:
As he circled the Indians, Richard Alexander thought about buying one.
"I could see one of the smaller ones along a wall in our family room," said his wife, Sharon, who watched him study the line of colorful, hand-carved wooden figures outside a souvenir shop near the middle of town. "I'd like to come home with some kind of memento." 
 Just contemplating an exotic memento of their vacation is a novelty for the Alexanders. After years of more modest vacations or no vacation at all, this summer the Alexanders, from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., chose the rugged landscapes of western Wyoming for a 10-day odyssey, a touring and camping adventure that has already included Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks.
"We haven't taken a 10-day vacation in several years, and we just decided it was time," said Mr. Alexander, an accountant. "This year we decided to let it all hang out."
The Alexanders are not alone. With the nation's economy relatively healthy, consumers confident that it will stay that way, and unemployment consistently low, travel industry officials say Americans this summer are driving, flying and cruising to destinations around the country in record numbers. From Bar Harbor, Me., to the Wisconsin Dells to the cushiest of Hawaiian resorts, hotel occupancy rates are up and golf courses and water slides are crowded.
Many national parks are overflowing, led by the Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the Tennessee-North Carolina border, where a record 1.165 million people visited in June, an increase of 20.5 percent over June of last year. At the Grand Canyon, where park officials have worried for years about overcrowding and adverse effects of too many vehicles, a record 665,255 tourists visited last month, an increase of 23.4 percent over June 1994.
"There has been a great deal of pent-up emotion over wish lists for travel for a long time," said William S. Norman, chief executive of the Travel Industry Association of America, a trade organization based in Washington. "A lot of people were thinking, Should we or shouldn't we? But there were enough positive indicators of the economy to decide, Let's do it now, and people are splurging."
In general, Mr. Norman said, vacationers this summer are spending more money, staying longer and upgrading accommodations and transportation where they can. All of this, he said, could result in an increase of 5 percent or more over the $416 billion that Americans and foreign visitors spent on travel and tourism in the United States last year. That would be the largest jump in five years.
Foreigners account for about 1 of every 5 tourist dollars spent in the United States, a proportion that has remained relatively constant in the 1990's.
Many more people are taking family vacations this summer. "People are feeling the need to spread their wings," said Kathy Sudeikis, a travel agent in Kansas City, Mo. "They have been thinking about family values and want to spend their vacation together. They want to play out that experience."
The evidence can be found almost everywhere, not just in traditional vacation meccas like Walt Disney World in Florida or Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco. In Bar Harbor, a coastal town near Acadia National Park, visitors from all over the East this summer are tying up traffic. "This year, it was more difficult to finding parking earlier," said Rosteen Masters, chief executive of the town's Chamber of Commerce. "Instead of July, it was happening in May."
In Myrtle Beach, S.C., where a record 12 million visitors last year jammed attractions along 60 miles of oceanfront, officials are predicting even higher numbers this year. Same for the Wisconsin Dells, a favorite Midwestern destination for its growing number of water parks, theme parks and theaters.
Even places not known as resort destinations are enjoying boom times. Sonny Marston, general manager of the side-by-side Plaza Theater Wax Museum and the Ripley's Believe It or Not Museum in San Antonio, said the crowds this summer could exceed last year's record numbers.
"People are always interested in seeing a two-headed pig," Mr. Marston said of the Ripley's museum, where visitors can also view an oil rig made of 400,000 matchsticks, an Eiffel Tower made of 20,000 toothpicks, various shrunken heads and the Lord's Prayer written on a pin.
Mr. Marston said visitors were equally excited about the array of film stars in wax, including the newly arrived Jim Carey and Whoopi Goldberg. "And we should be getting a Brad Pitt pretty quick," he volunteered.
Here in Wyoming, Jackson sits at the base of Jackson Hole, a 60-mile valley that runs through the Tetons up to Yellowstone. It has been a favorite summer resort destination for years for outdoor activities like camping, hiking, fly fishing and whitewater rafting. Next month, President Clinton and his family are expected for two weeks.
The town has a typical resort look, with lots of hotels, boutiques and souvenir shops -- but all in a western motif. A stagecoach with tourists aboard circles the town square all day, and the periodic gunshots are from two faux cowboys re-enacting a showdown. More than 15 movies have been shot in the area, including "Shane" and "Rocky IV," and town officials say Jackson was where John Wayne first rode a horse, in 1932.
Like the Alexanders, many visitors here said their time in Jackson Hole was part of vacation plans that were more ambitious than in recent years, whether measured by money spent, quality of accommodations or number of days away from their lives back home.
"I talk to a lot of people, and more than in the past, they're saying they have extended their vacation this year," said Gerald Humphries, a 41-year-old physical education teacher from Blackfoot, Idaho, who dons cowboy hat and boots each summer to drive the stagecoach. "It's like they're staying two weeks, rather than four or five days."
Driving through the area with their sons, Matthew, 11, and Jonathan, 8, Janet and Brad Belz of Manhasset, L.I., decided to stretch their vacation by 2 days, to 12, on a trip that began in the Black Hills of South Dakota.
"We really want the kids to experience as much as they can of state and Federal parks before they changed," Mr. Belz, a vice president at Macy's, said as his family spent an evening on a covered-wagon train to a western music show and barbecue dinner of chicken, roast beef, corn and beans. "It would have been just as easy to go to the Caribbean. But this is a lot more rewarding."
Craig Whittaker, a sales manager for an oil chemical company in Houston, said he and his wife, Terri, and their daughters, Leah, 8 and Rachel, 5, had generally spent vacations in and around Texas. But a scheduled business trip gave them the opportunity to plan something different.
"We decided to spend a little bit more money and bring the family along," Mr. Whittaker said during the covered-wagon ride, as his girls watched two men dressed like Indians pretend to attack. "It's been fun."
Sitting in the town square, with its portals of elk antlers at each corner, Neal and Mary Crout of Fond du Lac, Wis., said their nine-day vacation was a gift to themselves, a respite from their jobs. "We love to travel even if that means scrimping on something else," said Mr. Crout, a warehouse supervisor. "We decided to be good to ourselves this year."
"But," his wife insisted, "we're still pretty conservative. We're not the kind to buy a $500 Pendleton sweater. We're not from New York, you know."

HEADLINE: Vernon I. Cheadle, 85, Botanist And U. of California Chancellor

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Vernon I. Cheadle, a former Chancellor of the University of California at Santa Barbara whose 15-year tenure was marked by rapid campus growth as well as student unrest, died on Sunday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara. He was 85.
Dr. Cheadle, who lived in Santa Barbara, was an internationally known botanist. He was Chancellor from 1962 to 1977. In that time, the number of disciplines taught on the campus rose to 100 from 36, master's programs to 42 from 15, and Ph.D. programs to 27 from 2. Enrollment grew to more than 12,000 from 4,700. 
 Student unrest over civil rights, the Vietnam War and a feeling of powerlessness against political and economic institutions swirled around Dr. Cheadle when he was Chancellor. In 1969, members of the Black Students Union occupied a campus building and pressured the administation into creating a black studies program.
In February 1970, youths battled the police for three nights in Isla Vista, a college town of about 13,000 people, including 9,000 students, adjacent to the Santa Barbara campus. The violence left 1 student dead and more than 100 injured or arrested, and resulted in the destruction of several buildings, including a bank that was burned to the ground. The violence ended after Ronald Reagan, then Governor of California, declared an "extreme emergency" and called in the National Guard.
After his retirement Dr. Cheadle returned to his botany laboratory, where he studied water-conducting cells in higher forms of plant life, like corn and grasses. His specialty was the morphology of vascular plants.
Vernon Irving Cheadle was born in Salem, S. D., and received a bachelor's degree from Miami University in Ohio in 1932 and a master's degree and Ph.D. in botany from Harvard University.
He taught at Harvard and Rhode Island State College before joining the University of California at Davis as chairman of the botany department in 1952. He was acting vice chancellor at Davis when Santa Barbara named him as Chancellor.
He is survived by his wife, Mary; a son, Dr. William Cheadle of Louisville, Ky., a twin sister, Mrs. Joseph Ruden of Billings, Mont., and two grandsons.

HEADLINE: June Budget Surplus Less Than Expected

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
The Federal Government today reported a budget surplus for June as quarterly tax returns streamed into the Treasury.
While revenues were up, reflecting healthy business profits and higher taxes on the affluent, expenses also increased, the Treasury said. 
 As a result, the surplus came in at a smaller-than-expected $13.571 billion, down 8.6 percent from $14.850 billion in the month a year earlier.
Economists had expected a surplus of $18.4 billion for June 1995.
But the reason for the smaller surplus was mainly technical. The Government mailed Social Security payments, veterans' benefits and military paychecks for July on June 30 instead of July 1, which fell on a Saturday.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Financial Services Agreement Is Expected by End of Week

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 24

 BODY:
Europe's chief trade negotiator predicted today that more than 70 countries would agree by the end of the week on the world's first agreement liberalizing trade in financial services, although the United States would not be among them.
Japan and South Korea have not yet agreed to join the accord. But Sir Leon Brittan, who represents the 15 European Union nations, said at a news conference that he was confident the two nations would commit to join the pact during talks that start in Geneva Wednesday. 
 Their support would insure that the accord, which would allow banks, insurance companies and other financial companies easier access to other countries' markets, would be completed by Friday, Sir Leon said.
In talks at the World Trade Organization in Geneva last month, the Clinton Administration withdrew from the proposed pact because Asian and Latin American countries were unwilling to offer American financial companies the same access to their markets that the United States had been willing to offer them. Financial concerns from the European Union will still get free access to the United States because they offer American firms equal access. But the United States said it would allow other countries access only if they reciprocated.
The Administration's decision threatened to destroy the negotiations over financial services. Other countries reduced the access offers they had made when it became clear that those offers would not necessarily secure them better access to the American market.
In a bid to keep the talks alive, the European Union took the lead in putting pressure on the other countries to maintain their original access offers and seek a trial agreement of two and a half years, after which they would be free to renegotiate -- increasing or decreasing the access they offered foreign companies.
Sir Leon said today that the Administration's stance had not changed. "I never expected the U.S. to change its mind," he said, although he held out the possibility that it might agree to join the proposed trial agreement when it came up for renegotiation in 1997.
Sir Leon, who was accompanied by the Spanish Foreign Minister, Javier Solana, the current president of the European Union's decision-making Council of Ministers, spoke following a review of trans-Atlantic relations with the Secretary of State, Warren Christopher; the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin; the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and several Congressional leaders.
Mr. Rubin issued a statement saying that the United States supported the European Union's efforts to negotiate the trial agreement even though it would not join it.
Although most countries have accepted the plan for the trial agreement, European Union negotiators said Japan and South Korea must participate in the accord for it to be worthwhile.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Against Yen Following Elections in Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen yesterday after a poor showing by Japan's governing coalition in elections on Sunday suggested that Japan might ease its commitment to weakening the yen.
But the dollar was steady against the German mark, bolstered by speculation that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank,would cut interest rates soon. Lower German rates would hurt the mark by making bank deposits denominated in it less attractive. 
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar edged up to 1.3857 German marks from 1.3856 marks on Friday. The dollar fell to 87.52 Japanese yen from 88.52 yen.
The dollar initially surged against the yen on the results of the Japanese election, which left the coalition Government of Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama in power. But the dollar fell after it became clear that the coalition would be weaker than before.
The elections were for seats in Parliament's upper house, which is less important than the lower house. The elections were still seen as an referendum on the Government's performance.
"The dollar came off on uncertainty surrounding the Japanese elections," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets in New York. "The fact that the political scene is a bit muddled suggests that the reforms the market had hoped for and the closer cooperation with the U.S. the market had hoped for -- all that is under suspicion."
A weaker Japanese Government is unlikely to accelerate measures to deregulate and stimulate the Japanese economy, which would help reduce Japan's trade surplus with the United States. The surplus puts a wealth of dollars in the hands of Japanese exporters, driving up the value of the yen.
To bring the yen down, the Bank of Japan has bought as much as $1 billion for yen in each trading day in the two weeks leading up to the election, traders said. Though the central bank bought dollars again yesterday, its dollar-buying is likely to wane now that the election is over, hurting the dollar against the yen, they said.
The dollar gained against the mark after preliminary reports showed that prices declined in two German states during July. The data revived expectations that the Bundesbank could lower interest rates when it returns from its summer recess later next month.

HEADLINE: Four Oil Companies Report Strong Earnings in Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Four oil companies reported surprisingly strong second-quarter earnings yesterday, helped by higher oil prices and wider margins in chemical and refining businesses.
Results from the Mobil Corporation; the Shell Oil Company, part of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group; the Chevron Corporation, and ARCO exceeded analysts' expectations. The Amoco Corporation, however, reported earnings that fell short of estimates. 
 Despite the strong performance by the oil industry in the second quarter, there were also signs yesterday of a possible slowdown head. Mobil warned that chemical prices, which surged as the United States economy revived, were now in retreat. And oil prices have fallen since April.
"I wouldn't call it a red flag," said Paul Ting, managing director of oil industry research at Oppenheimer & Company. "I would certainly call it a yellow flag. It has a sobering affect on the third quarter."
Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., said it earned $179 million, or 42 cents a share, down from $198 million, or 46 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. But the results included a charge of $527 million, mainly for a revamping. Profit from operations rose to $706 million, or $1.75 a share, in the quarter, from $513 million, or $1.25 a share, a year earlier. The results beat expectations that Mobil would earn $1.65, according to Zacks Investment Research. Revenue rose 16 percent, to $18.85 billion from $16.22 billion, because of an increase in chemical and refined product sales.
Chemical results were the strongest, with operating profit more than quadrupling to $186 million, as division sales rose 41 percent.
Shell Oil earned $385 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $194 million a year earlier. In the recent quarter, charges for litigation and write-downs in properties and a coal company reduced earnings by $2 million. Revenue rose 25 percent, to $6.39 billion from $5.13 billion.
Shell Oil, based in Houston, said profit from operations rose 51 percent, to $387 million from $257 million. Chemicals performed best, more than doubling operating profit to $176 million. Sales from the unit rose 33 percent, to $1.3 billion.
Chevron, based in San Francisco, said earnings for the quarter more than doubled to $607 million, or 93 cents a share, from $257 million, or 39 cents a share, in the quarter a yeare earlier. The results exceeded Wall Street estimates of 84 cents a share, according to a survey by Zacks Investment Research. Revenues rose 8.4 percent. It was the company's best performance since the Persian Gulf war.
The chemical segment turned in the best performance, with operating profit more than tripling to $175 million from $49 million. Still, a Chevron official said prices for olefins and aromatics, two primary products of the chemical division, may have either plateaued or peaked.
ARCO earned $391 million, or $2.39 a share, in the quarter, compared with $24 million, or 14 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The most recent results included a gain of $10 million to settle insurance litigation, while the 1994 quarter included a restructuring charge of $154 million. The results exceed Wall Street expectations of $2.13 a share, according to a survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research.
ARCO, based in Los Angeles, said profit from operations rose to $381 million, or $2.33 a share, from $178 million, or $1.09. Revenue rose 8 percent.
The company's chemical interests, including a 49.9 percent stake in the Lyondell Petrochemical Company and a 83.1 percent stake in the ARCO Chemical Company turned in strong performances. Their combined contribution to earnings more than doubled to $201 million from $84 million.
Amoco, based in Chicago, said earnings rose 30 percent in the quarter, to $533 million, or $1.08 a share, from $410 million, or 83 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The 1994 quarter included a gain of $270 million for a tax dispute settlement and a charge of $256 million for restructuring. Chemical profit from operations rose to $246 million from $139 million.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Regain Some Ground; Shorter Maturities Weaker

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices regained some ground yesterday from last week's retreat. But prices for shorter maturities were mildly weaker as investors positioned themselves for an increase in supply this week.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 16/32 , to 10915/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.87 percent, from 6.96 percent on Friday. Investors gained about $11.25 for every $1,000 of bonds held. 
 Treasury prices opened higher, rebounding from last week's decline. Many traders said the sharp drop on Friday was exaggerated. With the absence of economic data yesterday, the market focused on supply.
The Treasury plans to sell $17.25 billion of new two-year notes today and $11.5 billion of five-year notes tomorrow. In when-issued trading the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.95 percent and the five-year notes at a price to yield 6.25 percent.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $26.4 billion of new three-month and six-month bills, with rates that were slightly higher than the previous week. The average rate for a three-month maturity was 5.47 percent, up one basis point from a week ago, while the average rate for a six-month bill was 5.46 percent, up six basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Eric Hamilton, a senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said there was stronger demand than usual from foreign buyers at the auction. Foreign investors usually buy about $1.5 billion to $2 billion of the bills, but Mr. Hamilton estimated that they took $3.4 billion yesterday.
The higher figure was "probably the result of central bank buying of dollars last week," he said, adding, "They have to put those dollars to work and typically those central banks buy bills with those dollars."
Treasury prices were supported in part yesterday by covering by short- sellers. A short-seller sells borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices and pocket the difference. If prices begin to rise instead of fall, as Treasury prices did early yesterday, a short-seller has to buy back, or cover, the securities to limit losses.
And portfolio managers were doing a little bottom fishing yesterday, buying some of the oversold securities.
Portfolio managers apparently reconsidered Friday's selloff over the weekend and returned to the market thinking that a yield near 7 percent was not such a bad deal after all, given an inflation rate of less than 3 percent.
Mr. Hamilton of Technical Data said there was some argument for further bond weakness but the fundamental picture was still sound. "I think a 7 percent long-bond yield will be a good support level for the short term," he said.
"Yes there are some supply concerns," he added, "but the two- and five-year note auctions should go fairly well."
