HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Lavazza Takes a Ride on America's Coffee Bubble

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: TURIN, Italy

 BODY:
Sipping espresso from a 1-ounce porcelain cup, Giulio Girotto almost shudders as he reaches for a 15-ounce foam container to discuss American espresso bars and drinks like cappuccinos and lattes that he refers to as "espresso-based beverages."
But how you take your espresso has become secondary to Mr. Girotto, the chief executive of Luigi Lavazza S.p.A., Italy's biggest coffee company, and these days he shudders all the way to the bank. Lavazza, which controls 43 percent of Italy's coffee market, is cashing in on America's flirtation with Italian foods, and above all its craze for exotic new coffees. 
 Lavazza (pronounced la-VAATZ-ah) is bringing its beans to the United States and has developed an espresso machine for coffee bars, offices and smaller restaurants. Sales of the machine, called Espresso Point, plus its Lavazza brand coffee, began last year and are expected to increase the company's United States revenue in 1995 by 40 percent, to $12 million.
Lavazza supplies the machines, provides service and, to insure freshness and uniform flavor, delivers coffee in vacuum-packed cartridges. There are now thousands of the machines in America, including those at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York and the garden cafe at the Museum of Modern Art.
With annual sales of $644 million, Lavazza is one of a phalanx of medium-sized, family-owned Italian food companies -- like Barilla S.p.A., the big pasta and baked goods producer, and Parmalat S.p.A., the leading Italian dairy company -- that have plunged into the United States, driven by stagnating or even declining sales in Italy.
Italian Government economists value the export effort because immense imports of milk products and meat from Northern Europe have resulted in an annual trade deficit in food items of $6.8 billion last year, second only to Italy's bill for oil.
Lavazza, which is based here, first went abroad in the 1980's, developing markets for espresso in neighboring France and Germany. But going into the United States is described here as a matter of survival.
"It's important to remember what became of the others," Mr. Girotto said, rattling off a list of smaller rivals that made only coffee and were gobbled up by food giants like Nestle and the Philip Morris Companies.
Six years ago, Lavazza looked at the United States and liked what it saw.
"First, there was this boom in the diffusion of Italian foods," said Ennio Ranaboldo, a spokesman for Lavazza. "Just look at olive oil. Twelve or 15 years ago, it was not part of the American landscape. Now the olive oil section is the largest of some supermarkets. There's even mineral water imported from Italy!
"At the same time, we saw the boom of the specialty coffee business. And for some, espresso was the largest part of this, if not the driving force."
For American tastes, Lavazza developed several new blends of regular and decaffeinated espresso, including one called Gran Filtro. Next, the company outfitted one of its line of electric espresso makers with stainless steel and brass for use in both liquor and coffee bars and in offices. Retailing at about $800, the Espresso Point is admittedly pricey, but as espresso drinking spreads in America, Lavazza hopes to sell it for home use as well.
America's giant coffee bar chains, like Starbucks, grind their own blends, so Lavazza set its sights on individual espresso bars, Italian restaurants, hotels and the growing office coffee business. Alberto Paderi, the president of Lavazza's New York-based operation, the Lavazza Premium Coffees Corporation, says he spends 70 to 80 days a year on the road, knocking on restaurant doors, visiting food trade fairs and securing shelf space for Lavazza at stores like A. & P. and Pathmark. But restaurants account for roughly half of Lavazza's business.
"Since people change their habits at home, because they've tried something at a restaurant," he said during a recent visit to Lavazza's headquarters, "we thought this is where we ought to start."
He said the Lavazza strategy was to move gradually into new regions and businesses.
In Manhattan, the Gramercy Tavern on East 20th Street started serving Lavazza coffee beans when it opened a year ago. Bob Wenzl, the beverage director, said: "There are a lot of other espressos. It just works quite well."
Lucy Di Saverio, who has been running Bleecker Street Pastry in Greenwich Village since 1966, said, "I've used it at intervals, on and off, and I'm using it now." The reason, she said, was "quality, and the people who sell it -- they're convincing."
Lavazza's tactics are a sharp departure from past importers who supplied restaurants with espresso machines, then failed to follow up with service or spare parts.
"Lots of restaurateurs said to us, 'Don't come to me with an espresso machine!' " Mr. Paderi said.
Partly, Mr. Paderi says, what drives espresso is profit. A latte -- espresso coffee and lots of steamed milk, and in some places a shot of syrup, like strawberry, raspberry or banana -- sells in New York coffee bars for $3 to $3.50, for instance. The ingredients cost 15 cents.
Still, Lavazza is not tempted to get into the coffee bar business itself. It does not want to compete with the espresso bars and restaurants that it supplies.
Will America's coffee bubble burst? "I don't think it's really a fad," Mr. Paderi said. "I'm sure there's a little bit too much around, and someday there will be less than the big numbers you see now. But no doubt you're going to see an espresso machine in most any food service operation.
"The big question for us," he added, "is whether it will enter homes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Luigi Lavazza, Italy's biggest coffee company, is trying to expand in the United States. While Lavazza sells espresso machines and beans, only the beans are used at a coffee stand in Bryant Park in Manhattan. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Union Chief Linked to the Mob Appears to Have Won a 2d Term

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
The head of the carpenters union in the New York City area, whose administration was under fire on charges of corruption, nepotism and favoritism to mobsters, appears to have been re-elected, according to an unofficial vote count completed last night.
A major issue in the campaign was the disclosures that aides to Frederick W. Devine, who was re-elected to a second term, had doled out lucrative jobs at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center to mobsters and former convicts. 
 Independent officials who supervised the election said that in an unofficial tally Mr. Devine defeated three candidates. He received 3,450 votes, and his closest opponent, Patrick J. Harvey, got 1,937 votes.
Two other candidates, John Abbatemarco and John J. Greany, were far behind.
The union, one of the largest labor groups in New York, has a 30-year history of being investigated by Federal and state authorities for links to the mob and for corruption.
Mr. Devine, 57, declined to be interviewed last night about his platform to win a second four-year term as the head of the union, the New York City District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America. He campaigned mainly on his experience and his granting of Christmas bonuses to about 5,000 retired members. He also promised to seek full medical benefits and pensions for members at age 55.
His opponents raised these issues:
*Mr. Devine secretly raised his annual salary to about $360,000, making him one of the nation's highest-paid union officials, while about 40 percent of the union's members are unemployed.
*Dozens of high-paying union jobs were given to relatives of Mr. Devine and his allies. Michael Devine, a son of Mr. Devine, is an assistant to his father at an annual salary of $110,000.
*Under Mr. Devine's leadership, the union's membership declined from 23,000 to fewer than 20,000 active members, while administrative fees soared to $15 million last year from $6 million in 1991.
Mr. Devine was a defendant in a civil racketeering suit brought in 1991 by Federal prosecutors in Manhattan. The suit was settled last year in an agreement that called for the appointment of Kenneth Conboy, a former Federal judge, as an investigator to look into wrongdoing and to supervise the direct election of new officers.
Mr. Devine's immediate predecessor, Paschal McGuiness, was acquitted in 1991 on Federal charges of taking bribes from contractors. Mr. McGuiness had been elected president after Theodore Maritas disappeared in 1982 while awaiting trial on extortion charges.
Law enforcement officials say that in the latest investigation, Federal prosecutors are examining allegations of bribery and kickbacks in the administration of the union's $1.5 billion pension and welfare funds.

HEADLINE: Chain Providing $96 Million for Minorities

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 25

 BODY:
Shoney's Inc., a family restaurant chain criticized for its treatment of blacks, agreed today to provide an estimated $96 million to assist minorities with business opportunities over the next three years.
The agreement covers employment and management opportunities, minority business development, franchise development and community service and contributions. 
 In 1992 the company, which is based in Nashville, paid $132 million to settle a racial discrimination lawsuit filed in 1989 in Florida by nine black former employees. The award went to many black employees and former employees of Shoney's.
Two previous agreements between Shoney's and the leadership conference, in 1989 and 1993, provided $190 million in business opportunities for minorities, the company said. Shoney's operates more than 1,800 restaurants in 34 states and Canada.
The new agreement was signed by Shoney's chairman, C. Stephen Lynn, and the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, the organization founded by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Earnings and a Jet Order Push Up Boeing's Stock
Boeing reported better-than-expected earnings for the second quarter and said it had received an order for 54 jets in a deal it valued at $2.25 billion. The combined news propelled its stock to an all-time high of $67 before closing at $66, up $2.
Excluding a $600 million charge for employee early retirement packages, the company earned $254 million, or 74 cents a share, in the quarter. With the charge, the company lost $231 million. [Page D2.]
 
Euro Disney Posts a Profit,
But Analysts Remain Wary
After nearly three years of heavy losses and a near brush with bankruptcy, Euro Disney announced its first quarterly profit, earning $35.36 million in its third quarter. But analysts cautioned that the theme park was not past its financial troubles. [D3.]
 
New Signs of Moderate Growth
More signs emerged that the economy is growing moderately without stirring inflation. Sales of existing homes rose a better-than-expected 6.5 percent in June, the National Association of Realtors said. Also, consumer confidence increased this month, the Conference Board said, while employment costs rose slowly in the 12 months through June, the Labor Department reported. [D16.]
 
Tobacco Industry Inquiry
The Justice Department has convened a grand jury to investigate whether tobacco companies misrepresented to Federal regulators the contents and ill effects of cigarettes. [A1.]
 
Fund Raises Estimate of Loss
The Common Fund has raised by nearly 8 percent, to $135 million, its estimate of the total losses it incurred from unauthorized trading at First Capital Strategists. [D4.]
 
RJR Nabisco Profits Climb
RJR Nabisco said that excluding one-time items, its earnings rose 15 percent as a result of strong growth in premium cigarette brands and international tobacco sales. [D2.]
 
Pepsi Earnings Rise 11%
Pepsico's net income rose 11 percent, to $487.2 million, or 61 cents a share, driven by strong operating income from its beverage business, Pizza Hut and Frito-Lay. [D4.]
 
An Exchange for Insurance Risk
The New York State Insurance Department has approved the creation of an exchange that would allow insurance companies to reduce their exposure to losses by swapping blocks of policies in different parts of the country. [D2.]
 
Russian Bank Drops Bid
A Russian bank abandoned its effort to take control of the Red October Chocolate Factory, in what had been the first hostile takeover bid in post-Communist Russia. [D3.]
 
Dismantling a Department
Congress is taking up the shredding of the Commerce Department, but as two days of hearings have revealed, it is a lot easier to talk about tearing a department apart than it is to figure out what to do with the pieces. [A16.]
 
Della Femina Answers Critics
Jerry Della Femina, one of advertising's best-known executives, whether from the front or the back, is addressing perceptions that his new agency, Jerry & Ketchum, is not fulfilling its considerable potential because of a dearth of important, big-budget, national clients. "To think you open up and say 'We're in business; send over the national accounts' is incredibly naive," Mr. Della Femina said. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Faster Flights Across Pacific
Passengers bound to Asia from North America have been able to shorten their trips across the Pacific by as much as three hours as airlines find ways to cut the flying time. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D4.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Inside Oil City, Hope Runs Dry

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: OIL CITY, Pa.

 BODY:
The oil industry got its start in this part of northwestern Pennsylvania with the drilling of the world's first commercial oil well in 1859. The Quaker State Corporation got its start in this town in 1931 by promoting the special qualities of Pennsylvania oil.
When the oil industry moved southwest, Quaker State stayed. And when other big corporations -- Pennzoil, Jones & Laughlin Steel, U.S. Steel and GTE -- began deserting Oil City, the townsfolk took comfort at the sight of the five-story, glass-and-concrete Quaker State headquarters building that reared up over surrounding storefronts. 
 Quaker State, they told themselves, was an immovable economic base that would eventually see them through to better times.
They were wrong. Quaker State is leaving the place it called home for more than 60 years and moving to Irving, Tex., near Dallas.
Just as Akron, in neighboring Ohio, lost tire makers and Youngstown is no longer home to any major steelmaker, Oil City, population 12,000, is losing the last of the oil companies that settled in this region. For Quaker State, the move is the latest of many changes brought about by its chairman, Herbert M. Baum, a former Campbell Soup executive hired two years ago to shake the company out of its doldrums.
The changes under Mr. Baum, the first outsider to head Quaker State, have improved profitability. But their impact on Oil City is another story. Like many small towns in America, it came to see itself as synonymous with the big company that dominated its economic life. And now it feels betrayed, robbed of both its proud past and of hope for the future. About half of the nearly 300 employees at the Oil City headquarters will lose their jobs and struggle to find new employment at much lower wages; the rest will be relocated in a strange place more than 1,000 miles away.
Judy Schwab, a receptionist for the company, has not been asked to move to Dallas. And, at age 52, she has scant hope of finding a job here that could match her current salary. Instead, Ms. Schwab, who has greeted visitors in the lobby for the last 17 years, is thinking of starting a bookshop that would serve tea in the nearly deserted shopping district.
"People had faith in the company, that it would stay and take care of them," she said. "It has taken away their hope that the company that started here would stay here."
Even for many of the 158 employees who received offers to move to Dallas, the future is worrisome. Bob Olen, the purchasing manager for Quaker State for 17 years, spent a weekend with his wife and 20 other couples recently in the Dallas suburbs, looking at homes that are much more expensive and a life style that is much more fast paced than back home.
Going to Texas would mean leaving behind his aging parents and two of his children -- one with a job and another who is finishing school. It would also mean selling his house on one and a half wooded acres in an area where both his and his wife's families have lived since the turn of the century.
But Mr. Olen says he has no choice. At his age, he figures, he would be lucky to find a job here that pays one-third of his current salary. "I would have to relocate anyway," he said ruefully.
The economic descent of Oil City has been relatively rapid. Conrad A. Conrad, the vice chairman and chief financial officer of Quaker State, said the town was a thriving metropolis of 20,000 when he joined the company in the early 1960's.
Oil City's history has always been tied to oil. It was one of the boom towns that sprang up shortly after Edwin L. Drake drilled the world's first commercial oil well 136 years ago in Titusville, about 15 miles to the north. It was built on four square miles straddling the Allegheny River, whose shores bristled with 2,000 oil wells by the late 1860's.
But it was only by a stroke of luck that it achieved prosperity in this century long after most other Pennsylvania oil towns had vanished, victims of severe declines in oil prices and dwindling supply. In 1931, Charles Pape, a Chicago stockbroker, combined a group of oil companies into the Quaker State Corporation and chose Oil City for its headquarters.
His strategy for competing against the huge new fields of Texas and Oklahoma was to start a catchy advertising campaign stressing the special lubricating qualities of the motor oil refined from Pennsylvania Grade crude. His success was soon copied by others, including Pennzoil United Inc. Big refineries were built and companies were formed to supply the needs of the growing industry. The Imperial Works unit of U.S. Steel made oil wells, for example, and the Manion Steel Barrel Company made barrels.
Main Street, which started in the 1860's as little more than a sea of oily mud and ramshackle hotels, was transformed into a bustling strip jammed with cars and lined with modern office buildings, banks, shops and restaurants.
Most important, Quaker State's commitment to continued growth in its hometown seemed unswerving: In 1977, the chief executive at the time, Quentin E. Wood, cut the ribbon on the new $5 million headquarters and said the company was proud to be part of the "continuing renaissance of Oil City." He and other executives served on local boards and were a major force in raising funds for a hospital and for the United Way.
But neither Oil City nor Quaker State could escape the larger forces that embroiled the oil industry in the 1980's: plunging oil prices, production cutbacks and breakthroughs in refining technology that eroded the quality advantages of Pennsylvania Grade crude.
Quaker State fought back by introducing better motor oils, but it continued to charge a premium for a product that retailers often used as a loss leader. That strategy led to a decline in its motor-oil market share from 20 percent in the 1980's to about 13 percent in 1993, second to Pennzoil.
Quaker State also attempted to diversify, buying an insurance group and a coal company, but those moves only dragged down its earnings further.
To reverse its fortunes, the company lured Mr. Baum from Campbell Soup in June 1993. A blunt-spoken executive known for his marketing savvy, Mr. Baum moved quickly, replacing most of the top management with outsiders, selling noncore business and shifting the company's focus from refining to marketing.
He also doubled its lubricant business by buying the Specialty Oil Companies of Shreveport, La., and Slick 50 Inc., a Houston maker of car-engine treatments. In 1994, his first full year on the job, the company's profit rose 37 percent, to $19 million, on a 12 percent increase in revenue, to $852 million. And yesterday, Quaker State reported that its second-quarter profit from continuing operations more than tripled from the corresponding period a year earlier, to $4.96 million from $1.5 million. The improved earnings were more than wiped out, however, by a $9.5 million restructuring charge for the move to Texas.
The company ranks 945th on Fortune magazine's list of the 1,000 largest American corporations.
In the last two years, as the focus of the company shifted to the Southwest, Oil City began to look more and more remote. The frustrations of relying on the two daily commuter flights from the local airport to connecting flights in Pittsburgh began to grate on executives and the sales force. Many chose instead to drive two hours over winding roads.
The company has also had difficulty persuading Wall Street analysts, potential new executives and even suppliers to travel to a place that offers one Holiday Inn and a few restaurants in its downtown.
Nevertheless, Mr. Baum, who had come from New Jersey and bought a large house and become active in the community, said he felt torn about leaving.
"I wish I could take this building and its people and drop them in Dallas," he said in an interview in his office, spreading out his hands as if to take hold of the edifice.
But he added that he was disillusioned with what he saw as the shortsightedness of some residents. Soon after he arrived, Quaker State and several local groups raised $40,000 for a campaign to attract a national retailer to a downtown building vacated years ago by Woolworth.
The effort fell apart, he said, when the landlord held out for a better deal on the lease. The building is still vacant. "The people in this town don't know how to win," he said. "They are their own worst enemy."
Quaker State has contributed $250,000 to an effort to find a company to take its place in Oil City. Cindie Litweiler, executive director of the Oil City Community Development Corporation, said she was hoping to find a financial institution, like a credit-card company, to set up a billing or processing center. She noted the town's abundance of skilled workers and its low cost of living.
"You don't have to pay $14 a square foot for office space and $400 a month for parking," she said.
But the companies she has been talking to generally do not pay much more than the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour, and they offer few if any fringe benefits. For Raymond Lawson, a father of two daughters who made $20,000 a year and enjoyed extensive benefits at his job of maintaining the Quaker State building and grounds, the prospect of a pay cut is daunting.
The best offer he has had so far is $6 an hour, a level he considers too low for someone skilled in carpentry and plumbing. "I feel devastated," he said. "What am I going to do?"

HEADLINE: Clinton Joins a Rally on Medicare's Birthday

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
President Clinton joined Congressional Democrats and hundreds of elderly Americans for a 30th birthday rally for Medicare on Capitol Hill today, attacking Republican plans to cut growth in the program and vowing not to "let the Government mess with your Medicare."
But the reality behind the political oratory was that most Democrats surrounding Mr. Clinton in the caucus room of the Cannon House Office Building bitterly oppose his plan for trimming growth in Medicare spending -- even though the President would do it more slowly than the Republicans and without reducing benefits to individuals. Mr. Clinton barely acknowledged that fact, though his remarks were far milder than those of his fellow partisans. 
 "We must be committed to reducing medical cost inflation and stabilizing the Medicare trust fund through genuine reforms not by destroying Medicare and hurting the people who are on it," Mr. Clinton told the group, which included several members of Congress who cast votes to establish Medicare in 1965.
If Mr. Clinton's efforts at compromise left him a bit of an odd man out among Democrats today, he won no praise from the Republicans either. They responded angrily that they had no intention of slashing Medicare or forcing beneficiaries to pay more for their coverage, though the Republicans have yet to divulge details of their proposals.
Speaker Newt Gingrich accused Mr. Clinton of indulging in a "very despicable strategy" to scare the elderly without producing more detailed alternatives of his own. "What is his solution?" Mr. Gingrich asked.
Speaker after speaker at the rally accused Republicans of planning to cut Medicare growth to finance tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans, and Mr. Clinton joined the charge. But the President left the toughest language to others, such as Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who told the Republicans, "Keep your tax-cutting, greedy hands off our Medicare."
Until about a month ago, the White House was raising the same cry. Then Mr. Clinton decided to propose his own plan to balance the Federal budget within 10 years, instead of the the seven the Republicans have proposed. To do so, he said he would rein in growth in Medicare spending by at least $124 billion during the next seven years, while the Republicans would cut it by $270 billion.
Mr. Clinton's proposal infuriated Congressional Democrats, who hope to make Medicare a major issue in the 1996 campaign, and today several appeared to be talking as much to Mr. Clinton as to the Republicans.
Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, whose father sponsored national health insurance legislation as a member of Congress in the 1940's, brandished the big wooden gavel he wielded in the House the day Medicare was approved.
"This is an important thing," Mr. Dingell said, turning to Mr. Clinton, "but, Mr. President, you've got something a lot more important in your pocket, and that's the pen that you're going to use to veto anything that the Republicans ----" as the rest of the phrase was lost in cheers and applause.
Mr. Clinton has taken considerable heat, and won little credit, for acknowledging that Medicare cannot be sustained in its current form, because its growth is outpacing its resources. A major part of the program, the trust fund that pays hospital bills for the elderly, is projected to go bankrupt by 2002.
In his failed health care plan last year, Mr. Clinton proposed major savings in the growth of Medicare to help finance expanded access to care, and he has always maintained that changes in Medicare should be part of a broader overhaul of the health system. Today he complained that "the same crowd that fought against Medicare" as socialized medicine in 1965 "were successful in derailing what we tried to do last year," in part by raising fears among the elderly that the Government would limit their coverage.
"Well, I got the message of the 1994 election, and I'm not going to let the Government mess with your Medicare," Mr. Clinton said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The President told fellow Democrats and hundreds of elderly Americans yesterday that he would oppose any Republican efforts to cut Medicare benefits, saying he would not "let the Government mess with your Medicare." Mr. Clinton spoke at a ceremony celebrating the program's 30th anniversary. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: California Takeover of Orange County Seems More Likely

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
As the financial crisis in Orange County, Calif., continues to worsen, chances are increasing that the state will seize control of its wealthiest county and force it to pay its debts.
A state appointment of a trustee to manage the county's fiscal affairs would be an action with little precedent: there have been few seizures of municipalities since the Depression, and never of a government of this size. But the magnitude of the county's bankruptcy -- its debts are around $1.9 billion -- and the county's inability to draft a plan to pay its creditors are creating a situation in which state intervention is all but certain. 
 "A trustee is a certainty," said Scott Johnson, legislative aide to Senator William Craven, a Republican from Orange County who is head of the State Legislature's local government committee. "The entire legislative delegation is united in the need for a trustee."
In May, Gov. Pete Wilson vetoed legislation that would have empowered a state trustee to take control of the county's finances, viewing that as a last resort. More recently he asked the county to come up with a plan to resolve its financial crisis by Aug. 15 -- or face state intervention.
Now the county's four state Senators and six Assemblymen seem to be answering that call, putting the finishing touches on legislation calling for the imposition of a state trustee. The bill is expected to be introduced within days in Sacramento, and could be enacted by September.
It is unclear how the Governor will respond to the measure. Russell Gould, the state's finance director and a top aide to Governor Wilson, said yesterday that he could not comment until seeing the measure. He reiterated the Governor's desire for a solution born in Orange County. Paul Kranhold, a spokesman for the Governor, said Mr. Wilson would be interested in seeing the reaction of the Orange County Board of Supervisors before passing judgment.
Still the measure promises to help end a bankruptcy that has dragged on for eight months and has come nowhere close to being resolved. It could also provide some political cover for a Governor caught between the gridlock in the county and the need for the county to pay its bills so that it -- and all California municipalities -- can continue to have access to the credit markets.
But whether such a measure provides enough political cover for Mr. Wilson, who is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, is a matter of some debate. Some people in Sacramento say Mr. Wilson may still seek an even broader consensus from officials in Orange County that a state trustee is necessary.
Another effect of the proposed legislation could be to prompt the county's Board of Supervisors to act on their own to resolve the crisis before Sacramento intervenes.
A state-imposed trustee would have the power to do exactly what the Board of Supervisors can -- but lacks the willingness to -- do. A trustee would be able to decide where to cut the budget and what tax monies could be diverted from specific projects to help repay the mounting debt -- including $800 million due within a year.
Still, there would be limits on a trustee's actions. Under California law, starting with Proposition 13 in 1978, a trustee cannot raise taxes without a vote by taxpayers.
The notion of naming a trustee took on more urgency after voters in Orange County, who are well known for their anti-tax views, rejected a half-cent increase in the sales tax last month to help pay the county's debts. Since then, the county's financial advisers have proposed that taxes dedicated for transportation and for the county's special districts, including water, sewer and beaches, be diverted to pay debts. Their proposal is already being attacked in Orange County.
The package from the Orange County legislators is a sign of the increasing frustration of many state legislators who see the Board of Supervisors as unable to agree on any plan. While the package is subject to approval by the full Legislature, some leaders in Sacramento said yesterday that they expected the Legislature to follow the wishes of the Orange County delegation.
"The plan is likely to move forward with or without the interest or support of the Orange County Board of Supervisors," said Karen Staph-Walters, an adviser to State Senator Lucy Killea, an independent from San Diego. "They may not like the idea of a trustee, but that may not matter. They've been given eight months to solve the problem and nothing has been done."
That the legislators have now come forward in seeking state control is a sign of the political gridlock in the county and its Board of Supervisors.
The fact that the action is being brought by the county legislative delegation, composed mainly of Republicans, could embolden Governor Wilson, whose reluctance so far to appoint a trustee stems at least in part from a desire not to alienate his core conservative supporters.
Orange County filed for bankruptcy in December, after making huge wrong-way bets on interest rates with taxpayer dollars. Since then the crisis has worsened as the county has been unable to come up with a financial rescue plan.
William J. Popejoy, a retired bank executive who was brought in as the county's chief executive to help resolve the crisis, resigned after the sales tax was defeated, saying the Board of Supervisors was "dysfunctional" and had undercut his authority.
"Once Bill Popejoy resigned, interest in having a strong state trustee was re-ignited," said Kenneth Emanueals, legislative assistant for the Orange County League of Cities. "People are throwing their hands up on everything else in Orange County. There is a sense that the county government can't execute anything."
The measure to be submitted to the Legislature by the Orange County delegation includes a debt-repayment plan in addition to the call for a trustee. The measure would provide for diverting some county sales tax revenue toward debt repayment.
It also asks that the Orange County cities and municipalities that lost money in the county's ill-fated investment pool hold off on seeking repayment of their claims.
Mr. Johnson, the aide to Senator Craven, said that even if the county's Board of Supervisors accepted this debt-repayment package, a state trustee might still be appointed -- mainly to accept the political heat that would come from putting the plan into effect.
Mr. Gould, the state director of finance, said that neither he nor the Governor had seen this proposal and could not yet comment on it. "The Governor will be looking at this proposal," he said.
In an interview in Sacramento last week, Mr. Gould said Governor Wilson would consider appointing a trustee "when the county convinces us that they will not act responsibly."
After the defeat of the sales tax increase, Governor Wilson sent top aides, including Mr. Gould, to the county to warn that if the county did not act on its own behalf, the state would intervene.
Senator Quentin Kopp, a San Francisco Democrat and a member of a Senate committee investigating the Orange County situation, said that there was no sympathy in the Legislature for the county's refusal to pay its creditors and that the Legislature would be inclined to support any measure forcing the county to do so. He also said in an interview last week that one impediment to putting in a state trustee had been a fear that the Orange County legislative delegation would oppose it -- something that has now changed.
Others in Orange County have been quietly calling for a state trustee. A recent poll taken by The Orange County Register, the county's newspaper, found that residents had far more confidence in Mr. Popejoy than in the Board of Supervisors.

HEADLINE: Why Gingrich 'Trots' for Presidency: It's Publicity

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Last month, Speaker Newt Gingrich said he was not shutting the door completely on a Presidential bid because if he did, no one would pay any attention to him.
Today, he said that if he opened the door completely, no one would pay attention. 
 "I'd become dramatically less desirable overnight because it's a basic rule of thumb in this business that the next potential candidate is always more exciting than the current candidates," the Georgia Republican told reporters at a breakfast meeting this morning.
"I'd be reduced to three minutes in various cattle calls, whereas right now I get 45 minutes as the guest speaker," he went on. "The places I go, I get longer to speak than the Presidential candidates, so becoming a Presidential candidate would reduce my ability to communicate a coherent message."
Mr. Gingrich has been opening and closing the door on a possible run for the Presidency for months. During a highly publicized trip in June to New Hampshire, where the nation's earliest primary will be held, he said he wanted to keep people guessing so that the press and others would pay attention to him.
Clearly, Mr. Gingrich likes the limelight, and he says he has found it by being the House Speaker. Huge crowds already seek him out, he noted, and his book, "To Renew America," has soared to the top of the best-seller lists.
This, he said, "proves that you don't have to run for President to have an impact, that being Speaker of the House in the way that I'm Speaker of the House -- oriented toward ideas and toward communications and spending probably a third of my time teaching -- that you can have an enormous impact on the Capitol and you don't have to go to the White House."
He mentioned another good reason not to run: "The minute I became a Presidential candidate," he said, "all of you then would re-open every investigative file you had, for one more whack at me."
That said, he proceeded to outline his thoughts about the Republican message for the 1996 Presidential campaign, including a suggestion that the candidates not exploit affirmative action to divide the party or the nation.
"From the Republican Party's standpoint," he said, "we need to be optimistic, we need to be inclusive, we need to argue the future, we need to argue responsibility and draw thematic choices between us and the President."
"I don't think the Republican Party should use affirmative action as a wedge issue," he continued. "We should focus more of our energy on how we design a helping hand."
But he went on to fault President Clinton, who gave a major address on affirmative action last week, for leaving what Mr. Gingrich called "wiggle room" over whether the President favored quotas.
His own view, the Speaker said, is that "there should be no race-based quota system or set-aside," but that "we have an absolute obligation to reach out a helping hand on a one-by-one basis to people who are trying to rise. That makes it more of an economic than a racial matter."
On the ethics charges that have dogged him since he agreed that media magnate Rupert Murdoch's publishing company, HarperCollins, would publish his book, he was asked why he did not select a publisher who did not have Congressional business.
"Everybody in the book industry has legislative interests," Mr. Gingrich replied.
Any other publisher he went with would probably be investigated by Democrats for potential conflicts, he said, adding, "I'm not going to go around from firm to firm, in the age of multinationals and conglomerates, and wait for five smart Democrats or three smart reporters to figure out the next problem."

HEADLINE: Washington Mayor Concedes Necessity of Job Cuts for Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
In his first public admission that many city workers will lose their jobs in a plan to return the District of Columbia to financial stability, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today that as many as 1,500 people, about 4 percent of the work force, could be dismissed over the next two years.
The job cuts are part of Mr. Barry's response to recommendations by the Federal Financial Control Board to guide the city out of its financial crisis. The board, appointed by President Clinton, earlier this month advised the city to eliminate 5,600 positions. Most of those job savings are expected to be achieved through attrition and early retirement. 
 By conceding the need for additional cuts, Mr. Barry acknowledged for the first time that for the city to balance its budget, as required by law, the large-scale reductions he fought to avoid were inescapable. His concession also indicated that he intended to cooperate with the newly created board, which has the power to oversee all financial decisions made by the Mayor and the City Council.
"Whatever it is, we've met it. We're committed," Mr. Barry said at an afternoon news conference, referring to the control board's recommended level of cuts. "We'll be at the number."
The job losses would increase Washington's already high unemployment rate -- it climbed to 8.3 percent in May from 7.9 percent in May 1994 -- but Mr. Barry said the city would create training programs to help people find jobs. Few issues have been more important to Mr. Barry than finding jobs for District residents, many of whom are low-income wage earners. During his three previous terms as Mayor, from 1978 to 1990, economic boom years for the country, the city government grew to more than 57,000 positions.
But as economic conditions turned sour during the term of his successor, Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly, bloated government was blamed for much of the city's growing financial difficulties.
During his campaign for mayor last fall, Mr. Barry refused to take responsibility for the economic downturn and campaigned on the theme of fixing a broken government without cutting jobs. Even when the Congressional committees that oversee the city's operations hounded him to cut jobs, Mr. Barry refused. Instead, he attributed the District's financial problems to Congress for shackling the capital's government with costs that other cities generally share with a county and state government.
But with the control board empowered to reject budget proposals, Mr. Barry acceded to its recommendation that the size of the city government, 45,461 positions, be reduced to 39,861 by the end of the 1996 fiscal year. His agreement to cut the work force, along with responses to other board recommendations, has been forwarded to the City Council for approval.
"The recommendation is based on what I believe is best for the city, not best for Marion Barry politically or the City Council politically, but what is best for Washington," Mr. Barry said.

HEADLINE: Hertz Increases Price of Car Rental by $5

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Hertz Corporation said yesterday that it would increase its daily rental rates by $5, effective immediately, to offset rising prices of new cars.
Avis Rent A Car System and Alamo Rent A Car said they would follow Hertz, the nation's largest car rental agency. 
 "The whole industry is in the same cost situation," said Craig Koch, president and chief operating officer of Hertz. "We wouldn't have taken the increase if we didn't think they would follow."
The costs of replacing cars in rental fleets has risen 30 percent a year since 1992. Hertz and some of its competitors tried to pass on some of those costs in September by raising rates $3 to $4 a day, but price wars chipped away the gains.
This time, vacation and business travelers will feel the pinch as Hertz increases its average rental rates from $45 a day.
The $14 billion industry -- dominated by Hertz, Avis, Budget and Enterprise -- relies on Detroit's Big Three auto makers to supply them with the bulk of their rental cars.
During the recession, auto makers gave rental agencies cut-rate prices to clear out vehicle inventories. But an improving economy has tightened supplies of automobiles and pushed up prices for the last three years.
"We certainly feel that it's imperative for rates to go up, given the circumstances with the manufacturers' price increases," said Demetria Mudar, a spokeswoman for Avis, based in Garden City, L.I.
The Hertz increases take effect immediately. Only rental rates in the United States are affected.

HEADLINE: A Second Look at Child-Support Laws

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 25

 BODY:
If James Pascale were living in California, he might be paying a lot less child support because of the time he spends with his 11-year-old son and twin 9-year-old daughters.
But he lives in New Jersey, where the State Supreme Court has ruled that his former wife, Debra Pascale, should continue to have complete control over the $25,000 both parents contribute each year to support their children. 
 "The way things are I might as well live on the moon and write checks," Mr. Pascale said, insisting that he does not want his support obligation reduced but that he only wants to share in decisions about how some of it is spent. He argued unsuccessfully that his visitation arrangement with his children was nontraditional and should be exempt from the state's child support guidelines.
The argument made by Mr. Pascale is being heard around the country, as courts and legislatures take a fresh look at divorce laws that include a crazy quilt of child-support standards.
Ellen J. Effron, secretary of the American Bar Association's Family Law Section, said, "Virtually every state is encountering arguments that noncustodial parents who spend much more time with their children should be allowed a deviation from the guidelines, and that's the problem."
An overwhelming majority of cases involve fathers who pay support and mothers who have custody. The Census Bureau reported earlier this year that there are 1.6 million custodial fathers, compared with 9.9 million custodial mothers.
"The big issue is, are we really going to redefine the family and fathers' roles?" said Marvin Ventrell, executive director of the National Association of Counsel for Children, based in Denver.
The unanimous New Jersey Supreme Court decision strengthened Mrs. Pascale's control over the "day to day structure of the new family." By contrast, in California, a noncustodial parent, usually the father, can reduce his support payments by increasing the number of visits with his children.
Michael Barber of Sacramento, a former member of the Federal Commission on Interstate Child Support and a former chairman of the child-support subcommittee of the American Bar Association, said that in a middle-class family with two children, a visiting parent who never saw his children pays about $1,050 a month in support payments, but that could be reduced to $123 a month if he divided child-care time equally with his former wife.
"This produces conflict, since the visiting parent is always trying to get to see the children more often to lower his support payments and the custodial parent is trying to frustrate that to keep the payments up," he said.
A better approach, he said, would be a two-tier system that provided a permanent level of support for fixed costs of maintaining the home for the children and a second level that could fluctuate with the frequency of visits.
Under the Federal Family Support Act of 1988, each state is required to establish child support guidelines, either by legislation, court rules or agency regulations, and to review them every four years.
In the last year, there has been increased pressure in Congress to establish a study commission to come up with national guidelines. But Bruce I. Afran, Mr. Pascale's lawyer, said a national support guideline would be a mistake.
"Each state knows what works best in their environment," he said. "Besides, there is a big difference between the cost of raising a family in Manhattan and in Montana."
The Federal Department of Health and Human Services has commissioned a study of state support guidelines, which is gathering information on the variety of issues that can occupy state rule makers.
In North Carolina, special adjustments for teen-agers' clothing was an issue. Elsewhere, states tried to decide whether courts should have the power to waive support payments, knowing that the children would suffer if a custodial parent impeded visitation. None of the reports discussed increasing support payments if the visiting parent failed to exercise visitation rights, which could add significantly to the custodial parent's expenses.
Colorado and Utah said the parent who did not have custody should have the children for overnight stays 25 percent of the time before becoming eligible for a reduction in support payments. In Alaska, the threshold was set at 30 percent, and Idaho recommended 35 percent. Several states concluded that the custody sharing would have to reach 50 percent before adjustments could be made. Other states avoided such tests entirely and said support levels should be left to the discretion of the courts.
A report released last year by the Women's Legal Defense Fund following a study of state guidelines, stated that the living standards of children continue to decline drastically after their parents divorce, just as they had before the 1988 law. Diane Dodson and Joan Entmacher, the authors of the report, said that applying Bureau of Labor Statistics standards, "The children's households' living standards would decline an average of 26 percent, and those of the fathers would increase an average of 34 percent, for all typical families."
Protecting the children's living standards, and preventing them from sliding into poverty, is a chief concern of courts dealing with child support issues. Justice Marie L. Garibaldi, who wrote the opinion, said parents who fight over their support obligations without considering the impact on their children are missing the point. In the court opinion, she said, "Child support is the right of the child and the responsibility of both parents, not a chip won or lost by the custodial parent from the noncustodial parent during divorce."
Gary N. Skoloff of Livingston, a lawyer specializing in family law, said the New Jersey Supreme Court opinion appeared to be a "result-oriented decision for efficient administration in certain cases" intended to avoid an increase in litigation. The result, he said, was unfair, ignoring the legitimate claims of "fathers, real fathers, not those who do the minimum necessary, but those who want to spend more and more time with their children."
The court is awaiting a new report from the Subcommittee on Child Support of the court's Family Practice Committee, which has reviewed the child support guidelines every two years since 1986. The aim is to base child support schedules on more accurate estimates of child-rearing costs and to increase the upper limit of those schedules, the court said.
The Legislature, which is considering revisions to the state's divorce law, decided not to deal with child support issues immediately, but asked Sara Flohr, manager of planning and budget for Princeton University, to act as liaison with the court's subcommittee. Ms. Flohr said the final report could be ready next month and that it might deal with the issues raised by the Pascale case as well provide an update of economic issues.
In addition, a bill that would create a legislative commission to study custody and child support has been passed by the Assembly and released by a Senate committee. It is expected to pass the upper house if the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, posts it for a vote when the Legislature returns later this year.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The End of Something

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: BORDEAUX, France

 BODY:
The U.S. consulate in Bordeaux died last week. It was 205 years old. The oldest living consulate in American diplomatic history succumbed to a variety of ailments, including CNN disease, faxatosis, AT&T-Direct, global integration and most of all the lingering effects of a Congressional ax attack. The Bordeaux consulate is survived by the American Embassy in Paris and its sisters, the U.S. consulates in Strasbourg and Marseilles. Memorial donations may be sent to the General Operating Fund of the U.S. State Department in Washington. (It needs the money.) No memorial service is planned.
Yes, in case you missed it, the State Department announced last week that to appease Congressional budget-cutters it was closing down 19 consulates and embassies, including Bordeaux. Normally the closure of a consulate with two U.S. diplomats and nine locals would not be worthy of note, but Bordeaux is a bit different. It was opened by the Washington Administration -- that's George Washington -- in 1790 as America's first consulate abroad. In closing consulates like Bordeaux, the U.S. is turning its back on the past and the future of U.S. foreign policy for the sake of the present. 
 Bordeaux port was named the first consulate because it had become renowned for supplying the American rebel colonists with arms (and wine). It was from Bordeaux that Lafayette sailed off to fight in the Revolutionary War and it was Bordeaux's city father, Baron Montesquieu, who inspired the separation-of-powers concept in the U.S. Constitution.
But Bordeaux's future is also intriguing. As several Bordeaux businessmen pointed out, an increasingly united Europe is moving today from a collection of states to a collection of economic regions. And the region of southwest France, of which Bordeaux is at the center, is among the most dynamic in Europe. It includes the core of the European defense and aerospace industry -- Airbus Industrie, ATR and Dassault -- the soon-to-be-opened French nuclear-weapons simulation center, Ford and I.B.M. plants and, of course, the cutting edge of the French wine industry. The U.S. is southwest France's biggest trading partner -- $5 billion in exports to the U.S., $3 billion in imports. It's a region worth watching.
"Europe is coming together and we're going home -- it makes no sense," says Charles de Guigne, an American businessman in Bordeaux.
Only in the present does it make sense. No question that in an era of CNN and fax machines, consulates are not as critical as they once were. But there is nothing like having a U.S. consul showing up regularly at the opening session of city governments, local functions and business gatherings, keeping tabs on everything and offering more in the way of American culture than McDonald's and Mickey Mouse. Bordeaux's closing is not a disaster, say French businessmen here, just another sign that the America they grew up with won't be around much longer.
Closing a consulate like Bordeaux might be all right if the U.S. Embassy in Paris could pick up the slack, but it can't. Like all other major European embassies, Paris is being cut by 25 percent. In a rare move, the State Department this year didn't even give the Foreign Service exam to young Americans aspiring to be diplomats, because it had no job openings.
According to diplomats, the U.S. ambassadors to Italy, France, Britain, Spain, the E.U., Germany, Russia and NATO got together in March and sent a secret cable to Secretary of State Christopher, signed by all of them, telling him that the "delivery system" of U.S. foreign policy was being destroyed by budget cuts. They pleaded with him to mobilize those constituencies in the U.S. that value the work of embassies, and volunteered to come to Washington to testify before Congress in their defense. The ambassadors got a polite note back from Deputy Secretary Strobe Talbott, telling them he understood their concerns but that there was a new mood in Congress. There was no invitation to testify.
But here's the good news. The closure of the 19 embassies and consulates will save the U.S. Treasury $12 million.
"Twelve million dollars a year?" asks Robert Beynat, head of the Chamber of Commerce of Bordeaux. "You are doing all of this for $12 million? That is 20 percent of the Bordeaux Chamber of Commerce's annual budget."

HEADLINE: Looking Backward in India

 BODY:
India's recent drive toward economic liberalization is a remarkable success story in the developing world. With overseas investment pouring in, the economy has boomed. But now many of India's gains are imperiled by a recrudescence of nationalist sentiment that threatens to drive foreign companies away. Fear of economic colonization is as old as India itself, but India's leaders must transcend these anxieties if future progress is to be secured.
The focus of the latest anti-foreign hysteria is a proposed $2.8 billion power plant to be constructed outside Bombay by a consortium of American companies led by the Enron Corporation of Houston, a large natural gas supplier. The plant would be the biggest foreign investment in India since the economy started opening up five years ago. It is also desperately needed. 
 Construction began earlier this year in Maharashtra state. But in March, the ruling Congress Party was swept from power in Maharashtra by two Hindu revivalist parties, which charge that the plant was a sweetheart deal and want to cancel it. They also complain that foreign investment has hurt India's poor. Suddenly, potential investors are wondering if India is reverting to the days when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi expelled Coca-Cola, I.B.M. and other big American companies, closing the country off economically for two decades.
This would be a startling reversal. In recent years, even the Communist Party has begun to welcome foreign investment. It is an especially ugly paradox that Mohandas Gandhi's inspiring independence-era cry for swadeshi, or self-sufficiency, has now been picked up by his old enemies, the Hindu chauvinists. Leading the charge is the Shiv Sena, a party with links to the goons who carried out the anti-Muslim riots in Bombay a few years ago.
Though committed to canceling the power plant, the leaders of Maharashtra could still support a face-saving deal, perhaps persuading the Enron consortium to charge lower prices for power. The Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao should continue to support the project by threatening to override any cancellation by the state government. But the ideal outcome would be for a show of political maturity by the other opponent of the plant, the Bharatiya Janata Party or Indian People's Party.
With the Congress Party splintered, the Bharatiya Janata stands a good chance of coming out on top in the next national elections. The Bharatiya Janata could gain respectability -- and save the project -- by showing that it can put national interests ahead of sectarian impulses.

HEADLINE: Bad Advice for Arafat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas Friedman's column ("Muffled Militants," July 19) on the Islamic fundamentalist challenge cites the new Palestinian state as an example of "secular authorities" improving living conditions because Yasir Arafat "today has 60,000 people on his payroll in Gaza," thus providing employment and weakening the ability of Hamas to recruit. 
 In the same column, Mr. Friedman attacks such "secular Arab states" as Egypt and Algeria for "heavy-handed bureaucracies," which quash "commerce and entrepreneurship."
But the Arafat statist achievement he praises is in direct opposition to the economic advice he gives other Islamic states. Similarly, his plea for the "liberation of women," if heeded, would flood Arab labor markets and further depress wages. His call for "privatization of state industries" would result in unemployment of many of those 60,000 workers in Gaza. Encouraging Mr. Arafat to repeat the mistakes of other secular Arab regimes is surely not a solution.
 
WILLIAM J. PARENTE
Professor of Political Science
University of Scranton
Scranton, Pa., July 20, 1995

HEADLINE: In Korea, Democracy Still Has Far to Go

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 19 news article on the hastiness of South Korea's postwar construction boom highlights the darker underside of Korea's "economic miracle." However, as I learned on a trip there last month, it is not only the recent construction boom that rests on a dangerous foundation.
The transition to the "New Korea" promised by President Kim Young Sam, where internationally guaranteed human rights would be respected, remains dangerously incomplete. The laws authorizing arbitrary arrest and detention, suppression of free association, expression and assembly that propped up decades of military rule are actively used by President Kim against political opponents and labor activists. 
 During May and June the Government invoked these laws against independent union leaders and activists in violation of basic human rights and labor rights in particular.
President Kim arrives in Washington in a few days for a three-day visit, and there is a real opportunity to press him to respect human rights. Korea has applied for membership in the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, the club of industrialized democracies. The O.E.C.D. entry process provides valuable leverage to press Korea to reform its labor laws to meet international standards.
 
RICHARD DICKER
Associate Counsel
Human Rights Watch
New York, July 20, 1995

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasurys Close Mixed Following Latest Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the long bond up, despite a barrage of indicators that suggested a sustained healthy economy would make it unnecessary for the Federal Reserve to lower rates again.
The 30-year bond gained 22/32 of a percentage point, to a price of 110 5/32. It yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.82 percent, from 6.87 percent on Monday and down from 6.92 percent at its worst point during the day. In the shorter maturities, bill rates were up about one-hundredth of a percentage point, and intermediate maturities were mixed. 
 Analysts said the market bounced back from its lows earlier in the day because of an encouraging outcome of a two-year note auction and because a Reuters report on Fed policy led to short-covering, which added momentum in the afternoon.
Short-covering occurs when a short sale goes awry. In a short sale, investors sell borrowed securities and hope to buy them back later at lower prices and pocket the difference. However, if prices begin to rise as they did yesterday, these investors have to cover their short positions quickly, buying back the securities to limit their losses.
Traders said the note auction went well, and that in itself suggested there was still a lot of positive feeling in the market. "There were a lot of reasons for this auction to go badly, and for it to go well is a good sign," said Waldo T. Best, senior economist at Barclays De Zoette Wedd Securities in New York. Two of the key reasons were reports signaling a significant pickup in the housing sector and in consumer confidence.
"If we could get the five-year to go this well, it would mean that the rally can still go further," Mr. Best added.
The Conference Board's July consumer confidence report rose to 99.9 from 94.6, indicating that consumers were feeling good about spending and the outlook for employment. This came on top of a report by the National Association of Realtors that showed housing resales in June were at their highest level since last October, as lower interest rates helped attract buyers. Overall sales were up 6.5 percent last month to an annual rate of 3.78 million, compared with a 4.7 percent gain in May.
Another report issued yesterday, this one by the Labor Department, showed that American businesses' wage, salary and benefit costs rose seventh-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, suggesting wage inflation was nearly nonexistent.
Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said yesterday's strong finish by the market surprised many.
He said market's turnaround from early morning weakness could probably be traced to a number of events, one of them being a report on the Reuters news wire that cited an unidentified Fed official as having said that future Fed rate moves hinged on whether inflation showed signs of slowing. "I'm sure that the market may have interpreted the story to mean that the Fed could lower rates even if business gets better, just as long as inflation is not a threat," Mr. Roden said.
"I think the weakness in the market over the last week or two reflects the market's readjustment in thinking, as it now realizes that it may not get these rate reductions by the Fed," Mr. Roden continued. "As a guy who runs money, I keep referring to the long end of market, and I think there is less room for interest rates to come down than there is for rates to move higher. Right now, I am more cautious at the long end of the market, and I am finding it better to err on the side of caution.
"On the short end of the market, rates probably could go lower, but only if European central banks cut their rates," Mr. Roden added.
The Treasury sold $17.75 billion of new two-year notes yesterday at a yield of 5.955 percent, up from 5.690 percent in June and the highest since 6.17 percent in May. Analysts had expected an even higher yield of 5.97 percent.
The Treasury is selling two-year notes in a single-price format, which the Government began after the 1991 Salomon Brothers scandal.
In the standard multiple-price auction, bids are awarded at the high, average and low yields. In the single-price system, notes are awarded at the highest yield needed to sell the securities.
Tomorrow, the Government will auction $11.5 billion of five-year notes, also through single-price auctions. And in when-issued trading late yesterday, the notes were being offered at a price to yield 6.25 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new two-year notes:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Data on U.S. Economic Gains Help Lift Dollar Against Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was stronger against most leading European currencies yesterday, bolstered by signs of economic growth in the United States.
But the dollar was little changed against the Japanese yen as investors questioned whether more dollar purchases by Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan, would lift it higher. 
 The dollar rallied after the Conference Board said consumer confidence increased this month. And a report by the National Association of Realtors showed a larger-than-expected 6.5 percent gain in sales of existing homes.
The data helped confirm expectations that the Federal Reserve, faced with a stronger recovery, would not cut short-term interest rates again this summer. Lower interest rates would hurt the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits less attractive.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.3942 German marks from 1.3857 marks on Monday. The dollar edged up to 87.79 yen from 87.52 yen.
The dollar also received a lift against the mark after the German state of Hesse reported low inflation in the month that ended in mid-July.
It was the third state to report low inflation this week, raising speculation the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, might cut rates soon. On Monday, Baden-Wurtemberg and North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany's most populous state, reported that consumer prices declined slightly in the period.
"The inflation reports were very helpful to dollar-mark because they leave the door open for another ease," said John Rothfield, an international economist at Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago.
The Bundesbank, which acts as the floor for German money market rates, last trimmed its discount rate on March 30 to a six-year low of 4 percent.
Against the yen, the dollar was little changed amid growing doubts that the dollar could be pushed higher.
Purchases by Japan's central bank were crucial to the dollar's rally last week, traders said. Analysts estimate that the Bank of Japan has bought as much as $1 billion a day since July 7, when both the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan stepped in and bought dollars, taking the market by surprise.
Some traders said the action by the Bank of Japan would not be enough to push the dollar higher.
"The dollar's move up was engineered and artificial and didn't get a lot of credence," said Jerry Egan, managing director of foreign exchange at MTB Bank in New York.

HEADLINE: Reports Show Growth but Not Inflation

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
Three reports issued today indicated that the economy was growing moderately without stirring inflation.
The National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes rose 6.5 percent in June, above analysts' expectations. The Conference Board said consumer confidence increased this month. At the same time, the Labor Department reported that employment costs increased slowly in the 12 months through June. 
 The Labor Department's Employment Cost Index advanced just 2.9 percent in the year ended in June, matching the smallest gain since the department began calculating the data in 1981. In the second quarter of this year, the index, which measures growth in wages, salaries and benefits, rose a seasonally adjusted seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The slow growth "points to something different about this cycle," Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said. "Inflation remains dormant in the fifth year of an expansion."
The index is considered one of the best gauges of inflationary pressures because employee compensation represents about two-thirds of the cost of a product.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich called the slow growth in compensation a "large cloud in an otherwise blue sky" and something that would eventually come to haunt employers. "Productivity improvements are going into corporate profits, not workers' pockets," he said in an interview. "Workers are consumers. At some point, American workers won't have enough money in their pockets to buy all of the goods and services they are producing."
He added: "The lack of inflation obviously is a plus for all Americans. But it's difficult for many Americans to enjoy it if their paychecks are dropping."
June's 6.5 percent increase in sales of previously owned homes lifted sales to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.78 million units, the highest since last October, the National Association of Realtors said. In May, sales had risen 4.7 percent.
Data from the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation showed that 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.53 percent in June, down from 7.91 percent in May and 9.15 percent in January.
The index of consumer confidence compiled by the Conference Board rose to 99.9 in July from a revised 94.6 in June. The index had reached 102 in May.
"While consumer confidence declined in June, the current reading is at a reassuringly strong level," said Fabian Linden, director of the New York group's consumer research unit. "Consumers remain optimistic about the health of the U.S. economy."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Some airlines are going to great lengths to shorten flying time between North America and Asia.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
WITH little fanfare, Asian-bound passengers from the United States and Canada have been able to shorten their flying time across the Pacific Ocean by as much as three hours. While the flights benefit business and leisure travelers equally, the real motivation behind many of the flights is to make flying more convenient for business travelers, who pay the highest fares.
Northwest Airlines, for example, is so determined to accommodate its business travelers to Asia that on some flights it chooses to carry fewer leisure passengers and less cargo. While it flies in the face of conventional aviation wisdom to leave passengers behind on planes that are not full, Northwest's purpose is to eliminate stops en route that otherwise would be necessary for planes carrying heavier loads. 
 Because such fuel stops can delay arrivals by one to three hours, causing some full-fare customers to miss connections or important meetings, Northwest concluded that it was cheaper in the long run to forgo the revenue from some cargo and excursion passengers than to inconvenience business travelers.
"Northwest generates greater revenues and profits when we provide the service as promised to our high-yield passengers," said Michael Levin, the carrier's executive vice president of marketing and international operations, "because they will be more inclined to fly Northwest again."
Carefully stressing that the new policy does not compromise safety, Jim McKie, manager of Northwest's flight operations, added that there were still circumstances that would require a fuel stop -- for example, stronger head winds than expected or winds that shifted from tail winds to head winds.
Northwest also saves as much as an hour on its Seattle-Hong Kong flight by flying over airspace near the border between Russia and China, which was off-limits to Western carriers during the cold war. A number of American and Canadian carriers are either already flying the corridor or plan to do so soon.
According to Mr. McKie, Northwest pioneered the post-cold war flights over the far eastern air space of Russia, beginning with cargo flights in 1990 and soon including its passenger flights between Detroit and Tokyo.
The decision whether to choose these routes is made on a case-by-case basis -- depending on whether the savings in time and fuel will offset the several thousand dollars the airlines are charged for each overflight. In 1990 and 1991, Northwest often flew the routes over Russia even when it cost the carrier money to do so. The carrier was eager to develop those routes and willing to put up the money to enable Russia to improve its flight control system. Now, having done so, "if the savings aren't there," Mr. McKie said, "we won't go."
 
Return of First Class
Wasn't it only a year or so ago that many airlines were jettisoning their first-class sections, on the theory that nobody pays first-class fares any more?
The answer, it seems, is an unqualified yes and no. Fewer corporations allow employees to fly first class, but since business travelers still prefer first-class comfort and pampering, many airlines have retained their first-class sections -- for that occasional business or leisure traveler willing to pay first-class fares, but mostly in order to reward loyal passengers with upgrades.
America West is going a step further, by adding first class to the 39 planes in its 91-plane feet that do not already have it. "We've often talked about having a business-class cabin," said Michael S. Leonard, the carrier's senior director of market development, "but we concluded that business class was better for international routes than for domestic," which comprises the bulk of America West's route system.
Since America West is locked in furious competition with Southwest Airlines, an all-economy-class carrier, it also considered making its fleet entirely economy class. "But on many other routes we compete with full-service carriers," Mr. Leonard said, "and our market research showed we'd be much better off financially with first class and economy."
This way, he said, first class would be available for any business traveler wanting to buy a first-class ticket, and for upgrading passengers who buy full-fare coach tickets and even leisure passengers who fly America West often.
 
Price Isn't Everything
With travel and entertainment budgets regularly thrust under corporate microscopes, it is logical to conclude that those who negotiate business travel arrangements for employees choose low-priced hotels. Logical, maybe, but misleading. After interviewing travel managers at 20 major corporations, researchers at Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration found that only 18 percent of them selected a hotel that offered only a low price. The hotels most likely to win corporate bookings, according to two professors, Russell Bell and Richard Morey, were those nearest the business traveler's appointment. And as hard as it may be to believe, free breakfast and free airport shuttle service had little or no impact on whether a hotel would be selected.

HEADLINE: In a Ranking of Maternal Health, U.S. Trails Most Developed Nations

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
The United States ranks 18th in an index measuring maternal health, lower than most other developed nations in the world, a new study says.
The study reviewed the data in 10 categories of maternal health and gave each of the 118 countries surveyed a score based on its performance in those areas. Areas rated included the number of women who die during childbirth, teen-age pregnancy, contraceptive use, prenatal care and availability of safe abortions. 
 The study, released on Monday, shows that the chance of dying from pregnancy or childbirth varies dramatically in different parts of the world, from 1 in 7 in Mali to about 1 in 17,000 in Italy. The rate in the United States is 1 in 5,669. The study was done by the research group Population Action International in Washington.
The countries with the best overall rankings were, in order, Italy, Denmark, Norway, Sweden and Belgium. Ranked the worst were Mali, Congo, Somalia, Angola and Zaire.
Although an important factor affecting the ranking is a country's relative wealth, said Dr. Shanti R. Conly, director of policy research for the group, some quite poor countries have worked on women's health issues and ranked well, while other nations of great wealth scored relatively poorly.
Last year, at the International Conference on Population and Development in Cairo, 180 nations reached an agreement urging all countries to make reproductive health services and contraceptives available to all by the year 2015.
The United States did not rank higher largely because of teen-age pregnancies -- its rate is about six times that of European nations -- and a relatively low rate of contraceptive use.
Although it still fell in the study's "very low risk" group of countries, the United States ranked behind such emerging countries as Taiwan and Singapore. And Dr. Conly contended that it "is likely to drop even farther if this Congress continues as it has started." A proposal to end public contraceptive services in the United States has been approved in committee, and another to cut aid to developing nations in Africa by one-third may be an indication of what is to come, she said.
Some relatively poor countries have made long-term commitments to health care and family planning, Dr. Conly said, and have succeeding in several important measures. "Their programs may not be the Cadillac models," she said, "but they give all people access to health care of some kind."
Costa Rica, Cuba and Sri Lanka have maternal death rates lower than 100 per 100,000 births, whereas about half the world's nations have rates of 200 to 1,750 per 100,000. The study also cited Tunisia and Vietnam as having made unexpected progress.
The report contained at least two surprises for researchers. One was that Italy ranked best in reproductive health in the world.
"We didn't expect this," Dr. Conly said, "because while use of family planning in Italy is high, over half of Italian couples use traditional methods like withdrawal and rhythm, which experts generally consider less effective. However, Italian women appear able to use these methods effectively, largely because safe abortion is available on request."
Another surprise, Dr. Conly said, was that countries like Indonesia and Bangladesh, which have become exemplary nations in offering family planning broadly, nevertheless fall in the "high risk" category because their death rates from pregnancy and childbirth remain high.
The study looked at three areas for each country: family planning, which the researchers said reduced the risks associated with frequent childbearing and reliance on unsafe abortion; pregnancy and childbirth, including such related health concerns as AIDS and anemia, and post-pregnancy issues like infertility.
The nations of the former Soviet Union were not included in the survey because some data for those nations were not available in comparable form.
