HEADLINE: Required Reading: Grisham, Clancy, Rice and Proust

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
When summer heats up, the reading list of the average college student splits three ways. It's a division that reflects struggle among three impulses. The urge toward enlightenment wrestles with the need to find a job, and both can be pinned to the mat by the swinish desire to wallow in trash.
An informal survey of college bookstores around the country yields a best-seller list that is fraught with contradictions. Some titles, tony and highbrow, suggest that America's colleges really are coaching the best and the brightest for victory in a highly competitive world economy. There are others -- many of them, in fact -- that paint a different picture of the college population. 
 It would be pleasant to think that the flower of American youth is taking advantage of the summer to mount a frontal assault on Gibbon's "History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire" or Proust's "Remembrance of Things Past." It's just as likely, though, that students are thumbing through the resume writer's equivalent of "Thinner Thighs in 30 Days" or staring slack-jawed at "The Courtship of Princess Leia."
John Grisham and Tom Clancy rule. "The Chamber" and "Debt of Honor" pop up on nearly every Top 5 list. "The Celestine Prophecy," a squishy New Age tome, also sells briskly.
The plea here seems to be, Guilty, with an explanation. "You've got to allow them one beach book," said Toby Cox, the promotions manager at Brown University's campus bookstore.
Other titles are harder to explain away. "I'm embarrassed by this, but in this store we actually do sell 'The Bridges of Madison County,' " said Joe Dickson, the trade-book buyer at the Johns Hopkins campus bookstore in Baltimore. Things could be worse, and they are. Also on the Hopkins best-seller list is "O. J.'s Legal Pad," a collection of sophomoric doodlings and comments presented as the handiwork of the world's best-known murder defendant. "I'm a little embarrassed by that too," said Mr. Dickson.
At the University of Texas, in Austin, students are bingeing on "Memnoch the Devil," by Anne Rice, and "The Illuminatus Trilogy," a cult science-fiction title by Robert Shea and Robert A. Wilson. Honor is saved by Milan Kundera's "Laughable Loves," Isabel Allende's "House of the Spirits" and Douglas Hofstadter's "Fluid Concepts and Creative Analogies."
Similarly, at Square Books, near the University of Mississippi in Oxford, the two top sellers, Kirsty Gunn's "Rain" and Sebastien Japrisot's "Very Long Engagement," suggest a level of taste and intellect one might hope for in William Faulkner's hometown. Unfortunately, "The Beer Lover's Rating Guide" lowers the tone.
Somewhat encouragingly, Richard Preston's "Hot Zone," a perfectly respectable title, is giving Mr. Grisham and Mr. Clancy a run for their money at nearly every college bookstore.
The looming prospect of job interviews and self-promotion has propelled sales of "The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People," by Stephen R. Covey, a best seller at many campus bookstores. At Cornell, students are also buying "Cover Letters That Knock 'Em Dead" and "Resumes That Knock 'Em Dead." Although the resume book does not go into this, it's probably not a good idea to put "Tom Clancy novels" under the heading "Outside Interests."
Highbrow titles fall into two categories: proven commodities and local cults. Most college bookstores report steady, strong sales for Mr. Kundera's "Unbearable Lightness of Being," Ms. Allende's "Paula," Toni Morrison's "Beloved," Gabriel Garcia Marquez's "Love in the Time of Cholera" and Sandra Cisneros's "House on Mango Street."
At the University of Southern California, students are still buying the old warhorses like Jack Kerouac's "On the Road" and the novels of Ayn Rand. At Brown, "Lolita" and "The Sound and the Fury" make the Top 20.
Local taste and local conditions can bend the best-seller list in strange ways. Terry Zwigoff's documentary film "Crumb" opened recently in Austin, Tex., and it has pumped up demand for "The Complete Crumb Comics." This year, A. R. Ammons edited "Best American Poetry," a popular annual anthology. He teaches at Cornell, and his influence is reflected in strong local demand. Likewise, "Montana 1948" is a top title at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis at least in part because its author, Larry Watson, is a Minnesota writer and the book is published by a local press. At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, "Being Digital," by Nicholas Negroponte, sells well, which is not surprising, since its author is the founder and director of the Media Lab at M.I.T.
In general, movies move books, at least temporarily. Many college bookstores report Maeve Binchey's "Circle of Friends" among their Top 10 titles, as well as "Apollo 13," by Jim Lovell and Jeffrey Kluger. In Austin, the title gets an extra boost. "He's almost local," said Ella Watson, the manager of the general books department at the University Co-op Bookstore, referring to Mr. Lovell, the former astronaut. "He lives about 30 miles from here."
Some titles, of course, defy the changing seasons and are immune to fickle fashions and trends. Colleges throughout the land report steady demand for that next-best thing to the book itself: Cliffs Notes.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Living Desk

HEADLINE: A Workaholic's Worst Nightmare? Vacation

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
WHEN Brian Fraidin invites friends to go away with him on vacation, he speaks frankly. Don't get too excited, he warns, because he will probably cancel. In fact, he regularly aborts trips just days before they are supposed to happen. He can live with disappointing others, he said, because work comes first.
"Sitting on a beach sounds appealing to me," said Mr. Fraidin, who owns a venture capital firm in Baltimore and took his last vacation three years ago (it was a weekend trip to Florida). "But once the day is over, what have you accomplished?" 
 Summer travel is booming, agents are reporting huge numbers of bookings, and travel during May was up 11 percent from the same period last year, said Steve Loucks, a spokesman for the American Society of Travel Agents, a trade group in Alexandria, Va.
Yet, there are still some feverish holdouts who refuse to leave their office chairs, even when the rest of their colleagues have long ago left to burn under the sun. They just cannot seem to take all the time they have coming to them, even when their employers insist they must.
Those who go months and even years without vacations do so for a variety of reasons, including widespread layoffs that have increased the workload on individuals, economic insecurity and simple garden-variety neuroses, said human-resource managers and employees in more than a dozen companies around the country.
In interviews, a fairly consistent portrait of vacation-free employees emerged. They tend to be salaried rather than wage employees, often working in management. Most said their own sense of responsibility, or fear of how bosses might react to requests, pushed them to work hard.
"I hadn't been at the company very long," said Elizabeth English, 29, a senior programmer at Lehman Brothers in New York. "So I felt eight days were too many to take last year. It seems hard to get away in general because there are so many demands to be met. It took me four weeks to ask for a vacation this year, and even then, I asked for it in E-mail."
Certain professions like advertising, law and financial trading seem to draw such people. Eileen Canty, an organizational psychologist at William M. Mercer, a human resources consulting group in New York, said that they were easy to spot.
"People say, 'For my vacation, I'm going to paint the garage,' " she said. "They feel they always have to get something done."
A just-released survey done for the Hilton Hotels Corporation found that 38 percent of adults in the United States have not taken a vacation in at least a year. Despite their reluctance to leave work, 67 percent of those surveyed said they would trade a day's salary for a day off.
The survey, conducted by Strategic Consulting and Research in Los Angeles in random telephone interviews with 1,025 adults last fall, also found that while 19 percent of the respondents sneaked away from the job to play hooky last year, just as many skulked off during their vacation to work. The study has a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The travel industry is fighting to make sure these people do not slip through the cracks. It has come up with new ways to snare those who can afford only weekend getaways, and airlines have increased the number of rock-bottom fares they offer for fast trips to places like Paris, where travelers can presumably take a bite of a croissant, wipe their mouths and then head back to the airport.
"The offerings of four-day, three-night packages to places like London or Paris have dramatically increased in just a couple of years," Mr. Loucks said.
A number of human resource managers said they could not estimate the number of employees who take less than their allowed vacations, because they do not keep records of how much vacation time is used; presumably, too, they are not eager to paint themselves as holding cells for workaholics.
But many acknowledged that they had a problem getting some people to take vacation time.
"It tends to be the case that top management here has a healthy allotment of time off and that they often don't take it," said Lorrie Crum, a spokeswoman for Rubbermaid Inc. in Wooster, Ohio.
Jon Firestone, the president and chief executive of BBDO, Minneapolis, an advertising agency, said: "We find that most of our senior employees never use up all of their vacation. It is just consistent with the dedication and kind of drive that got them where they are to begin with."
Some people said that visions of an overflowing in-box would destroy the scant thrill brought on by a jaunt to Martha's Vineyard.
"I haven't taken a vacation for three or four years," said Daniel Braun, 34, a vice president of graphic services at a New York advertising agency. "If I took one, I would just have more work when I came back."
Companies often offer incentives to encourage workers to take vacations because the unused time is treated by their accountants as debt. To address the problem, many companies push employees to take vacation time by refusing to allow them to roll it over to the next year. Others, like Interbake Foods, Bausch & Lomb and Du Pont, offer workers a chance to "purchase" time by taking payroll deductions in exchange for an extra week of vacation. The logic may be that if it costs something, workers will feel they deserve it.
In the early 1980's, the Intel Corporation, in California's Silicon Valley, started a mandatory paid sabbatical program for employees who have worked for seven years or more. "We were finding that people who had been strong, successful employees would burn out after seven years," said Howard High, a spokesman for the company. "And we would start to see a blip in turnover at those points."
For at least eight weeks, employees go to the beach, teach a class or do whatever else they fancy, with a guarantee that they have a job to come back to. Among the advantages, Mr. High said, are that subordinates get to try their hand at more difficult jobs and receive critiques, while those who actually hold the positions come back refreshed and recharged.
Clearly, though, vacation phobia is simply built into some personalities. It would seem, for example, that people would naturally dream of free time, of a place far away and exciting. A place with frozen drinks.
Bob Amos is not one of those people. A product development manager at MCI in Washington, Mr. Amos, 32, does not remember his last vacation and says he finds that fine. "It's not really a negative thing, because I enjoy what I do," he said. "My fantasy self is a tour guide leading a trip through the Amazon. Because to work is to be on vacation."
Kim Lepine, 48, a hairdresser, took her last vacation three years ago. Now that she owns her own salon on the Upper East Side, she does not plan to see the inside of an airplane anytime soon, unless, of course, it is for a business trip. "It's just my nature," Ms. Lepine said. "I've been working since I was 13. It's what I do. I'm a worker."
Sometimes, however, the family must take control. Bill Lynch, who was a Deputy Mayor of New York in the administration of David N. Dinkins and is now a vice president of McAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., has taken only one vacation in five years.
It was not his idea. In 1990, his wife and two children strong-armed him into a week in Puerto Rico. Just to be sure no last-minute demands would derail the vacation, his daughter Stacy unplugged the phone before they went to the airport.
"I had to laugh and ask her, 'Am I really that bad?' " Mr. Lynch said. "I guess I am just paranoid that the city will fall off and float away when I'm not here."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Puts Heat on the Commerce Dept.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 25

 BODY:
With a summer heat wave that has gripped the capital for weeks, it was only a matter of time before Democrats and Republicans began bickering over what to do about the weather -- and more specifically, whether predicting it is still a legitimate role of government.
How to deal with the Government's giant weather bureaucracy -- privatize it, restructure it or cut its budget drastically -- is just one of the bitter arguments that broke out this week as Congress began to tackle the messy business of dismantling the Commerce Department, an invention of President Theodore Roosevelt that has come to embody all that the Republicans, especially the tear-it-up freshmen, say is wrong with big government. 
 It is hard to tell what the Republicans hate most about the Commerce Department, which Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, with an eye to staying abreast of other contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination, today called "the basement of the Federal bureaucracy."
In two days of hearings, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, a branch of the Commerce Department, was blamed obliquely for the suicide of overregulated fishermen, its $491 million budget to promote promising but risky technology was labeled "corporate welfare," and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown was accused of judging potential participants in his trade missions by their contributions to the Democratic National Committee -- an accusation that he vociferously denied.
Mr. Brown has dished it right back. He called the bills in the House and Senate to dismantle the department "unilateral disarmament" in trade competition against Japan. On Monday, he told Republicans in the House that he suspected they were on a "trophy hunt," eager to hang a Cabinet agency on their wall, and delivered a hard-edged message from President Clinton that he would veto a bill to scrap the department.
Mr. Brown, by all accounts, has been one of the most successful Commerce secretaries in years, a point that even many of his Republican sparring partners acknowledge. But with investigations into his own finances continuing, the Secretary's political capital these days is low. And on Capitol Hill, his department is a fat watermelon of a target.
Its problem is that it does everything. It negotiates trade agreements, it takes the census, it hands out money to cities and towns facing economic hardship (a role that no one in Congress has lambasted too harshly), it worries about sea turtles, it totals the gross national product and it runs the United States Travel and Tourism Administration.
But as two days of hearings have shown, it is a lot easier to talk about tearing a department apart than it is to figure out what to do with the pieces. The department's executioners say they can save nearly $8 billion over five years by dismantling it soon, killing some parts and moving other elements elsewhere.
But others say that figure is a budget-cutting fantasy, especially because most of the "dismantlement" bills simply move the department's functions elsewhere.
"Box shuffling does not make a government work any better," Mr. Brown told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee today. Then he told his Republican interlocutors that they would simply be playing into the hands of the Japanese, the Chinese, the European Union and other trade rivals. "We've finally got it working the way it should be working," he said.
Mr. Brown's critics are quick to note that many of the department's functions, working or not, duplicate other parts of the Government.
L. Nye Stevens, a General Accounting Office official, today delineated how the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which accounts for 44 percent of the Commerce Department's budget, overlaps work done by the Department of the Interior, the National Science Foundation, the Office of Naval Research, the Department of Energy, the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
The issue that most seems to divide Democrats and Republicans is what to do with the parts of the department that hone in on national competitiveness.
Initially, for example, the critics, led by Representative Dick Chrysler, a Michigan Republican, wanted to wipe out the department's International Trade Administration, which negotiates and monitors trade agreements and puts political pressure on foreign governments to buy American goods. But at the hearings, even the most radical budget-cutters backed away.
"It makes a difference," Mr. Brown said, "when a Secretary of Commerce, accompanied by 25 or so chief executives, gets off a plane emblazoned 'United States of America."
Hard-line Republicans say that such trade advocacy smacks of corporate welfare. But since the International Trade Administration accounts for only 4 percent of the department's $4 billion budget, they have focused on other targets within the department. One of the juiciest is the department's Advanced Technology Program, which awards "seed money" to companies to pursue risky high-technology ventures.
The House Appropriations Committee recently cut such programs out of its proposed budget, calling them a Clinton Administration giveaway to business.
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, said today that if he believed in conspiracies, he would regard the effort to dismantle the Commerce Department as "some kind of foreign plot" intended to "force a technological and economic surrender."
Caught in the middle is American business, at once the beneficiary of many of the department's proposals and the biggest advocate of cutting government budgets and regulations. The Republicans seem confident that they can slash at the department without paying a big price among their traditional supporters. But Mr. Brown insisted today that he had received 2,000 letters from companies seeking to keep the department alive and well.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. Says It Is Willing to Address Players' Concerns

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Five weeks after they thought they had completed labor negotiations for the next six seasons, officials of the National Basketball Association and its union of locked-out players returned to the bargaining table yesterday but made no instant progress toward another agreement.
"We discussed and covered a lot of areas," Commissioner David Stern said after the five-hour meeting at a midtown Manhattan hotel. "I can't say that substantial progress was made, but we did indicate the owners' willingness to attempt to address areas of concern that have been raised by the players as long as a deal remained sensible economically." 
 Before leading a contingent of a dozen players to the talks, Simon Gourdine, the union's embattled executive director, dealt with yet another internal matter that has added to the image of a union under siege from within.
Gourdine wrote a four-page letter to W. Charles Bennett, who 24 hours earlier resigned as the union's financial consultant. Bennett charged, among other things, that Gourdine had misrepresented Bennett's analysis of N.B.A. profits to support the agreement the players refused to ratify.
In the letter, Gourdine recalled instances during negotiations in which he said Bennett expressed views contrary to those he stated in his letter of resignation. Bennett disputed that characterization.
In the renewed negotiations, Gourdine raised several issues dealing with the payroll cap and exceptions to it. The union's primary goal is to induce the league to abandon its quest for a luxury tax on top of the cap.
Gourdine agreed to the idea in the June 21 agreement in principle, but the players reacted vehemently to the tax, which teams would pay, ultimately at a 100 percent rate, if they exceeded the payroll cap by signing their own free agents to raises exceeding 10 percent.
"That was the challenge we all agreed was worth looking at," Stern said, referring to the tax. "We weren't able to make any progress on that point today."
The commissioner said the league was "determined" to try to address the concerns players have raised as long as the answers could be found in the economic package that would have been created by the rejected agreement, a package that he said would be worth more than $5 billion over six years.
Asked if he thought a deal could be reached quickly and easily, Stern said: "I don't think it can be done easily. As a result, it probably can't be done quickly. But both sides seem to be willing to engage in strenuous discussion."
The two sides did not schedule another session but agreed to speak in the next day or two. Faced with the possibility the players could vote to decertify the union, thus nullifying any agreement the negotiators might reach, Stern reiterated that the lockout would continue in the absence of an agreement.
Stern also said he felt that if an agreement were to be reached before a decertification election, the players would vote depending on how they viewed the new labor contract.
If the two sides reach agreement, the union will handle ratification differently than it did last month. In a memo to players, Gourdine told them, "If we are able to reach a new agreement with the owners, we will hold regional meetings for all players, and then each of you will be given an opportunity to vote on whether it should be approved."
Regional meetings and vote of the entire membership, not just the player representatives, are steps the union rejected after they were requested last month by the union's agents advisory committee. Players who are clients of agents on the committee began the movement to decertify the union.
The resignation of its financial consultant is the latest problem the union has had to face. Responding to Bennett, Gourdine defended his view of Bennett's analysis by recalling a bargaining session last May 18. At that session, Gourdine wrote, Stern said a union proposal "would 'bankrupt the owners.' "
Bennett, Gourdine added, acknowledged before a break in the session that the proposal would "leave the owners with a minimal profit -- a total of $14 million for all the teams, to be exact."
"In sum," Gourdine wrote, "the teams' profits are declining, and to the extent that your letter disputes this reality, we are at a complete loss to understand where you are coming from and where you have been for the past 16 months."
Bennett said he would answer Gourdine privately in another letter but that Gourdine's recollection made no sense.
"If it takes you three months to analyze the league's revenues, you can't analyze profits just before the break," Bennett said by telephone from Albuquerque, N.M.
In a memorandum to players two weeks ago, Gourdine said the league had given the union financial data showing a decline in operating income from $195 million for the 1992-93 season to $177 million for the 1993-94 season to $115 million for the 1994-95 season.
Leaguewide revenues, Gourdine told the players, had increased at a rate of about 8 percent a year while player salaries increased "at a greater and greater rate each year, reaching 20 percent last season."

HEADLINE: A Realistic Entity: Greater Sarajevo

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel, professor of international relations at the University of Southern California, is author of "Temptations of a Superpower."

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The fall of the isolated Muslim enclaves in eastern Bosnia, including Zepa yesterday, may be a blessing in disguise. In threatening air strikes to protect the "safe havens," NATO is misguided. The eventual withdrawal of Muslim troops and civilians from Gorazde, Bihac and Tuzla could hold the key to a political settlement.
The Bosnian Government should have abandoned these towns long ago. They were held because they were considered useful in the effort to reclaim lost territories and because the plight of their refugees engaged the conscience of the West. Now the Bosnian Government should scale back its unrealistic ambitions and withdraw its army to establish a viable, independent republic around Sarajevo. 
 This would help end the war. But for a truce to be established, the combatants and the Western allies will have to take hard realities into account. The Muslims cannot recapture the havens. Neither the United States nor Europe will send in enough ground troops to force the Serbs out of lands they consider theirs. The Muslim state in Bosnia is essentially greater Sarajevo and its hinterland.
Although the legacy of Munich in 1938 is often invoked in discussing the Bosnian tragedy, the conflict is a civil war. A better analogy is the Indian subcontinent in 1947, where Muslims insisted they could insure their safety only through partition into a Muslim Pakistan and a predominantly Hindu India. They have not been good neighbors since then, but both countries still exist.
In effect, Bosnia has already been partitioned. The Bosnian Serbs now have their homeland, which they will likely confederate with Serbia. The Bosnian Croats have their slice, which they expect to link to Croatia. And the Bosnian Muslims have the core of the country around Sarajevo. The Muslim army is larger than that of the Bosnian Serbs and, if the West forced the Serbs out of mortar range of the city, should be able to defend itself.
Would this division constitute ethnic cleansing? Yes, in the European tradition that did not stop with World War II. In 1945, millions of Germans were expelled from Poland and Czechoslovakia. In 1974, Greeks and Turks fled to separate parts of Cyprus. Although the Bosnian Serbs have been extremely cruel and brutal, their primary objective has been to drive the Muslims from coveted territory. This cannot be condoned. But it is not equivalent to Nazi genocide.
A political settlement does not have to assume good will on the combatants' part but simply that they recognize reality. The Serbs have largely achieved their territorial goals. Now they must be made aware that they have reached their limit. The Muslims must realize that others will not retake for them the lands they have lost.
So far, the West has not developed a strategy for dealing with Bosnia but has reacted spasmodically to events. (A typical case was the apparent bombing of Pale on Monday, for which France denies responsibility despite American claims that it was carried out by French planes.) Yet the fall of the "safe havens" makes possible a settlement that all sides can live with. This would involve:
* Withdrawing refugees (along with the United Nations forces) from the enclaves and resettling them in Sarajevo and predominantly Muslim areas around it. This area, a little smaller than 50 percent of the old Bosnia-Herzegovina, is big enough for the fewer than two million Muslims.
* Returning the Bosnian Muslim army from distant outposts so that it can defend Sarajevo. NATO air power and the forces being assembled by the British and French should be used to help the Muslims end the shelling of the capital, open the airport and carve out new borders around the lands they hold.
* Recognizing that Bosnia must shrink to survive. Just as Yugoslavia could not endure as a multiethnic state, neither can a greater Bosnia. Cosmopolitan Sarajevo may deserve its reputation as a multiethnic haven, but the rest of Bosnia is not one.
Small countries can prosper if reconciled with their neighbors, and Sarajevo has a relatively well-educated population and has been a center of industry. The West should offer economic and humanitarian aid and induce Croatia, an ally of Sarajevo's, to offer the Bosnians an outlet to the sea.
* Avoiding manipulation. The Muslims must understand that NATO will not grind the Serbs into submission. The Muslims should have the means to defend themselves but not enough to reopen the war. If they mount an offensive, the West should pull out its forces, withdraw its guarantees and terminate economic aid.
Would the Muslims accept such a solution? Probably, because they depend almost totally on Western protection. Would the Bosnian Serbs recognize this smaller Sarajevo? No one can be sure, but they are dangerously overextended and would have no desire to face a serious Muslim offensive around Sarajevo backed by Western air power. Further, Belgrade wants to bring them under control in anticipation of renewed war with Croatia.
Why not avoid all these unknowns and simply lift the arms embargo, as is called for in legislation making its way through Congress? Because then Europeans would immediately pull out their forces, leaving many civilians without food or shelter. The Bosnian Serbs would almost certainly attack Sarajevo. And the pressure for United States intervention would not diminish, particularly if the Muslims continued to lose the war.
Through clandestine shipments, the Muslims already have most of the weapons they can absorb. More weapons are unlikely to turn the tide of battle but would cause more casualties and could lead to a war between Serbia and Croatia. In that event, Bosnia would be but a sideshow, eventually to be divided up between its two more powerful neighbors.
A brokered political settlement is not a perfect solution. But it offers more hope than any alternatives. And it recognizes that since the Bosnians, like the other Yugoslavs, cannot live together, they must live separately.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Court Will Decide Future of Smoking Suit
 In a victory for the tobacco industry, a Federal appeals court in New Orleans ruled that it would decide whether a giant class-action against the nation's seven largest tobacco companies could continue. 
 The court's final decision could determine the fate of Castano v. the American Tobacco Company et al., the largest class action in history. The suit accuses the tobacco companies of addicting smokers. [Page D3.]
 Two Congressmen have proposed a plan that they say could curtail teen-age smoking without Federal regulation of tobacco. [A16.]
 
Discovery Lifts Amgen Stock
 Researchers have discovered a hormone that makes animals lose body fat, and Amgen has paid Rockefeller University $20 million for a patent license. The news sent the company's stock up $4.375, to $84.25. [A1.]
 
Anheuser-Busch in Spinoff
 Anheuser-Busch said it would spin off Campbell Taggart, the nation's second-largest bakery. The company also said its second-quarter earnings rose 2 percent to $329.1 million, or $1.27 a share. [D5.]
 
Turnaround at Borland
 Borland reported a turnaround in its first fiscal quarter, as cost reductions and demand for its new Delphi software development tool brought the software maker its first operating profit in more than a year, even though net income fell 95 percent. Analysts expected a loss on operations. [D2.]
 
An Exemption for Murdoch
 The F.C.C. is expected on Friday to give Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation an exemption from its foreign ownership restrictions for the Fox network. [D9.]
 
Soros Hedge Funds Decline
 George Soros's Quantum Fund lost more than $200 million, or 6.2 percent of its value in the first six months of this year, and his Quantum Emerging Growth Fund lost 8.8 percent. [D2.]
 
Pollution Rules May Die
 The House of Representatives is preparing to vote on a measure forbidding enforcement of rules the E.P.A. is about to issue to curb toxic air pollution by the oil refining industry. [A18.]
 
Disney Earnings Rise 19%
 The Walt Disney Company said its fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 19 percent to $318.2 million, or 60 cents a share. [D9.]
 
Regulators Draft Bank Rules
 Federal banking regulators plan to review the risks to banks in the wake of the collapses of Barings P.L.C. and the Mexican economy. [D4.]
 
Mutual Fund Buying Soars
 Mutual fund investors put $7.9 billion into funds that invest primarily in American stocks in June, and the biggest chunk of that went into aggressive-growth equity funds. [D4.]
 
Being Mightier Than the Pen
 Montblanc wants to be known for more than its fancy pens, so it is starting an advertising campaign that will focus on its new stand-alone boutiques. The stores will offer European luxury leather accessories, including organizers, wallets, briefcases and garment bags, as well as jewelry like cuff links and tie bars. The campaign begins in October. Advertising. [D9.]
 
Viacom Avoids Taxes in Deal
 Just like Viacom's previous deal to sell its cable operations, the sale announced Tuesday enables Viacom to avoid capital-gains taxes. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]

HEADLINE: Dayton Economic Message Mixed, Like Nation's

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio

 BODY:
At the Voss Auto Network, which runs five dealerships in the Dayton area, cars are hardly moving. Things are not much better at the cavernous BHA Piano Center here, where a weak dollar has sharply raised the price of the Japanese and South Korean models that increasingly dominate the market. Sales of homes are below 1994 levels, and Roberds Furniture and Appliances, with a half-dozen stores in and around the city, has increased its advertising but has yet to reap any benefits.
Six months ago, the Dayton region was riding the crest of an industrial revival in the heartland that had driven down the unemployment rate to 3.6 percent. But now, in the city where the Wright brothers created airplanes in bicycle shops and where John and Frank Patterson built the cash register industry, there are discouraging, if inconsistent, signs of a downturn. 
 Is the slowdown an early warning signal or a minor market correction, as they say on Wall Street? In recent months, economists and policy makers have pondered that question for the country as a whole. And just as an answer has eluded the Federal Reserve, there is no clear explanation for the mixed message found in showrooms and on factory floors here.
As is the case in many parts of the country, the signs in the Dayton region do not all point downward. In the auto supply factories and the General Motors and Chrysler assembly plants in the region, the demand is up for industrial parts and for used cars. And even as the demand for new cars has fallen, there is a surge in orders for auto parts.
All of this has led many to say that last year's boom may be over but nothing as serious as a recession is in the offing. After all, executives are continuing to bet with their order books that consumers will be regaining their confidence.
Despite a buoyant job market, the weakest part of the economic picture here, as it is around the country, is consumer reluctance to buy cars and other big-ticket items that involve borrowed money. Since consumers account for two-thirds of economic activity, the Federal Reserve probably had the caution of shoppers in mind when it decided last month to cut interest rates for the first time since 1992.
A disquieting sign of the times here for big factory employers is that the hot-selling Chevy S-10 Blazer, a sports utility vehicle made only in neighboring Moraine and in Linden, N.J., has suddenly become available to customers without a wait, even as G.M. has added a third shift here to produce it.
Selling new cars is "like hand-to-hand combat" these days, said Steve Lace, general manager of the Voss Auto Network, which sells Chevrolet, Cadillac, Dodge, Honda and BMW, among others. Fierce competition has prompted auto makers to offer ever-higher rebates and other incentives, and Voss has absorbed the 20 percent jump in the cost of floor planning (what it pays to finance its inventory) that resulted from the Fed's raising the interest rate seven times since February 1994.
Bob Royer, president of the BHA Piano Center, a family-owned company he describes as the state's second largest of its type, said sales are off 8 percent so far this year while profits are down twice that much.
More recently, skittishness about the economy on the part of consumers has spread to some manufacturers in the region. Dayton's reliance on factories is relatively high, with slightly more than 20 percent of jobs here factory-related. Unlike the 1980's, in the last year or so that rate has kept pace with employment growth. But this is starting to slip.
"We're beginning to see the average workweek dropping a bit," said John Weiler, director of the Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Dayton. This indicates less factory overtime, one of the most sensitive gauges of business activity.
Nonetheless, company officials said what they were seeing was different from what they saw in the months leading to the 1990-91 recession.
"We're seeing strength in all our product lines," said Hugh Becker, a spokesman for Robbins & Myers Inc., a producer of pumps, industrial mixers and large glass-lined vessels for industries like chemical makers. Not only have revenues surged by about 15 percent in the current fiscal year but backlogs climbed to $98.7 million at the end of May, from $77.6 million last November.
At the Dayton Supply and Tool Company, which distributes cutting tools to the auto industry, Carl Woessner, the president, is basking in a 25 percent revenue surge this year and marveling at the lack of any indication the pace will slacken.
"We couldn't be busier," Mr. Woesnner said, adding that his 40-employee company normally is one of the first to feel a downturn. "I don't see anything right now," he said. "That's what's so surprising to me."
And at the Ratliff Metal Spinning Company -- which makes parts for light fixtures and food processing equipment -- business is up 15 percent through June and three employees have been added to bring the work force to 17. In fact, Ratliff said, orders for its products are at record levels.
Such bulging order books bode well for the Dayton economy, suggesting unemployment will remain low here -- the latest reading is 4.1 percent -- and incomes will rise enough to bring consumers back to stores and showrooms.
If Dayton proves typical, the Federal Reserve will then have largely succeeded in engineering the so-called soft landing of the economy it has sought. There could be one more cut in the interest rate in late summer as final insurance against anything more serious than a pause for consumers to catch their breath after a euphoric ride.
"I just don't see the signs that we're going to have a really big downturn," said John A. Allen, general manager of Harmon Cadillac/ Saab on North Main Street, where sales of used cars have been especially strong this year. "People have substantial amounts of money and it's just a question of whether they want to turn loose."

HEADLINE: For Better or Worse, A Marital Milestone;
Ithaca Officials Endorse a Gay Union

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y., July 20

 BODY:
On Valentine's Day, hoping to reverse a streak of poor romantic luck, Toshav Greene took a chance, called Phillip G. Storrs and invited him on a blind dinner date.
By the time they got to the strawberry cake, it was plain that Mr. Greene's luck had changed. The two men quickly fell in love. By mid-May, they had moved here together from nearby Elmira, hoping to marry and rear children. When they went to City Hall to apply for a marriage license, however, they expected a rejection. 
 Instead, much to their own surprise, they may get a license.
The Mayor and other leaders in this college town, home to Cornell University, have embraced the idea of granting a marriage license to a gay couple. They would be the first officials in the nation to do so deliberately in more than a dozen years.
Occasionally, a clerk may grant a license to a same-sex couple, particularly if the names are indeterminate. Pasha and Penny Rivers-McMahon received a license in Burlington, Vt., last August, but the clerk asked to get it back minutes later and has since refused to record the union of the two women.
Phillip and Toshav Storrs (Mr. Greene has changed his last name to that of his partner) may not hold on to their license very long, either. City clerks merely act as agents of the state in registering marriages, and Republican officials in Albany may object to such a license and try to quash it.
But that does not deter Mayor Benjamin Nichols, 74, a Democrat and 40-year veteran of the civil rights movement, who has met with the gay couple and said, "If they really want to go ahead with it, my position is that they should be granted a license."
The City Attorney expects to rule by the end of the summer on whether the Federal or State Constitutions would compel issuance without regard to a couple's sex. And on July 5, the all-Democratic Common Council unanimously endorsed the right of same-sex couples to marry.
National gay civil-rights advocates fear that a short-lived victory here could provoke judicial and legislative setbacks for their movement. Several organizations are in the paradoxical position of urging the couple to hold off.
Confessing a "totally divided heart," Paula Ettelbrick, legislative counsel of the Empire State Pride Agenda, said: "Part of me very much wants to say: 'Go for it. The question has been called.' But what would be gained if we won the right today and lost it tomorrow because we had not done the grass-roots lobbying that we needed to do?"
Evan Wolfson, senior staff attorney of the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, said, "If you go to a court that is uneducated or that is going to rule in a climate that's unreceptive, you're almost certainly going to get back a decision you didn't really want."
Mr. Wolfson is co-counsel to two lesbian couples and a gay couple who were denied licenses in Hawaii. The Hawaii Supreme Court ruled in 1993 that a denial appeared to violate the constitutional guarantee of equal protection. It sent the case back to a lower court for a trial that is to begin in July 1996. A license granted to a gay couple in Boulder, Colo., was invalidated by a Federal court in 1982, Mr. Wolfson said.
Since that time, weddings and commitment ceremonies have become a more common feature of gay life, as have the limited benefits offered by some governments and companies to domestic partners. But no lesbian or gay couple has won the considerable range of economic and legal rights that come with officially sanctioned marriage.
In the eyes of many people, that is as it should be. "Marriage is for men and women," said Arthur J. Golder, a lawyer in neighboring Trumansburg who has spoken out against issuing a license. "It's not about better health-insurance premiums or credit ratings or access to bridal registries."
"We're created as male and female for a reason," he said. "It's not to enjoy sex. It's to procreate. That's nature's mandate. And nature's mandate becomes man's law."
State officials may not put it quite that way, but no one expects them to look kindly on an attempt to certify a gay marriage.
Lawyers involved with the Ithaca case say they are watching to see whether Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco will nullify the license or prevent its issuance. His office would not comment. The Legislature might amend the domestic-relations law, which does not specify sex, to state explicitly that marriage can occur only between a woman and a man.
None of this has served to dissuade the Storrses.
"It could be potentially detrimental in the short term," Toshav Storrs allowed. "But it could be potentially fantastic. From the information we have, that's a 50-50 call. If it's right on the line, I opt to move forward."
And Phillip Storrs said it would be useful for the public to see that they were "just a couple of regular people." Mr. Storrs, 36, grew up in and around Troy, Pa. He works at the Toshiba television tube factory in Horseheads, N.Y.
Toshav Storrs, 34, grew up in rural Oklahoma and came here in 1979 as a freshman at Cornell. He dropped out of school but returned to Ithaca in the 1980's and met Daniel Chiarilli. They moved to Tulsa and reared two children. Mr. Chiarilli was killed in a car accident in 1991.
Mr. Storrs came back to central New York last year and enrolled at Elmira College. This fall, he plans to return to Cornell, in human development and family studies.
When they applied for their license, the Deputy City Clerk, William Kaupe, started filling out the form but the City Clerk, Julie Conley Holcomb, returned from lunch and halted the proceeding.
She cited the domestic-relations law but the couple challenged her to find any explicit prohibition of same-sex marriage. She could not. Ms. Holcomb directed them to City Attorney Charles J. Guttman.
He took their inquiry seriously, as did Mayor Nichols, whose background is steeped in leftist progressivism. "I started out the meeting saying I didn't know whether we could do it, but that I'd like to issue the license," Mayor Nichols said.
The Mayor's support turned their application from quixotic to conceivable. "He's the one who's made this engine run," Toshav Storrs said.
The legal issue, Mr. Guttman said, centers on whether denying a license to a couple of the same sex violates the constitutional guarantee of equal protection and the fundamental right to marry.
For Ms. Holcomb, the issue is whether she might be found guilty of a misdemeanor for issuing a license improperly or, were she to refuse to grant one, end up being dismissed for insubordination.
Phillip and Toshav Storrs did not wait for the government. They exchanged vows in a private ceremony and then, on June 22, at a more public gathering. Rabbi David Castiglione presided at both.
If they get their license, a third wedding is in store. Toshav Storrs's sister, Cindy Williams, could not travel from Tulsa for the June 22 event. "She's hoping to make it to the next one," her brother said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mayor Benjamin Nichols of Ithaca, center, has given his blessing to the Storrses -- Toshav, left, and Phillip G. -- to marry. But the couple, who announced their union in The Ithaca Journal, will also need the state's. (Linda Rosier/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cost of 'Quiet on Set' Is Escalating

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 26

 BODY:
In his seven years as a location manager in the film industry, Patrick McIntire has rented noisy chain saws just so he could turn them off and paid lawn crews to stop clacking their shears and revving their leaf-blowers. Loud radios, barking dogs and immovable people have cost him a bundle.
Mr. McIntire is not alone. In Los Angeles and other California areas popular for filming, residents are sometimes making thousands of dollars from movie crews by promising to vacate outdoor sets, tone down noise or otherwise stop harassing them. The problem has become so acute that the State Legislature has stepped in, drafting laws to make harassing film crews for profit a criminal offense. 
 "It's gotten to the point where at almost every shoot, somebody has their hand out," said State Senator Herschel Rosenthal, Democrat of Van Nuys, the sponsor of one such bill. "People blow horns, walk through shots, make their dogs bark or crank their stereos. And they all demand money to stop."
A survey of 113 people in film production conducted by the California Film Commission in January found that half had been harassed by opportunists jockeying for money. One production manager said he had paid a man in Culver City to stop pelting his crew with pebbles and debris.
"The individual was compensated for the disruption," the manager wrote, adding that "after filming was in process, he decided the compensation was not enough and decided to throw empty cans."
Sometimes, hecklers wind up in jail when film production people decide to take the time to press charges under public nuisance laws. But enlisting law enforcement does not always stop the harassment. One production manager said he had called the police after a store owner in Venice Beach turned on a "boom box" during filming. After the police ordered the offender to tone down the music, the respondent wrote, "the owner still would not comply, instead calling his lawyer, who arrived with threats." The company, he said, finally gave up and moved.
Patti S. Archuletta, director of the film commission, which promotes shooting movies in California, said: "Warner Brothers called me saying they were held up for $500 by a guy wielding a ladle and a bucket, and a whole neighborhood tried to charge another group $500 just to let a film truck drive down the street. This has really gotten out of hand."
Though no one believes such penny-ante ploys will bankrupt the state's film industry -- a $17 billion-a-year business that employs more than 350,000 people -- some companies now routinely look for film locations outside of California to avoid harassment, Ms. Archuletta said. Others have moved their entire operations out of the state to get away from it, she said.
"This kind of institutional extortion is very bad for California," she said, "particularly Southern California. We have come to a point where people think it's business as usual to stand in front of a production and make life difficult. It's bad for the economy. It has to stop."
Film companies in New York City have not gone unscathed. City officials say that a man who claimed to be running a film school for disadvantaged youth tried to extort money from so many productions, including those of Woody Allen and Spike Lee, that the city was seeking a permanent court order to keep him off movie locations.
In California, two separate bills in the Legislature are aimed at halting the practice. One would make the offense a civil infraction, the other a criminal infraction, but both would carry fines. The bills, with separate sponsors, are now in committee. One is sponsored by Senator Rosenthal and the other by Assemblyman Jim Brulte, Republican of Rancho Cucamonga.
The bills would allow off-duty officers and licensed security guards to ticket offenders after one warning. Both bills would impose fines of up to $100 for the first offense and up to $500 for each later infraction.
Though the bills have strong bipartisan support, residents of popular filming locations and some union representatives have expressed concern that such a law could be used by film companies to muzzle the outspoken.
"I have seen horn honking, and I have seen residents shine lights at the set," said Robert G. Picard, chairman of the Department of Communications at California State University at Fullerton, and a resident of a popular filming area. "But a lot of this is not extortion; it's anger.
"You see some production crews who are very arrogant, and they just say: 'Get out of our way. We're bulldozing through, blockading your street and trampling your bushes.' And that's just not right. If this law is written over-broadly, it could make reasonable requests for compensation a criminal offense."
Ms. Archuletta said that the proposed language for both bills would protect the rights of unions to picket film companies and would allow residents to voice complaints about unruly productions to the commission.
"If you don't seek money, you can't be cited," she said. "This is not going to stop disgruntled people from being noisy. It's going to stop people from holding hostage an industry they perceive to be a cash cow."
She added that the law, which would allow officers to ticket extortionists immediately, could save productions thousands of dollars by reducing unnecessary delays. "Time is money in this business," she said. "As it stands, companies face hours of delay waiting for police to arrive and drag someone off to jail."
Mr. McIntire recalled the man in downtown Los Angeles with the sputtering chain saw, which he offered to the film crew for $5,000. The man, who was more than a block away, enlisted the help of lookouts on the street, Mr. McIntire said, and would open the throttle full bore every time the director yelled, "Action." The saw would miraculously go quiet at every shout of "Cut!"
When the chain-saw operator was given a package containing several hundred dollars, Mr. McIntire said, the saw fell silent.
"I don't mind forking over some cash if we are creating an inconvenience for people," Mr. McIntire said. "But a lot of this is just blackmail and bribery, and right now movie companies can't do anything but open their wallets."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Film industry officials are paying more to shoot on location in California, as residents are sometimes making thousands of dollars by promising to vacate outdoor sets, reduce noise or stop harassing them. Two strollers who were just curious, Javier Amezquita and his son, Gabriel, watched the filming of the movie "One More Shot" two weeks ago in their Van Nuys neighborhood of Los Angeles. (Jan Sonnenmair for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Crunching Numbers So the Bills Add Up

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 24

 BODY:
By his own estimate, Alan R. Kooney's line of work doesn't strike sparks at social gatherings.
"I tell people what I do and watch their eyes glaze over," he said. 
 Unless, of course, the listener happens to be one of the army of lobbyists wise to the back corridors of power in Trenton. Their eyes gleam when Mr. Kooney speaks, because they understand his vital role in helping frame the way New Jersey will spend $16 billion in the next fiscal year.
Mr. Kooney is the chief budget and fiscal officer in the Office of Legislative Services, the staff of nonpartisan experts who quietly run the nuts-and-bolts machinery of legislative government and try to stay out of the spotlight.
That is not always possible. When Mr. Kooney's team of fiscal analysts concluded last March that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed budget contained exaggerated revenue projections, State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer strongly hinted that the analysis was slanted to play into the hands of those who opposed the Governor's income tax cut program.
"When the State Treasurer comes out and says our figures are dead wrong, things can get hot around here," said Albert Porroni, executive director of Office of Legislative Services and its chief legislative counsel. "But our ability to provide the best information available to the Legislature in a fair and nonpartisan way is the backbone of our work, even when that information may conflict with the goals of the party in power."
Legislators and their aides, past and present on both sides of the aisle, said the office walks the straight and narrow when it comes to partisanship.
"I can't remember a single episode of political favoritism shown by an O.L.S. staffer," said Brad Brewster, a lawyer and lobbyist who once worked as a committee aide in the Legislature and as staff director of Assembly Republicans. "They do a great job of instilling the idea of nonpartisanship and sticking to it."
Handling a mind-boggling variety of responsibilities, most of the office's 330 employees are quartered in the State House Annex, a squat granite pile next door to the domed Capitol. The annex was built in two stages, with the result that its electrical systems don't match, much like the politics played out in the building's high-ceilinged committee rooms.
Here the staff is available to lawmakers for one-stop shopping to get quick expert advice on legal, financial and procedural matters that may be unavailable from their own staff members, who are generally hired more for their skill in politics than their policy expertise.
The most influential jobs of the Office of Legislative Services are done by its career staff of 83 lawyers, fiscal analysts and a smattering of Ph.D.'s who run committees in both houses.
They schedule hearings, research and draft bills, and are called upon to perform a wide range of support activities.
"Part of my job is being so well versed in every bill on the agenda that when hard questions come up in debate, I'm the one everyone turns to for answers," said Kevil Duhon, a 35-year-old lawyer who serves as staff aide on the Senate Natural Resources, Trade and Economic Development Committee.
Other things the staff does include writing nonpartisan speeches for lawmakers on complex or esoteric subjects.
Other staff members also run the bill room in the State House, which provides the press and public with updated versions of legislative bills, and they run a computer service to 120 legislative offices around the state and 500 locations in the capital that lists legislative schedules, committee hearings and bill status reports.
Even as legislators and their partisan aides come and go, the professional staff stays in place, providing experience and institutional memory when more power is devolving to the states from Washington.
It wasn't always this way.
The office was created in 1979 to combine fiscal and research functions for the Legislature that were largely ignored in the past. Before the court-ordered "one person one vote" redistricting in the 1970's, which took control away from county political bosses, legislators labored in the shadow of a powerful executive branch.
"Bills were created by the governor, written into law by the governor, and the legislators all scrambled for a piece of the pie," recalled Mr. Porroni, a 24-year veteran of government service.
When legislators did propose bills, they were written by lawyers hired for the occasion or by lobbyists representing special interests. Substantive issues were debated in caucus, and bills were passed behind closed doors according to agendas set by party leaders.
Redistricting changed all that, by sweeping more independent-minded legislators into power who soon clamored for equality with the executive branch. The Assembly and Senate adopted a committee system staffed with professional aides who could match the expertise of bureaucrats in departments that reported to the governor.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean recalls that as a legislative leader in the 1970's, he urged a reluctant Gov. William Cahill to sign a bill creating an independent fiscal study group for the Legislature. "I don't think future governors will thank me for this," Mr. Kean remembers the Governor saying before signing the measure.
"When I became Governor and was fighting with the budget analysts over in the Legislature, I thought a lot about those words," Mr. Kean said jokingly in an interview recently.
In the view of Steven P. Perskie, a former Democratic majority leader in the Senate, the Legislature rapidly went from having "the barest skeleton staff" to having one of the best in the country.
In 1986, the Office of Legislative Services underwent further reorganization to consolidate the committee staffs. "We formed 10 teams according to subject areas like judiciary and environment, each team headed by a section chief," said Glen E. Moore 3d, director of the office's central management unit, a native Kentuckian with a taste for mints and wry humor.
Section chiefs, he continued, are seasoned masters of dealing with legislators who can turn snappish under great pressures to produce immediate solutions to a problem. "Meeting that demand in a professional manner becomes tricky, because there are a lot of alligators in the Legislature," he said. "Section chiefs can tell which are the rocks and which are the alligators."
Expertise is demanded of staffers, but so is a willingness to suppress egos and hold confidences, Mr. Moore said. "We look for personable people who are very interested in politics but have no political ambitions. People who won't push for passage of a bill just because they had worked on it for two months."
Lawyers and academics head the list of those who apply for staff jobs, which begin at $35,000 and top off at $70,000 after 20 years. By comparison, legislators are paid $35,000 a year and each has a total of $70,000 a year to spend on staff aides. Women fill about half of the staff openings, including four section chief slots, though the number of racial minorities is low: four are black, two are Hispanic and one is Asian.
Since confidentiality is part of the staff's requirements, stories about the shortcomings of legislators who arrive green and unprepared for a demanding job are not easily shared with outsiders.
Mr. Moore, who can't help laughing when he mentions episodes of what he calls "the legislative follies," does tell about a former legislator who once asked a staffer to write a bill requiring the construction of fishing platforms on all bridges in the state. "He was advised it would save the state money if the fishing platforms were limited to only those bridges crossing a body of water," Mr. Moore recalled, his blue eyes dancing.
"But many members are three steps ahead of us," he quickly pointed out, lest anyone think the chambers were filled with dunderheads.
Work on the budget represents six months of number-crunching by Mr. Kooney and analysts he borrows from section teams until the June 30 deadline for passage.
"In January, when the Governor proposes a budget, everything is lover-ly," Mr. Porroni beamed as he fluttered his hands and pirouetted on his office floor to portray a couple representing the Executive branch and the Legislature dancing in harmony.
"Then comes our budget analysis and party meetings," he says, his hands fluttering to a stop as the first sour notes are heard. "Then, on the eve of passage, all the budget is shoved at us and we have to put together a bill that has to be perfect." He drops his hands to his side in feigned exhaustion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I tell people what I do and watch their eyes glaze over," said Alan R. Kooney, chief budget and fiscal officer in New Jersey's Office of Legislative Services, which runs the nuts-and-bolts machinery of government. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Woman Is Charged in Beating Death of Her Daughter, 3

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
A mother who lived with her husband and four young daughters in a cramped, subdivided Brooklyn apartment was charged with murder yesterday in the beating death of one of the children, a 3-year-old girl named Gabriella, who the police said bore the bruises of continual abuse.
The parents, Sara Munoz and Gilberto Vasquez, were illegal immigrants who came from Mexico several years ago, the police said. They found their way to Sunset Park, where many poor immigrant families live in illegally divided apartments and work in local factories and sweatshops. 
 Shortly after 7 A.M. yesterday, Mr. Vasquez, 25, took Gabriella to Lutheran Medical Center, saying he had found her unconscious, said Doram Tamari, a police spokesman. The girl died a while later, and hospital officials, whose suspicions had been aroused by the infant's heavily bruised body, alerted the police of possible child abuse.
After several hours of interrogation, Ms. Munoz, 25, was charged with second-degree murder. Mr. Vasquez was charged with endangering the welfare of a child, the police said, because Gabriella had been abused for some time and he had known about it.
The couple's three other daughters -- ages 6, 5 and 6 months -- were examined by doctors who found no evidence of abuse. They were placed in the custody of the city's Child Welfare Administration.
It was not clear last night why Gabriella was fatally battered or how long the abuse had continued. Nor could the police say why Gabriella had been singled out, and why her three sisters had been left physically unharmed.
"Who knows?" said Detective Jose Caban, one of the investigators who worked on the case at the 72d Precinct. "Sometimes one child is a little overactive. They lived in a very small apartment, and it was hot. So who knows?"
At the station house, the couple were "very somber," the detective said, adding, "They were just very, very quiet, looking down, not saying much."
The couple's journey to Sunset Park began five years ago when the father left Mexico and illegally entered the country, the police said. His common-law wife joined him two years later.
At some point, they gravitated to Sunset Park, which in recent years has seen an influx of legal and illegal immigrants from Ecuador, the Dominican Republic and Mexico. The couple settled in the neighborhood's southern section, a block east of the Gowanus Expressway, where most of the Hispanic immigrants are concentrated -- unlike the area's other large group of newcomers, the Chinese, who live further east along Eighth Avenue.
Neighbors said the family occupied one bedroom inside a three-bedroom apartment where another family -- a couple with one child -- also lived. The two families shared a living room and bathroom. The four-floor walk-up building, at 6005 Fourth Avenue, had apparently been separated into smaller units, the police said.
"Almost every day, new people come to live here," said Gloria Flores, who lives on the fourth floor and who said the couple had lived in the building for only a short time.
Theirs was a noisy avenue. A bit further north, several X-rated businesses opened in the last three years, and closer to their apartment, drug sales are common and out in the open. And in the backyard of the couple's building, neighbors said, a body was found a few months ago, apparently tossed off the roof.
Like many of the area's newcomers, Detective Caban said, Mr. Vasquez found sporadic work in the factories and sweat shops that dot the neighborhood's west end, near the waterfront. But a neighbor on the same floor, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Vasquez, who used to work 12-hour days, had been unemployed recently.
The couple blended into the neighborhood, and even after the several years they had spent in the city, they had learned little English. And even though the authorities believe Gabriella had been abused for some time, there had been no reports to Child Welfare, Detective Caban said.
In fact, he added, there were no official records at all of the couple's existence here.
But Ms. Flores, who lives directly above the couple, said she called Child Welfare a few months ago when she heard screaming from below.
"At night, I would look out the window, and I heard the kids screaming in the apartment," she said. "I thought something was wrong, but I didn't think things would end this way."
She said the mother took the daughters to a nearby day camp at a public school every morning. "The kids were skinny and always dirty, but the baby was healthy," she said.
But the neighbor who did not want to be identified said the mother had tried to make the best of things, staying at home with the children.
"The daughters are my daughter's friends," he said, as he stoodwith his 10-year-old girl. The mother "came here and had coffee several times," he said. "She was a very nice lady. We came from the same state in Mexico -- Puebla."
His 10-year-old daughter said she had been puzzled by Gabriella's demeanor on Tuesday. "She looked sad," she recalled. "I asked her why, and she didn't want to tell me why."

HEADLINE: Experts Offer a Wish List to Improve Transportation on the East Side

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A team of transportation experts studying ways to relieve overcrowding on streets and subways on the East Side of Manhattan presented more than two dozen possibilities at a public hearing yesterday, from completing the abandoned Second Avenue subway line to starting a ferry line along the East River.
While it will be more than a year before the study is completed and as long as 10 years before work would begin on the most ambitious of the plans, the officials presented the options to an audience of about 70 people yesterday as a kind of grand wish list, from which a few of the best ideas would be chosen during the next six months. 
 The $5.4 million Federal study was started in January to come up with a long-range plan for the East Side, whose subways, bus lines and roadways are among the city's most heavily used. City planners have warned that the crush of subway and bus riders, cars and trucks is far outpacing the area's capacity, and that the congestion will eventually hurt the economy and the environment.
"This is without a doubt one of the busiest transportation corridors in the country," said James W. Dubbs, an assistant director of government and community relations for the New York City Transit Authority.
On an average weekday, according to the authority's statistics, 72,000 Lexington Avenue subway riders, 22,000 bus passengers, 35,000 Metro-North passengers and 50,000 cars and trucks enter the East Side business district during the morning rush.
The study, which will be used by state officials to decide where to use Federal transportation money, has also been spurred on because of a need to determine the fate of the Second Avenue subway line.
Three sections of the line -- a total of about a mile of a planned 14-mile route -- were built in the early 1970's before work was halted because of the city's fiscal crisis. The state tried unsuccessfully to revive plans for the line in 1991, and the tunnels, in East Harlem and Chinatown, now sit dormant.
"I think this study really emanated from the question, 'Should we complete the Second Avenue subway line?' " said Peter Allibone of Vollmer Associates, a consulting company working on the study.
The plans being looked at now include completing the 1974 design for the Second Avenue subway by linking the tunnels and creating a line that would run from the southern tip of Manhattan to East 125th Street and would connect to another line running into the South Bronx.
But officials admitted that the enormous cost of creating a completely new subway line makes that solution unlikely. It cost about $65 million to dig the existing sections of tunnel 25 years ago. Because of crosstown lines that bisect the area, new tunnels would have to be dug beneath them, at a cost of hundreds of millions.
Norman Silverman, a planner for the transit authority, said that building the full Second Avenue line is on the "outer bounds" of possibility.
"But we've taken special care not to remove any of the options at this point," he said. "It's difficult to say exactly what will happen in July 1997 when this is finished."
Other plans being looked at range from simple, inexpensive measures -- such as adding trains to the Lexington Avenue line and coordinating signals to move them more swiftly -- to reviving an idea to create a "busway, " a plan first discussed when the Second Avenue subway line was shelved.
The plan calls for building a concrete barrier down part of First Avenue or Second Avenue to reserve lanes exclusively for buses. The buses would run more frequently than those on the line that now serves the area, the M15, which is among the most crowded in the country.
Officials also discussed ideas for creating new elevated lines and for building trolley cars or light rail lines that would run on the street. Another idea was a ferry line that would stop at existing piers and connect with shuttle bus service from docks to points west.
The study will move to its next stage in late November or early December, when officials will decide on what they believe to be the best plans. A final set of recommendations will be presented to the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council, which helps allocate Federal transportation money, in mid-1997.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Surge After a Report Of Declining U.S. Inventories

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Oil prices jumped yesterday after a report showed an unexpected sharp drop in domestic inventories of crude oil and a fall in supplies of heating oil.
On other commodity markets, coffee prices rose sharply. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities rose 1.38 points, to 235.28. 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for September deliver rose 57 cents, to $17.50 a barrel. August heating oil rose 1.53 cents, to 48.04 cents a gallon, and August gasoline was up 0.52 cent, to 52.89 cents a gallon.
"It's the most significant price action we've seen for some time," said Michael Hiley, an analyst with Smith Barney.
The rally came after the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude oil stocks dropped 7.25 million barrels last week and now stood nearly 22 million barrels lower than in the corresponding period a year ago. The report was released after the market closed on Tuesday.
"This may be the catalyst to start what is not an untypical modest seasonal rally in the third quarter," said William Brown of W. H. Brown & Company.
Crude prices fell 16 percent from May 1 through last Friday, as the market overcame concerns about possible gasoline shortages and increases in oil production in the North Sea.
At the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, coffee traders began buying after a group of coffee exporters reached consensus on a plan to prop up prices.
At a meeting in New York, African and Asian coffee-growing nations joined with Latin American nations to withhold coffee from the market in an effort to reduce supplies and force consuming nations to deplete stocks.
September coffee rose 4.95 cents, to $1.523 a pound.
The Association of Coffee Producing Countries, representing nations that grow 80 percent of the world's coffee, said after emergency talks late Tuesday that it planned to limit exports to 60 million 132-pound bags over the next 12 months. Including production from countries that are not members of the association, world exports would reach 69 million bags; current demand is estimated at 71 million bags.
The move would cut exports by about 9 percent from previously expected levels.
