HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: 'A Wall in the Mind';
Rising Resentment in the East Divides Germany

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: BERNAU, Germany

 BODY:
The concrete-block factory sits abandoned on the outskirts of this eastern German town. Inside, one of the most modern machines for making circuit boards for computers and televisions lies idle.
The company that owned the plant was sold by the Government to a subsidiary of Veba A.G., a utility giant in western Germany. Veba already controlled two companies in the west making similar products, and it closed the plant here, saying it was losing money. The circuit-board machine is now for sale to anyone who will take it out of Germany, so that it does not compete with Veba. 
 Many of the Bernau plant's managers, whose hopes had once soared with the arrival of western German business muscle and know-how, have long since become disillusioned. "Whenever a western German firm has to choose between jobs in western Germany or eastern Germany, it will always choose the west," said Edmund Luhrmann, a former senior manager of the eastern German company, Elektrolaminate.
Almost five years after German reunification, the situation here speaks to the frustrations of many eastern German entrepreneurs and managers who believed the claims of western German politicians that their industries would flourish within five years.
Some, like Mr. Luhrmann, accuse western German companies of buying up potential eastern German competitors in order to close them down. Veba denies that accusation. Others say that shrewd western German businessmen negotiated enormous tax breaks by buying in the east, then closed down shop and ran when those breaks were used up. Others complain that western German retailing chains refused to put eastern German products on their shelves not only in the west but also in the east, where they were once the dominant brands. And still others, who bought small businesses from the Government, say that western German banks have denied them loans, making it difficult for them to expand and compete.
"We feel intentionally betrayed by the west, with very little strength to respond," said Karl-Heinz Herms, a former manager of an eastern German steel fabricating plant in Eisenhuttenstadt and now a struggling entrepreneur. "They told us we were all brothers and sisters, that we would work together. And we believed them. Now, they control our industry. They decide what to keep open and what to shut down. They threaten to put us out of work. And what is our option? We have to be like them, or we don't survive."
Some in eastern Germany even call it the colonization of their economy by the powerful west.
Many in western Germany are aghast at such declarations, calling them the height of ingratitude. They say they have poured more than $660 billion into rebuilding eastern Germany, and will continue such payments for years. Eastern Germans are reaping enormous state subsidies for pensions, medical care and education. They can now afford to drive new Opels and Volkswagens instead of the symbol of the broken socialist economy, the Trabant. And the eastern German economy is the envy of the countries of the former East bloc, with growth this year expected to match last year's 9 percent.
And some of the complaining in the east can indeed be attributed to confronting a bitter reality. Over the last five years, one of the biggest industrial shakeouts of modern times has occurred, forcing a painful adjustment in a region that was protected from outside competition for decades. Vast eastern German chemical, steel and automotive plants were closed, causing the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs.
The western Germans, responding to their accusers, say they are only following sound business practices in eastern Germany. For example, bankers say they have to be cautious about lending because so many eastern German companies fail.
Even so, some business and political leaders in western Germany acknowledge that there have been abuses. Kurt Kasch, the head of Deutsche Bank A.G.'s Berlin office, said easterners' lack of familiarity with western-style auditing, marketing and other business practices had left them open to exploitation. 'It's true and it's nasty," he said. "But it happened."
Among the complaints from those doing business in eastern Germany are that western German companies have bought and shut down potential competitors, sometimes taking big tax write-offs or draining the acquired company of its assets.
In Communist times, for example, Schiffswerft Oderberg G.m.b.H., now dormant, was a thriving ship-door maker with 400 employees. The company, in Oderberg, was among the few eastern German companies able to compete in the international shipbuilding business.
After reunification, it was sold to a Bremen shipping entrepreneur, Hans Biedemeier. But Mr. Biedemeier died early last year and state officials discovered he had drained Oderberg of $12 million in state financial aid and operating revenues and concealed the funds in his Bremen holdings, leaving the Oderberg operation without enough funds to pay its workers.
What is more, it will be very hard now to rescue such a failing business, said Susanne Muller, a lawyer in charge of the liquidation of the shipyard. "There is no bank that would lend to an eastern German manager enough money to do such a transaction," she said.
Another complaint is that western German companies are keeping eastern German products off their shelves. For example, an American entrepreneur, Ray Learsy, made a major investment two years ago to modernize Berlin Cosmetics, once the biggest cosmetics company in the East bloc. But he has barely been able to crack the German retail distribution system.
Mr. Learsy, who sold his New York commodities-trading business in the 1980's, took over Berlin Cosmetics after the German privatization agency had all but dismantled the work force, reducing it to 95 from 8,500, and replaced its machinery with new stainless-steel equipment.
But though his company's lipsticks, shampoos, facial creams and other products were once sought-after treasures throughout Eastern Europe, Mr. Learsy found he could no longer sell them in eastern Germany. Western German retailing chains had bought up all the outlets and declined to stock them with eastern German goods. With the cosmetics market saturated with western-made goods, they contended there was no need to add goods that they considered second-rate to their displays.
Mr. Learsy also found bank credit hard to come by. Lacking money to pay for advertising, he concentrated on selling in the former Soviet Union. He said it took him months to get an appointment to show his products to a middle-level manager of a western German retailer, only to be asked "why eastern Germans would want to buy an eastern German product while they had western Germany products now available."
After almost a year, he went public with his frustrations, giving interviews to the local press. Now he says he sees growing hope, and the company's Koivo products can be found in almost all of eastern Germany and are slowing appearing in the west.
"Basically eastern German products are restricted to eastern Germany," Mr. Learsy said. "The western German chains have the distribution power and they can lock you out of the market if they want. But eastern German customers are forcing them to act otherwise."
Klaus Kropelin, a senior official of the Chamber of Commerce in the eastern German town of Frankfurt an der Oder who advises small-business owners in his region on adapting to the free-market economy, said it was unfair for western Germans to look down on eastern Germans. "Don't think that the western system cannot be improved," Mr. Kropelin said.
Sometimes, the tales of misfortune in eastern Germany have had a happy ending. Mr. Luhrmann and some of his co-workers, for example, found a new investor for Bernau. Ziegelwerk Werbellinsee, a Bavarian brick company, is building a factory in the town, right next to the closed factory.
But such stories do little to soften the bitterness among many eastern Germans. In a society reeling from 40 percent unemployment, many of them yearn for the guaranteed housing and jobs they enjoyed under the Communists.
A recent poll by the magazine Der Spiegel disclosed the mixed emotions of the easterners. A majority of those surveyed thought social conditions were better under the Communists than today, and described the transition to capitalism as worse than they expected. But a majority also believed the free market offered them a better chance to improve their living standards.
An overwhelming 67 percent said they thought a psychological wall -- "a wall in the mind" -- was growing between east and west.
"The Ossi must always prove to the Wessi manager that he is not just an Ossi," said Mr. Luhrmann, the former senior manager at the Bernau factory, using the two vernacular terms for eastern and western Germans. "The Ossi always thinks that he has a stable smell."

HEADLINE: Municipal Bond Regulation Debated at House Hearing

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the financial debacle in Orange County, Calif., Congress began asking today whether greater financial disclosure was needed in the municipal bond market to prevent similar catastrophes.
At a hearing before a House Banking subcommittee, no consensus emerged, even though spokesmen for both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the nation's two top credit-rating agencies testified that they had investigated Orange County's investment practices late last year and -- based on public information at that time -- found nothing amiss. 
 Testifying before the committee, which is headed by Representative Richard H. Baker, a Louisiana Republican, top officials from California and Orange County said that while additional financial disclosure would have been helpful, it might not have prevented the $1.9 billion losses caused by a highly risky investment strategy that went awry, leading to the county's bankruptcy filing.
Municipal securities are not subject to the same financial disclosure requirements as corporate securities. Municipal issuers are not regulated by the S.E.C. and they do not have to file the same annual and quarterly financial reports as corporations. In the last year, the S.E.C. imposed new disclosure regulations on municipal bond dealers, but not on issuers. Today's hearings focused on whether this was sufficient to inform investors of municipalities' risky investment practices.
Representative Christopher Cox, a Republican whose district includes Orange County, said it was not. "Municipal securities have been exempt from disclosure rules that apply to virtually everyone else," Mr. Cox said. "We are now reaping the whirlwind from the unjustified distinction. Municipal disclosure rules are virtually free form."
William J. Popejoy, the departing Orange County chief executive, also said that municipal market disclosure was insufficient. "The municipal market is based on trust," he said. "It's almost like a gentleman's club. A corporation would not be allowed to issue casino bonds like Orange County did."
He was referring to $600 million in taxable notes that Orange County issued to bet on the direction of interest rates.
But Paul S. Maco, director of the S.E.C.'s Office of Municipal Securities, dismissed the need for further disclosure, saying that a combination of the antifraud provisions of existing Federal securities laws and new market disclosure initiatives from the S.E.C. were sufficient.
In some of the day's most arresting testimony, Mr. Maco outlined a meeting between S.E.C. officers and the former Orange County Treasurer, Robert L. Citron, and his staff in the months before Mr. Citron's investment fund collapsed.
"The S.E.C. had read articles about Citron's risky strategy," Mr. Maco said. On May 2, 1994, seven months before the Orange County's investment losses forced it to file for bankruptcy, S.E.C. officials in Los Angeles met with Mr. Citron and his staff. "The county represented to us that the pool was in fixed-rate instruments," he said. "They showed us a list saying that there were no risky securities in the investment pool. They said the pool was within state law and that their actions were exempt from S.E.C. regulations."
"Absent any indication of fraud, we cannot act, nor question the investment strategy of a local government," Mr. Maco added. Asked later whether the S.E.C. was "lied to," Mr. Maco declined comment, citing an S.E.C. investigation into the matter.
Mr. Maco added that the S.E.C. believed that "matters of investment strategy and what is permissible is the responsibility of the state and local governments. It is not something for which there is an appropriate Federal role."
Top executives of the nation's leading rating agencies -- both of which had given Orange County top investment grades -- explained their analysis of the county.
"We relied on the county's disclosures," said Daniel Heimowitz, head of municipal securities at Moody's Investors Service, which is owned by Dun & Bradstreet. "We're not auditors. Between the time public attention was drawn to the investment pool and the bankruptcy filing, we rated Orange County bonds eight times. Each one of those issues was secured by the county's general resources and not the investment pool."
Mr. Heimowitz said that based on Orange County's "wealth, low debt and good management," along with a large position of liquid reserves in the investment pool, "we felt that nothing was out of the ordinary."
Richard Larkin, head of the municipal finance section of the Standard & Poor's Ratings Group, a unit of McGraw-Hill, said, "We had lots of information from the county that the investment pool had $1 billion in liquid marketable securities and that the investors in the pool did not need their money immediately and could ride out any fluctuation in interest rates."
When pressed as to why his rating agency gave a high rating to the $600 million taxable note -- the so-called casino bond -- Mr. Larkin responded that his agency felt comfortable because it was not only the investment pool's earnings that backed the bond but also Orange County's general obligation to repay its debts. Mr. Larkin said that from May to September 1994, his agency had "several" meetings with Orange County officials to discuss their investment strategy and felt that investors in those bonds had sufficient credit protections.

(Karin Anderson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Securities Prices Fall; Traders Focus On New Issues

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as traders focused on the supply of new issues poised to come to market over the next month.
Later the losses deepened as investors pondered conflicting reports over comments made by a Fed official and moved to the sidelines ahead of the durable goods report due today. A rise in oil prices also kept the pressure on bond prices. 
 The market will get a glimpse of the labor market today when the weekly jobless claims report is released. Reports are also due on factory orders and durable goods, and tomorrow the preliminary second-quarter G.D.P. is due.
Analysts note that the market had closed higher on Monday and Tuesday, reversing much of last week's deterioration.
A Japanese newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, quoted a Fed governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, on Tuesday as having said the central bank had room to cut interest rates further. Yesterday the Fed called the report a fabrication.
The Treasury's long bond dropped 24/32 , to a price of 10913/32 yesterday for a yield of 6.88 percent, up from 6.82 percent on Tuesday, with the short-maturity bills mixed.
Market analysts said the day's lows were extended mostly on concern over the coming heavy supply of new issues. Corporate issuance is up because of the low rates.
Traders had not expected yesterday's five-year note auction to be much of a problem, and it turned out to be slightly better than expected. Retail interest, however, was disappointing, but some analysts said that has been typical of recent five-year auctions.
At auction the notes were awarded at a high yield of 6.219 percent, up from 5.905 percent last month and the highest since May 24, when the yield was 6.25 percent.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said that the current market showed a lack of conviction, whereas three weeks ago it did not. "And to me that signals that it's probably wise to at least play this market from the cautious side of the table," he said.
"I think the basic economic information shows we are out of danger from falling into a recession," Mr. Donne said, "but that doesn't necessarily mean we will see explosive growth or even strong growth. But growth nonetheless."
He said the need for the Fed to ease had dimished considerably, and so the timing and magnitude of future Fed moves was increasingly doubtful and the market was reflecting that.
The market extended its losses in the afternoon following the note auction. Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, said: "What we think happened was that dealers tried to push the market price higher after the auction but were unable to induce follow-through buying on the part of retail. And with that being the case, it was time to reverse the field and probe for a price where retail did have an interest. I believe that interest was achieved at the 6.25 percent level."
Mr. Davis cited two other possible reasons for the market's slide. One was a rumor that many of Boeing's plane sales in June would make it into the durable goods data, so that the consensus of five-tenths of 1 percent could jump as high as 3 percent if the orders were included. The second item is that a report released by the American Petroleum Institute yesterday showed low stocks of oil and gas. "A signal," Mr. Davis said, "that the heavy driving season is upon us; consumers are on the road, and since they are on the road they are likely spending money."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
MINNESOTA MINING & MFG. CO. (MMM,N)

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, also known as 3M, said yesterday that its earnings rose slightly in the second quarter, but the results were below analysts' forecasts; 3M's share price fell $3.50, to $56, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company, based in Maplewood, Minn., reported a 2.9 percent rise in earnings to $353 million, or 84 cents a share, from $343 million, or 81 cents a share, for the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue climbed 9.8 percent, to $4.14 billion, from $3.77 billion last year. 
 The company's chairman and chief executive, L. D. DeSimone, said earnings showed strong growth internationally. The company does more than half its business abroad.
"However, economic softening slowed U.S. volume growth, which held back our overall profit gain," Mr. DeSimone said.
Internationally, sales for the quarter increased about 19 percent, while United States sales increased only 1 percent, according to the company, which makes a variety of products, including adhesives, abrasives, and telecommunications and electronics products.

HEADLINE: Pilots of All Ages Undergo Medical Testing

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Elderly Pilots, Too, Need More Stringent Testing" (letter, July 19): Aircraft pilots of all ages undergo rigorous, regular medical testing during their flying careers to keep their licenses valid. The least frequent is every three years, with airline pilots tested every six months. This has kept the most handicapped specimens out of the pilot's seat. 
 Indeed there has only been one reported fatality caused by a medical malfunction among pilots over 70 in the last 10 years.
The mandatory retirement of airline pilots at 65 has more to do with $200,000-a-year salaries and their economic impact on the airlines than the condition of the arteries of these healthy, mature and highly skilled pilots. The low accident rate among mature pilots suggests that many are "self-grounding." It also reflects well on the federally qualified aviation medical examiners who perform their duties with evident success.
Statistically, one or two undiscovered health faults among three-quarters of a million pilots is about as good as it will ever get. There is no threat to the public caused by "chronic medical conditions of elderly pilots."
 
JOSEPH J. LANE
Rye, N.Y., July 20, 1995
 
The writer is a pilot.

HEADLINE: Trade Accord Without U.S. Set in Geneva

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 26

 BODY:
Japan and South Korea agreed today to join more than 80 other countries in a pact to liberalize world trade in financial services, clearing the way for the accord to be put into effect without the United States, which has refused to participate.
Even though the Clinton Administration will not be signing on to the accord, which will cover the entry into countries of foreign banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions, American companies will still be able to benefit from the extra access that the participants in the agreement will offer one another. The rules of the World Trade Organization, the new body that oversees international commerce, require that trade concessions extended to one member country be extended to all other countries. 
 The support of Japan and South Korea was considered essential for the success of the agreement, which will carry the global liberalization of trade into the realm of services for the first time.
The accord was welcomed by Renato Ruggiero, the head of the World Trade Organization, which was created at the start of this year to replace the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But he said he regretted the Clinton Administration's refusal to join.
"This must be a second-best result with one member absent, but it is a very good second best," Mr. Ruggiero said. "It is a step toward a more integrated world and a better world. We hope the U.S. will come aboard soon."
Under pressure from American banks and financial institutions, the Clinton Administration has refused to join the pact, complaining that it does not require the rapidly growing economies of Asia and Latin America to open their markets fast enough.
The Administration will allow the foreign financial service companies already in the United States to remain there, and it has told the 15 countries in the European Union that their companies may enter the American market freely because those countries give American companies the same access. But the United States has said it reserves the right to restrict the entry of companies from elsewhere in the world unless their home governments offer American financial firms equal treatment.
The Clinton Administration's decision last month to remain out of the global accord is in contrast to the support the United States has traditionally given to a nondiscriminatory international trading system, free from the kind of deals it now wants to negotiate directly with recalcitrant countries.
Moreover, the United States led the campaign to include service industries in the agreement to liberalize trade in goods that was reached last year under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs on Trade.
After meeting with senior European trade officials in Washington on Monday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin reiterated the objections of the Administration and confirmed that it would not join the pact. But apparently stung by criticism from Europe and elsewhere that the United States was abandoning its commitment to a global trading system, Mr. Rubin pledged "continued participation in the multilateral process in Geneva."
Under today's agreement, which runs until the end of 1997, many developing countries will offer foreign providers of financial services substantially better access to their markets than they have offered in the past.
Argentina, for instance, is lifting its ban on new banks. Brazil will allow more foreign insurance companies into the country and India will license eight new foreign banks a year. The Philippines is to end a 50-year-old prohibition against new banks and insurance companies and Malaysia will raise the ceiling on foreign ownership of insurance companies to 49 percent from 30 percent.
Even so, these steps fall well short of the virtually unrestricted access that the European Union countries are offering foreign financial service companies. European financial companies have said, however, that even an unbalanced agreement offers some additional access and prevents developing countries from further closing their markets.
The trade agreement negotiated last year requires participants to negotiate a further round of liberalization in financial services in 1999.
After the Clinton Administration said at the end of last month that it would not join the accord on financial services, the negotiations seemed likely to collapse as countries scaled back the access offers they had prepared on the assumption that they would gain automatic entry into the American market. But the European Union started an energetic campaign to keep the talks alive, pressing other countries to maintain their access offers and to enter into the pact.
The accord is scheduled to be endorsed formally on Friday, giving members of the World Trade Organization up to then to consider any last-minute changes. The deal does not include the huge markets of China and Russia, which are still negotiating membership in the trade organization.

HEADLINE: Blame the U.S. Consumer for Latin Sweatshops

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bob Herbert, in his heart-wrenching columns (July 21 and 24) on the hapless Central American maquiladoras who produce our cheap clothes, shoots at the wrong target. The culprit is not the ruthless capitalist who pays low wages, but the ruthless American consumer who would quickly punish more benign, high-cost producers. 
 Imagine the following scenario: The Gap posts a sign in its store windows announcing that Gap's prices are higher than the competition's because the Gap pays the maquiladoras a humane $2 an hour, rather than the 56 cents paid by more ruthless competitors in Central America or elsewhere.
Do we imagine millions of compassionate Americans flocking to the Gap to support with higher prices some unknown workers in a faraway land? Come on! In their quest for a good deal, American consumers have not even hesitated to devastate their very own neighbors in their own downtowns, as they have flocked to the lower-priced Wal-Marts in the outskirts.
Social envy may make us pick on the income earned by the Gap's owner, but that is just a classic cheap shot. Even if we took all of that income and distributed it to the maquiladoras working for him, the sum would not be large enough to help each of them very much.
 
UWE E. REINHARDT
James Madison Professor of
Political Economy, Princeton
Princeton, N.J., July 24, 1995

HEADLINE: Barings and Mexico Spur New Rules for U.S. Banks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 26

 BODY:
Alarmed by the collapses last winter of Barings P.L.C. and the Mexican economy, Federal bank regulators are preparing new procedures to review the risks posed to big American banks by their futures and options brokerage units and by financial markets in newly industrializing countries, a senior regulator said today.
The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates 3,300 federally chartered banks, is drafting two separate sets of guidance and procedures for Federal bank examiners to use in ruling on the safety and soundness of bank practices, Douglas E. Harris, the senior deputy comptroller for capital markets, said in an interview this afternoon. 
 One set of rules will cover bank operating subsidiaries that are members of options and futures exchanges, like the Chicago Board of Trade, either in the United States or abroad. Barings, based in London, failed this spring because a trader at its operating subsidiary in Singapore lost about $1 billion placing bad bets on the direction of Japanese stock and bond prices.
The other set of rules will apply to American bank operations in emerging markets like Mexico, and will cover everything from the trading and underwriting of stocks and bonds to the issuing of corporate loans. The comptroller's office has been quietly working on such rules for two years, and stepped up the effort after the collapse of the Mexican peso and financial markets last December, although American banks do not appear to have suffered losses in that instance, Mr. Harris said.
The main banking companies involved in futures brokerage and in emerging markets are among the biggest in the United States, notably Citicorp, BankAmerica and First Chicago.
Mr. Harris emphasized that the new procedures, which he plans to announce in a speech in New York on Thursday, were not being drafted in response to any findings by examiners of previously unsuspected losses at big banks.
The details of the new guidelines will not be completed for a few weeks, he said.
The comptroller's bank examiners currently look at futures and options brokerage and emerging markets activities as they encounter them, but have no comprehensive rules for dealing with them. The Federal Reserve, which regulates bank-holding companies and state-chartered banks that are members of the Federal Reserve System, has rules on futures and options brokerage that are not under review after the Barings incident, a Fed official said. The Fed does not treat emerging markets as a separate issue.
Mr. Harris said that banks' activities in emerging markets needed a specific review because "we have greater concerns about volatility and liquidity risks in emerging markets debt and equity issues than in nonemerging markets."
In the case of the new rules for futures and options brokerage subsidiaries, he said, "It's something we hadn't added before and in light of Barings, it's obvious that if a regulator is concerned about a bank, he should be concerned about its operating subsidiaries."
When Barings failed, Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, immediately asked his subordinates whether his agency had any specific procedures to catch similar problems at American institutions. When he found that there was no formal set of rules for examiners to follow in such reviews, he demanded that such procedures be drafted as fast as possible, Mr. Harris said.
The bank examination procedures for futures and options brokerage units will emphasize risk-management and risk-control issues, while leaving such issues as customer protection and the pricing of futures and options to regulation by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Mr. Harris said. The new rules for emerging markets will focus on the allocation of capital, risk limits and the amount of oversight by senior managers.
Neither set of procedures will be aimed at prescribing or banning a specific list of activities. That is in keeping with an international consensus among regulators that new trading practices and financial products are being developed at such a brisk pace that the best approach to insuring the safety and soundness of banks is to require that they have adequate management processes to recognize new risks as they come up.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Day Little Changed When Rate-Cut Report Is Denied

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday in trading that turned listless after initially being buffeted by speculation on the course of American interest rates.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.3877 German marks from 1.3942 marks on Tuesday. The dollar edged up to 87.91 Japanese yen from 87.79 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5932 from $1.5905. 
 Foreign-exchange markets were roiled after Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a Japanese business newspaper, reported that Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, said in an interview that there could be an additional one-half-point reduction in short-term interest rates. Mr. Lindsey subsequently denied the report as "absolutely ridiculous" and said that he did not discuss Fed policy with the news media.
On July 6, the Fed reduced the rate on overnight loans between banks by a quarter-point, and traders had been looking for signs of further cuts. Lower interest rates in the United States would make dollar-denominated assets less attractive to investors, reducing demand for dollars.
The Japanese report sent the dollar down against the mark and the yen during the morning session of New York trading, said Liz Goldberg, an assistant vice president of Bayerische Hypotheken-und Wechsel-Bank A.G.
The dollar received some limited support from more reports of moderate inflation in Germany. Consumer prices in western Germany fell one-tenth of 1 percent in the month that ended in mid-July, according to preliminary data, the first monthly drop since March 1991. The western German state of Bavaria also reported declining inflation.
If a resurgence in inflation is not a threat, there would be room for German central bankers to cut interest rates, something that would make mark-denominated investments less attractive. But traders are already expecting such a cut and have factored such action into their transactions, said Jack Griffin, a foreign exchange vice president at the New York branch of Fuji Bank Ltd.
Among the unknowns facing the market is the strength of the United States economy. Traders are focusing on a report due at the end of the week on the United States gross domestic product, with expectations of a slight increase. Too vigorous growth would reduce chances for further interest rate relief from the Fed.
"Ever since people walked in on Monday they have been talking about G.D.P. on Friday," Ms. Goldberg said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Theme Parks Help Disney's Earnings Rise

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., July 26

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said today that earnings rose 19 percent in the third quarter, aided by increased attendance at its theme parks and a smaller loss on its investment in Euro Disney.
The results were also helped by growth in the company's consumer products operations and by a smaller-than-expected decline in operating income in the filmed entertainment division. 
 Net income rose to $318.2 million, or 60 cents a share, from $267.5 million, or 49 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue increased 17 percent, to $2.76 billion from $2.35 billion.
The per-share profit of 60 cents exceeded Wall Street expectations of 56 cents, which was the average estimate of 16 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. Disney's stock closed at $56.875 today, up $1.125, in Big Board trading.
"We're hitting on all cylinders," Disney's chief financial officer, Stephen Bollenbach, said in an interview. "The quarter is a good demonstration of the balance in our businesses."
Operating income from theme parks rose 27 percent, to $302.5 million from $238.3 million, while revenue increased 20 percent, to $1.13 billion from $942 million. The quarter's results included a $14.4 million loss from the company's 39.9 percent stake in Euro Disney, which operates a large theme park outside Paris. That was narrower than a $52.8 million loss a year ago.
Operating income from filmed entertainment fell 8 percent, but that was not as bad as expected, said Jill Krutick, an analyst at Smith Barney. "The company got a lift in international video from the release of 'The Return of Jafar' and 'Pinocchio,' " she said.
Attendance rose at the company's Florida and California theme parks during the quarter. Mr. Bollenbach said the parks had been "severely impacted" over the last few years by a slowing in the international economy. "Now we're seeing record-high attendance at the parks," he said. "They are one of the major elements of our growth."
On Tuesday, Euro Disney reported a profit of $35 million for its latest fiscal quarter -- its first profit since the theme park opened in April 1992.
The film division's operating income fell 8 percent, to $153.3 million from $167.4 million, on a 15 percent increase in revenue, to $1.16 billion from $1 billion.
Operating income from consumer products rose 23 percent, to $106.5 million from $86.9 million, while revenue increased 25 percent, to $475.1 million from $407.7 million. The growth reflected expansion and sales increases in the Disney stores and the strength of sales of licensed character merchandise.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Energy standards aren't as oppressive as they may seem.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
DOES Washington know your needs better than you? Most people, it is safe to assume, would like a little help from Uncle when it comes to choosing, say, pesticides or antibiotics.
But some Americans undoubtedly resent being told which water heaters to buy or how much insulation they should stuff in their walls. And with that in mind, the House of Representatives voted last week to stop the Clinton Administration from spending any money to set energy-efficiency standards for household appliances or to design model building codes. 
 Robert Hahn, an economist who specializes in regulation at the American Enterprise Institute, is pleased. There is no energy crisis and thus, he suggests, no compelling national interest in regulating the use of electricity or forcing the pace of technological change. "When in doubt," he says, "less is better."
But defenders of energy-efficiency regulations are not just the sort of folks who spend their spare time recycling aluminum foil. "Killing the standards would be a triumph of blind ideology over economic common sense," said Daniel Lashof, a senior scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. And whether or not one agrees, there is surely a plausible economic rationale for interfering with the market in energy-related products.
While it is widely assumed that the appliance standards and model building code programs were the handiwork of liberals who never met a payroll, the enabling legislation was, in fact, signed by President Ronald Reagan in 1987 and reinforced by President George Bush's Energy Policy Act of 1992. In part, Republican support reflected the business reality that there was money to be made in selling insulation and designing energy-efficient machines. In part, it reflected appliance makers' fears that the national market would be balkanized, as states -- notably California -- set their own standards.
The program has not generated much public controversy. The Department of Energy has been cautious in limiting standards to those that can be justified on purely economic grounds. Regulators have, in effect, asked what rational consumers would want: Efficiency is mandated only where the likely savings in utility bills substantially exceed the up-front cost.
And why wouldn't consumers make the same decisions on their own, driving the market to produce the desired level of energy efficiency and obviating the need for rules?
One reason, Mr. Lashof suggests, is that consumers have limited time and often leave the decision to a contractor whose primary incentives are to keep prices low and profit margins high. Much the same can happen in appliance stores. "Salesmen usually have only a few minutes to show off the features of their products," said Mike Thompson, director of governmental relations for the Whirlpool Company, "and energy saving isn't high on the list."
In study after study, Mr. Lashof adds, consumers have been shown to make myopic choices, passing by energy-efficient appliances even when the payback period is just one to three years. Hazel R. O'Leary, the Secretary of Energy, estimates that appliance rules already in place will save consumers $1.7 billion annually by 2000.
If the department has behaved cautiously, why the Congressional challenge? For one thing, regulators did raise hackles in proposing rules for fluorescent light fixtures that would force a rapid switch to new technology and would not be cost-effective for lights that were used only a few hours a month.
The department relented after two lighting manufacturers, Magnetek and Philips, protested. And it is now considering the creation of a separate category for lighting that is likely to be used infrequently. But the case illustrates a tension inherent in tinkering with the market: Some producers will have a strong advantage where the pace of technological change is forced by government.
That, in large part explains why Whirlpool is eager to see the current round of rule-making through to completion and why many of its rivals are not. Whirlpool, for example, would probably increase market share in clothes washers if proposed rules go into effect because it has already invested in technology for reducing the amount of hot water needed to get clothes clean.
Those opposed to energy rules will not have as easy a time in the Senate. Some manufacturers, including Whirlpool, will register their distress. Others will no doubt remember that they supported appliance standards in the first place in order to pre-empt state initiatives. If they do not, environmental groups are eager to remind them -- two have already petitioned the California Energy Commission to carry on making rules if the standards are abandoned by the Department of Energy.
Lost in the debate, one suspects, will be any systematic consideration of when interference with free markets is economically justified. That is a pity, but no surprise.

HEADLINE: Michael Andrews, British Painter, Is Dead at 66

BYLINE: By JOHN RUSSELL 

 BODY:
Michael Andrews, a painter who for more than 30 years was an elusive but legendary presence in the London art world, died on July 19 in London. He was 66.
The cause was cancer, London newspapers reported over the weekend. 
 While a student at the Slade School of Art in the early 1950's, he painted a large picture with overtones of a psychiatric case history called "A Man Who Suddenly Fell Over."
Even when young, he was a famously slow worker, known for very large canvases that took him forever. But homes were found for many of his best paintings at the Tate Gallery, at the National Galleries in Melbourne and Canberra, Australia, and with a steadfast handful of private patrons.
Mr. Andrews functioned as a purposeful absentee. No sooner was he acknowledged as an incomparable chronicler and deconstructer of the rackety London scene of the 1960's than he began a series of large paintings based on the adventures of a gas-filled balloon.
First seen as a milk-white presence high above an English pastoral scene, the balloon then hovered above Westminster by night. It monitored more than one largely obsolete pleasure resort on the southern coast and finally defined itself as a moving shadow heading for a landfall somewhere between sand and sea.
From 1975 onward, Scotland seized Mr. Andrews's imagination, in part for its stern and often tumultuous history, in part for the austere and geometrical ritual of deer stalking in castle country. No living painter was better at taking a well-beaten subject and giving it a whole new spin.
In 1983, acting on a 25-year fascination with Ayers Rock, he visited Australia. Not until 1989 did he complete the series of big paintings that resulted. Though many now consider Ayers Rock a hackneyed tourist attraction, Mr. Andrews made it new.
In his later years he appeared in a long series of exhibitions -- notably his retrospective at the Hayward Gallery in London in 1980-81 -- that confirmed not only his own status but the high esteem in which he was held by his peers. "I can't better that," said Lucian Freud when reminded of the saying that "Andrews is such an economical painter, he only paints masterpieces."
His first and only show in New York was at the Grey Art Gallery of New York University in 1991.
Mr. Andrews was born on Oct. 30, 1928, in Norwich, England, where his father was an insurance agent. He was called up for military service from 1947 to 1949, and spent 19 months in Egypt. From 1949 to 1953 he studied at the Slade School of Art in London. His first one-man show in London was at the Beaux-Arts Gallery in 1958.
Though mistrustful of honorifics, Mr. Andrews served briefly as a trustee of the National Gallery in London and was elected to the Royal Academy. He was also made a Fellow of University College, London.
He is survived by his wife, the former June Keeley, and a daughter, Melanie.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Michael Andrews, left, and one of his figure studies from 1967. (British Art Center)

HEADLINE: Nutting, Nuts Hero

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

 BODY:
SCORNED after his death in 1941 as a sentimental crackpot with an unhealthy yen for Pilgrim days, the Rev. Dr. Wallace Nutting, a Congregational minister turned photographer, author, antiques expert and furniture manufacturer, is enjoying an unexpected revival.
"Antiques dealers used to pooh-pooh and say, 'Oh, we couldn't possibly carry junk like that,' " said George Monro of North Caldwell, N.J., who, along with his late wife, Justine, founded the Wallace Nutting Collectors Club in 1973. "Now, every shop wants him." Initially, the club had three members; today it has nearly 350. 
 Maybe it is the conservative climate, or maybe it is just long enough after Dr. Nutting's heyday for his work to prove interesting once again. From 1912 to 1941, Dr. Nutting was America's premier preservationist and historian, known as the Father of American Antiques. In that, he was supported by an infrastructure of colorists, rug weavers, etchers and silhouette designers. Between 1917 or 1918 and the early 1940's, cabinetmakers at his factory in Saugus, Mass., turned out exact reproductions of Early American furniture.
His forte was hand-colored, softly focused platinum-print photographs of subjects guaranteed to put a smile on buyers' faces -- rose-clad cottages, birch-shaded streams, apple orchards in bloom. They were sold by the hundreds of thousands in the early 1900's for around $2.
A team of young women hand-colored, framed and mounted his photographs, which were sold singly or on holiday cards and calendars in galleries and 10-cent stores across the country. He also produced nearly 20 beautifully illustrated but clumsily written books on American architectural history and decorative arts, each a hardcover sermon pleading for the preservation of classic Americana. A three-volume set, "Furniture Treasury," a study of early Colonial furniture, remains a standard reference work among antiques dealers.
But after his death at age 79, many of the photographs were thrown away, derided as pseudo-Impressionist pablum in sophisticated urban circles where the work of Steichen and other art photographers held sway.
NOW, nearly a century after Dr. Nutting began taking his pictures, they are being collected again, and given the rate of inflation, the prices are still good, generally between $25 and $75. Equally desirable though harder to find is the handmade, hand-carved furniture -- from cradles to radiator covers to highboys -- that Dr. Nutting began manufacturing in 1917, most of the pieces copied or adapted from 17th- and 18th-century American originals in museums or his personal collection. Prices now range from $195 for a simple maple stool to more than $15,000 for a set of eight Windsor chairs.
If Linda Palmer has her way, Dr. Nutting's reputation will spread far beyond the community of collectors. Last year, Mrs. Palmer, a 48-year-old nursing student and Nutting collector in Kent, Conn., began a letter-writing campaign to the Postal Service for a Wallace Nutting commemorative stamp. So far, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, has joined the effort.
"What did Marilyn Monroe or Elvis do to deserve a stamp?" Mrs. Palmer said. "Nutting was the man who made Americans proud of America."
Among the collectors is William Hamann, 51, a Cleveland banker. He and his wife, Gretchen, bought their first Nutting photograph 15 years ago, "and the next thing I knew we had hundreds," Mr. Hamann said. And with his wife's bemused blessing, he has been decorating their house in the suburb of Shaker Heights with what Nutting nuts consider to be one of the finest collections of Nutting furniture, including nearly a dozen Windsor chairs.
Modern reproductions of Dr. Nutting's "original" reproductions can be had from Berea (Ky.) College, which inherited the unsold stock and blueprints after his furniture company closed in 1944. Prices range from $300 for a Sheraton-style stool to $10,600 for a walnut corner cupboard with pediment. Catalogues are available by calling Berea at (800) 347-3892.
Whether they consist of old or new pieces, Nutting collections have a way of expanding. "It's like potato chips," Michael Ivankovich. "You can't have just one of anything by Nutting. A Doylestown, Pa., auctioneer who has become an expert on Dr. Nutting, Mr. Ivankovich runs three all-Nutting sales each year. (The next will be at the Ramada Inn in Danbury, Conn., on Nov. 3-4.)
More than 200 people turned out for the last auction, in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in June, where they bid on 305 lots that ranged from a 1923 copy of Dr. Nutting's book "Connecticut Beautiful" (it brought $20) to a reproduction Philadelphia Chippendale mahogany chair ($650) to "Pilgrimage Prints," a rare intact collection of 25 signed photographs that Nutting took while he and 800 fellow ministers and their wives toured Palestine in 1904 ($5,800).
Among the bidders were Elizabeth Elliot and her husband, Lloyd, a dapper man in a slouchy white linen suit who designs leather goods for Guess and Avanti. They found their first Nutting photograph at a flea market in the Catskills: "It's like giving birth," Mrs. Elliot said, tucking her dog, a papillon named Rambo, under her arm. "You can never forget."
Dr. Nutting owed his fame to physical frailty. A fear of heights, which prevented him from ascending to the pulpit, and a nervous breakdown in 1904 forced him into early retirement at age 43 in the bucolic village of Southbury, Conn. His wife, Mariet, doubtless exasperated by his daily presence in the house, encouraged him to take his bicycle and go off on long relaxing rides. He took along his camera. Forty thousand photographs later, he was an industry.
His patriotic exhortations and his expertise in American antiques were heeded by even the most experienced collectors. John D. Rockefeller commissioned him to make furniture for the Raleigh Tavern and House of Burgesses in Williamsburg, Va. The Daughters of the American Revolution invited him to design a room at their headquarters in Washington. When money problems beset Dr. Nutting in the 1920's, J. Pierpont Morgan came to the rescue, buying his enviable collection of early New England furniture and ironwork and donating it, in Dr. Nutting's name, to the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, where it remains on permanent exhibition.
"Nutting was a true evangelist, the man who got people to shout 'Hosanna!' when they saw a Windsor chair," said William N. Hosley, the Atheneum's curator of American decorative arts. "He installed this apparatus that evoked the American way. It was a romanticized, Anglocentric view of America, but his genius was that he created multiple reinforcing agendas -- the books supported the furniture supported the house restorations supported the photographs and back again.
"It was a relentlessly clever piece of marketing, whatever the audience, though I've always suspected that the people who appreciated him most were paranoid, bigoted city women with a chip on their shoulder. What's really important about Nutting is that his pictures inspired people to hit the road and see the beauty of America."
EVEN preservationists, who once loathed Dr. Nutting's enthusiastic "improvements" to Colonial properties, have begun to revise their opinions. At the 18th-century Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum in Weathersfield, Conn., which was restored in the 1930's as one of Wallace Nutting's Chain of Colonial Houses, the design equivalent of roadside circus, Beth Ann McPherson, the museum's curator, is overseeing the restoration of a Nutting mural.
Covered by wallpaper in the 1970's, it depicts George Washington and his British adversaries in garish Technicolor reds, blacks and greens.
"He moved walls, added cupboards and paneling, anything to make rooms look more Colonial than they were, which is heresy in most circles," she said. "But what Nutting did here is part of the evolution of the house and should be studied."
Still, even Dr. Nutting's staunchest supporters sometimes have trouble keeping a straight face when confronted with his knack for faux-Puritan melodrama.
At the Saratoga Springs auction, Nancy Novick rolled her eyes at the sight of one of Dr. Nutting's "personals," so-called for the use of models -- occasionally his wife, but most often pretty young neighborhood girls -- placed in a historic interior. This particular example depicted a gently colored image of a spinning wheel operated by a winsome young woman in Williamsburg garb: mobcap, heavy shoes, downcast but ecstatic eyes.
"Kitsch, isn't it?" whispered Ms. Novick, a Manhattan graphic designer who is working on a book about Dr. Nutting. Though she suspects he was a "tremendous prig and a lunatic, too," she said she was amazed by Dr. Nutting's professional artistry especially the landscape and garden photographs. She compared their colors and composition with those of the paintings of the American Impressionist Childe Hassam.
For Dorothy Manville, a collector who lives in Southbury, Conn., where Nutting opened a studio in 1905, Dr. Nutting's appeal is more basic. "He captured something we cannot replace," she said. She and her husband, whose mother posed as a child for Dr. Nutting's personals, own more than 800 Nutting photographs. "So much of that landscape is gone today, and that's what Wallace Nutting was trying to preserve through his pictures. The walls, the apple trees, the little white houses -- those are what people see in their minds when they think of America."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Environmental Aid for Trenton

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Trenton will be one of 15 cities across the country to receive Federal money for a pilot program to redevelop abandoned, contaminated properties into new enterprises that can create jobs and tax revenues, The Associated Press reported. 
 City officials said they would use the $200,000 grant, awarded yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency, to develop plans to give minority residents a say in how the sites should be cleaned up and used. Trenton's unemployment rate is 11.8 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Up as Orders Slow

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday after a report showed weaker-than-expected factory orders, easing investor concern that strong economic growth would accelerate inflation.
The Commerce Department said orders for big-ticket items designed to last for more than three years fell a tenth of a percent in June; a gain of seven-tenths of a percent had been expected. 
 Analysts said the report suggested an anemic economy that could lead the Fed to reduce interest rates again. But they cautioned that the report did not show an across-the-board weakness; indeed, the report indicated pockets of strength.
The 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to a price of 10929/32 for a yield of 6.84 percent, down from 6.88 percent on Wednesday, with rates on short-maturity bills down an average of 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the durables report was very much a confirmation of a soft landing in the economy. He said he expected a continuation of moderate growth, averaging 2.5 percent in the long run.
"What the June statistics reveal," Mr. Platt said, "is a major slowing in the capital goods ordering process of the second quarter, relative to the first quarter, and that is going to translate into a continuation of subdued economic activity in the manufacturing sector, probably only for the next few months, with only slightly positive increases in industrial production.
"The market will probably remain range bound in the near term because it must come to grips with the fact that the economy is not plunging into recession, and that the Fed is not going to ease at August Federal Open Market Committee meeting. I suspect after a few months the market can improve significantly."
The Labor Department in its weekly report on the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits, said yesterday that 40,000 fewer, or 374,000, had filed. In the prior week new claims were put at 17,000 from an initially reported 18,000 gain, but analysts said the data had little impact on the market.
Traders said gains in Treasury securities yesterday were limited as the supply of new issues continued to hamper the market. Next week the Treasury will announce the size of its quarterly refunding and many expect the size to remain unchanged from February's $40 billion package, including $17 billion in 3-year notes, $12 billion in 10-year notes, and $11 billion in 30-year bonds. Others are projecting a rise to as high as $42 billion.
In the municipal bond market, prices gained as investors sought securities with maturities of 10 years or less. The short end of the market has become more attractive amid concern that proposed tax law changes could make some bonds less attractive.
New York investors are expected to demand extra compensation in the form of higher rates on next week's $1 billion sale of New York City's general obligation bonds.
New York State, New York City and their agencies plan to sell $7.3 billion in securities in the third quarter, according to State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. That is up $1.73 billion from the amount of debt sold last year in the similar quarter.
According to Bloomberg Fair Value Analytics, general obligation bonds due in 30 years and rated double-A are yielding 5.97 percent, up from 5.81 percent last Friday.
In only its second debt sale in a little more than a year the Province of Ontario sold $1 billion of 10-year global bonds through Merrill Lynch International and Lehman Brothers International at a price to yield 7.005 percent, or 57 basis points more than a 10-year Treasury. The debt is rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.
In the corporate market, TCI Communications Inc., a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., priced $1 billion of debt securities in two parts through Merrill Lynch. Some $350 million of 10-year notes were priced to yield 8.074 percent, or 165 basis points more than a comparable Treasury, while $750 million of 20-year debenutures were priced to yield 8.81 percent, or 195 basis points more than a 30-year Treasury.
Underwriters said both parts were rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB- by S.& P. and Duff & Phelps.

HEADLINE: David G. Hays, 66, a Developer Of Language Study by Computer

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
David G. Hays, a social scientist and early practitioner of the budding discipline of computational linguistics, died on Wednesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 66 and lived in the Inwood section of Manhattan.
The cause was lung cancer, his family said. 
 Computer-aided linguistics -- akin to artificial intelligence -- uses computational procedures called algorithms, mathematical models and computer systems in researching language. It is applied in translation, documentation and lexicography and in the study of stylistics and content analysis.
Early in his career, Dr. Hays taught at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., and wrote about computer-assisted language processing as early as 1957. He was project leader on computational linguistics at Rand from 1955 to 1968.
From then until 1980, he was professor of linguistics, computer science, and information and library studies at the State University at Buffalo. He then worked as an independent researcher, writer and consultant in New York City and taught on-line courses at the New School for Social Research.
As a scholarly discipline, computational linguistics has been much refined since the models of the late 1950's. Part of its folklore is an early program that supposedly rendered the English sentence, "The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak," into Russian as "The vodka is strong, but the meat is rotten."
More recent programs of the kind Dr. Hays worked with are far more discriminating. They feature immense dictionaries and are able to analyze the grammatical structure of sentences and to summarize dense legal documents.
David Glenn Hays was born in Memphis and graduated from Harvard College in 1951. He also received his master's and Ph.D. degrees in sociology from Harvard.
He wrote many scholarly articles and six books, including "Introduction to Computational Linguistics" (Elsevier, 1967) and "Cognitive Structures" (H.R.A.F. Press, 1981).
At his death, he was studying how motion elicits emotion, focusing on the ballets of George Balanchine.
Dr. Hays is survived by his wife, Janet Ginsberg Adelson Hays; a daughter, Dorothy A. Hays of Palo Alto, Calif.; two sons, Warren S. T., of Tokyo, and Thomas G., of San Francisco; a granddaughter; three stepsons, James Adelson of Harvard, Mass., Joshua Adelson of Sharon, Mass., and Andrew Adelson of Newton, Mass.; two stepdaughters, Lisa Eisenberg of Harvard, Mass., and Nancy Allison of Sharon, Mass., and 10 step-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Managua Journal;
Ghosts in Nicaragua? No, Somozas in the Flesh

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua

 BODY:
Their name may still be regarded here as a synonym for corruption and brutality. But ever so cautiously, the Somoza family is beginning to return to Nicaragua, hoping to find a place now that memories of its five decades of dictatorship are beginning to fade.
Three brothers, grandsons of the founder of the dynasty that ruled this country as a classic banana-republic dictatorship from 1933 to 1979, are leading that effort and say ordinary Nicaraguans are proving surprisingly receptive. Eduardo Sevilla Somoza, a 42-year-old Washington-based businessman, visited recently for the first time since the Sandinista National Liberation Front overthrew his uncle, Anastasio Somoza Debayle. 
 Eduardo's elder brother, Luis Sevilla Somoza, is a 48-year-old Miami resident who visits here regularly.
"We want to put right the family name and talk about the positive as well as the negative," Luis said.
A third brother, Alejandro, a 39-year-old marketing consultant, added that "there's a negative aura that the Somozas had, and we think it's unjustified."
Just a few years ago, when the Sandinistas were still in power, that argument would have been considered counterrevolutionary. But with the Sandinistas themselves now on the defensive and the Government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro floundering, some Nicaraguans seem nostalgic for the old order.
Hundreds of thousands of Nicaraguans have personal mementos of the political violence that racked the country under the Somozas. Mrs. Chamorro still keeps the tan Saab that her husband, the opposition editor Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Cardenal, was driving when he was assassinated in 1978, setting off the final uprising that brought the Sandinistas to power.
But half of Nicaragua's population of 4.5 million is 16 years of age or younger, meaning that their first memories are of the Sandinistas' revolution and their struggle with American-backed contras.
"In school, they taught us that the Somozas were greedy and killed a lot of innocent people," said Carmen Buitrago, a high school student here, said. "But it was the Sandinistas who sent my cousins to fight at the front and now we are living in a state of crisis, so how much worse could the Somozas have really been?"
As part of their effort to rehabilitate the family's reputation, the Sevilla Somoza brothers have set up the Nicaraguan-American Humanitarian Assistance Foundation to aid health programs here. Projects they are supporting include a leper colony, a children's hospital and a clinic for disabled veterans of the decade-long civil war that followed the collapse of the Somoza dictatorship.
Visiting Children's Hospital this month, Luis and Eduardo Sevilla Somoza encountered fading posters that proclaimed "Somoza will never return." But the hospital's directors appeared interested, nonetheless, in the brothers' offer to bring a group of American pediatric surgeons here and send their local counterparts to Miami for specialized training.
While helping the less fortunate, the Sevilla Somozas have also been pursuing claims to scores of Somoza family properties the Sandinistas expropriated the day after they entered Managua in July 1979. These include houses, hotels and ranches as well as cement, beer, fishing, logging and mining companies, whose total value they estimate as more than $250 million.
"We know we are last in line and we understand why," said Alejandro Sevilla Somoza. "They've used us as the scapegoat for all the evil there could ever be in Nicaragua."
Luis, Alejandro and Eduardo Sevilla Somoza are three of the nine children of Lilian Somoza, the daughter of the founder of the dynasty, Anastasio Somoza Garcia. She is also the older sister of Anastasio Somoza Debayle, who was assassinated in Paraguay a year after being overthrown in 1979.
As Alejandro sees it, the Somoza family's was "a benevolent dictatorship" that achieved much and deserves credit for its accomplishments. "The last few years may have gone a little crazy, but there was progress here," he argued.
That opinion is now expressed with considerable frequency here, especially among those who opposed the Sandinistas and see their 11 years in power as the main source of Nicaragua's current political andeconomic ills. These include high unemployment, inflation, a weak currency and a huge foreign debt.
"Somoza was 10 times better than those thieves," said Jose Sanchez, a 48-year-old printer. "Yes, he stole. But our foreign debt was $1 billion after nearly 50 years of the Somozas, and a decade later it was $12 billion and we had nothing to show for it. So I ask you: who was the bigger thief?"
The emergence of such sentiment also helps explain another change in the political climate: the sudden resurgence of the Liberal Party, which for many years was a pliant vehicle of the Somoza dictatorship. All polls agree that the front-runner in next year's presidential election here is the Liberal nominee, Arnoldo Aleman, Mayor of Managua.
Liberal leaders are basking in that popularity but appear uncertain how to deal with the party's historical connections to the Somozas. At the party's convention July 11, speakers read off a long list of Liberal luminaries, but pointedly made no mention of any member of the Somoza family.
But the Sevilla Somoza brothers did attend the party gathering, greeted many former family friends and allies there and met with Mr. Aleman. "We're Liberals as a family tradition," said Eduardo Sevilla Somoza. "We have that in our blood and will help in whatever way we can."

HEADLINE: Port Agency Trims Budget And Its Scope

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Under pressure from the governors who oversee it, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has begun a round of budget cuts that appear to be a prelude to more drastic steps, indicating that the agency may soon be forced to scale back its historical role as a power in the region's economic development.
 The authority's new executive director, George J. Marlin, has moved forward in recent weeks on his mandate to trim its work force and costs by ordering a hiring freeze and reductions in travel and other expenses. Yesterday, the authority's board began examining the first results of a study on how the agency can reduce its spending by eliminating some jobs. 
 The actions demonstrate that Gov. George E. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman are intent on subjecting the authority, which has often been criticized as bloated and inefficient, to the same regimen of budget and staff cuts that they have imposed on their own state governments.
"The organization is going to be smaller," said Charles A. Gargano, the vice chairman of the authority and Mr. Pataki's top economic adviser. "That is certain. The prudent thing to do is to look at the organization and try to save as much as we can in restructuring, as we have done in New York State government."
Mr. Gargano said that there had been no decisions on how the authority's $2.7 billion budget or 9,000-person work force would be trimmed. But some senior officials in the Pataki and Whitman administrations said they thought the work force could end up being reduced by 5 or 10 percent through attrition, buyouts and, if necessary, layoffs.
"It's very hard to argue that they are understaffed," said a high-ranking official in the Whitman administration, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The Pataki and Whitman officials said they envisioned a Port Authority that concentrates largely on transportation, possibly by shedding some of the other responsibilities that it has picked up over the years, like economic forecasting, policy analysis or its network of foreign trade offices.
In what may have been a preview of this new era of retrenchment, Mr. Marlin said recently that the authority would have to abandon its proposal to build a 22-mile railway between Manhattan and Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports in Queens because of rising costs.
What repercussions the new cuts will have on the authority's services is not known. Officials like Mr. Gargano said they believed that the budget could be trimmed without causing hardships to the hundreds of thousands of people in the region who use the authority each day.
But it is also clear that the agency may soon not have the resources to do some of the things that it has long been known for, like its surveys of the economic impact of tourism and the arts on the region, or the assistance it provides to small businesses that want to start exporting products.
The authority, which was chartered in 1921 by Congress, is the largest port authority in the country. It operates or owns the three major airports in the region, the George Washington and other bridges, the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, the PATH commuter line, the World Trade Center, most of the major marine terminals on New York Harbor and industrial parks.
Over the years, the Port Authority has taken on more and more commitments, acting as a financier, planner, analyst and, most important, sponsor of such projects as Kennedy and Newark International Airports. Its work force grew to nearly 10,000 people by the late 1980's before it pulled back because of the recession.
Though it has long been respected as the region's master builder, the authority has also been attacked as being wasteful and extravagant. Several times over the last few decades, it has been involved in scandals over the perks of its executives, who were found to have regularly traveled first class on airplanes and used helicopters for jaunts around New York City.
One issue that is driving the campaign to cut costs is the possible need for an increase on the tolls for the authority's bridges and tunnels, as well as a rise in the PATH fare. Stanley Brezenoff, Mr. Marlin's predecessor, said late last year that the agency would face a budget gap if tolls did not rise.
The one-way tolls, which are $4 into the city, have not changed since 1991. But aides to both Mr. Pataki and Mrs. Whitman said the two were unlikely to agree to any increase because they considered it akin to a rise in taxes. As a result, the gap in the authority's budget would have to be closed by cutting spending.
"If you don't do a toll increase, you have to do some fairly dramatic things," said a former senior official at the authority who has kept in contact with officials there and who insisted on anonymity. "So they are in the process of looking at a very dramatic downsizing."
The tolls and the future of the Port Authority are to be discussed next month at a meeting between Mr. Pataki and Mrs. Whitman, officials said. The two will also review the study that is being conducted on reorganizing the agency.
People who have seen the first results of the study, which is being done by the consulting firm of Deloitte & Touche and will not be completed for several weeks, said it identified areas where the authority could cut its staff. It noted, for example, that the agency often had managers and auditors at both its headquarters and its divisions doing the same work.
The authority also recently commissioned a study on whether it should sell all or part of the World Trade Center.
And the authority, which in the 1980's expanded into areas like industrial parks and office buildings, has in recent months stepped up its efforts to divest itself of such assets, thereby allowing it to focus more on transportation. It has sold some of its properties at its industrial parks in Yonkers and Elizabeth, N.J., and it has put the New York Vista Hotel at the World Trade Center on the market.
Mr. Marlin declined to comment about the cost-cutting at the authority. But people who work him say he is approaching the changes with more of a political perspective than Mr. Brezenoff. Mr. Marlin, who has long called for government to reduce its obligations, ran for New York City mayor in 1993 on the Conservative Party line.
"There are some people who feel that he has too political an orientation," said a senior official at the agency. "Frequently, he will think about issues in terms of how political officials, elected officials or others react. But I don't think that is a negative."
Rumors that are swirling around the authority's headquarters in the World Trade Center about large layoffs are unfounded, Mr. Marlin's chief deputy, John J. Haley Jr., said earlier this week. But Mr. Haley did say that in one or two years, the authority would be a different organization.
"The instruction that we have from both administrations and the board is that there are no sacred cows here," Mr. Haley said. "We have to look at everything. The Port Authority has what is a traditional militaristic structure that is heavily layered. It has a lot of layers of management. What we are doing is examining all that."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Urges Big Spending To Cure Capital's Problems

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
With Republicans everywhere else in Congress urging less spending and bureaucracy, five of them from the House today recommended an array of new programs for the District of Columbia that would cost the Federal Government billions of dollars.
Sounding unexpectedly like the Democrats they criticize for excessive spending, the Republican lawmakers said at a subcommittee hearing that the programs would help create a vision of the urban future that could serve as a model for other troubled cities. 
 But as urgent as the proposals sounded, the notion of making major changes in a largely Democratic city that has no voting representation in Congress struck the only Democrat present as heavy-handed and unfair.
"To me, this is a serious step back from home rule," said Representative Julian C. Dixon of California, former chairman of the panel, the Appropriations Subcommittee on the District of Columbia, referring to the limited autonomy that Congress granted the District in 1974. But he predicted that the price tag for many of the recommendations would make them "a long way from reality in this Congress."
With a newly appointed financial control board for the city focused on short-term budgetary problems, House Speaker Newt Gingrich asked five Republicans to investigate long-term solutions to Washington's problems, including middle-class flight, rising crime rates and the deterioration of public schools.
Their recommendations were presented in informal fashion today, with each lawmaker appearing for about 30 minutes. But Representative James T. Walsh of upstate New York, the subcommittee chairman, said that ideas earning the widespread support of the control board, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., the City Council and public interest groups could be put into effect as part of the city's 1996 budget.
The most expensive of the recommendations appeared to be a package of economic initiatives proposed by Representative Amo Houghton Jr. of upstate New York that would cost $224 million next year and $2.76 billion over four years.
The essence of his plan is similar to ideas proposed by Jack F. Kemp, the former Housing Secretary, who has consulted with both Mr. Gingrich and Mayor Barry in recent months over ways to revitalize the city. In Mr. Houghton's proposal, the District would become an enterprise zone, providing employer tax credits and tax-exempt financing as a way to attract new businesses, and local residents would pay reduced Federal income taxes.
He also noted in written testimony for the subcommittee that "the D.C. tax base is insufficient," a conclusion that contradicts a view held by many Republicans, including Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d of Virginia, the Republican chairman of the District Subcommittee of the House Government Reform and Oversight Committee, which drafted the legislation that created the financial control board.
Mr. Davis, who opposes any commuter tax for the thousands of people who work in the District and live elsewhere, has steadfastly insisted that Washington's financial problems have been caused by management failures, not the tax structure.
Representative Fred Heineman, a North Carolina freshman and former New York City police officer, also recommended increased Federal spending. In his analysis of the District police department, in which officers this year lost 4 percent of their base salary as part of the city's overall effort to balance the budget, Mr. Heineman said the $8.3 million in savings should be restored.
"The morale is devastating," Mr. Heineman said of the local police. He urged that annual salaries be raised by $5,000 for each of District's 3,700 officers. That's another $18.5 million in proposed spending.
Representative Steve Gunderson of Wisconsin said his recommendations for the school system would be presented next week, when Mr. Gingrich meets with local residents at a town hall type of meeting.
Addressing proposed changes for human services and welfare, Representative James M. Talent of Missouri recommended a series of new programs, including one that would eliminate welfare benefits for unwed mothers under the age of 21 and create group homes for them, and a program that would reward teen-agers who did not get pregnant.
Representative Rick A. Lazio of Suffolk said efforts to improve housing and community development should focus on helping residents become homeowners as a way to stabilize neighborhoods.
