HEADLINE: Five Indicted in Extortion by Meatpackers' Union

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Five current and former officials of a meatpackers' union extorted bribes from meat and food wholesalers and a supermarket chain in the New York region to guarantee deliveries and labor peace, Federal prosecutors charged yesterday.
Mary Jo White, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said the union officials shared the bribes with the Gambino and Genovese organized crime families who, she said, "supervised and protected the criminal activities of the defendants and their co-racketeers." 
 In exchange for the payoffs, Ms. White said, the union officials also allowed some companies to freeze wages and shortchange pension and welfare benefit funds for their workers.
None of the victimized companies named in the Federal indictment were charged with any crime, however. Marvin Smilon, a spokesman for the United States Attorney's office, declined to comment on which companies had shortchanged their workers, whether their actions were illegal or whether they might face criminal charges themselves.
"We are not allowed to comment unless someone has been charged, and at this point, no one else has been charged," Mr. Smilon said. "However, the investigation is continuing."
The indictment charged that beginning in the early 1970's, the defendants used their positions as officials of Local 174 of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union "to enrich themselves with bribes they demanded and accepted from food wholesalers, retailers and processors within Local 174's jurisdiction."
The indictment said the defendants and the crime families extorted cash payments "by exploiting employers' fears of physical and economic harm, such as work stoppages and other forms of labor unrest."
Ms. White said one company, a chain of Associated Supermarkets operated by the R.B.G. Management Company of the Bronx, paid a total of $76,500 in bribes between 1985 and 1993.
The union officials named in the indictment were Robert Wilson, president of Local 174 from 1983 to 1993; Phil Falcone, a business agent of the local until 1989; James Coniglio, a vice president of the local until this year, and Jose Rodriguez and Heinz Ottmar, vice presidents of the local. If convicted, they face sentences of 45 to 50 years in prison. Each was released on $1,000 bail.
A sixth person, William Kissel, a former official of the local, was named as an unindicted co-conspirator and is expected to be a witness for the Government.
A woman who answered the union's telephone at 540 West 48th Street said no one could take a call requesting comment. An official at R.B.G. Management also declined comment.
The other companies named as victims of the extortion scheme were: Republic Food Corporation; Alliance Meats Inc.; Dilrich Provisions Inc.; S. Tichauer; the Republic Veal Boning Corporation; John W. Williams Inc.; Westchester Meats; GT Food Inc., and S & W Hotel Restaurant Supply. Telephone calls to each of the companies were not returned last night.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Banks Find Themselves Under the Gun

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 27

 BODY:
Five years ago, Kichinosuke Sasaki was on top of the world, controlling $11 billion in real estate and riding a wave of optimism that saw property prices rise relentlessly.
These days, his empire has pretty much collapsed, amid a wave of pessimism that is relentlessly driving prices down. Now, he says his assets are worth less than the $3.4 billion he owes the banks. 
 That is not only bad news for Mr. Sasaki, but also for his bankers, for the Japanese economy -- and for the United States.
As business magnates like Mr. Sasaki struggle to pay back loans, Japan's banking system is left nervously clutching real estate deeds and stock certificates that are worth a fraction of what they were when the loans were made -- and which may be worth even less next month.
That is why some financial experts are whispering about an almost unthinkable possibility that sends chills down the spines of bankers around the world: a financial meltdown in Japan.
A meltdown could be set off by a sudden further plunge in real estate prices, leading people like Mr. Sasaki to default. The banks might then dump their real estate and stock holdings, sending prices plummeting even more and possibly precipitating bank runs and collapses. The resulting panic would spread in all directions, including to America's board rooms and trading floors.
To be sure, almost no one thinks a meltdown is likely. But not many rule out the possibility.
A somewhat more conceivable scenario is the collapse of a single Japanese bank, brought down by word -- or even rumor -- of acute financial difficulties. Analysts say that any crisis is unlikely to get far because the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, would step in immediately to contain the damage.
Still, on Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin expressed concern that the Japanese authorities have not done enough to stimulate the economy and avert a banking crisis. When asked by reporters in Washington about worries that a big Japanese bank might fail, he said that the Bank of Japan was "simply going to have to do whatever is necessary to prevent that from happening," adding that "the earlier you act on these things, the better."
Regulators in the United States have been discussing the situation for months. Some financial experts fear that a sudden collapse of a big bank in Japan, if poorly handled by bankers and regulators, could inflict heavy losses on American banks and even disrupt the American financial system.
Japan is suffering from record-high unemployment, deflation, a depressed stock market and a stagnant property market at the same time. But looming over all those problems are the growing fears about the banks.
The Ministry of Finance has said that the nation's lending institutions are sitting on bad debt worth 40 trillion yen, $450 billion at current exchange rates, or 9.5 percent of Japan's annual economic output. This official estimate is about equal to the combined equity of all Japanese banks, but many analysts say the amount of bad loans may be significantly higher, perhaps as much as $800 billion.
Not all of the bad loans will have to be written off entirely; the Government apparently estimates that only about one-third will be complete losses. Nonetheless, the mountain of bad debt -- and the uncertainty over its exact dimensions -- is weakening the heart of Japan's financial system.
"The myth was maintained by the M.O.F. that it was almighty and could handle all situations," said Richard Koo, an economist at the Nomura Research Institute, referring to the Ministry of Finance. "As long as the M.O.F. maintains the myth, all the banks could technically be bankrupt," yet continue to do business as usual.
The question is whether the myth can be maintained much longer. Naturally, the Bank of Japan could guarantee funds in a banking crisis or loosen monetary policy to avoid severe economic contraction. And the Government could lift the economy with a huge spending spree. But so far, these steps have not been taken in a convincing way, economists say.
If a crisis were to occur, American banks face several risks, which because of scant financial details are difficult to assess, experts say.
The least threatening risk is that Japanese banks might be unable to repay loans or deposits from American banks, but international procedures for resolving such defaults minimize the threat to American institutions.
A larger risk lies in possible Japanese defaults on financial contracts with American banks that allow them to swap interest payments. The scale of this "counterparty" risk between American and Japanese banks is hard to determine.
Potentially the biggest risk, and the least understood, involves failures that might prevent a Japanese bank from honoring its foreign exchange contracts. In the interval after Japan has ended its business day and before the opening of the day in America, Japanese banks may have accepted payments in yen for currency deals and other transactions without making the corresponding payments in dollars to American banks.
With the enormous expansion of foreign currency trading in recent years, nobody knows precisely the dimensions of such risks to American banks.
Many economists say they are confident that business investment will pick up and that Japan's economy may bounce back by December, and some say growth could be significant next year. But others say a recovery is unlikely any time soon, noting that the economy grew only one-tenth of 1 percent in the first quarter. Indeed, some in this group believe Japan is now undergoing a slight contraction.
"It's Japanosclerosis," said Mi neko Sasaki-Smith, an economist at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd.
After more than four years of economic troubles, experts say, there is a remote possibility that Japan's economy could deteriorate into a deflationary spiral and a prolonged recession of the kind that John Maynard Keynes cautioned about in his writings in the 1930's.
"Whoever resolves this recession will win the Nobel Prize," said Jesper Koll, an economist at J. P. Morgan Securities Asia Ltd.
The Bank of Japan has been dribbling funds into the financial system to get the economy moving again. The discount rate, the rate at which banks borrow from the central bank, stands at 1 percent, and interest rates are at their historic low. Economists expect the bank to lower rates again, raising the possibility of zero or even negative nominal rates.
A negative rate is extremely rare, for it means that banks charge customers interest on their deposits and pay them to borrow. A version of that happened in the late 1980's when speculators poured money into Hong Kong in expectation of an appreciation of the Hong Kong dollar. As a result, banks imposed interest charges on customers who placed large deposits in Hong Kong dollars.
But Mr. Sasaki, the beleaguered real estate tycoon, doubts that the economy will pick up "even at zero interest rates or negative 2 percent rates."
The problem with banks paying him to borrow, he said, is that he would still have to repay the loan. And with taxes and other high costs in Japan, he is not sure he could make money from an investment in property.
Such uncertainty has depressed demand for commercial real estate, and prices have fallen up to 90 percent in some areas. Residential prices have also fallen, by one-third to one-half, making homeowners feel poorer and less likely to fill up their shopping carts.
This languishing demand has spread to the banking industry, the stock market and slowly throughout the economy. Nationwide deflation is already beginning to bite, although partly because of cheaper imports resulting from the surge in the value of the yen. Now the term that elicits sighs of resignation from Japanese executives is "kakaku hakai," or "price destruction."
During the outlandish bubble economy of the late 1980's, when the economy was inflated to spectacular heights, the Japanese bubble kings moved about Tokyo in their Mercedes-Benzes and Bentleys, scouting for properties. Their quest for new acquisitions helped inflate prices to astronomical levels -- an apartment for a top foreign executive in Tokyo can rent for $30,000 a month -- and created the impression of Japanese invincibility.
Now, the creases on Mr. Sasaki's face tell of the battles he has endured. His staff has shrunk to 35, from about 100, and he has cut his operating costs to one-fifth of their peak levels.
"It's a nightmare," Mr. Sasaki said. "Since I don't see the economy improving, I think I'm facing an all-out failure. But if I fail, the entire country will fail."

HEADLINE: Clinton and the Economy;
Even if Growth Rebounds, the President May Not Win Comparable Political Gains

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
On Friday morning, the Commerce Department will issue a figure that until very recently the White House was dreading: an accounting of the economy's paltry growth in the second quarter of the year, a grim statistic that for much of the year looked as if it would be the first step off a steep cliff.
The number will likely be around five-tenths of a percent, a long, long fall from the economy's spectacular performance last year. But now there is a growing consensus among economists and traders that the figure will likely be the year's worst and that a rebound is already under way. 
 They are basing their optimism on the usual hodgepodge mix of home sales, the pace of exports, inventory levels and other straws in the economic wind that recently suggest that the worst is probably over. At the White House, officials are already declaring that the much talked-about "soft landing" has arrived.
"The second-quarter figure is coming out at a time that the second quarter seems no longer relevant," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who has predicted publicly for several months that the rebound would start in the second half of the year, said today. "The question now is how strongly do we resume growth."
The political import of all this is lost on no one in Washington: It has been more than 40 years since a Democratic incumbent ran for the Presidency with the economy seemingly strong, inflation under control and unemployment off the front page. Against all the speculation just a few months ago, Bill Clinton now looks as though he may break the spell.
What that means in concrete political terms -- the first primary is still seven months away -- is anyone's guess. Even if the economy does bounce back in coming months, it is far from clear that there will be corresponding political gains for Mr. Clinton.
Growth was strong and inflation was low last November, and the result was a Republican seizure of both the House and the Senate. In the postwar era, growth had to average more than 4.6 percent in the year leading up to an election for a Presidential incumbent to be re-elected.
And the stagnation of wages and the job insecurity felt by millions of Americans remain a major economic problem, and an even bigger political one, a point Mr. Rubin and other Administration officials acknowledge.
But an economy in downturn as the primaries approach seemed probable just a few months ago, and Mr. Clinton's economic advisers are delighting in the fact that the business cycle seems unlikely to give the Republicans any fresh ammunition.
"This gives tremendous momentum to the Clinton re-election candidacy," Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee who until a few months ago was considered a likely candidate to run the campaign, said in his office today. "We ought to take the quotes from all those guys on the Hill who were predicting doom and gloom and throw them back in their faces."
The Republicans, of course, will retort that the man who brought about the soft landing was not Bill Clinton but one of their own: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. Last year he was regularly portrayed by the White House as the lurking force of evil in the economy, raising interest rates last year to head off inflation.
On several occasions the White House forgot its stated policy of never arguing in public with the Federal Reserve, carping about its approach and saying that it would cost jobs and growth. More than a few times Mr. Rubin had to call his colleagues in the Cabinet and ask them, politely, to shut up.
Now, after a considerable amount of revisionist thinking, Mr. Greenspan has become something of an economic hero in the White House. The interest-rate increases are now viewed in a kinder light, in part because they choked off inflation but especially because rates began to come down again last month.
Suddenly the most likely successor to Alan Greenspan, whose term runs out next March, is Alan Greenspan. (The reality is that probably no one else could get confirmed: The Republican leaders of the Senate would probably hold up the nomination of any other candidate until after the next election.)
Certainly not all the news has been good, and anyone wanting to construct a pessimistic outline for the months ahead has plenty to work with. In May, personal income declined slightly, the first fall since January 1994. In June, a leading index of manufacturing purchases declined for the second consecutive month, after nearly two years of growth. Car sales plunged alarmingly in the spring, leaving the chief executives of the Big Three shaken. Mortgage applications are down, even though interest rates have dropped nearly two points in eight months. The savings rate continues to fall.
Some economists maintain that any good news is simply a delay of the inevitable. "If the economy survives 1995 without a recession, next year will offer no respite from hazards," the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College wrote last week in one of the blitz of newsletter analyses that has preceded Friday's report on gross domestic product. "The probability of a recession beginning either this year or next is 60 percent."
If so, Mr. Clinton could find himself in exactly the condition he managed to exploit brilliantly against George Bush.
But inflation seems increasingly unlikely to be an issue as the election approaches; it is not only down in this country but around the world. The job market has remained surprisingly strong, an impression bolstered today when the Government announced a large decline in claims for unemployment benefits. Retail sales are up, though much of that comes from huge promotions that car makers are using after they were caught by surprise by slow sales early in the year.
There are three major issues that seem to bother the Administration's top officials when they talk about the economy: What will happen to personal income, whether a showdown with the Republicans over the budget sends the markets into a tailspin and what happens if the country's export boom suddenly dries up.
All the economic indicators in the country can turn up, but if income stays stagnant, Mr. Clinton's advisers agree, he will be unable to convince voters that much has changed. "It's the problem the President works on the most," Mr. Rubin said today, referring to proposals in his budget for training and education. "Because median real wages have not behaved well, too many Americans don't feel in their own lives what has happened in the economy."
The second concern is that the battle over the budget will bring the Government to a standstill in October, with all kinds of hard-to-predict economic fallout. "We've had the Government close for a day or two in the past, but what we are worried about is something much longer and worse," a top Administration official said recently. "And it is unclear who would be blamed for that, Bill Clinton or Newt Gingrich."
And the third concern is that the hidden miracle of the economy -- exports -- will finally cool off. Just how much exports are rising is a matter of how you measure, but the trend is pointing to a 15 percent increase over last year, fueled by the weak dollar. That is a remarkable achievement at any time, but particularly when the country's No. 2 and No. 3 trading partners, Japan and Mexico, are in the most dire economic trouble they have suffered in years.
Whether the country's economic growth can be sustained even if the domestic economy slows further, then, depends in large part on keeping up a huge flow of goods to Europe and Southeast Asia. And that means depending on economies over which Mr. Clinton has virtually no control.
"What no one has noticed in the past year or so is that now fully 50 percent of our exports go to the Pacific Basin," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative and another potential candidate to run Mr. Clinton's campaign. "That is why we have such a critical interest in continuing the market openings there and building those relationships."
But Asia is also where the United States has its biggest trade deficits, and they, too, have widened over the year. That could be the wedge the Republicans turn to first.

Durable Orders Drop

 WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters) -- Orders for durable goods edged lower last month, the Commerce Department said today, but economists said the report indicated factory activity was stabilizing.
Orders for items like cars and computers fell one-tenth of a percent to a seasonally adjusted $159.4 billion. While the drop was a weaker performance than expected, it followed a revised 2.6 percent rise in May orders and three months of larger declines.
Excluding the volatile category of aircraft and parts, orders for durable capital goods rose 2.5 percent in June and 5 percent in May.
Activity at factories has been weak in 1995, with orders for durable goods running 3.3 percent lower in the second quarter than in the first.
Separately, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing initial claims for state unemployment pay fell 42,000 last week, to 374,000. The four-week average for jobless claims, a less volatile gauge of employment conditions, rose to 389,000 from 387,750.

HEADLINE: Penny-Pinching on Nicaragua

 BODY:
Senator Jesse Helms's vindictiveness should not be allowed to threaten the tiny amount of foreign aid Washington now sends to Nicaragua. Mr. Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has cooked up a bogus issue to hold over the head of Nicaragua's President, Violeta Chamorro. He says her Government has not made enough progress in settling the claims of American citizens whose property was seized by the Sandinistas after their revolution in 1979.
Before Monday President Clinton must certify that Nicaragua's actions on settling the property disputes and on human rights is satisfactory. Otherwise aid will be cut off unless he grants a waiver. 
 In fact, progress on the property rights issue in the past six months has been better than ever, and the President should certainly go ahead with the certification. But a bill before the Senate would shift the power of certification to a hostile Congress. The bill would also force the Administration, in the absence of certification, to vote against loans to Nicaragua from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
A provision in the Senate's State Department appropriations bill would exclude anyone who owns or "traffic[ks] in" confiscated property from entering the country. This is a ridiculously onerous provision that could exclude virtually any politician from Cuba or Nicaragua, executives of multinational corporations and ordinary tourists.
Congressional supporters of former landowners tend to view all their claims favorably. Some are credible. But the Nicaraguan Government says that some people are asking for compensation for the full value of properties that were heavily mortgaged, or properties on which banks had already foreclosed. Fewer than one-third of the former landowners seeking redress were American citizens when their property was expropriated.
The land claimed by former owners amounts to a quarter of Nicaragua's arable land. The estimated cost of compensation is 35 percent of the country's gross domestic product. This is clearly beyond the financial ability of Nicaragua's Government to resolve immediately. Nicaragua has already resolved 2,200 claims and has 3,000 to go, including those of about 640 American citizens. Cutting the country's $30 million in projected aid is not likely to speed up compensation.
The timing of Mr. Helms's onslaught could not be more inappropriate. Recently an agreement was reached in Nicaragua by groups of farmers, holders of compensatory Government bonds and people who received urban properties after the revolution. Americans with property claims were represented at the meeting. Nicaragua has also signed an agreement with the International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes, which is part of the World Bank. Claimants can bring property disputes to this body, and Nicaragua will accept its jurisdiction.
Most of Nicaragua's land was traditionally controlled by a ruthless elite. The Sandinistas' goal of redistributing land was a legitimate one, although the process was highly flawed and often unfairly administered. Land redistribution is also part of the peace process in El Salvador, a policy Washington supports and part of the peace negotiations now under way in Guatemala.
Mr. Helms cannot forgive Mrs. Chamorro for trying to work with the Sandinistas, whom she defeated in elections in 1990. Mrs. Chamorro is doing her best to stitch her tattered country together. She has made impressive progress on many other fronts, including privatization, eliminating hyperinflation and reducing the army. By trying to deprive Nicaragua of its aid, and the help of lending institutions, Mr. Helms shows a callous disregard for the Nicaraguan people.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Arresting The Negotiators

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The top political and military leaders of the Bosnian Serbs must be arrested and held for war-crime trials if they appear in any country in the world. This decision by a United Nations tribunal pleases Western governments trapped in the Bosnian disaster as it will please millions passionate against the Bosnian Serbs.
All right, then, the question is: What now?
How do you negotiate with men you demand be arrested on sight? The answers I get from officials of the U.S., the U.N., the tribunal and diplomatic veterans of Bosnian peace negotiations are totally clear: "We don't know."
The price of making negotiations impossible by issuing arrest warrants for one side can be terrifyingly high. Without peace talks, the ever-deeper Western involvement can bring Europe to where it stood 81 years ago this week -- at the cusp of a world war.
The issue was what Bismarck had predicted would bring war one day -- "some damn foolish thing in the Balkans." It turned out to be Serbia. Crowds in Austria, which wanted to swallow Serbia, screamed, "Serben mussen sterben." Serbs must die.
The outlines of a Bosnian solution have been heartbreakingly obvious. Yesterday I received a faxed letter from one of the indicted men, the Bosnian Serb President, Radovan Karadzic. It came after I had inquired among supporters of the Bosnian Serbs in the U.S. about the Serbs' bottom line.
Dr. Karadzic said the "blueprint for peace" was a European plan of 1993, originated by Lord Owen of Britain and Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway. It called for the recognition of Muslim, Croatian and Serbian republics within a loose Bosnian government. The plan gave 49 percent of the land to the Muslim republic, 33.5 to the Serbs and 17.5 percent to the Bosnian Croats, and proposed two years of U.N. administration of Sarajevo.
Dr. Karadzic said that the plan meant self-determination for all parts of the former Yugoslavia. Interpretation: The Serbs must have the same rights of self-determination and alliance that the Muslims and Croatia have won.
The Bosnian Serbs and Croats accepted the European plan; the Muslims did not. Two years later, the West has to recognize that putting pressure on the Bosnian Serbs will not bring peace unless some is also put on the Muslims.
But how to resume negotiations? One way would be for the top Serbs to fly off somewhere, maybe Pakistan or Iran, which have offered to jail them, and hold out their wrists. Or the West could do what the Muslims want -- stall negotiations until the Bosnian Serbs are smashed. That would take a massive Western invasion, followed by an occupation to keep the Serbs submissive, something not even the Nazis managed.
The other is to think of gimmicks to get around the negotiating roadblock of the arrest edict. Hold them in Bosnia? No, that would make the site an instant death trap. U.N. headquarters? Not legal, says the tribunal prosecutor. An Italian judge even raises the question whether any country can negotiate with indicted men. So -- "We don't know."
The concept of war-crime trials is important. But after the World War II trials, the nations lost enthusiasm. Saddam Hussein was not tried for invading Kuwait. Hafez al-Assad of Syria got away clean with capturing Lebanon. That fellow in Libya, whose terrorists the West says blew up Pan Am 103, still sits in his deluxe tent, receiving figs and ambassadors.
Pol Pot faced no court for mass murder in Cambodia. The Communist Chinese not only get away with using torture and slavery as tools in the international market, but have a judge sitting on that U.N. tribunal.
The nations run from every war-crime trial that is politically or economically inconvenient, which has meant everybody but the Bosnian Serbs.
Still, the world should not bury war-crime charges with the victims. The tribunal has not finished looking into charges against Muslims and Croats. Any trials should come when peace is negotiated -- and for accused from all sides at the same time.
Like Congressional pressure to arm the Muslims, the Serb-only indictments, coming now, postpone peace. Every delay kills more people, every single day, to no avail.
In that other July, in 1914, then too the great men of power did not believe it could ever really happen, the guns of August.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
HBO-Showtime Clash Is Pretty Fine Bout, Too

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
As rain pelted an umbrella at Bryant Park shortly after Wednesday's Evander Holyfield-Riddick Bowe outdoor news conference was canceled, a well-dressed young man calmly ate a sandwich and discussed the bubbling excitement he felt about Mike Tyson's return. "I'd pay to watch him fight my mother," he said.
But would he pay for Bowe-Holyfield ("The People's Championship") and Tyson-His Mom if both aired on pay-per-view the same night? 
 That would mean $90 to $100 on the month's cable bill.
That's the choice fight fans face Nov. 4 if detente is not achieved between HBO's TVKO (Bowe-Holyfield) and Showtime's S.E.T. (Tyson versus His Mom).
"There isn't that much money in the market to make it comfortable," said Richard Aurelio, president of Time Warner's New York City Cable Group.
Gary Shaw, a spokesman for T.C.I.'s New Jersey cable system, said: "We'd prefer to have one pay-per-view fight per month."
Pragmatism suggests a settlement (greed will win), but let's hope for a smidgen more of the hostilities. For the sheer amusement found in corporate loathing, little surpasses the HBO-Showtime feud, born of the enmity between Seth Abraham, the president of Time Warner Sports, and Don King, without whom Showtime's boxing and Bruce Seldon as a heavyweight champ would not exist.
"We will not surrender at any cost," King vowed Wednesday via fax.
This is an ego-driven tale of who-came-firsts. Last month, TVKO and S.E.T. told Request TV, a key pay-per-view distributor, that they wanted to stage fights on Nov. 4. TVKO wanted the date for a George Foreman fight that never materialized, S.E.T. for Tyson's second fight. When Request requested that one party make a $50,000 deposit, S.E.T. paid up.
"Request never asked for that before," said Abraham, "and we never go to the cable industry without a signed fight and a site."
Before confirming late Wednesday that peace talks had begun with TVKO, McAdory Lipscomb, S.E.T.'s executive vice president, called his rival "a greedy company" that wants to "rob the viewer."
Added King: "We had the date first and we will not be bullied."
The two sides have accommodated each other before. In late May, King faxed the Nevada State Athletic Commission to reserve Sept. 16 for a Julio Cesar Chavez fight (on S.E.T.), 20 minutes before promoter Bob Arum's fax to get the date for an Oscar De La Hoya bout on TVKO. "Two weeks later, Arum moved De La Hoya to Sept. 9," said Marc Ratner, executive director of the commission.
For the Nov. 4 fight, Ratner said a fax sent by Rock Newman, Bowe's manager-promoter, beat King's, on behalf of Tyson, by two days.
Said Ratner: "We'd honor both fights but we'd need extra staff. We're preparing for both, but I don't think both will come off."
If the combatants prove to be economic rationalists, what factors will help them decide on a solution?
1. Having enraged cable systems with onerous demands to carry Tyson's Aug. 19 fight, S.E.T. may try to re-establish good relations by magnanimously offering to move the fight to December.
2. TVKO would find it tough to move its fight at the Caesars Palace outdoor stadium because nighttime in December is chilly. The Tyson fight is scheduled indoors at the MGM Grand.
3. Cable operators and the casinos that stand to lose a bundle if the two fights are broadcast at once may step in to force one of the parties into sanity.
4. Tyson's performance on Aug. 19 could embolden or weaken King's resolve. King may want to capitalize on a quick, brutal knockout of Peter McNeeley and boldly risk direct competition on Nov. 4; but if Tyson is unremarkable, King may feel that a retreat to December is beneficial.
5. One side could drop its pay-per-view plan and downshift its fight to its premium TV arm. The betting here is that switching Bowe-Holyfield from TVKO to HBO would wrest more viewers from the Tyson bout on S.E.T., than vice versa.
What's the real solution? Forget Tyson, Holyfield or Bowe. Make Don Fehr and Bud Selig square off in the "Ultimate Fighting Championship," a martial arts cockfight. For $19.95, it would outsell pugilism.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Agents Say Home Sales Remain in the Doldrums

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
As the summer doldrums settle in, real estate agents across the metropolitan New York region are hoping for cooler weather -- and more sales.
With the exceptions of small bustling pockets of good business and a few agents who insist that this is one of their best seasons ever, the spring and the months of June and July have left many agents glum. 
 In Connecticut, William Raveis, who owns a company based in Shelton with 1,200 agents across the state, said house sales were "very difficult," adding that sales statewide were down about 15 percent this spring from last spring.
"And some markets are even worse," he said. "The shoreline east of New Haven was off 30 percent, New Haven was off 40 percent, Hartford was off about 20 percent and the town of Avon was off 40 percent." Sales in Fairfield County, with homes within commuting distance to New York City, he said, were off between 10 and 12 percent.
"We're going to just loll in this malaise for a long time," he predicted, citing the state's problems with layoffs in the insurance and military industries. "In 1996, it'll start trickling back but it's still been a struggle."
In 1994, agents said, interest rates were low and sellers had brought their prices down to a manageable level. When interest rates started to perk upward, a mini-boom began, which the more optimistic heralded as the end of the real estate recession. Now, many are not so sure.
In New Jersey, Peter L. Mosca, a spokesman for the New Jersey Association of Realtors, said that sales were off from 1994 partly because of a lessening of consumer confidence -- a factor that he said seems to have dipped further in the last couple of months.
He said that while 43,000 house sales had been reported in the second quarter of 1994, preliminary figures were "somewhere between 37,000 and 40,000 for the same period of 1995." He said exact figures would be released in two weeks.
In Summit, N.J., Marjorie K. Robertson, the agent who writes the newsletter for the Faitoute real estate agency, said volume was "down significantly" in the area of Summit, New Providence and Berkeley. In the first half of 1995, she said, overall sales in Summit were down 29 percent (with 123 closings in 1994 versus 87 so far this year); down 35 percent in New Providence and down 30 percent in Berkeley. In Short Hills, she said, volume was down 12.5 percent.
Among the reasons for the decline, she said, were that " Wall Street bonuses were significantly lower and there were a lot of layoffs in industry here." New listings of properties for sale are "twice what's going off," she said.
The lack of bonuses on Wall Street was also cited by brokers in New York City and by Deborah Beck of the Real Estate Board of New York. Although statistics were not available for total city co-op and condo sales -- not every real estate brokerage reports to the real estate board -- Ms. Beck cited a drop in average room prices from last year's second quarter to this year's.
The average per-room price of a one-bedroom apartment in sales reported to the board fell to $49,286 this year from $56,262 a year ago; a two-bedroom apartment to $81,250 from $86,400, and a three-bedroom apartment to $179,639 from $187,500.
Barbara Corcoran, head of the Corcoran Group in Manhattan, said her sales were off 8 percent from last year. This summer seems to be slower than past summers, she said, predicting that autumn "will bring fewer sales and higher prices on the really desirable properties."
At Julia B. Fee Real Estate in Westchester, a spokesman said that "as we headed into the summer, sales are falling off dramatically." And although there is a lag of two to three months from the time a contract is signed and a closing, "what we're hearing anecdotally from brokers about upcoming sales is small comfort," he said.
Nevertheless, there are markets that appear hardy. One broker in central Connecticut cited the low end of the market -- especially the first-time home buyers -- as business "that's keeping us alive."
Klara Madlin, whose company aims at the Upper West Side of Manhattan, said a huge chunk of this year's business -- which she reported was up 18 percent from the first half of last year -- was sales to young first-time buyers.
The situation is just the opposite in the Hamptons, where Philip Fenwick Elliott, who runs Sotheby's East Hampton and Southampton offices, said that it was the low end that was languishing -- not multimillion-dollar sales.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Lower vs. Mark As Traders Await G.D.P. Data

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped slightly against the German mark yesterday as currency dealers adjusted their portfolios ahead of today's report on economic growth in the United States.
Currency dealers said they would look at the second-quarter figure for the gross domestic product for clues about how it might influence the Federal Reserve on interest-rate policy. 
 "We are sidelined pending tomorrow's G.D.P. numbers," Gabriele Schmitt, a vice president at Bank of New York, said yesterday.
Economists expect that the G.D.P. report will show the pace of growth to be slower than previously thought. They estimate that the report will show a growth rate of four-tenths of 1 percent, down from 2.7 percent for the first quarter and 5.1 percent for the last three months of 1994.
A weak report could improve the chances that the Fed will soon cut short-term interest rates. After the Fed lowered its target rate for overnight loans by a quarter-point on July 6, many dealers expected that it would cut rates again in August. But recent data provided signs that the economy was strengthening.
Lower interest rates tend to make a country's assets less attractive to international investors and place downward pressure on a currency.
"Nobody's really expecting a rate cut but all that really matters is the G.D.P. tomorrow and what the Bank of Japan and Bundesbank do with rates in the near future," said Charles Fago, currency dealer at Gulf International Bank.
Dealers said the dollar was caught in a downward trend against the mark, but it was also falling against weaker European currencies.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.3833 marks from 1.3877 marks on Wednesday. But the dollar edged up to 88.10 Japanese yen from 87.91 yen.
Dealers attributed the dollar's strength against the yen to uncertainty about whether the Bank of Japan would lower interest rates to stimulate a sluggish economy.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: In Minnesota, Hardship and a Fallen Star;
Rocky Off Season for the Vikings Culminates in Moon's Arrest in Assault

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE 

DATELINE: MANKATO, Minn., July 27

 BODY:
Off season in the National Football League is a time for each club to lick its wounds, to reload, to rededicate and to prepare for the grueling 16-game run to the playoffs and the Super Bowl. For the Minnesota Vikings, however, it has been sheer turmoil.
Their brutal off season began last winter after a stunning, listless 35-18 playoff loss at home to the Chicago Bears (a team Minnesota had beaten twice in the regular season) was quickly followed by accusations of sexual harassment against the Vikings' head coach, Dennis Green, and the team's defensive backs coach, Richard Solomon. 
 There were more embarrassing incidents but none as devastating as the one last week when the Vikings' star quarterback, Warren Moon, was arrested on a charge of assaulting his wife, Felicia.
These are hard times for the Vikings, who last Sunday opened training camp as a team on the edge of the National Football League's elite. The Vikings thought that the worst was behind them because the 1980's were full of misery. That decade included a series of drunken driving charges against several players, a management that players described as racist and one that was considered inept.
Remember the sour 1989 trade with the Dallas Cowboys for running back Herschel Walker for all of those Vik-
ings draft picks?
In hiring Green before the 1992 season and in acquiring Moon from the Houston Oilers before last season, the Vikings hoped they were putting an end to those problems. Green was cast as the new sheriff in town. Moon, after 10 gritty Oilers seasons, was considered the epitome of excellence in character and in integrity.
Now, in some circles, there is no escaping this idea: The solutions have become even bigger problems.
The Moon ordeal was the final, stinging stab for the Vikings, a mystifying occurrence for those who know him as a charitable man and an important role model.
On July 18, police in Missouri City, Tex., were called to the Moon home by either the family's housekeeper or the youngest of Moon's four children, 7-year-old Jeffrey. Felicia Moon told the police that after a heated argument Moon struck her in the head with an open hand and choked her to the point of losing consciousness.
Only a few months before, it had been revealed that Moon had been accused of sexual assault by a Vikings cheerleader, a case that was settled out of court and one that Moon today insists had no basis.
All of this was beyond comprehension for those who have followed Moon's brilliant career. Moon has known Felicia since he was 16. They met in their hometown of Los Angeles, and their 14-year marriage and nearly 23-year association had been full of teamwork, especially in their charitable organization, the Crescent Moon Foundation.
Though Felicia decided not to press charges against Moon, three days after the incident, last Friday, he was arrested, charged and released on a $1,000 personal recognizance bond.
"One of the goals for myself had always been not to get arrested in my life for anything," said Moon, who turns age 39 on Nov. 18. "It was a goal for my family as well as for me. After the press conference last Friday where I apologized to Felicia in front of our kids, in front of the world, and apologized to her family and my family and to my fans, I was told I would be arrested and to come to the police station.
"I pulled into the garage down under the police station and the judge was already there. I didn't even know the procedure. It was unreal. The fingerprinting. Taking the mug shots. It is something I will never forget, something you can never prepare for. But I must say that it set into quicker motion me getting help for myself. I had already begun to realize that I needed help in beginning to analyze why I have such a burning need to succeed and to keep busy and to take care of others more than myself. And how I had begun to take my marriage and my family for granted when they are the most important things in my life."
In counseling since, Moon said he has come to realize at least two things. In one session, a counselor asked Moon what were his hobbies, what does he do to relax and unwind.
Moon surprised himself because he could not answer. He did not have any except for running tirelessly from football to his work in television to his work in real estate to his work in his charities. And he found that his penchant for work might be traced to the day when his father died when Moon was 7, when his mother and five sisters told him that he was now the man of the household.
"I guess ever since that day, I have overloaded myself," Moon said. "I've taken on so many others' problems and never examined my own. And then my kids and my wife always expected me to be gone during the football season. But with all of the other business I began to take on, I was gone during the off season, too. We grew apart. The strain was too much. Nobody knows what Felicia and I have already been through. We've made it together and the love is still there. I've got a lot more work to do on myself and on us. And we will do it together."
Moon said it was the first and the only time he had hit his wife.
Moon, Felicia and their children held news conferences in Missouri City and in Minneapolis after the incident and Felicia repeated her desire that she did not want to press charges. The Fort Bend County District Attorney, John Healey, said this is why his office did so, anyway:
"In a hypothetical case such as this, prosecutors have been educated to the point where they are aware there can be many reasons as to why a complainant many not want to press charges. Among them could be a deep and abiding feeling that it has never happened before or won't happen again or a feeling of the threat of future physical harm or of economic or family pressures. A combination of these things can be in existence in any type of domestic violence case and the prevailing philosophy of health care professionals has been that it is best not to ignore the problem by dropping the charges at the request of the complainant."
Moon was criticized for having his children (girls ages 12 and 10 and boys ages 14 and 7) present at both news conferences. If he had it to do over, he said he would have them there again.
"What do you do?" he asked. "Put the children upstairs or outside or down the street and have it? They know what's going on. Do you think it was any worse that what they would hear at the Astrodome from unruly fans or at school on a Monday after a loss? I know it was not. I wanted them there to hear me apologize to their mother and to the world. Felicia and I consulted our counselor and our minister and all of us agreed that is the way it should have been done. We are going to tackle this as a family and we are going to make it as a family. There is no way to soften it for the kids or for us. Not only this, but everything from now on we are going to do as a family, enjoying the good and tackling the bad."
He said there is so much that he needs to work on that all starts within:
"All of my life there has been pressure, the pressure of being the leader of the family as a child, the pressures of proving myself as a black quarterback, the pressure of being passed over by most major colleges, and at first by the N.F.L. and then going to the Canadian Football League and then trying to earn my way in the N.F.L. The circus atmosphere in Houston and being the spokesperson and then the blame for everything that went wrong there.
"I've been doubted all of my life. I'll just have to show them and myself one more time, and if I'm healthy I will do that on and off the field once again. This is one more major hurdle. I know that life can be better now than it has been in a long time."
Green said he has told Moon that "there is always tomorrow" and added, "we both know about tough times."
Green has survived the accusations of sexual harassment, including one made by an office worker at Stanford, where Green was the head coach before taking the Vikings job.
The worker, in a wrongful dismissal lawsuit against the university, said Green had harassed her. The lawsuit was settled out of court, and Green denies the accusation. He has signed a contract extension with the Vikings through 1998.
Green knows that the Vikings have little time to regroup, especially since their season begins with four playoff teams from a year ago. The Vikings start with games against divisional rivals Chicago and Detroit followed by Dallas and Pittsburgh.
"We've had our program in place for three years and we've won divisional titles in two of those three years with a team that was 6-10 and 8-8 before we took over," Green said. "We've won 30 regular-season games in those three seasons. We set a club record for attendance last season. We've established we can be a good football team and can win and that we have quality people. That is why the league selected us to represent it in the bowl games in Berlin in '93 and in Tokyo in '94.
"I don't like the false perceptions that are said about our football team and I don't like the false whispering campaign. But our focus right now is on football and on winning. We have a chance to be very good this year. Our team and Warren are going to be like me: I was raised to be a very spirited and tough man."

HEADLINE: THREE BIG UNIONS ARE SET TO MERGE, CREATING A GIANT

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 27

 BODY:
In the face of the American labor movement's long-skidding fortunes, three of the nation's biggest industrial unions -- the steel workers, the automobile workers and the machinists -- declared today that they would merge. They invited other unions to join them.
The merger announced today will take five years to complete, the unions' leaders said, but the result will be a two-million-member behemoth. Together these unions' wage gains of the 1950's and 1960's led American blue-collar workers into the middle class. Now these workers are losing ground to inflation, cuts in benefits, and the shrinkage of manufacturing industries. 
 But there is little evidence yet that a General Motors will buckle any faster to a bigger union than it will to the auto workers alone, or that the unions will find it easy to blend their vast administrative organizations without the kinds of layoffs and anger associated with the contraction of a company.
"I'm so excited about this it almost brings tears to my eyes," said a man better known for his brawn and bravado, George Becker, 66, president of the United Steel Workers of America. "These are very turbulent days for trade unions in America." He added, "Workers want somebody to protect them, to stand up and fight for them."
Mr. Becker, who represents 700,000 workers, joined Samuel P. Yokich, 59, president of the 800,000-member United Automobile Workers, and George J. Kourpias, 63, president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, with nearly 500,000 members, in announcing the agreement at a news conference here.
Dissident leaders within organized labor cheered the announcement. Dave Yettaw of Flint, Mich., president of the largest General Motors local and co-chairman of a campaign to reorganize the auto workers, said, "I'm pleased to see this."
He noted that the three unions had a fund of more than $1 billion to use for strikes and organizing. "That's a lot of money to muscle around," he said.
The agreement is a striking new development in a summer of turmoil for a labor movement that for decades has resisted the changes sweeping other big institutions, like the admission of women and minorities to leadership.
"As far as I can tell, this is unprecedented," said Peter Feuille, director of the Institute of Industrial Relations at the University of Illinois. "These are not three little bitty struggling unions that need a bigger union to gobble them up and give them safe haven." Still, he warned that unions were much harder to bond than businesses and that the accord could crumble.
Richard W. Hurd, director of labor studies at Cornell University, said, "In all these union mergers, they often end up talking about who's going to get what position and what the salaries will be." For the three leaders, however, that issue is moot. All will have retired by the merger's scheduled completion.
Unions -- and in particular their umbrella organization, the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations -- tend to deny their declining influence or blame others, primarily Republican Presidents.
President Ronald Reagan, for example, fired striking air traffic controllers in the early 1980's, an act that set a precedent in industry, and Republicans in Congress have blocked attempts to prohibit the practice.
"The Contract With America," Mr. Yokich said, referring to the Republicans' current political agenda, "means the contract on the workers of America."
Still, unions cannot ignore numbers that suggest trouble within labor's leadership. The number of workers who belong to unions has shrunk from nearly a quarter of the labor force in the 1950's to less than 16 percent today.
With diminished membership has come diminished clout. Employers routinely threaten to fire workers who try to form unions or strike, so the number of strikes has collapsed from an average of 352 in the 1950's to fewer than 50 a year since 1987.
As strikes have diminished so have wages. In terms of what they will buy, workers' average wages have been falling for 22 years.
Many analysts attribute labor's decline as much to a failure to organize new workers, especially in the fast growing service and retail industries, as to a hostile political climate. The three merging unions have won members outside their base industries: About 62 percent of the U.A.W.'s members work outside the automobile industry, for example. But the diversification has only helped slow the fall of membership.
The merger, Mr. Hurd, said, "has the potential to be very important if they can use it to shake up enough institutionally and get new resources into organizing."
"That's the key question for the future," he said, adding that at present unions were locked into "a certain institutional rigidity."
In addition, a single, merged union would have more resources to try to organize workers, and would eliminate the waste of money and manpower that comes from competing to enlist employees at the same company. A year ago, for example, the machinists and the steel workers went after 8,000 workers at USAir, a campaign that the machinists ultimately won.
The merger announced today seems part of a trend. It follows two smaller mergers this summer -- the steel workers' absorption of the impoverished United Rubber Workers of America and the combination of the two proud old New York unions, the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union and the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union.
Currently more than 80 national unions represent about 17 million workers. With 2.2 million members, just one labor organization, the National Education Association, is larger than the group announced today, but not all of its members are covered by collective bargaining agreements. It is now in the throes of merger discussions with the American Federation of Teachers.
Mr. Becker, Mr. Yokich and Mr. Kourpias are also leaders of an effort to topple the current leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., whose member unions represent 13.3 million of all unionized workers.
They and the heads of several big service unions forced the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, 73-year-old Lane Kirkland, to abandon his attempt to run for another two-year term in elections in October. They also have declined to support his longtime deputy and heir apparent, Secretary-Treasurer Thomas R. Donahue, who will be 67 by October. Mr. Kirkland and Mr. Donahue, both erudite men and career-long administrators, have presided over the federation for 16 years.
The leaders of the auto workers, the steel workers and the machinists, along with the heads of several other of the nation's biggest unions, have aligned instead behind the John J. Sweeney, 61, president of the big Service Employees International Union, one of the few in the federation that has been growing.
Next week, Mr. Kirkland will officially resign, and the executive council of the federation, made up of the heads of most large unions, will meet in Chicago and appoint Mr. Donahue to complete Mr. Kirkland's term without opposition from Mr. Sweeney. That will come at the federation's convention in New York in October, when all member unions will elect three top officers.
Whatever their differences with Mr. Sweeney, Mr. Kirkland and Mr. Donahue saluted the merger. In a joint statement, they said: "The step taken today by three great unions to join forces sends a powerful message. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. congratulates them on their solidarity."
An hour before the news conference today, the merger announcement was approved at a breakfast attended by representatives of the three unions. There were three tables, one for each union, arranged in a triangle to show that no one of the unions will control the new organization.

Big Charge at Paine Webber Leads to $90.5 Million Loss
Paine Webber took a $200 million pretax charge in the second quarter to cover the costs of lawsuits arising from its sales of limited partnerships a decade ago.
The one-time charge, which Paine Webber expects will cover the costs of paying S.E.C. fines and settling suits by individual investors, caused the firm to report a $90.5 million loss for the second quarter. [Page D3.]

3Com to Buy Chipcom
3Com agreed to buy Chipcom for roughly $700 million in stock, creating the nation's second-largest maker of computer network equipment. The acquisition would enable 3Com to sell a wider range of products to corporate customers. In response, 3Com's shares lost $2.125, while Chipcom's shares gained $7.50. [D3.]
 
'Soft Landing' May Be Here
Economists and traders expect today's gross domestic product to be the year's worst. At the White House, officials are already declaring that the much talked-about "soft landing" has finally arrived. News Analysis. [A1.]

Westinghouse and CBS were said to have tentatively scheduled board meetings next week to vote on Westinghouse's bid to buy CBS at $81 a share in cash. [D7.]

Three of the nation's biggest industrial unions -- the steel workers, the automobile workers and the machinists -- said they would merge in about five years. The merged union would have two million members. [A1.]

AT&T Invades Washington
Thousands of AT&T managers swept into Washington for a lobbying blitz. Long-distance telephone companies are the only clear losers in a sweeping House bill to deregulate communications and are fighting to keep the House from voting on it next week. [D4.]
 
Wireless Auction Blocked
For the second time in four months, a Federal appeals court has blocked the Government from reserving a block of wireless telephone licenses for small businesses. [D4.]
 
Times Mirror's Conservative Plan
Mark H. Willes, the new chief executive of Times Mirror, laid out a conservative view of the company and how he intends to expand it by focusing largely on its newspapers. [D7.]
 
Delta Profits Top Estimates
Delta Air Lines earned $251 million, or $4.49 a share, in the fourth quarter,surpassing expectations and providing strong evidence that its aggressive cost-cutting has been working. The company shaved operating costs by $250 million, or 8 percent. [D4.]
 
Dow Chemical Earnings Soar
Dow Chemical said second-quarter earnings more than doubled to $503 million, or $1.84 a share, reflecting higher prices. [D4.]
 
No Trade Gain Seen for U.S.
The Director General of the World Trade Organization said the United States would gain no advantage by not joining the agreement on trade in financial services. [D2.]

Those closed-circuit TV services for hotel guests are getting a wake-up call by interactive technology, but advertisers are still cautious. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: A Joining of Three Varied Old Warriors

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Putting to rest the once-fierce division in labor ranks that time has made irrelevant, a merger of the auto workers, the steel workers and the machinists, if it takes place, will unite three still powerful if diminished unions with colorful, varied histories.
The steel and auto unions were formed during the Depression-driven rush to organize entire industries in the 1930's; the machinists, in contrast, trace their roots to the last century, when highly skilled mechanics who kept the railroads running organized themselves along craft lines. 
 During the labor wars of the 1920's and 1930's, the craft unions, gathered in the American Federation and Labor, stood largely aloof from the efforts to organize whole sectors of the economy regardless of craft.
As a result, both the auto and steel unions were organized with the help of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, headed during the 1930's by the formidable John L. Lewis. The two organizations have long since joined, leaving little distinction today between a craft worker and an industrial worker.
Although Mr. Lewis was instrumental in organizing both the steel and auto unions, he left distinctly different marks on them.
The first president of the steel union, Philip Murray, came from Mr. Lewis's coal miners union and concentrated power largely at the top, in coal miner tradition. Individual workers had little to say about the contracts that regulated their income and working conditions for decades, although in recent years the steel union has become more democratic.
The same thing might have happened in the auto union but for the presence of a self-taught machinist named Walter Reuther. Mr. Reuther, president of the union from 1946 until his death in an airplane crash in 1970, believed in democracy and institutionalized it in the union.
In the auto union, the rank and file have voted on contracts since Mr. Reuther's rise, and the individual members vote for the delegates to the convention that selects the union's top officers.
Both the steel and auto unions were organized only after bitter violence.
Early attempts to organize steel workers at what became U.S. Steel's sprawling plant at Homestead, Pa., were met at first with armies of Pinkerton guards who tried to drive the workers out of the plant. When the workers, firing a Civil War-era cannon loaded with scrap, defeated the Pinkertons, the company's management persuaded Pennsylvania's Governor to call out the state militia to break the union.
The automobile companies were similarly resistant to organization. Even after the passage of laws giving workers the right to organize, the companies riddled their plants with spies to identify union sympathizers, who were promptly fired.
When Mr. Reuther and some aides tried to hand leaflets to workers at the gate of the Ford Motor Company's sprawling manufacturing complex in Dearborn, Mich., the company sent out a squad of enforcers who battered the union men.
They did so despite the presence of news photographers. The images of a bloodied Mr. Reuther and the others became famous in labor circles, and the incident is known as the "battle of the overpass."
Other fighting occurred in Flint, Mich., which was the hub of manufacturing operations for the General Motors Corporation. The company accounted for 80 percent of the jobs in the city and dominated its political institutions, police and courts.
In early 1937, the union began a series of sit-down strikes in Flint, seizing control of plants and demanding that the company recognize the union as the bargaining agent for workers. At first the company tried to use the Flint police to dislodge the strikers inside.
The police tried firing tear gas through the windows but were driven off by workers firing hinges and other metal objects from slingshots made of tire tubes. When the strikes spread, G.M. tried to emulate the Pennsylvania experience by asking the Governor, Frank Murphy, to use National Guard troops to take control of the plants.
It was only when Mr. Murphy refused that the company relented and signed its first contract with the United Auto Workers.
After World War II, the steel and auto industries largely dropped their hostility to the unions so they could participate in the great consumer goods boom of the 1950's and 1960's. It was during this time that the auto and steel unions, in competition with each other, extracted wages that made their members among the best-paid industrial workers in the world.
Fringe benefits that now seem commonplace, like cost-of-living pay adjustments, pensions, medical insurance and paid vacations, were won, as the companies usually calculated that the increased cost would be less damaging than the loss of production to a strike.
That good life began unraveling in the 1970's, when cheap steel from efficient overseas mills and domestic mini-mills began taking sales from the established mills and motorists found that cars made in Japan went a long way on a little gasoline and were not as trouble-prone as Detroit products.
Meanwhile, deregulation of the airlines and the collapse of some carriers has put pressure on the machinists union. And the shrinking of the defense industry will have an adverse impact on both the auto and machinists unions, which represent workers in aircraft and components factories.

When the workers, firing a Civil War-era cannon loaded with scrap, defeated the guards, the company's management persuaded Pennsylvania's Governor to call out the state militia to break the union. HEADLINE: We Won't Get Far Without Affirmative Action;
A Backward Move

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I applaud President Clinton for taking a strong position to uphold affirmative action. Republican attempts to dismantle this program designed to achieve equal opportunity for minorities and women in the work force is mean-spirited and antithetical to the aims of what we claim America to be as a democracy. 
 While former Communist nations struggle to achieve America's standard of equality and fairness, we are moving backward in race relations. Affirmative action provides people an opportunity to get in the door and should be strengthened, not abolished.
In the 1980's the Republicans abused their economic power. The result is a suffering economy and angst among many people, especially white men, that they will be jobless.
The Republicans have almost bankrupted our nation, our concept of a democracy and faith in our political establishment.
Racism is becoming as mean as it was several decades ago. If we want to improve our country, we cannot get caught up in language of quotas or preferential treatment. Such words are dangerous and impede our country's progress. Through affirmative action we can challenge injustices and move forward as a nation.
 
(Rev.) CALVIN O. BUTTS 3D
Pastor, Abyssinian Baptist Church
New York, July 20, 1995

LENGTH: 369 words

HEADLINE: We Won't Get Far Without Affirmative Action;
Not a Recompense

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Andrew Sullivan (Op-Ed, July 23) is right on some points. The criteria for affirmative action should not be racial. There is no valid reason for giving the children of black or Hispanic (not to mention Asian) academics or business executives or upper-echelon government officials or high-ranking military officers preference in hiring or admission to postsecondary education over those of working-class whites. 
 Nor should affirmative action be seen as a recompense for past wrongs. Those political leaders, white or black, who justify it on this basis are making a grave mistake. Affirmative action can be justified only as a means of giving everyone an equal chance at success.
However, when Mr. Sullivan defines the liberalism he upholds as "the only creed that can recognize and repulse the ethnic, collective urges that are darkening the Old World," I must part company with him.
It is part of people's nature as social animals that they sort themselves out into groupings according to various indexes -- purely biological at the early stages of development; ethnic, religious, linguistic, political or economic at later ones. Mr. Sullivan for some reason perceives these normal manifestations of human social nature as negative phenomena to be struggled against and if possible overcome.
He seems to envision a future world of dissociated human beings governed by some social equivalent of the laws of quantum mechanics -- individual human atoms, each one revolving in his or her private orbit, with no relationship with or obligation to anyone else, save those arising from freely concluded contracts.
As a person disabled from birth, dependent on the help of others in living from day to day in accomplishing whatever I accomplish (dependent, as all of us are, except that some are sometimes in a position to deny or ignore this dependence, as I never am), I find this prospect not only unattractive but grotesque. I find it, in a word, not liberating at all, but a prospect of slavery, misery and self-deception.
 
STEPHEN P. DUNN
Berkeley, Calif., July 24, 1995
 
The writer, an anthropologist, is director of research, Highgate Road Social Science Research Station.

HEADLINE: Man Is Killed In Park Area Along Hudson

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A man who appeared to be in his 50's was shot and killed in the middle of the afternoon yesterday in Riverside Park, and his body -- with a single bullet hole in the forehead -- was discovered sprawled beneath a park bench.
 Even though the shooting occurred between 91st and 92d Street in a section of the park usually filled in the afternoon with joggers and families, investigators said they were having difficulty finding reliable witnesses, and they did not know last night who the man was or why he was killed. 
 The victim, who had no wallet and no identification, was discovered beneath a bench on an asphalt walkway that runs along the Hudson River and becomes a dirt path about 10 feet from where the body lay.
 Parks enforcement officers on a routine patrol found the body at about 3:30 P.M. and called the police, who pronounced the man dead 20 minutes later. They said he had been shot about 3 P.M.
The police said the man appeared to be Hispanic and was dressed in a black T-shirt, black tennis shoes and faded blue jeans, with his pockets empty except for two dollar bills.
 "Nobody was seen running away," said Detective Thomas Barnes of the 24th Precinct, who added that despite the absence of a wallet, he did not think that the man had been robbed because his pockets were not turned inside out and there were no marks to indicate that rings or chains had been ripped off.
 "But we're not discounting anything at this point," he said. "We have no motive at this time."
 Mark DeKornic, a 39-year-old unemployed man who frequents the park, said he heard the shooting and had been questioned by the police, but officers said later that they were skeptical of some elements of his account. Mr. DeKornic said he told the police he had been walking along the pavement south of the shooting site when he heard a sound. "It sounded like a cap gun," he said. "One shot went off."
 "There was a bunch of high school kids down here," he continued. "It was like they were shooting a bird. I saw birds scatter." He also said he had seen two teen-age boys running away from the scene, but investigators were unsure about that assertion.
 Detective Barnes said investigators were trying to find another person, who either saw the shooting or heard it and was questioned by parks enforcement officers but left before the police arrived.
 Officer Joseph Shields, one of the first to arrive after parks employees called 911, said he did not believe that the shooting victim had been homeless. "He doesn't look like a homeless guy," he said. "He looks very clean. His clothes looked clean."
 Several people interviewed yesterday on the path near the site of the shooting, where the body remained for several hours, said they did not recognize the man. Others who passed by later said they did not know of anyone fitting the victim's description who frequented that part of the park.
 Many said they were shocked by such a shooting in a place where they feel safe strolling even at night and where they cannot remember a recent crime more violent than a mugging.
 "This happens in Brooklyn," said Bernard Skinner, 28, a pathology technician at Kings County Hospital Center who recently moved to West End Avenue. "But I'm surprised this happened here. I walk out here at midnight."
 In April last year, a 40-year-old woman was sexually assaulted while walking in the park near 89th Street at 2 A.M. Two weeks before that incident, another woman was attacked, but she fended off her assailant with an ice pick.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An unidentified man was found dead with a single bullet hole in the forehead in Riverside Park yesterday. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)
 
Map of Riverside Park showing location of the site of the shooting.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk
