HEADLINE: Disney's Deal: A special report.;
A Mix of Glamour and Hardball Won Disney a Piece of 42d Street

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
It was 3 o'clock one morning in late 1993, when Frank S. Ioppolo Sr. decided he had had enough.
As the chief real estate negotiator for the Walt Disney Company, he had been meeting with New York City and state officials through the night about his company's interest in restoring the decrepit New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street. But after several hours of trying to persuade the public officials to absorb more of the project's costs, Mr. Ioppolo grew incensed. 
 Snatching up documents and throwing them into his briefcase, he angrily declared that the company's interest in renovating the theater was dead. "That's it," he said, according to a person who was at the meeting. "We're finished."
Actually, they were not. A few weeks later, after the two sides reconciled, Disney got what it wanted. The city and state agreed to provide the company with low-interest loans to cover more than 75 percent of the $34 million restoration, in addition to other concessions.
Mr. Ioppolo's walkout and threat to call the deal off is a vivid example of how Disney wielded its power and influence to secure a set of economic incentives -- far beyond what other companies involved in the 42d Street project are getting -- before it finally committed itself to rebuilding the New Amsterdam.
In the eyes of city and state officials, the largess made perfect sense. To them, the company's decision to take on the New Amsterdam, announced with great fanfare last week, is the linchpin in their long and often frustrating effort to transform 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues from a shadowy strip of rundown theaters and sex shops into a boulevard of bright lights and tourist attractions.
With the move, Disney not only gets a home to produce musical spectacles, but it also gets a low-risk way of testing the urban entertainment market -- an area where the company is cautiously exploring opportunities. As in Las Vegas, where casino officials have said Disney is searching for a way into the gambling business without tarnishing its clean image, the company's move onto 42d Street was brokered in a way that protects its reputation, yet creates future growth opportunities.
"The city and state have made it easy for Disney to go there," said C. Bradley Mendelson, a New York real estate broker who has worked with companies involved in the project. "If Disney is successful, it will be a great deal for the city too. But if it is not successful, Disney can say it's because the city didn't create a good environment."
The players and methods used in business negotiations at Disney are rarely revealed. But interviews with government officials, development experts and Disney's real estate executives help illustrate not only how Disney was able to get substantial government subsidies for the New Amsterdam, but also how the company has influenced several other projects that are planned for 42d Street.
For example, Disney officials forced the city to find other family-oriented entertainment companies before finally committing to the New Amsterdam project, and they used their leverage to help determine which other companies should be a part of the project. Disney officials even requested -- albeit unsuccessfully -- a first right of refusal for every property on the street, which would have allowed them to match any offer, from any company.
Although the city paid to condemn sites that other companies will develop, Disney is the only one that has been offered public money to subsidize its costs. Other firms are unhappy that they have not received the same treatment. Viacom, for example, wants to develop production studios for its MTV unit on the block, but the government's refusal to provide subsidies has stalled those talks.
While the city and state expect to get about $600,000 a year from Disney in interest, rent and revenue sharing, the return on the public's investment in Disney's New Amsterdam is minimal. But if all goes according to plan, the real return will come in the jobs and tax revenues generated by other companies that gravitate toward Disney.
"I'm not going to claim we'll get a market return on the deal," said Clay Lifflander, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which played a key role in the talks. "But we subsidized it to get the other activity on the street. In the retail business, it's what you call a loss leader."
 
The Disney Style
A Fuzzy Image, A Lion's Heart
 The New Amsterdam, a fabled theater that opened in 1903 and was once home to the Ziegfeld Follies, was in pathetic shape when it was bought by the state for $247,000 in 1992. There was water damage from holes in the roof, the smell of urine in the air, dead cats in the basement and mushrooms sprouting out of the main floor.
While other potential developers were scared off by the condition of the theater, Disney executives were keeping a close eye on the property. One of Disney's board members, Robert A. M. Stern, in fact, created the guidelines for much of the Times Square redevelopment.
But they were also concerned about the theater's condition. Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chief executive, who first toured the theater in the spring of 1993, told the New York officials that the extensive work required on the theater made it necessary to include public dollars in the project. Otherwise, it could not be done properly and profitably.
Public officials were elated at the prospect of Disney bringing its wholesome image to the nation's most notorious red-light zone. They readily agreed that public subsidies would be necessary before Disney or anyone else would take on the theater restoration.
"Disney brought to the table, all by themselves, the possibility that the project would get done, and that it would be done by the most important entertainment company in the world," said Rebecca Robertson, head of the 42d Street Development Corporation.
But local officials were about to learn, firsthand, that beneath Disney's warm and fuzzy image was a real estate developer with a lion's heart. Since the time that Walt Disney began buying land in California and Florida, the company has leveraged its glamour to control business negotiations and squeeze concessions from property owners and local governments eager to latch on to the Disney name.
Disney's development negotiators "are very good," said Mr. Lifflander, the president of the city's economic development agency. "They're clever and brilliant. They don't miss a single opportunity."
 
The Players
Two Deal Makers Take the Lead
 To begin discussing terms on the New Amsterdam, in the summer of 1993, Mr. Eisner dispatched David A. Malmuth, vice president of Disney's development unit. Mild-mannered and boyish-looking, the 40-year-old Mr. Malmuth was well suited to project Disney's neighborly image.
In the Disney organization and in Mr. Malmuth, the New York officials may have had something working to their advantage from the very beginning. The company was still smarting after losing a public battle to develop a historic theme park in Virginia, and real estate prices had also forced Disney to scale back plans to expand its Disneyland theme park.
Likewise, Mr. Malmuth had devoted two years to head up a plan to develop a theme park on the waterfront in Long Beach, Calif., and that project had been recently scrapped after fierce opposition from environmentalists.
So by the time he arrived in New York to discuss 42d Street, Mr. Malmuth was hungry for a big victory. "I'd committed to myself that I was not going to invest another two years of my life to a project that wasn't going to go forward," he said in a recent interview.
Though Mr. Malmuth was officially in charge of the talks, Mr. Ioppolo clearly took the lead in negotiations. A shrewd deal maker, the 53-year-old Mr. Ioppolo is a former senior partner and head of the real estate practice of the New York law firm Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine. Among his clients was the New York State Urban Development Corporation, whose representatives he would now face from the other side of the table.
"He knew how deals got put together by the state," Mr. Malmuth said of Mr. Ioppolo. "He knew what they would and wouldn't do."
Like a classic pair of good and bad cops, Mr. Ioppolo's contentious style contrasted sharply with Mr. Malmuth's amicable demeanor, according to people who were involved in the talks. As one city official, who would only comment anonymously, said: "David was more enthusiastic, and Frank, as the quality control lawyer, played the skeptical role."
Through months of difficult and sometimes acrimonious talks, the two Disney representatives wrung concessions from the city and state. In addition to the government subsidies, the executives also requested that Disney be protected against any lawsuits involving the project. After a protracted fight, the city and state gave in.
 
The Demands
Haggling Over Stage Drapes
 Another contentious issue involved Disney's plans for top-quality theater production materials, like the latest sound and lighting systems. Although the city and state agreed to help pay for what could be considered "Broadway standard," Disney wanted more expensive custom-quality items.
For example, the stage drape that Disney intends to install costs $10,000 more than the one that the public officials were willing to help pay for. Such excess costs, or "scope items," as they were called during the talks, were Disney's full responsibility, so there was constant bickering over whether an item was Broadway standard or scope.
When negotiations started, Disney had no firsthand experience on Broadway. But all that changed in April 1994, when "Beauty and the Beast" made its debut at the Palace Theater. Soaring box office sales solidified Disney's desire to make the New Amsterdam project a reality. "The more 'Beauty' would be successful, the more we sparked to the idea of the New Amsterdam," Mr. Iopollo said.
During frenzied negotiations on New Year's Eve 1994, the city and state struck an agreement to provide Disney with a $21 million loan, at 3 percent interest payable over 30 years. Still several weeks later, the company began pushing for more money from taxpayers. Reluctantly, public officials agreed to an additional $5 million loan, payable at 3.5 percent over 30 years. With those terms, Disney would use $8 million of its own money to meet the $34 million budgeted for the project.
But then a few weeks ago, when final cost estimates came in excess of $34 million, Disney asked to return to the negotiating table. Finally, hours before last week's announcement, the two sides came up with a plan under which Disney, the city and state would share evenly any additional costs over $32.5 million.
The final terms also call for Disney to pay an additional $2 million for "scope items," and the city and state have to provide a $1.9 million contingency fund for unforeseen costs.
For its part, the city and state will collect 2 percent of the New Amsterdam's revenues, up to the first $20 million annually, and 3 percent above that figure. In addition, Disney will pay a small percentage of revenues in rent plus an additional sum in lieu of annual taxes.
Given the interest that is being paid on the loan to Disney and current market rates, public officials estimate the net value of the government's subsidy is about 35 percent of the project's total cost.
 
'They Were Tough'
Exerting Influence Down the Block
 Although they gave up a lot, the city and state negotiators held their ground on some of Disney's demands. For example, the two sides fought over a request by Disney that it have the right to match any offer that the city and state received to develop other property on the street. Fearful that such an exclusive right would chill interest from other companies, the public officials rejected Disney's request.
Still, the Disney executives exerted influence up and down the block. Mr. Malmuth introduced state officials to executives of American Multi-Cinema, a nationwide movie chain that has worked with Disney on other development projects and is also the largest distributor of Disney movies.
Mr. Malmuth said he told A.M.C. executives that a multiplex on 42d Street is "a hell of an idea if you do it right."
"Don't go in there and do it with just six screens," he told them. As a result, A.M.C. has an agreement to open a 25-screen theater on the street.
Disney officials also held conversations with officials of Madame Tussaud's, the London wax museum that also recently reached an agreement to open an attraction on the street. "I spoke to people in their development company and I spoke with Michael Eisner," said Martin King, Tussaud's general manager for new business development. Disney was "a factor in our negotiations," he said.
Disney's power was also apparent when the city and state selected a developer for a $303 million hotel and entertainment complex on the street. Although the Marriott Corporation was proposing to build a hotel with its own financing and was prepared to start immediately, Tishman Realty & Construction had Disney on its side.
Disney officials worked closely with Tishman, a construction company in Manhattan, helping to select the hotel's architect, and Mr. Eisner himself even met with the architect to discuss the hotel's design. Disney would also be the main tenant in the retail and entertainment area of the complex.
On May 11 of this year, Tishman won the competition. "We feel that the Disney name was most important to the people who were making the decision," said Susan Katz, president of Triarc Equities Corporation, Marriott's partner in its failed proposal.
In addition to the entertainment that Disney plans for the hotel site, the company also has the option to use part of the building to sell time-share units for its growing vacation club. And the company is also scheduled to open a new Disney Store a few doors east of the New Amsterdam in 1996.
With all the pieces that have been put together thus far, Disney can stage entertainment at the hotel, have motion pictures produced by Disney Studios playing at the A.M.C. theaters, provide time shares for Disney Vacation Club members, have a Disney musical running at the New Amsterdam and cash registers ringing up T-shirts and mouse ears at the Disney Store -- all at the same time, on the same midtown block.
Looking back at the two years of negotiations, public officials said that in many instances they had little choice but to acquiesce to the company's demands. After all, Disney was offering the first real opportunity -- in nearly two decades of trying -- to actually jump-start development on the moribund street, they said.
"They were tough negotiators," said Charles A. Gargano, who as chairman of the state's economic development agency. "When you're dealing from a position of strength, you can negotiate hard."

HEADLINE: Hanoi Joins a Club Created to Blackball It

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28

 BODY:
Vietnam was admitted today to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the first Communist nation granted membership since it was founded 28 years ago, in part as a bulwark against Communism.
The admission of Vietnam is a critical step in Hanoi's integration into a region that includes most of Asia's fastest-growing economies. Its membership was formalized at a ceremony in which the Vietnamese flag was raised at the association's annual ministerial meeting, in Brunei. 
 The association, known by the acronym Asean, was founded in 1967, at the height of the Vietnam War, to promote political and economic solidarity among the non-Communist nations of the region.
But today it seems well on its way to becoming a partnership of all 10 nations in the area. The association has emerged as the premier diplomatic grouping for the region, and it has championed the creation of a free-trade area early in the next decade.
Only Cambodia, Laos and Myanmar, formerly Burma, are not yet full members, and their inclusion appears to be only a matter of time. The military junta that runs Myanmar announced on Monday that it would take the first step toward membership.
Vietnam and its non-Communist neighbors still have broad ideological differences. But the other members appear willing to overlook them for now in hopes of cooperation in trade and investment.
Vietnam's rapid economic growth -- about 8.8 percent in 1994 -- and an educated, low-wage work force have made it an attractive market for foreign investors, especially since the United States ended the trade embargo it imposed at the end of the war.
At today's ceremony, Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Manh Cam, signed the association's membership declaration as foreign ministers of the other member nations watched. "You are just across the water from us, and for too long we have been distant strangers," Foreign Minister Mohamed Bolkiah of Brunei told the Vietnamese.
It has been a heady summer of diplomatic triumphs for Vietnam, which won full recognition from the United States earlier this month. Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to participate in the summit talks in Brunei next week and then travel to Hanoi, the first American Secretary of State to visit Vietnam in 25 years.

HEADLINE: On Issue of Family Values, Clinton Unveils an Agenda of His Own

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Synthesizing many of his recent positions into a platform to compete with the reigning conservative manifestos, President Clinton today outlined a 14-point "American Family Values Agenda" ranging from a higher minimum wage to a national crusade against teen-age pregnancy.
Mr. Clinton made clear that he would not let the Republicans alone define family values. He outlined measures that he said would help families grapple with the economic and social problems they face, proposals for the preservation and expansion of gun-control laws, for instance, and for moderate increases in health insurance coverage. 
 "Families do not eat and breathe and sleep political slogans," Mr. Clinton said in an address to a conference of the American Federation of Teachers, the nation's second-largest teachers union.
In the first direct indication that he plans a campaign against tobacco use by young people, Mr. Clinton included a battle against teen-age smoking in his list. "If you want to cut health care costs and increase life expectancy, do something to stop all these kids who are beginning to smoke at early ages," he said.
Mr. Clinton was greeted with a standing ovation by the several thousand convention delegates gathered at a Washington hotel who clapped and chanted, "Four more years."
"I must say I enjoyed the class being a little rowdy this afternoon," Mr. Clinton joked.
The President did not make any direct comparison of his own agenda for family values with the House Republicans' Contract With America or the Christian Coalition's 10-point plan called the "Contract With American Families."
But since last November's Republican sweep of Congress, Mr. Clinton has been searching for some formulation of his own to pose against the Contract With America's 10 planks and the emphasis placed on cultural issues by the Republican Presidential contenders.
While agreeing with Republicans that Americans have to take more responsibility for themselves, he said that many of their problems stemmed from economic woes that government should help address.
"We don't have to have a partisan, divisive fight about family values," Mr. Clinton said. "And we don't have to argue whether we need improvements in personal conduct or political policies and economic policies. The truth is, we need a whole bunch of both."
Borrowing the language of the right though not its policy prescriptions, he said, "What we really need is an American family values agenda." He then rattled off 14 points, many of which were calls for protection of existing Government programs and Administration initiatives against cuts by the Republican Congress. He called for an end to cuts in environmental programs, supported public broadcasting and called for the preservation of a law that gives employees the right to family medical leaves from work.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Decline As Investors Take Profits

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday as investors took profits after the week's earnings-driven rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed off 17.26 points at 4,715.51, but ended the week with a gain of 73.96 points. 
 In the broader market, declining issues led advancing ones by 1,148 to 1,106 on volume of 311.6 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.29 points, to 562.93. The Nasdaq index ended 5.38 points lower at 1,005.28 after closing at a record 1,010.66 on Thursday.
Analysts said weakness in the bond market also put pressure on stocks. The 30-year bond dropped 25/32 , or $7.81 for $1,000 of bonds, to a price of 1094/32 and a yield of 6.90 percent, up from 6.84 percent on Thursday.
One reason that bonds fell was a rise in the University of Michigan's July consumer sentiment index to an unexpectedly strong 94.4 from 92.7 in June. Traders took it as an indication that the Federal Reserve would not be easing rates again soon.
"Today, good news was bad news," said Marshall Acuff, portfolio strategist at Smith Barney. "The confidence survey indicated consumers are inclined to buy more going forward." He predicted that stocks would remain volatile.
"The day-to-day profit reports and day-to-day indicators are going to bring a more volatile period for a while than in the first half" of the year, he said.
The market will face a host of economic reports next week, including those for personal income and consumption, the National Association of Purchasing Management index, leading indicators, and new-home sales.
Among individual issues, James River climbed 7 1/4 yesterday, to 33, in heavy trading after the maker of paper tissues announced a restructuring plan. Analysts upgraded the stock.
The Bank of Boston was up 2 1/8 at 43 3/4 after the abrupt departure of its chief executive, Ira Stepanian, late Thursday raised hopes that new leadership would finally result in a successful merger for the bank.
Computer Associates rose 2 3/8, to 72 1/4, after the Justice Department approved its much-delayed deal to buy Legent, whose shares rose 2 11/16 , to 47 13/16 .
Microsoft fell 3 7/8, to 92 5/8, on speculation that the Justice Department would sue the company to block it from building access to its planned on-line service into its Windows 95 operating system software.
The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.49 point, to 522.07. The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.75 point, to 301.38. The average share was down 9 cents.
In Tokyo, stocks managed to recoup early losses and finish a little higher yesterday, aided by arbitrage-linked buying in the late afternoon. However, trading was subdued as many investors were reluctant to take positions ahead of the weekend.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 24.26 points, or 0.15 percent, at 16,649.45 after falling as low as 16,434.07.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers China 2 Olive Branches, but Not on Taiwan

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
Hoping to halt the deterioration in its relations with China, the Clinton Administration has offered two positive gestures but ruled out the one concession Beijing wants: a ban on all future visits to the United States by Taiwan's President.
On the positive side for the Chinese, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the Administration had decided not to impose punitive economic sanctions on China, at least not for the moment, for selling missile technology to Iran and Pakistan. 
 And in another move that Beijing is likely to view favorably, President Clinton intends to send President Jiang Zemin a letter suggesting that they meet to work out their differences when he comes to the United States this fall, senior officials said.
Mr. Christopher made his remarks in a speech to the National Press Club that was intended to clarify the Administration's policy toward China before a meeting with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in Brunei next week.
On the negative side for the Chinese, although Mr. Clinton's letter to President Jiang will affirm the Administration's commitment to its "one China" policy, it will not pledge to never again issue a visa to the Taiwan leader, Lee Teng-hui.
"The private visit by Lee Teng-hui was a special situation and a courtesy, consistent with American values and opinion," Mr. Christopher said, referring to Mr. Lee's private visit to Cornell University in June. "It did not constitute a shift in our policy toward Taiwan and China."
But asked whether the United States would rule out giving another visa to Mr. Lee, whose trip worsened relations between Beijing and Washington, Mr. Christopher said, "No, the answer is it will not."
In a separate interview, he explained, "We're not prepared to say that some comparable circumstances might not arise."
Mr. Lee's visit to the United States set off an angry reaction in Beijing, with some Chinese officials reportedly convinced that Washington is determined to deprive China of its rightful place as a world power. Apparently in an expression of displeasure, China fired test missiles off its southern coast this month, and the Beijing press accused Mr. Lee of plotting with "some people" in the United States to declare Taiwan officially independent.
Mr. Lee has no announced plans to seek another visa to the United States. The United States received a message from the Taiwan Government today that he has decided to decline an invitation by Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaskan Republican, to a meeting on United States-Taiwan trade in Anchorage in September, a senior State Department official said.
The letter from Mr. Clinton to Mr. Jiang will also include the invitation for a meeting this fall, possibly in New York during celebration of the United Nations' 50th anniversary.
Mr. Clinton may go further than that. He told recent visitors to the White House that in principle he would like to invite Mr. Jiang for a state visit to Washington as one way out of the crisis, participants in the meeting said.
But there is a disagreement in the Administration about whether to invite Mr. Jiang to Washington, a gesture the Chinese have long sought.
Some officials believe that the Chinese would reject the offer since it would come on the heels of the visit by Taiwan's President; others are convinced that that the visit would not produce tangible progress on issues like human rights, and that Mr. Clinton would be criticized for being soft on the Chinese.
In any case, a visit to Washington would be politically impossible unless the Chinese released Harry Wu, the Chinese-American human rights advocate who has been charged with espionage. In his speech today, Mr. Christopher demanded Mr. Wu's immediate release.
There is also a deep division in the Administration about whether Hillary Rodham Clinton should proceed with plans to take part in the United Nations women's conference in Beijing next month.
As for the decision to avoid imposing sanctions on China for its weapons-related exports, Mr. Christopher said, "At the present time, although there is a fairly large body of evidence, we do not think there is the evidence there that would justify the imposition of sanctions."
Other Administration officials said the decision was based on the failure of intelligence agencies to agree on whether the Chinese deliveries constitute a violation of an international accord that bans the transfer of certain types of missiles and technology.
In the interview, Mr. Christopher said he sought in April to telegraph to the Chinese Foreign Minister that the official policy of barring entry by Taiwan's top leaders was rapidly being eroded by Congress.
"I tried my best to signal to him that the Congressional mood was a very serious problem," Mr. Christopher said. "I told him I pressed on the Taiwan situation several times, and I failed to persuade anyone that I had talked to."
But his warning was lost on Mr. Qian, who reported back to the ruling Politburo an ironclad reassurance he felt he had received.
"He said, 'I was assured a visa would not be issued,' " a recent American visitor to China paraphrased Mr. Qian as saying. "He said, 'Imagine what I thought and what was thought of me when the visa was granted.' "

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Falling U.S. Bonds Drag Down The Dollar Against the Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark yesterday, dragged down by a decline in American bond prices.
A report indicating an upswing in consumer confidence prompted the selloff in Treasury securities. Falling bond prices hurt the dollar because when foreign investors sell American bonds, they convert much of the dollar proceeds into their own currencies. 
 "The bond selloff undermined the dollar a little bit," said Stephen Jury, chief currency dealer at the Union Bank of Switzerland in New York.
A drop in American stocks also weighed on the dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 17.26 points, to 4,715.51.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.3807 marks from 1.3833 marks on Thursday. But the dollar was steady against the yen, at 88.11 yen, up from 88.10 yen.
"The dollar is showing some life against the yen," said Bob Gruber, senior currency salesman at Chemical Bank. With Japanese banks still facing huge losses and Japan's economy teetering on the edge of recession, "U.S. fund managers are lined up to buy dollars," he said.
Lingering speculation that Japanese interest rates will be cut soon helped bolster the dollar against the yen during Tokyo trading. Japanese overnight money rates have fallen close to the record low of 0.75 percent they set earlier in July, spurring talk that the Bank of Japan could soon trim its discount rate, which is already at a record low of 1 percent.
Lower rates hurt the yen by making bank deposits denominated in the currency less attractive.
"The market is once again gearing up for a cut in rates in Japan," said Tim Fox, international economist at Credit Suisse in London. "Money market rates are already low, which is why the yen is weak."
Three-month yen deposits last yielded 0.81 percent, compared with 5.88 percent for three-month dollar deposits.
The dollar also received some support from the Commerce Department's report on the gross domestic product, which showed that the United States economy grew by only half a percentage point during the second quarter. The sluggish picture confirmed expectations that the Federal Reserve would not cut short-term interest rates for a second time this summer.

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
There's a Big Demand for a Few, Too Good Men

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 28

 BODY:
The Russian Mr. Right is 30, sexually active but monogamous. He is healthy and does not smoke or drink. And he has two children.
This is the ideal for anonymous sperm donors set by Russia's largest private infertility clinic. Such a man is hard to find. There are plenty of Russian men who have fathered two children. But the dearth of men who neither smoke nor drink nor sleep around is not only something Russian women have complained about for generations, it is now the lament of Russian infertility specialists. 
 "We don't get volunteers," said Dr. Valery M. Zdanovsky, director of the center, EKO, which opened five years ago. "We pay all our donors, and we never have enough."
The clinic, which pays donors about $15, screens them for venereal disease and AIDS. Smoking and drinking are mostly taken for granted. Patients' husbands and clinic employees are often pressed into service.
Clinics like EKO are facing a rising tide of infertile women. Most are married, but in the last few years, there have been more and more single, older women who want a baby and prefer an anonymous donor. They are ready to pay for treatments ranging from artificial insemination to in-vitro fertilization, techniques that until recently were little known in Russia and socially taboo. There are only 12 such fertility clinics in a country of 150 million, and demand is growing almost as fast as the Russian birth rate is declining.
Taboos are fading, but not as quickly. Dr. Zdanovsky said that his clinic treated more than 2,500 patients a year and that its success rate was close to 25 percent, the same as in Europe and the United States. But he added that he could not be sure of the figures, because so many of the clinic's patients, particularly those from the provinces, receive the treatments, go home and, desperate to keep their mission a secret, never call in again.
But some women are becoming more open about their quest. "I want a baby more than anything in the world," said Antonina Sokhach, 37, a social scientist from Chita, Siberia, who was at the clinic for her fourth attempt at in-vitro fertilization. She grew tearful talking about it. "All my money and strength are going to this," she said.
She said her husband, an Aeroflot pilot, left her after she became pregnant during her last treatment and miscarried after eight weeks. She seemed sanguine about joining the huge ranks of Russian single mothers, saying with a shrug, "Men are much weaker than women." If she becomes pregnant, she said, she plans to move from Siberia to her native Ukraine, where her mother and sister will help her raise the child.
"I don't want to know who the donor is, but I'm not worried," Mrs. Sokhach said with a smile. "The male genes alone do not determine the character of a child."
Mrs. Sokhach said she was not sure what had made her infertile, but blamed the winters. "I lived in western Siberia for 10 years," she said. "I think the cold prevented me from getting pregnant."
One of her doctors, Aleksandr S. Dogobetsky, said it was more likely that she suffered from pelvic inflammation, a result of two abortions.
Dr. Zdanovsky said one of the major causes of infertility in Russia was scarring caused by abortion, which is still one of the most common methods of birth control here. Some women have had as many as nine. In 1992 in Moscow, official statistics estimated that there were 300 abortions for every 100 live births.
There are no reliable statistics on infertility in Russia, but the birth rate, 1.4 million babies in 1993, is down a whopping 44 percent from 1983.
For several generations, economic circumstances have forced Russian women to have small families, often only one child. Now women in their late 30's and 40's are looking to new technologies for their last hope of a second child.
"My daughter is 22, and I was 18 when she was born," said a 40-year-old woman who quit working two years ago to be a housewife to her newly successful husband, a banker. "I want a second chance."
Treatment in Russia is not as expensive as in the West -- EKO charges about $600 for artificial insemination, and in-vitro is about $4,000 -- but it is too costly for the average Russian. EKO's waiting room was filled mostly with well-groomed professionals, but Dr. Zdanovksy said the clinic offered free treatment to widows, mothers of sons killed in combat and women who lost a child under the age of 16.
Almost all the medical equipment is made in the West. But the clinic has retained a Russian sense of privacy. There is one examining room with four beds with stirrups. Sperm donors make their contribution in an unlocked closet-sized room with fading nude pinups for company.
There are other things that might appear jarring in the West. Dr. Zdanovsky explained that when husbands are discovered to have a deficiency, they are invited to bring their brothers and cousins to provide sperm for artificial insemination of their in-law. "If the husband wishes, we do it without telling the wife that it is not her husband's sperm," he said. "We don't deceive her, really, because genetically, it is just like his sperm."
But he said he would never give a patient artificial insemination without informing the husband. "That," he said gravely, "would be lying."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fertility clinics in Russia are facing a rising demand from both married and single women. Antonina Sokhach, from Siberia, was at a clinic in Moscow for her fourth attempt at in-vitro fertilization. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Growth Stalled In 2d Quarter, But Signs Point To Resumption

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 28

 BODY:
The economy barely grew over the last three months as companies chose to forgo expansion and instead sold off part of their backlogs of goods, the Commerce Department said today.
But traders and financial economists, together with Clinton Administration officials, shrugged off the announcement that gross domestic output rose by only half a percentage point during the second quarter. They pointed to signs over the last month that economic growth might gradually recover in the second half. 
 "April and May were clearly weak months, what people talked about as part of a bumpy soft landing," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. "The indicators that came out in June and July have been more upbeat."
Sales of goods and services to consumers and other end users actually rose at a strong annual pace of 2.1 percent in the second quarter, allowing stores and other businesses to clear their shelves quickly of excess goods. "Assuming that the inventory correction was well advanced in the second quarter, growth should resume a sluggish pace in the second half," said Rosanne M. Cahn, the chief economist for stocks at CS First Boston.
Martin N. Baily, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers, predicted that the pace of growth would rise through the third quarter and reach an annual rate of around 2.5 percent by the end of the year. Most economists believe that the economy cannot grow faster than 2.5 or 3 percent a year without producing uncontrollable pressures for higher inflation.
Strong business investment and consumer spending compensated in the second quarter for the shrinkage in inventories, a continued drop in Federal spending, a dip in housing construction and a persistent trade deficit.
Congressional Republicans were the least enthusiastic about today's announcement, which could point to a fairly strong economy in 1996 that might help President Clinton's reelection campaign. Representative Jim Saxton, the New Jersey Republican who is the vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said that the weakness during the second quarter justified a move to stimulate the economy by cutting taxes, shrinking the Government and eliminating regulations.
"Although economic growth may revive in the future, we are clearly seeing the indications of a soft economy," he said. "This soft economy is the result of President Clinton's 1993 tax increase and the unwise policies of the Federal Reserve."
The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates seven times over a 12-month period beginning on Feb. 4, 1994, in an effort to prevent brisk economic growth from leading to inflation. The central bank then shaved one of the short-term rates that it controls on July 6 in response to the economy's weakness in late spring.
Most private economists and many Administration officials have viewed the interest rate increases as necessary.
Mr. Stiglitz played down potential risks to the economy's health in the coming months, particularly the threat of a deep recession in Japan. While exports to Japan would fall if its economy slumped, these exports play such a small role in the United States economy that a 5 percent drop in Japanese economic output may trim economic growth in the United States only by a tenth of a percentage point, he said.
Many private economists have begun warning that a recession in the United States becomes ever more likely as the current economic expansion continues into its fifth year, but Mr. Stiglitz took issue with this view. Historical studies show that the odds of a recession in any given year of an economic recovery are unrelated to the number of years since the previous recession, he contended.
Today's statistics also provided further evidence that inflation was under control. The prices of goods and services produced in the second quarter, as measured by the gross domestic product deflator, showed a 1.3 percent inflation rate, the same as the fourth quarter of last year and below the first quarter pace of 2.2 percent. The fixed-weight price index for domestic purchases, which in contrast to the deflator does not reflect the changing composition of output, crept up at a pace of 2.9 percent, compared with a 3 percent rise in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Global Services Pact Concluded: Good News and Bad for the U.S.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 28

 BODY:
The global pact covering financial services was concluded here today. And even though the Clinton Administration has declined to join the new agreement that liberalizes trade in financial services, American banks, insurance companies and brokerage houses still have a chance to obtain new business in fast-growing developing countries because of the pact.
At the same time, however, American money managers may now face increased competition in seeking to manage Japanese public and private pension funds, officials at the World Trade Organization said today. The funds have a total value of about $1 trillion. 
 The global pact will remain in effect until the end of 1997, when countries will be free to improve or withdraw the trade concessions they have offered.
The United States would not join the agreement because it said the pact did not require the buoyant economies of Asia and Latin America to open their markets to foreign financial companies quickly enough.
Nevertheless, the rules of the World Trade Organization require that trade concessions extended to one member country be extended to all other countries. The United States thus will become a so-called free rider, with its companies picking up benefits in foreign markets even though it has not made trade concessions of its own.
That will give American financial companies the opportunity to win new business in such quickly growing markets as Thailand, Brazil, the Philippines, Egypt and India.
A total of 43 countries, including the 15 members of the European Union, agreed today to offer foreign companies access to their financial services markets that was more extensive than the access they had promised when the negotiations to liberalize world trade concluded in December 1993. The 1993 accord was conducted under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The countries did so largely at the urging of the Clinton Administration, which had found their initial access offers insufficient -- and is still not satisfied with what they are offering.
Nineteen of the countries are offering foreign insurance companies better access to their markets, while 23 are lifting restrictions on foreign banks and 14 on foreign securities companies.
About 50 other countries, mainly developing nations with relatively unimportant financial service markets, left their original access offers unchanged.
The United States has said that foreign financial firms already in the country may stay and that European companies may make new investments because the European Union is offering American companies free access. But financial firms from elsewhere may be excluded from the United States unless their home countries offer reciprocal access.
Officials at the World Trade Organization said Japan, Thailand, the Philippines, India, Brazil and Egypt were among the countries that agreed to lift significant barriers to foreign banks and other financial companies.
Thailand will license five new foreign banks by 1997 and will allow seven foreign banks that now are restricted to offshore business to start taking domestic deposits and making domestic loans.
The Philippines plans to license 10 new foreign commercial banks between 1995 and 2000 and will allow all foreign banks as many as four branches. It will raise the ceiling on foreign ownership of domestic banks to 49 percent from 40 percent and grant free access to foreign insurance and reinsurance firms.
India will increase the number of new foreign banks it licenses to eight a year from five and will allow foreign brokerage firms to own as much as 49 percent of brokerage firms set up in the country. But India still has not agreed to scrap its state-owned insurance monopoly.
Brazil has promised to lift its constitutional ban on new foreign insurance companies, banks and brokerage firms within two years. It will allow foreigners to buy state-owned banks and other financial firms as they are privatized. And it will permit foreign-owned banks to install automatic teller machines.
Egypt is eliminating the 49 percent ceiling on foreign equity in insurance companies and will guarantee all foreign equity holdings in banks established before 1992.
Japan already allows American investment firms to manage pension funds in the country. Its main contribution to the liberalization of trade in financial services will be to expand that provision to cover money managers from all of the World Trade Organization's 103 member nations.
It will also end a restriction that had allowed American managers to handle only new pension money, permitting foreign managers to bid for the right to existing funds in their entirety.

HEADLINE: Rise in Consumer Optimism Sends Bond Prices Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities, after holding steady yesterday on the release of weak data on second-quarter economic growth, fell when a report showed consumer sentiment was stronger than had been expected.
The University of Michigan's final consumer sentiment index for July rose to 94.4, from 92.7 in June. The Michigan index is a component of the Government's leading economic indicators, and is seen as a sign of future consumer spending for homes and durable goods. 
 "However, it's not merely a measure of whether people will spend, because they will continue to buy the necessities no matter how they feel, but it's a measure of their willingness to take on debt," said Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The better they feel, the more willing they are."
Bond prices also fell because of supply pressure, as traders pondered government, municipal and corporate plans to issue debt. Next week the Treasury will announce the size of its quarterly borrowing.
The 30-year bond dropped 25/32 , or $7.81 for $1,000 of bonds, to a price of 1094/32 and a yield of 6.90 percent, up from 6.84 percent on Thursday.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said the only surprise in yesterday's report on gross domestic product was the extremely restrained pace of inflation.
"Real G.D.P. was well within market expectations, meaning that changes in business inventories were considerably less in the second quarter than in the first quarter, and as a result real final sales were up 2.1 percent," Mr. Fine said, "which means, away from the inventory adjustment process, the economy was growing at a rate of about 2 percent. The most important thing to note, however, is that the economy appears to be moving towards a soft landing."
The economy is currently growing year over year at a 3.1 percent pace, he said. "That's down from 4 percent in the first quarter," Mr. Fine said yesterday, "and assuming G.D.P. is 2 percent in the third quarter, which is a perfectly reasonable assumption given the final sales number today, year-over-year growth in the third quarter would be 2.6 percent.
"This is the Fed's perfect world -- the economy's trend rate of growth seems to be slowing to a pace of between 2 to 2.5 percent, while at the same time inflation remains benign. It's an economic environment that will allow the Fed to ease again, although not immediately at this juncture. I would expect another one-quarter-point easing move as early as September, or possibly as late as November."
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said the G.D.P. report validated the Fed's wisdom in easing this month.
According to some economists, the numbers that are most likely to influence the market over the near term are the purchasing managers report, motor vehicle sales, and of course, the July labor market statistcs, which are due next Friday.
Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Shapiro & Company, said the economy had largely adjusted to the overheating in 1994. "The report for second-quarter G.D.P. showed a sharp reduction in inventory accumulation, suggesting business has come close to restoring inventories to preferred levels," he said.
Mr. Sherman expects there will be some further adjustment in the third quarter. He noted there had already been signs of a recovery in housing, with a pickup in sales of existing and new homes. "That," he said, "should lead to some acceleration in housing starts and consumer spending for household goods and service."
"In short," Mr. Sherman said, "conditions are in place for renewed energy in the maturing expansion. At the same time, inflation, in G.D.P. terms, is still well contained."
